notes: North American Aveo models used the 1.6L Ecotec I4 exclusively, with a 2009 output increase to 108 hp.
Introduced a fully boxed frame with new coil-over front suspension and retained a manual gearbox option through the 2008 model year.
Two-tier instrument panel models share the 1.8L i-VTEC base engine, with the Si receiving the 2.0L K20Z3 and the Hybrid pairing a CVT with Honda's Integrated Motor Assist system.

North American XV40 Camry models launched for 2007 with the 2.4L 2AZ-FE; a 3.5L V6 paired to a 6-speed automatic joined at launch, and the 2010 refresh introduced the 2.5L 2AR-FE four-cylinder with new 6-speed gearboxes while the hybrid kept the 2AZ-FXE and eCVT setup.

JK Wrangler debuted for 2007 with the 3.8L EGH V6 and either a 6-speed manual or 4-speed automatic, while the 2012 update brought the 3.6L Pentastar and a 5-speed automatic; select fleet Wrangler Unlimited trims offered 4x2, but retail models remained 4x4.

Fourth-generation Altima sedans launched for 2007 with the 2.5L I4 or 3.5L V6 and Nissan's Xtronic CVT, retaining an available 6-speed manual on select trims; the Altima Hybrid (2007-2011) paired the 2.5L with an eCVT using Toyota-supplied hybrid components, while the coupe body style joined in 2008.

Fourth-generation Silverado light-duty trucks launched for 2019 with multiple cab lengths and a mixed-material boxed frame; powertrains range from the TurboMax 2.7L to the 6.2L V8 and Duramax I6 diesel, each tied to specific 6-, 8-, or 10-speed automatics and extensive electronic service procedures.

Silverado EV rides on GM’s BT1 Ultium skateboard with 350+ kW DC fast charging, four-wheel steer, and PowerBase bidirectional outlets; service requires HV lockout, battery module cooling bleeds, and steer-by-wire calibration. Data sourced from the September 2025 Wikipedia revision.

GMT400 Suburbans adopted independent front suspension, driver airbags, and available Autotrac transfer cases; rust-prone brake lines, poppet-injected Vortec fuel spiders, and 6.5L turbo-diesel PMD failures push service times. Cited from the October 8, 2025 Chevrolet Suburban GMT400 article.

GMT800 Suburbans received hydroformed frames, Stabilitrak, Autoride air assist, and OnStar integration; servicing 8.1L oil coolers, rear air shocks, and drive-by-wire throttle bodies typically exceeds mobile labor allowances. Data from the October 8, 2025 GMT800 Suburban update.

GMT900 Suburbans introduced AFM 5.3s, aluminum hoods, magnetic ride, and a 300V two-mode hybrid; technicians must address AFM lifter collapse, hybrid battery isolation, and liftgate module programming. Referenced from the October 8, 2025 GMT900 Suburban article.

K2XX Suburbans debuted aluminum liftgates, higher-strength frames, and enhanced safety electronics; MagneRide dampers, DFM-equipped 5.3s, and 8/10-speed shift adapts require scan-tool calibrations and additional lift setup. Based on the October 8, 2025 Chevrolet Suburban K2XX section.

The 2021+ F-150 retains aluminum body panels but introduces the PowerBoost hybrid, BlueCruise-capable electronics, and a consolidated 10R80 automatic across all engines, making battery isolation, high-voltage safety, and adaptive calibration resets key service considerations.

North American XA50 RAV4 models pair the 2.5L Dynamic Force engine with either Direct Shift 8AT, hybrid AWD-i, or plug-in hybrid components manufactured in Ontario and Japan, requiring awareness of high-voltage isolation and AWD torque-vectoring clutches during service.

Sixth-generation CR-Vs sold in North America launched for 2023 with EX/EX-L gas trims and Sport/Sport Touring hybrids using Honda's two-motor e:HEV system; AWD variants employ Real Time AWD with hill-descent control, while the 2024 e:FCEV adds limited high-voltage hydrogen service requirements.

Camaro-inspired midsize crossover packaging crowds the transverse V6 and front subframe, and every engine pairs with GM's 9-speed automatic; AWD uses disconnectable rear drive modules that need proper clutch calibration after service.

North American D2XX Equinox introduced switchable AWD, start-stop, and tight under-hood turbo plumbing; diesel variants require DEF and aftertreatment resets, while 2.0L nine-speed models need updated TCM software after repairs.

Modular subcompact crossover rides on GM's VSS-F platform; AWD adds a twin-clutch rear module and 9-speed automatic, while 2024 refresh introduced larger 11-inch infotainment that demands software validation after replacements.

Third-generation Traverse adopts GM's VSS-S architecture with a 328 hp turbo four, steer-column shifter, and available Z71 twin-clutch AWD; the 17.7-inch screen and Super Cruise hardware require careful recalibration after service.

Independent rear suspension, Air Ride Adaptive Suspension, and extensive electronics make chassis work more involved; 3.0L Duramax adds diesel service steps, and 2025 update increases torque requiring current ECM calibrations.

engines: Ultium single-motor RWD (102 kWh pack, RS)
notes: Ultium-based Blazer EV offers front-, rear-, and all-wheel drive layouts with 85 or 102 kWh packs, while the 557 hp SS dual-motor model demands HV isolation and performance brake calibration after service and software campaigns.

Bolt EUV pairs a 65 kWh LG-supplied battery with the 200 hp front motor and offers GM Super Cruise; battery replacement follows recall torque specs and HV insulating glove requirements after the 2021–2023 pack campaign.
Sixth-gen Camaro’s tight Alpha chassis crowds the firewall and steering rack; ZL1 LT4 cars need intercooler bleeding and track alignment specs after service.

Third-gen Colorado switched exclusively to the 2.7L turbo-four in multiple output tunes with an 8-speed automatic and a crew-cab/short-bed layout; desert-focused trims add Multimatic DSSV dampers needing torque-indexed hardware.
Mid-engine C8 Corvette uses dry-sump LT2/LT6 V8s with an 8-speed DCT, and the E-Ray’s electric front axle adds HV disable steps plus AWD bleed procedures before brake or hub work.

Ultium-based Equinox EV delivers up to 326 miles of FWD range or 290 hp dual-motor AWD, and its floorpan battery with 150 kW DC fast charging demands precise lift placement and HV disconnects before underbody service.

GM’s BrightDrop Zevo vans ride on Ultium hardware with up to 250 miles of range and 150 kW DC fast charging; isolating the battery, calibrating advanced driver-assist sensors, and servicing composite body panels extends field repair time. Data sourced from the October 2025 Wikipedia revision.

E2XX Malibu uses downsized turbo engines with active grille shutters; 2019+ CVT models need adaptive learn resets, hybrids require HV isolation before coolant work, and production winds down in November 2024 ahead of the Bolt EV retool.

T1 heavy-duty trucks feature boxed frames, Digital Variable Steering Assist, and massive cooling modules; diesel models need DEF/DPF service and Allison fluid life monitoring, while 2024+ gas trucks upgraded to the 10-speed Allison.

Navistar-built Silverado medium-duty trucks offer PTO-capable Allison gearboxes, 4x4 transfer cases, and upfitter-friendly straight frames; DEF dosing, kingpin lubrication, and multiplexed electrical systems require extended service windows. Data sourced from the October 2025 Wikipedia revision.

Long-wheelbase Suburban shares Tahoe’s independent rear suspension and available Air Ride plus Magnetic Ride Control, and the 2025 refresh adds a 17.7-inch display and higher-output Duramax diesel requiring updated calibration uploads.

Chevrolet Express continues for fleet duty with the 4.3L V6 or 6.6L gasoline V8 and an 8-speed automatic; boxed-frame packaging and the announced 2026 phase-out mean careful lift placement and transition planning to electric BrightDrop vans.
Brass-era flagship assembled in Flint with acetylene lamps, pressurized oiling, and wood-spoke wheels; scarce drivetrain parts mean custom machining and hand-fit brass trim are routine.
Early OHV four-cylinder runabout offered multiple open body styles and mechanical brakes; wood-framed bodies require careful preservation and bespoke panel fabrication.
Ford Model T competitor with cone clutch and rear mechanical brakes; frequent band adjustments and non-synchronized gearbox demand period service techniques.
One-year Series F introduced electric lighting and top-hinged doors; original wiring looms and wooden frames complicate modern service.
Short-lived first Chevrolet V8 uses unique lubrication and two-piece crankcase; cylinder blocks and pot-metal timing housings are fragile and usually require specialist restoration.
FA updated the 490 chassis with higher-compression four-cylinder power and larger wheelbase; transmission uses cone clutch facing prone to glazing, so period-correct relining is essential.
FB expanded wheelbase to 110 inches and added Fisher closed bodies; mechanical brakes require regular equalization and fabric lining inspection.
Superior introduced pressed-steel disc wheels and Fisher-bodied closed cars; axle oil seals and spiral-bevel rear gears require proper shim pack setup during service.
Capitol adopted four-wheel brakes and retained the dependable 171 cu in four; brake cable synchronization and wooden steering wheels need careful handling.
One-year National delivered over 1.1 million units with mechanical four-wheel brakes; production identification relies on heel-board stamped codes and band brakes demand regular adjustment.
First mass-market Chevrolet inline-six (“Stovebolt Six”) introduced seven-bearing crankshaft and cast-iron pistons; distributor lubrication lines and cork clutch facings merit attentive inspection.

engines: 271 cu in (4.4L) Sterling L-head inline-six (35 hp)
notes: Chevrolet's 1914–1915 Light Six replaced the Classic Six with a 35 hp Sterling L-head and rear-mounted cone-clutch 3-speed, and as a brass-era tourer it typically requires hand-fabricated trim and driveline parts (inference).

engines: 135 cu in (2.2L) copper-finned air-cooled inline-four (approx. 22 hp)
notes: The 1923 copper-cooled Chevrolet used Kettering’s finned air-cooled inline-four, and with only 759 built before GM recalled most cars, surviving examples demand vigilant cooling-fin and ignition maintenance (inference).

engines: 194 cu in (3.2L) Stovebolt OHV inline-six (50 hp)
notes: 1930 Universal models kept the 194 cu in Stovebolt six while expanding closed and commercial body offerings; the unsynchronized 3-speed and mechanical brakes benefit from careful double-clutching and adjustment (inference).

engines: 194 cu in (3.2L) Stovebolt OHV inline-six (50 hp)
notes: The Independence stretched to a 109-inch wheelbase, retained the 194 cu in Stovebolt six, and made wire wheels and heater controls available, so 6-volt accessory wiring and engine mounts should be inspected during service.

engines: 194 cu in (3.2L) Stovebolt OHV inline-six (60 hp)
notes: The 1932 Confederate introduced Chevrolet’s downdraft-carb Stovebolt and a silent synchromesh 3-speed with freewheeling, so linkage adjustment and carb calibration are critical after long storage.

engines: 206.8 cu in (3.4L) Stovebolt OHV inline-six (65 hp)
notes: Mid-1933 Eagle models were renamed Master once the Standard Six launched, and the CA’s 206 cu in, 65 hp Stovebolt six plus Art Deco trim pieces require careful identification of brightwork and chassis hardware when sourcing parts.

engines: 181 cu in (3.0L) Stovebolt OHV inline-six (60 hp)
206.8 cu in (3.4L) Stovebolt OHV inline-six (74–79 hp)
notes: Launched as the low-cost Mercury in 1933, the Standard rode a 107-inch wheelbase with the 181 cu in Stovebolt and adopted the 206.8 cu in six later in the run, so verifying engine swaps and body vent hardware is essential.

engines: 206.8 cu in (3.4L) Stovebolt OHV inline-six (80 hp)
notes: Master models adopted a 112-inch wheelbase with upscale Fisher bodies and optional Dubonnet knee-action suspension from 1934 onward, so front suspension seals and low-pressure lubrication systems require careful inspection.

engines: 207 cu in (3.4L) Stovebolt OHV inline-six (60–79 hp)
notes: Introduced in 1935 as an all-steel eight-passenger wagon on the half-ton chassis, first-generation Suburbans shared the Stovebolt six and removable seating, so seat hardware and torque-tube driveline seals often need renovation.
Art Deco AK trucks shared passenger-car styling cues, vertical Chevrolet grilles, and the 216 cu in Thriftmaster six, making torque-tube seals and 6-volt electrical grounds common service points.

Postwar Advance Design trucks debuted with wider Unisteel cabs, five-bar grilles, and Thriftmaster/Loadmaster sixes—later years added column shifts and optional Hydra-Matic—so drivetrain ID and cab corrosion checks are routine.

engines: 216.5 cu in (3.5L) Victory Six inline-six (85–90 hp)
notes: The 1941 Deluxe ushered in integrated headlights, a 116-inch wheelbase, and column-shifted synchromesh behind the 216.5 cu in Victory Six, so preserving 6-volt wiring, vacuum wipers, and interior woodgrain is central to service work.

Postwar Stylemasters reused prewar Master Deluxe tooling as Chevrolet's entry trim with the 216.5 cu in six and column-shift three-speed, so 6-volt electrics, vacuum wipers, and sedan delivery wood framing need inspection.

Fleetmaster sat atop Chevrolet's A-body range with Fisher No-Draft cabins, Fleetline aero fastbacks, and the 216.5 cu in Stovebolt six, so woodie wagon body checks and torque-tube driveline seals remain service priorities.

engines: 235 cu in Blue Flame inline-six (105–125 hp)
notes: Debuting in 1950 as Chevrolet's premium pillarless hardtop, early Bel Airs migrated to full model-line status by 1953 with Blue Flame inline-sixes and Powerglide automatics; restorations require attention to 6-volt electrics and stainless roof trim unique to hardtops.

Tri-Five Bel Airs introduced the small-block V8, 12-volt electrics, and optional Rochester mechanical fuel injection; modern service focuses on two-piece driveshaft lubrication, Hy-Power brakes, and Turboglide fluid coupling setup.

Chevrolet's fleet-oriented One-Fifty delivered minimal trim but shared Blue Flame sixes and V8 options with higher trims; service techs often retrofit sway bars and dual-circuit brakes to improve handling and safety.

The volume-leader Two-Ten mixed Bel Air brightwork with fleet-friendly interiors, pairing Blue Flame sixes or small-block V8s with Powerglide automatics; period-correct restorations require stainless trim alignment and kingpin front-end servicing.

Chevrolet Townsman wagons served families and fleets with two- or four-door layouts, retaining Blue Flame sixes and small-block V8s with Powerglide; tailgate hinges, woodgrain applique, and rear leaf shackles often need refurbishment.

The Nomad began as a two-door Bel Air sport wagon with ribbed tailgate and sliding rear glass, later transitioning to four-door Impala-based wagons—unique roof flashing, liftgate struts, and wraparound glass demand specialized adjustment.

Chevrolet Task Force trucks introduced wraparound windshields, 12-volt systems, and the Cameo Carrier fleetside bed; service highlights include Napco 4x4 conversions, drop-out rear third members, and hydraulic clutch systems.

Biscayne served as Chevrolet's budget full-size model with taxi and police packages, offering everything from Blue Flame sixes to 409 big-blocks; fleet service requires monitoring heavy-duty cooling, drum brakes, and taxi-specific wiring looms.

Brookwood wagons sat mid-pack in Chevrolet's lineup with two- and four-door offerings in 1958 before standardizing on four doors; large tailgates and one-piece curved glass require careful adjustment and liftgate counterbalance service.
Kingswood nine-passenger wagons used B-body chassis with self-leveling rear suspension and 348 V8 availability, so maintaining load-level control arms and triple-tail lamp wiring is essential.

The inaugural 1958 Impala paired X-frame construction with triple tail lamps and 283/348 V8 options; frame crossmembers and coil-spring rear ends need careful support during onsite brake or suspension jobs. Data sourced from the October 10, 2025 revision of the Chevrolet Impala article.

Seventh-gen Impala SS sedans shared the Caprice 9C1 police chassis with DeCarbon shocks, 12-inch brakes, and the LT1 V8; dealing with OptiSpark moisture issues, rear axle limited-slip clutches, and heavy suspension components adds labor. Sourced from the October 8, 2025 Impala seventh-generation entry.

Eighth-gen Impalas replaced the Lumina with 3.4 and 3.8 V6 power plus an SS supercharged trim; lower intake manifold gasket reseals, passlock resets, and 4T65-E pressure control solenoids frequently expand repair time. Documented in the October 8, 2025 Impala eighth-generation section.

Ninth-gen Impalas kept the W-body and added AFM 5.3L V8 and later LFX 3.6L DOHC power with six-speed automatics; AFM lifters, active engine mounts, and police-package ABS wiring require additional diagnostics. Based on the October 8, 2025 Impala ninth-generation update.

Tenth-gen Impalas moved to GM’s E2XX platform with start-stop 2.5L engines, MyLink infotainment, and optional bi-fuel CNG tanks; electric parking brakes, radar sensor calibrations, and CNG fuel system venting extend mobile service times. Cited from the October 8, 2025 Impala tenth-generation section.

The 1959–1960 El Camino combined Brookwood wagon structure with full-size Chevrolet drivetrains, offering six or V8 power; bed drain channels, tailgate seals, and rear coil springs require extra inspection on these car-truck hybrids.

The 1960 C/K trucks introduced independent front suspension on C-Series models, torsion-bar setups from 1960-1962, and optional factory 4WD on K-Series; service work often centers on converting closed driveshafts to open U-joint setups.

Action Line C/K trucks brought coil-spring rear suspensions, factory air conditioning, and CST/Super Cheyenne trims; modern service often adds front disc brakes (1971+ standard) and repairs lower cab rust near rocker panels.

Third-generation "Square Body" C/K trucks introduced improved HVAC, catalytic converters, and available diesel power; service concerns include rust-prone cab corners, dual-tank fuel switching valves, and 4WD front axle service.

The 1988 GMT400 introduced fuel-injected small-blocks, independent front suspension on 4WD models, and electronic 4L60E automatics; common service issues include throttle-body injection tuning and ABS module diagnostics.

The rear-engine Corvair featured air-cooled flat-sixes, swing-axle (1960–1964) and fully independent (1965–1969) suspensions, and turbocharged variants; service demands include checking magnesium cooling fan integrity and proper rear camber adjustments.

Corvair 95 forward-control vans and pickups relocated the air-cooled flat-six beneath the rear floor and offered Rampside drop-side beds; technicians must monitor belt-driven cooling, throttle cross-shafts, and swing-axle camber compensators.

First- and second-gen Chevy II/Nova compacts used simple leaf-spring rears and optional small-block V8s; drum front brakes and steering box lash often need upgrades before mobile service. Data sourced from the October 10, 2025 revision of the Chevrolet Chevy II/Nova article.

Chevelle spanned from family sedans to SS 454 muscle cars, introducing A-body innovations like full-coil suspension, cowl-induction hoods, and LS6 450 hp big-blocks; sagging rear control-arm bushings and frame corrosion near the rear axle are common service points.

Alusil block etch liners and poor cooling margins make head-gasket sealing critical; front subframe bushings and battery-tray corrosion accelerate body rot, while Cosworth fuel injection and unique stainless headers demand careful parts sourcing.

Imported Isuzu chassis uses metric hardware, torsion-bar front suspension, and vacuum-assisted front hubs on 4WD models; frame corrosion near rear spring shackles and scarce diesel glow components add time to mobile service visits.

Laguna’s urethane nose, NASCAR aero front fascia, and big-block cooling packages demand careful alignment after collision work; limited reproduction trim and boxed rear lowers often add sourcing time when servicing these mid-1970s A-bodies. Data sourced from the October 9, 2025 Wikipedia revision.

H-body Monzas pack V8 options into a cramped engine bay with removable subframe crossmembers, fragile torque arm bushings, and unique cable-operated shifters; rotary-program fuel tanks and tight exhaust routing complicate modern service. Data sourced from the October 9, 2025 Wikipedia revision.

Rear-wheel-drive T-body hatchbacks use a torque-arm live axle and tight engine bay packaging; rust-prone floor pans, carbureted choke pull-offs, and diesel glow plug relays commonly extend labor beyond baseline book times.

Downsized G-body Malibus share police-package frames and boxed crossmembers; servicing rust-prone rear frame rails, diesel fuel system contamination, and 9C1 cooling upgrades routinely extends labor beyond base estimates. Data sourced from the October 9, 2025 Wikipedia revision.

First-wave X-body FWD packaging crowds the transverse V6 and TH125; common service concerns include rear brake proportioning valves, subframe bushing collapse, and the need to drop the cradle for clutch or transmission R&R.

Early J-body Cavaliers suffer from firewall rust, disappearing carburetor parts, and Z24 V6 accessory packaging that complicates belt service; convertible-only chassis reinforcements add labor when accessing exhaust and rear suspension. Data sourced from the October 9, 2025 Wikipedia revision.

Celebrity’s first-wave GM A-body platform uses aluminum engine cradles, vacuum-actuated HVAC controls, and optional diesel V6 power; chronic rear brake proportioning-valve corrosion and digital dash diagnostics add complexity for mobile technicians. Data sourced from the October 9, 2025 Wikipedia revision.

First-gen S-10 compact trucks pair ladder frames with torsion-bar 4WD fronts and tight engine bays; rust at cab mounts, vacuum-operated front axles, and the mix of carbureted/TBI drivetrains require additional diagnostic and fastener time.

Rear-drive Astro/Safari vans share S-10 powertrains with optional AWD after 1990; hydroboost steering/brake pumps, tight doghouse access, and frame rust at rear spring shackle mounts add labor. Data sourced from the October 6, 2025 Wikipedia revision.

Medium-duty Kodiak/TopKick platforms cover GMT530 and GMT560 trucks with Caterpillar 3208 and later Duramax power; Allison service, air-brake inspections, and cab-tilt access control add significant prep time. Data sourced from the October 8, 2025 Wikipedia revision.

L-body Corsicas pair transverse fours and V6s with 3T40/4T60E automatics; cradle bushings, Dex-Cool cooling maintenance, and rusty rear brake hardware are common mobile service pain points. Data sourced from the September 2025 Wikipedia revision.

Beretta coupes share L-body mechanicals with Corsica but add Quad 4 service and door-handle hardware unique to the B-pillar design; aging headliners and 3.1L intake gaskets often necessitate extra time. Data sourced from the August 2025 Wikipedia revision.

Composite-body Lumina APV vans use GM U-body transverse V6 drivetrains and modular seating; power sliding doors, rear air-leveling compressors, and SMC panel removal make prep and parts sourcing slower for mobile repairs. Data sourced from the September 2025 Wikipedia revision.

Geo/Chevy Tracker mini SUVs use ladder-frame Suzuki underpinnings with removable tops; rusted rear link mounts, manual hub service, and cramped engine bays around J20/H25 drivetrains prolong field work. Data sourced from the September 2025 Wikipedia revision.

W-body Lumina sedans span 1990-2001 with 3.1/3.4/3.8 V6 power and 4T60-E/4T65-E transaxles; ignition module corrosion, intake manifold leaks, and rear cradle rust complicate mobile service. Data sourced from the September 2025 Wikipedia revision.

First-gen Tahoe/GMT400 SUVs retain body-on-frame layouts with Vortec V8s and optional 6.5L diesels; ABS modulators, rear brake backing plates, and tight engine bay access around poppet injectors drive up wrench time. Data sourced from the September 2025 Wikipedia revision.

GMT600/610 Express vans (1996–2022 fleet run) mix small-block gas, 6.0L Gen IV, and Duramax diesel options; doghouse removal, ABS module corrosion, and AWD front differential access extend mobile service timelines. Data sourced from the September 2025 Wikipedia revision.

Second-generation GM U-body Venture vans share LA1 3400 V6 and 4T65-E drivetrains; intake manifold gasket failures, sliding-door harness breaks, and rear air-shock compressors drive additional service planning. Data sourced from the September 2025 Wikipedia revision.

GMT800 Silverados introduced hydroformed frames, LS-based V8s, and early Duramax diesels; brake line corrosion, CP3 injector pump diagnostics, and transfer-case pump rub repairs typically exceed flat-rate assumptions. Data sourced from the October 2025 Wikipedia revision.

Avalanche midgate pickups integrate composite cladding, convertible cargo seals, and Autoride rear air suspension; cladding refinishing, midgate weatherproofing, and 6L80 fluid services add complexity. Data sourced from the September 2025 Wikipedia revision.

GMT360 TrailBlazers pair DOHC LL8 inline-six and V8 SS trims with Autotrac transfer cases; coil-spring rear air suspensions (EXT), front differential drop, and ignition module heat issues require extra prep. Data sourced from the September 2025 Wikipedia revision.

SSR retro roadsters combine a power retractable hardtop with hydroformed frames and Corvette LS power; roof module calibration, limited interior trim, and rear suspension packaging drive higher labor estimates. Data sourced from the September 2025 Wikipedia revision.

First-gen Colorado/Canyon trucks use Atlas inline engines with variable valve timing updates and optional 5.3L V8; timing chain stretch, frame rust at rear shackle hangers, and electronic power steering recalls extend wrench schedules. Data sourced from the September 2025 Wikipedia revision.

Second-gen Colorado reintroduced midsize trucks with 2.5L gas, 3.6L DI V6, and 2.8L Duramax options plus improved infotainment; DEF injector cleaning, 8L45 fluid service, and Z71 DSSV damper replacement often exceed standard times. Data sourced from the October 2025 Wikipedia revision.

Theta-based Equinox crossovers rely on a front subframe with Aisin automatics; plenum gasket leaks, rear differential clutch servicing, and HVAC blend door actuators are common add-ons. Data sourced from the September 2025 Wikipedia revision.

Uplander extended-wheelbase vans keep steel bodies with Montana/Buick twins; sliding door wiring, ABS hub failures, and 4T65-E pressure control solenoids frequently require additional onsite time. Data sourced from the September 2025 Wikipedia revision.

Retro HHR wagons share Delta architecture with the Cobalt; blend door actuators, electric power steering columns, and turbo intercooler access push beyond standard labor times. Data sourced from the September 2025 Wikipedia revision.

Cobalt compacts use Ecotec drivetrains and EPS columns; ignition switch recalls, front subframe corrosion, and LSJ/LNF intercooler service add labor over baseline. Data sourced from the September 2025 Wikipedia revision.

North American Cruze sedans/hatches use small turbo gas and 2.0L diesel options; intake valve coking, water pump recalls, and diesel DEF heater service drive higher-than-book labor. Data sourced from the September 2025 Wikipedia revision.

Chevrolet Volt combines Voltec dual-motor EV drive with gasoline range extenders across two generations; high-voltage isolation, battery coolant bleed, and electric brake booster calibration demand PPE and specialized diagnostics. Data sourced from the September 2025 Wikipedia revision.

Bolt EV’s 65 kWh Ultium-derived pack and single-motor drive require HV lockout/tagout, updated torque specs after recall pack swaps, and thermal runaway monitoring during post-service charging. Data sourced from the September 2025 Wikipedia revision.

Lambda Traverse offers three-row seating with LLT/LFX direct-injection V6s and 6T75 transaxles; timing chain stretch, liftgate struts, and AWD clutch packs commonly extend repair visits. Data sourced from the September 2025 Wikipedia revision.

Second-gen Traverse moves to C1XX with a smaller turbo option and 9-speed automatics; stop/start batteries, active aero shutters, and dual-clutch AWD modules add service complexity. Data sourced from the September 2025 Wikipedia revision.

First-gen Trax uses Gamma II underpinnings with 1.4T Ecotec and optional AWD; turbo oil feed leaks, HVAC condensers, and AWD module calibration typically require extra time. Data sourced from the September 2025 Wikipedia revision.

Second-gen Trax grows on the VSS-F platform with 1.2L turbo I3 and standard driver assists; tight packaging around the integrated exhaust manifold and ADAS sensor calibration extend mobile service tasks. Data sourced from the August 2025 Wikipedia revision.

Forward-control Chevy Vans (1964-1970) evolved into G-Series "shorty" vans with front engine boxes; service needs include coolant flow management around the doghouse, drum-to-disc brake retrofits, and reinforcing door hinges on heavily used units.

Late G-series vans adopted aerodynamic front clips, TBI fuel injection, and hydroboost brakes; accessing serpentine-driven accessories still requires doghouse removal, and ABS/airbag retrofits plus rusted rear spring shackles raise on-site labor. Data sourced from the October 9, 2025 Chevrolet Van article.

Caprice evolved from upscale Impala trims to GM's B-body flagship with big-block power, Caprice Classic woodgrain wagons, and later downsized aerodynamics; service techs should monitor frame rust, climate control vacuum pods, and Olds 350 diesel maintenance.

The K5 Blazer married a shortened C10 frame with removable fiberglass tops (1969-1975) and later fixed roofs, available full-time NP203/NP205 transfer cases, and heavy-duty axles; watch for rocker rust, tailgate window motors, and diesel glow plug relays.

Kingswood Estates pair Caprice running gear with power clamshell tailgates and concealed headlamp doors; servicing tailgate tracks, vacuum actuators, and rear air shocks often exceeds baseline book time. Data sourced from the October 9, 2025 Chevrolet Kingswood revision.

Long-hood Monte Carlos share A-body chassis with unique front clips; aligning the urethane nose, servicing hideaway wipers, and accessing big-block accessories demand additional setup. Based on the October 9, 2025 Monte Carlo first-generation update.

Colonnade Monte Carlos add urethane bumper systems, swivel bucket seats, and power accessories that tax 1970s wiring; bumper shock replacement and vinyl top water intrusion remediation often extend labor. Pulled from the October 9, 2025 Monte Carlo second-generation revision.

Downsized Montes use metric chassis hardware, optional turbo Buicks, and 200-series automatics; carb-to-fuel-injection conversions and diesel glow circuits add diagnostic time. Data drawn from the October 9, 2025 Monte Carlo third-generation section.

Fourth-gen SS Aerocoupes rely on 200-4R overdrives, fiberglass backlites, and fragile bumper fillers; power-window motors and frame ear rust routinely add hours. Referenced from the October 9, 2025 Monte Carlo fourth-generation update.

W-body Monte Carlos share subframes with the Lumina; 3.4 DOHC timing belt access and 4T60-E pressure solenoid replacements require dash and cradle drops in mobile settings. Data from the October 9, 2025 Monte Carlo fifth-generation revision.

Sixth-gen Monte Carlos add tap-shift 4T65-E transaxles, cylinder-deactivation LS4 V8s, and electronic steering; technicians must handle cradle drops, steering intermediate shafts, and supercharger belt swaps. Covered by the October 9, 2025 Monte Carlo sixth-generation update.

N-body Malibus suffer intake manifold leaks, aging passlock modules, and front cradle rust; mobile techs plan extra time for aluminum head torque cycles and ABS harness repairs. Based on the October 9, 2025 Malibu fifth-generation section.

Epsilon-platform Malibus use electric steering columns and sliding rear seats; steering motor replacements, BCM programming, and Maxx glass hatch alignments extend labor. Reference: October 9, 2025 Malibu sixth-generation update.

Seventh-gen Malibus introduced BAS hybrid batteries, electric power steering, and complex seat airbags; hybrid lockout/tagout and 6T70 clutch relearns increase job time. Drawn from the October 9, 2025 Malibu seventh-generation revision.

Stop/start 2.5s, eAssist mild hybrids, and 2.0T intercoolers tighten the Epsilon II engine bay; ADAS calibration and high-pressure fuel pump service typically exceed standard hours. Based on the October 9, 2025 Malibu eighth-generation section.

First-gen F-bodies use bolt-on subframes, multi-leaf rears, and vacuum-operated RS headlamps; aligning sheetmetal around the cowl tag and servicing big-block cooling demands extra prep. Information from the October 8, 2025 first-generation Camaro article.

Second-gen Camaros have heavy doors, sagging subframe bushings, and emissions-era carb calibration challenges; SS/Z28 brake boosters and shoulder belts require extra adjustment time. Source: October 8, 2025 second-generation Camaro article.

Third-gen Camaros concentrate electronics in the dash and hatch area; T-top sealing, torque-arm bushings, and TPI fuel line routing warrant extra mobile-service time. Referenced from the September 25, 2025 third-generation Camaro page.

Fourth-gen Camaros pack opti-spark ignitions, polymer body panels, and power top hydraulics; LS1 clutch work requires exhaust drops and torque-arm support. Documented in the October 4, 2025 fourth-generation Camaro article.

Second-gen S-10s mix torsion-bar 4WD fronts, CPI-to-CSFI fuel systems, and rust-prone frame kick-ups; crew-cab brake lines and vacuum hubs often require fabrication onsite. Verified from the October 7, 2025 Chevrolet S-10 revision.

GMT800 Tahoes introduced Autoride air shocks, StabiliTrak, and electronic throttle; brake line corrosion, rear A/C leaks, and intermediate steering shafts are high-probability adders. Source: October 8, 2025 Chevrolet Tahoe article.

GMT900 Tahoes add AFM engines, hybrid battery packs, and Autoride dampers; HV battery isolation, active exhaust manifold tuning, and power liftgate resets increase service hours. Referenced from the October 8, 2025 Tahoe third-generation section.

K2XX Tahoes employ aluminum exterior panels, inlaid doors, and updated MagneRide/air suspensions; ADAPT recalibrations, AFM lifter service, and power-fold seating add to service complexity. Documented in the October 8, 2025 Tahoe fourth-generation update.

AK-series Suburbans retained two-door carryall bodies with 216 cu in Stovebolt I6 power and a column-shift three-speed; full-drum brakes, torque-tube driveline service, and heavy rear barn doors demand extra setup space for mobile repairs. Data sourced from the October 9, 2025 Chevrolet Suburban article.

Advance Design Suburbans add Hydra-Matic options and rear-barn access while keeping two-door packaging; split front benches, sliding second-row seats, and tight toe boards complicate modern HVAC and steering retrofits. Data sourced from the October 9, 2025 Chevrolet Suburban article.

Task Force Suburbans introduced wraparound glass and NAPCO four-wheel drive kits; servicing torsion bars, kingpin front ends, and 4WD transfer cases in confined work bays adds labor over flat-rate assumptions. Data sourced from the October 9, 2025 Chevrolet Suburban article.

Early C/K Suburbans use torsion-bar IFS, trailing-arm rears, and optional factory 4WD; coil spring rust, divorced transfer cases, and single-driver-door access stretch mobile service times. Data sourced from the October 9, 2025 Chevrolet Suburban article.

Action-Line Suburbans stretch to a 127-inch wheelbase with three-door access; servicing rear AC ducting, drum-to-disc brake conversions, and optional big-block cooling in driveway conditions requires added labor planning. Data sourced from the October 9, 2025 Chevrolet Suburban article.

Rounded-Line Suburbans adopt four passenger doors, Detroit Diesel options, and evolving NP transfer cases; handling sagging rear leafs, TBI fuel systems, and 4WD hub service on-site typically exceeds baseline labor. Data sourced from the October 9, 2025 Chevrolet Suburban article.

Second-gen Impalas retained GM’s X-frame with full coil suspension and expansive body styles; X-frame jack points, wraparound tailfins, and wide rear quarters demand extra setup to avoid flex when using portable lifts. Data sourced from the October 10, 2025 revision of the Chevrolet Impala article.

Third-gen Impalas introduced the Super Sport package with 409 and lightweight 427 W-series options plus upgraded brakes; heavy big-block front ends and cowl-induction ducting require reinforced stands and careful hood removal during mobile service. Data sourced from the October 10, 2025 revision of the Chevrolet Impala article.

Fourth-gen Impalas adopted perimeter frames, hidden wipers, and optional big-block Turbo-Jet V8s plus power front discs; boxed frames and long wheelbases require multiple jack stands and brake proportioning valve bleeds onsite. Data sourced from the October 10, 2025 revision of the Chevrolet Impala (fourth generation) article.

Fifth-gen Impalas rode on 121.5-inch wheelbases with clamshell wagon tailgates, high-compression big-blocks, and early front disc brakes; accessing tailgate actuators and bleeding height-sensitive rear drums adds time for mobile crews. Data sourced from the October 10, 2025 revision of the Chevrolet Impala (fifth generation) article.

Downsized sixth-gen Impalas kept B-body frames with lighter panels, optional Oldsmobile LF9 diesel, and early 700R4 overdrive automatics; TV-cable setup, diesel glow systems, and lanky wagon rear doors increase service time in the field. Data sourced from the October 10, 2025 revision of the Chevrolet Impala (sixth generation) article.

Third-gen Novas shared Camaro front subframes, optional SS 396 big-blocks, and available hatchbacks; subframe bushing wear, cowl induction clearance, and drum-to-disc conversions extend onsite labor. Data sourced from the October 10, 2025 revision of the Chevrolet Chevy II/Nova article.

Fourth-gen Novas debuted Colonnade styling with catalytic converters, HEI ignition, and optional Super T-10 four-speeds; emissions-era vacuum plumbing and hatchback struts often need extra time in driveway repairs. Data sourced from the October 10, 2025 revision of the Chevrolet Chevy II/Nova article.

NUMMI-built fifth-gen Novas shared Toyota AE82 underpinnings with EFI 4A engines and optional Twin Cam trims; tight transverse engine bays and electronic idle controls add setup time for mobile diagnostics. Data sourced from the October 10, 2025 revision of the Chevrolet Chevy II/Nova article.

Second-gen El Camino shifted to the Chevelle A-body with SS 396 availability and double-walled cargo beds; frame-mounted rear air shocks and bed drain service make mobile suspension work more involved. Data sourced from the October 10, 2025 revision of the Chevrolet El Camino article.

Third-gen El Camino adopted long-hood A-body styling with SS 454 options, cowl-induction hoods, and rear load-leveling; big-block cooling and cowl seal adjustments require extra time in driveway repairs. Data sourced from the October 10, 2025 revision of the Chevrolet El Camino article.

Fourth-gen El Camino Colonnades featured energy-absorbing front ends, swivel buckets, and larger bumpers; heavy bumper shocks and evaporative emission canisters complicate driveway disassembly. Data sourced from the October 10, 2025 revision of the Chevrolet El Camino article.

Fifth-gen El Camino G-bodies offered V6 economy and optional 5.7L diesel plus 200-4R overdrive transmissions; frame-boxed rear sections, air-adjustable shocks, and diesel fuel system bleeding add labor for mobile techs. Data sourced from the October 10, 2025 revision of the Chevrolet El Camino article.

Third-gen Bel Airs rode on GM's new cruciform X-frame with optional air suspension and big-block 348s; safe cribbing demands frame-rail pads and wheel chocks to prevent flex when servicing brakes or driveline. Data sourced from the October 4, 2025 revision of the Chevrolet Bel Air article.

engines: 348 cu in Turbo-Thrust V8 (up to 335 hp)
notes: Winged fourth-gen Bel Airs kept the enlarged X-frame and wide rear overhangs; driveway jobs need extra jack stands and caution around triple two-barrel 348 horsepower packages. Data sourced from the October 4, 2025 revision of the Chevrolet Bel Air article.

Fifth-gen Bel Airs introduced bubble-top roofs and 409 Super Sport options; cowl induction plumbing, dual-quad 409 tunes, and wagon tailgate harness repairs lengthen mobile service times. Data sourced from the October 4, 2025 revision of the Chevrolet Bel Air article.

Sixth-gen Bel Airs added perimeter frames, big-block 427s, and Turbo-Hydramatic automatics; bulky bumpers, hidden rear drums, and wagon power tailgates add setup and safety time for on-site repairs. Data sourced from the October 4, 2025 revision of the Chevrolet Bel Air article.

Seventh-gen Bel Airs targeted fleets with heavy bumpers, Turbo-Hydramatic drivetrains, and optional 454s; column-shift linkages, emissions-era vacuum hoses, and wagon clamshell tailgates demand extra labor planning. Data sourced from the October 4, 2025 revision of the Chevrolet Bel Air article.

Canadian-market eighth-gen Bel Airs used downsized B-bodies with Astro Ventilation, Turbo-Hydramatic automatics, and optional 350 diesel V8s; winter corrosion at control arm mounts and diesel fuel-conditioning add service complexity. Data sourced from the October 4, 2025 revision of the Chevrolet Bel Air article.

engines: 283 cu in (4.6L) V8 with fuel injection (283 hp)
notes: C1 Corvettes featured hand-laid fiberglass bodies, solid rear axles, and were initially powered by inline-six engines before switching to V8s in 1955. The 1957 fuel-injected 283 was the first American engine to reach 1 hp per cubic inch. Convertible was the only body style until 1963. Data sourced from the October 10, 2025 revision of the Chevrolet Corvette article.

engines: 396 cu in (6.5L) Big Block V8 (425 hp)
427 cu in (7.0L) Big Block V8 (425-435 hp)
notes: C2 'Sting Ray' introduced independent rear suspension, hidden headlamps, and the distinctive split-window coupe in 1963. The 1963 model featured Mako shark-inspired styling and was available in both coupe and convertible body styles. Z06 performance package available from 1963. Data sourced from the October 10, 2025 revision of the Chevrolet Corvette article.

engines: ZL-1 427 cu in (7.0L) all-aluminum V8 (430 hp)
L83 fuel-injected 350 cu in (5.7L) V8 (200 hp)
notes: C3 'Sting Ray' generation had the longest production run of any Corvette. Featured T-top removable roof panels, Mako Shark-inspired design, and was available as both coupe and convertible (until 1975). Last year of C3 production featured the fuel-injected L83 engine. Production moved from St. Louis to Bowling Green in 1981. Data sourced from the October 10, 2025 revision of the Chevrolet Corvette article.

engines: L98 350 cu in (5.7L) V8 with tuned port injection (230-240 hp)
ZR1 LT5 DOHC 350 cu in (5.7L) V8 (375 hp)
Callaway B2K Twin-Turbo 350 cu in (5.7L) V8 (345-450 hp)
notes: C4 generation skipped 1983 model year. Featured all-aluminum suspension, electronic dashboard with digital displays, and retractable headlights. First year of production of the ZR1 with Lotus-designed LT5 engine. Convertible returned in 1986 after an 11-year absence. Traction control introduced in 1992. Data sourced from the October 10, 2025 revision of the Chevrolet Corvette article.

engines: LS1 346 cu in (5.7L) V8 aluminum engine (345-350 hp)
notes: C5 completely redesigned from the ground up with near 50/50 weight distribution and 0.29 drag coefficient. Introduced the Gen III small block LS1 engine family. Z06 returned in 2001 with LS6 engine. Active handling stability control system standard. Magnetic Selective Ride Control available from 2003. Data sourced from the October 10, 2025 revision of the Chevrolet Corvette article.

engines: Z06 LS7 427.6 cu in (7.0L) V8 'small block' (505 hp)
ZR1 LS9 376 cu in (6.2L) supercharged V8 (638 hp)
transmissions: Computer Aided Gear Selection (CAGS) for manual
notes: C6 returned to fixed headlights after 42 years of retractable units. LS2 engine bumped from 5.7L to 6.0L with 50 HP gain. ZR1 introduced with Eaton supercharged engine (638 hp). Grand Sport returned in 2010. Engine Build Experience available for Z06 and ZR1 buyers from 2011. Data sourced from the October 10, 2025 revision of the Chevrolet Corvette article.

engines: LT1 376 cu in (6.2L) V8 with direct injection (455-460 hp)
Z06 LT4 supercharged 376 cu in (6.2L) V8 (650 hp)
ZR1 LT5 supercharged 376 cu in (6.2L) V8 (755 hp)
notes: C7 returned the 'Stingray' name and featured Gen V small block engine family with direct injection, variable valve timing and active fuel management. Carbon fiber hood and removable roof panel. New aluminum frame with wider track. Last front-engine Corvette generation. ZR1 became most powerful Corvette at 755 hp. 0.28 drag coefficient. Data sourced from the October 10, 2025 revision of the Chevrolet Corvette article.

Only car in its class assembled in America at Orion Assembly, Michigan. Featured suspension tuning by Corvette Racing engineer John Buttermore for US models. Facelift in 2016 with restyled front fascia and LED tail lights. RS trim standard for hatchbacks with unique wheels and red accents. Data sourced from the October 10, 2025 revision of the Chevrolet Sonic article.

Based on the Suzuki Cultus platform as an entry-level subcompact car. Known for fuel efficiency (up to 40+ mpg highway) and basic but reliable transportation. Replaced by the Geo Metro in GM's lineup after 1988. Data sourced from the October 10, 2025 revision of the Chevrolet Sprint article.

Based on the Suzuki Swift/Cultus platform after Geo brand discontinued. Part of GM 'x-car' family alongside Pontiac Firefly. Known for excellent fuel economy (up to 38-40+ mpg highway) as a 'no frills' economy car. Eventually replaced by Aveo/Sonic lineage. Data sourced from the October 10, 2025 revision of the Chevrolet Metro article.

Joint venture between GM and Toyota at NUMMI plant in Fremont, California. Essentially a rebadged Toyota Corolla with shared platforms, engines, and components. Offered more features and refinement compared to Metro. Known for Toyota's reputation for reliability and durability. Data sourced from the October 10, 2025 revision of the Chevrolet Prizm article.

Rebadged Opel Antara sold primarily to fleet buyers after Saturn brand discontinued. Based on GM's Theta platform, it was a 5-door, 5-seater crossover (different from 7-seater Captiva). Available FWD or AWD configurations. Discontinued in the US after an abbreviated 2015 model year. Data sourced from the October 10, 2025 revision of the Chevrolet Captiva Sport article.

Rebadged Nissan NV200 built in Mexico, marketed as a commercial cargo van for fleet buyers. Offered 122.7 cubic feet of cargo space and 1,350 lbs maximum payload capacity. Low roofline for easier garage access designed primarily for urban delivery applications. Data sourced from the October 10, 2025 revision of the Chevrolet City Express article.

Compact pickup sharing platform with Chevrolet S-10. Called S-15 in 1980s, renamed Sonoma in 1991. Four-wheel drive Insta-Trac system added 1983. Extended cab introduced 1983. Name continued into 1990s-2000s. Data sourced from Wikipedia Chevrolet S-10 article, October 11, 2025 revision.

Compact SUV based on S-10 platform, smaller than full-size Jimmy. Only 2-door available in 1980s (4-door added 1991). Optional diesel engine available. V6 received throttle-body fuel injection in 1986. 4.3L V6 became sole engine 1989. Data sourced from Wikipedia Chevrolet S-10 Blazer article, October 11, 2025 revision.

Mid-size van sharing platform with Chevrolet Astro. GM's first response to Chrysler minivans using S-10 light-truck components. 111-inch wheelbase. AWD became available in 1990. Standard and extended length options. Data sourced from Wikipedia Chevrolet Astro article, October 11, 2025 revision.

GMT400 Sierra launched in 1988, replacing C/K designation with Sierra branding for GMC. Introduced independent front suspension on 4WD models and fuel injection. Optional 6.2L Detroit Diesel. Continued production through 1999-2000. Data sourced from Wikipedia GMC Sierra/Chevrolet Silverado articles, October 11, 2025 revision.

Rebadged Suzuki Sidekick sold exclusively in Canadian market through GMC dealerships. Base and SLE trims available. Discontinued 1991 when renamed Asüna Sunrunner. Light-duty off-road vehicle. Data sourced from Wikipedia Geo Tracker article, October 11, 2025 revision.

engines: Various diesel and gasoline options (medium-duty commercial)
notes: Medium-duty commercial truck series for vocational applications. TopKick branding introduced in 1980s. C-Series designation covers multiple weight ratings (C4500-C8500). Commercial chassis cab configuration requiring specialized knowledge for air brakes and commercial drivetrains. Limited consumer documentation available.

Heavy-duty conventional truck for commercial/vocational use. Part of GMC's commercial truck lineup alongside General. Requires specialized commercial vehicle service knowledge including air brake systems, heavy-duty transmissions, and commercial diesel engines. Limited consumer market documentation available.

First-generation Yukon replaced full-size Jimmy in 1992. Available with optional 6.5L turbodiesel. Special Yukon GT edition 1992-1994. Transitioned from 3-door to 5-door body style mid-generation. Data sourced from Wikipedia GMC Yukon article, October 11, 2025 revision.

GMC Savana introduced in 1996 as rebadged Chevrolet Express on GMT600 platform. Available in cargo and passenger configurations with multiple engine options including diesel. Fleet-oriented full-size van. Data sourced from Wikipedia Chevrolet Express article, October 11, 2025 revision.

High-performance turbocharged pickup with AWD (35% front, 65% rear split). 0-60 mph in 5.3 seconds. First production truck with 4-wheel ABS. Only 2,995 units produced in 1991, all in black. Mitsubishi TD06-17C turbocharger with Garrett intercooler. Data sourced from Wikipedia GMC Syclone article, October 11, 2025 revision.

High-performance SUV variant based on GMC Jimmy with same turbocharged 4.3L V6 and AWD system as Syclone. Limited production performance vehicle with specialized turbocharger and intercooler requiring performance-oriented service knowledge. Data sourced from Wikipedia GMC Syclone article, October 11, 2025 revision.

First-generation Envoy was highest luxury trim of GMC Jimmy (1998-2000). Features included leather interior, Bose sound system, HID headlights, heated seats, and monochromatic exterior. Discontinued after 2000, name revived for standalone SUV in 2002. Data sourced from Wikipedia GMC Envoy article, October 11, 2025 revision.

GMT800 Sierra launched August 1998 as 1999 model. First year featured Regular and Extended cab only (Crew cab added 2001). GMT400 'classic' models continued production alongside new GMT800 for two years. Vortec engine family with improved efficiency. Data sourced from Wikipedia GMC Sierra and Chevrolet Silverado articles, October 11, 2025 revision.

First-generation Canyon midsize pickup shares GMT355 platform with Chevrolet Colorado and Isuzu i-Series. Available in Z71 Off-Road and ZQ8 Sport suspension packages. Three cab configurations with multiple I4, I5, and V8 engine choices. Data sourced from Wikipedia GMC Canyon article, October 11, 2025 revision.

Envoy XL extended-wheelbase variant (129 inches, 16 inches longer than standard) designed for third-row seating. GMT360 platform shared with TrailBlazer. 5.3L V8 power increased to 300 hp in 2005. Data sourced from Wikipedia GMC Envoy article, October 11, 2025 revision.

Unique retractable-roof vehicle inspired by Studebaker Wagonaire. Features midgate system similar to Avalanche and plastic-lined cargo area with drainage. Discontinued after two years due to low sales. Complexity of retractable roof mechanism increases service difficulty. Data sourced from Wikipedia GMC Envoy article, October 11, 2025 revision.

First-generation Acadia is GMC's first unibody vehicle, replacing Safari van and Envoy. Lambda platform shared with Chevrolet Traverse and Buick Enclave. Denali trim introduced 2011. 2013 facelift with redesigned grille. 5,200 lb towing capacity. Data sourced from Wikipedia GMC Acadia article, October 11, 2025 revision.

GMT900 Sierra featured redesigned exterior, interior, frame, and suspension with improved aerodynamics. Launched late 2006 as 2007 model. Multiple Vortec engine options with 4-speed or 6-speed automatic transmissions. Data sourced from Wikipedia GMC Sierra article, October 11, 2025 revision.

First-generation Terrain compact crossover on GM Theta platform. Denali trim added 2013. 2016 mid-cycle refresh with updated styling and LED daytime running lights. Natural gas bi-fuel version available 2013-2014. Engine upgrade from 3.0L to 3.6L V6 in 2013. Data sourced from Wikipedia GMC Terrain article, October 11, 2025 revision.

K2XX Sierra 1500 introduced Denali luxury trim and All Terrain X edition. Features EcoTec3 engine family with direct injection and variable valve timing. Apple CarPlay/Android Auto available from mid-cycle refresh. Data sourced from Wikipedia GMC Sierra article, October 11, 2025 revision.

K2XX Sierra HD received significant Duramax power increase in 2017 (445 hp, 910 lb-ft). Allison 1000 transmission on diesel models requires specific fluid and service procedures. DEF system on diesel models. Data sourced from Wikipedia GMC Sierra article, October 11, 2025 revision.

Fourth-generation Yukon K2XX features aluminum hood and liftgate, magnetic ride control on Denali, active noise cancellation. Received 10-speed automatic transmission on Denali from 2018. Fold-flat second and third-row seats. Data sourced from Wikipedia GMC Yukon article, October 11, 2025 revision.

GMC Savana is rebadged Chevrolet Express, continuing GMT610 platform through 2010s. Available in 1500/2500/3500 configurations with various wheelbases (135"/155"). Diesel option discontinued 2016. Fleet-oriented vehicle. Data sourced from Wikipedia Chevrolet Express article, October 11, 2025 revision.

Second-generation Terrain launched in 2018 with downsized turbocharged engines. 1.6L diesel option available 2018-2019 but discontinued. Replaced first-generation Lambda platform with C1XX platform. Note: Full second-gen coverage in 2020s decade file. Data sourced from Wikipedia GMC Terrain article, October 11, 2025 revision.

engines: 3.0L LM2/LZ0 Duramax Diesel I6 (277 hp 2020-2022, 305 hp 2023+)
notes: Fourth-generation T1XX Sierra shares platform with Chevrolet Silverado. Features optional carbon fiber bed, two-piece MultiPro tailgate, and Duramax diesel option from 2020. Multiple transmission options depending on engine choice. Data sourced from Wikipedia GMC Sierra article, October 11, 2025 revision.

engines: 6.6L L5P Duramax Diesel V8 (445 hp 2020-2023, 470 hp 2024+, 910-975 lb-ft)
notes: Heavy-duty T1XX Sierra HD models feature Allison 10-speed transmission and Duramax diesel with up to 975 lb-ft torque. Maximum towing capacity of 35,500 lbs. Diesel exhaust fluid (DEF) system and emissions equipment require specialized service knowledge. Data sourced from Wikipedia GMC Sierra article, October 11, 2025 revision.

Fifth-generation Yukon on GMT T1XX platform shares architecture with Chevrolet Tahoe/Suburban. Available Duramax diesel option and independent rear suspension improve ride quality. Denali trim features 6.2L V8. Data sourced from Wikipedia GMC Yukon article, October 11, 2025 revision.

Third-generation Acadia returns to full-size crossover segment on GM VSS-S platform. Features 15-inch infotainment, optional Super Cruise semi-autonomous driving. Available in Elevation, AT4, and Denali trims. Data sourced from Wikipedia GMC Acadia article, October 11, 2025 revision.

Third-generation Canyon shares GMT 31XX-2 platform with Chevrolet Colorado. Crew Cab only configuration for North American market. Multiple engine options using 2.7L turbo I4 variants. Data sourced from Wikipedia GMC Canyon article, October 11, 2025 revision.

Second-generation Terrain received 2022 refresh with updated styling and AT4 trim. Diesel 1.6L option discontinued after 2019. Standard 9-speed automatic on gasoline models. Data sourced from Wikipedia GMC Terrain article, October 11, 2025 revision.

All-electric Hummer EV features Ultium battery platform with up to 246.8 kWh total capacity. CrabWalk four-wheel steering and Extract Mode suspension require specialized diagnostic equipment. High-voltage system (400V/800V switchable) demands EV-certified technicians. Range up to 329 miles. Data sourced from Wikipedia GMC Hummer EV article, October 11, 2025 revision.

SUV variant of Hummer EV with 5-door configuration and removable roof panels. Shares Ultium platform and CrabWalk/Extract Mode features with pickup. Range 298-314 miles depending on wheel configuration. 18-camera system and high-voltage battery require EV certification for service work. Data sourced from Wikipedia GMC Hummer EV article, October 11, 2025 revision.

GMC Model 16 three-quarter-ton light commercial truck (1916-1919). Featured inline-4 gasoline engine, brass-era construction with wooden-spoke wheels. Hand-crank starting, mechanical brakes on rear wheels only, magneto ignition. Difficulty modifier 1.4 reflects brass-era fragile construction, hand-fitted components, obsolete ignition/brake systems, wooden components requiring specialized restoration, and near-zero parts availability. Data sourced from Wikipedia GMC truck history articles, December 19, 2024 revision.

GMC K-16 one-ton military troop carrier for WWI U.S. Army use (1917-1919). Heavy-duty inline-4 engine, reinforced frame for military service. Featured open-cab design with troop seating area. Difficulty modifier 1.4 reflects WWI-era brass construction, military-spec variations, hand-fitted components, magneto ignition, mechanical brakes, wooden components, and extreme parts scarcity. Data sourced from Wikipedia GMC truck / WWI military vehicle articles, December 19, 2024 revision.

GMC ambulance chassis for U.S. Army Medical Corps in WWI (1917-1918). Heavy-duty truck chassis with ambulance body by various coachbuilders. Featured inline-4 engine and reinforced suspension for medical transport. Difficulty modifier 1.4 reflects WWI brass-era construction, military ambulance specifications, hand-fitted components, magneto ignition, mechanical brakes only, wooden body components, and near-zero parts availability. Data sourced from Wikipedia GMC truck / WWI medical vehicle articles, December 19, 2024 revision.

GMC K-20 bus chassis for commercial transit and school bus applications (1922-1924). Featured heavy-duty inline-4 engine and robust frame construction. Body installed by coachbuilders. Difficulty modifier 1.3 reflects early 1920s brass-era construction, hand-fitted components, magneto ignition, obsolete mechanical brake systems, and extreme parts scarcity. Data sourced from Wikipedia GMC truck history articles, December 19, 2024 revision.

GMC T-19 and T-30 1½-ton light trucks (1927-1931). Represented GMC's late-1920s light commercial truck offerings. Featured inline-4 and inline-6 engines, mechanical brakes, and solid construction. Difficulty modifier 1.25 reflects late-1920s vintage complexity, transition era from brass to modern, mechanical brake systems only, 6-volt electrical, and very limited parts availability. Data sourced from Wikipedia GMC truck history articles, December 19, 2024 revision.

GMC export trucks built for Japanese reconstruction efforts after 1923 Great Kanto Earthquake (1923-1925). Heavy-duty commercial chassis exported for rebuilding Japanese infrastructure. Featured robust inline-4 engines and reinforced frames. Difficulty modifier 1.3 reflects early 1920s brass-era construction, export-spec variations, hand-fitted components, and extreme rarity/parts scarcity. Data sourced from Wikipedia GMC truck history / international operations articles, December 19, 2024 revision.

GMC T and F series light-duty trucks from late 1930s (1937-1939). Featured Art Deco-influenced styling of the pre-WWII era. Inline-6 engines only, typical of 1930s truck design. Difficulty modifier 1.2 reflects brass-era proximity, obsolete mechanical systems, 6-volt electrical, and very limited parts availability. Data sourced from Wikipedia GMC truck history articles, December 19, 2024 revision.

GMC AC/AF series cabover (COE) medium/heavy-duty trucks introduced in 1939. Featured cab-over-engine design for improved maneuverability and cargo space. Heavy-duty commercial chassis for freight and delivery applications. Difficulty modifier 1.2 reflects late-1930s vintage complexity, cabover service access challenges, and obsolete systems. Data sourced from Wikipedia GMC truck / cabover articles, December 19, 2024 revision.

GMC Yellow Coach parlor buses for intercity passenger service (late 1930s). Yellow Coach was GM's transit bus division, merged with GMC truck operations. Featured streamlined Art Deco styling and advanced (for 1930s) comfort features. Early adoption of diesel engines for commercial transit. Difficulty modifier 1.25 reflects 1930s commercial bus complexity, early diesel technology, air brakes, and extreme parts scarcity. Data sourced from Wikipedia Yellow Coach / GMC transit bus articles, December 19, 2024 revision.

Wartime and early postwar GMC light/medium-duty trucks (1941-1947). Production severely limited during WWII (1942-1945) with most output diverted to military contracts. Featured inline-6 engines only due to wartime material restrictions. Difficulty modifier 1.15 reflects 1940s vintage vehicle complexity, obsolete parts, and wartime production variations. Data sourced from Wikipedia GMC truck / Chevrolet AK Series articles, December 19, 2024 revision.

GMC's 'New Design' postwar light/medium-duty truck series (1947-1955), first major styling update after WWII. Featured all-new cab design with improved visibility and comfort. Platform shared with Chevrolet Advance Design trucks. FC-series designation for GMC variant. Difficulty modifier 1.1 reflects late-1940s vintage service requirements. Data sourced from Wikipedia Chevrolet Advance Design / GMC truck articles, December 19, 2024 revision.

GMC CCKW 2½-ton 6x6 military cargo truck, workhorse of Allied forces in WWII (1941-1945). Featured all-wheel-drive 6x6 configuration, dual rear axles, and heavy-duty construction. Over 560,000 units produced. Used for cargo transport, weapon platforms, recovery vehicles. Difficulty modifier 1.2 reflects military-spec construction, 6WD complexity, and WWII-era vintage. Data sourced from Wikipedia GMC CCKW article, December 19, 2024 revision.

GMC DUKW 'Duck' amphibious 6x6 military cargo truck (1942-1945). Based on CCKW chassis with watertight hull and marine propeller for amphibious operations. Critical for beach landings and supply operations in WWII. Over 21,000 units produced. Difficulty modifier 1.3 reflects amphibious system complexity, 6WD drivetrain, specialized marine components, and WWII military-spec construction. Data sourced from Wikipedia DUKW article, December 19, 2024 revision.

GMC's 'Blue Chip' light-duty truck series (1955-1959), Task Force styling counterpart to Chevrolet. Featured GMC's unique V6 engines (305/347 cu in) alongside inline-6 and V8 options. Available in 1/2-ton through 2-ton configurations. Difficulty modifier 1.05 reflects vintage parts availability and obsolete GMC V6 service requirements. Data sourced from Wikipedia GMC truck / Chevrolet Task Force articles, December 19, 2024 revision.

Full-size SUV/wagon variant of GMC pickup platform, predecessor to Yukon XL. Body-on-frame construction with enclosed passenger area and rear cargo space. Shared platform with Chevrolet Suburban. Difficulty modifier 1.05 reflects 1950s vintage vehicle service requirements. Data sourced from Wikipedia Chevrolet Suburban / GMC truck articles, December 19, 2024 revision.

GMC 'Old Look' transit bus series (1940-1969), iconic urban transit and school bus platform. Featured rear-engine layout with Detroit Diesel or GMC gasoline engines. Heavy-duty commercial chassis with air brakes. Difficulty modifier 1.2 reflects commercial bus service complexity, air brake systems, and diesel engine maintenance. Data sourced from Wikipedia GMC transit bus / TDH series articles, December 19, 2024 revision.

First generation C/K series full-size pickup trucks. C-series was 2WD, K-series was 4WD. Platform shared with Chevrolet C/K trucks. Available in C10/K10 (1/2-ton), C20/K20 (3/4-ton), and C30/K30 (1-ton) configurations. Fleetside and Stepside bed options. Standard service complexity for 1960s light/medium-duty truck. Data sourced from Wikipedia Chevrolet C/K article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Compact forward-control van based on Chevrolet Corvair platform and later Chevy II platform. Handi-Van was cargo variant, Handi-Bus was passenger variant. Rear-engine layout until 1967, then front-engine. Unique compact van design for 1960s. Standard service complexity. Data sourced from Wikipedia Chevrolet Corvair / GMC Handi-Van articles, December 19, 2024 revision.

First generation full-size SUV based on C/K pickup platform (K5 Blazer twin). Body-on-frame construction with removable hardtop. Introduced in 1969 model year as GMC's answer to Chevrolet K5 Blazer and Ford Bronco. Standard 4WD with part-time transfer case. Standard service complexity for 1960s full-size SUV. Data sourced from Wikipedia Chevrolet K5 Blazer article, December 19, 2024 revision.

GM A-body platform shared with Chevrolet El Camino. Coupe utility (pickup/car hybrid) based on Chevelle/Malibu platform. Sprint was renamed to Caballero in 1978. Standard service complexity for 1970s light-duty truck. Data sourced from Wikipedia GMC Sprint / Caballero article, December 19, 2024 revision.

GM G-body platform (1978-1987), downsized from A-body Sprint. Coupe utility design shared with Chevrolet El Camino. Renamed from Sprint starting 1978 model year. Standard service complexity for late-1970s light-duty truck. Data sourced from Wikipedia GMC Sprint / Caballero article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Second generation full-size van platform shared with Chevrolet Van/Sportvan. Vandura was cargo van, Rally was passenger variant with windows. Body-on-frame construction with cab-forward design. Standard service complexity for 1970s full-size commercial van. Data sourced from Wikipedia Chevrolet van article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Heavy-duty conventional cab Class 7/8 trucks for commercial applications. General was medium-duty variant, Brigadier was heavy-duty. Featured air brake systems, multiple diesel engine options from Detroit Diesel, Caterpillar, and Cummins. Requires specialized commercial diesel and air brake system service. Difficulty modifier 1.3 reflects heavy-duty commercial diesel complexity. Data sourced from Wikipedia GMC Brigadier and GMC General articles, December 19, 2024 revision.

Third generation performance coupe on GM G-platform (RWD). Famous for turbocharged variants: T-Type, Grand National (all-black), limited-edition GNX (1987, 547 units). 3.8L V6 with various turbo configurations. RWD only. Grand National/GNX are highly collectible performance vehicles. Difficulty modifier 1.1 reflects turbocharged performance systems requiring specialized service. Data sourced from Wikipedia Buick Regal / Buick Grand National articles, December 19, 2024 revision.

Sixth generation full-size sedan, downsized and converted to FWD on GM C-platform. 3.0L V6 initially, 3.8L V6 standard by 1986. Replaced by Park Avenue for 1991. Standard service complexity for 1980s full-size FWD sedan. Data sourced from Wikipedia Buick Electra article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Seventh generation full-size sedan, downsized and converted to FWD on GM H-platform. 3.0L V6 initially, 3.8L V6 by 1986. Coupe variant offered 1987-1991. Transitioned to eighth generation (1992) on same platform. Standard service complexity for 1980s full-size FWD sedan. Data sourced from Wikipedia Buick LeSabre article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Fifth generation compact sedan/coupe on GM N-platform shared with Pontiac Grand Am, Oldsmobile Calais. Multiple engine options including high-performance Quad 4 inline-4. FWD only. Somerset nameplate used 1985-1987, renamed Skylark 1987+. Standard service complexity for 1980s compact FWD sedan. Data sourced from Wikipedia Buick Skylark article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Two-seat personal luxury coupe/convertible hand-assembled at Lansing Craft Centre. GM E-platform (shortened). 3.8L V6 with 4-speed automatic. FWD only. Coupe 1988-1989, convertible 1990-1991. Low production numbers (21,751 total). Touchscreen CRT interface (innovative for 1988). Discontinued after 1991 model year. Standard service complexity for 1980s-1990s personal luxury vehicle. Data sourced from Wikipedia Buick Reatta article, December 19, 2024 revision.

engines: 3.8L V6 (170 hp base, 205 hp supercharged Ultra)
notes: Full-size luxury sedan on GM C-platform. 3.8L V6 standard; supercharged 3.8L in Ultra trim. FWD only. Replaced Electra nameplate. Discontinued after 2005 model year. Standard service complexity for 1990s-2000s full-size sedan. Data sourced from Wikipedia Buick Park Avenue article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Full-size RWD sedan and wagon on GM B-platform shared with Chevrolet Caprice. 5.0L V8 for 1991-1992, upgraded to 5.7L LT1 V8 for 1994-1996 (no 1993 model year). Estate wagon variant popular. Last RWD Buick sedan. Discontinued after 1996. Standard service complexity for 1990s full-size RWD sedan. Data sourced from Wikipedia Buick Roadmaster article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Eighth generation personal luxury coupe on GM G-platform. Supercharged 3.8L V6 standard (output increased for 1998-1999). FWD only. Final generation of Riviera. Discontinued after 1999 model year. Standard service complexity for 1990s personal luxury coupe. Data sourced from Wikipedia Buick Riviera article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Sixth generation compact sedan/coupe on GM N-platform shared with Pontiac Grand Am, Oldsmobile Achieva. Multiple engine options: 2.3L Quad 4 inline-4 (performance), 3.1L V6, 3.3L V6. FWD only. Discontinued after 1998 model year. Standard service complexity for 1990s compact sedan. Data sourced from Wikipedia Buick Skylark article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Sixth generation midsize sedan on GM W-platform. Base 3.1L V6; optional 3.8L V6 in Custom trim. FWD only. Platform shared with Buick Regal, Chevrolet Lumina/Monte Carlo. Discontinued after 2005 model year. Standard service complexity for 1990s-2000s midsize sedan. Data sourced from Wikipedia Buick Century article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Fourth generation midsize sedan on GM W-platform. Base 3.1L V6, optional 3.8L V6, high-performance supercharged 3.8L in GS trim. FWD only. Platform shared with Century, Chevrolet Monte Carlo. Discontinued after 2004 model year. Standard service complexity for 1990s-2000s midsize sedan. Data sourced from Wikipedia Buick Regal article, December 19, 2024 revision.

engines: 3.8L V6 (170 hp base, 205 hp supercharged Custom)
notes: Eighth generation full-size sedan on GM H-platform. 3.8L V6 standard; supercharged variant in Custom trim (1992-1999). Engine output updated for 2000 model year. FWD only. One of Buick's best-selling models. Discontinued after 2005 model year. Standard service complexity for 1990s-2000s full-size sedan. Data sourced from Wikipedia Buick LeSabre article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Midsize crossover SUV on GM U-platform shared with Pontiac Aztek. Three engine options through production: 3.4L V6 (2002-2003), 3.5L V6 (2004-2006), 3.6L V6 (2006-2007). FWD standard, AWD optional (Versatrak system). Third-row seating available. Discontinued after 2007 model year. Standard service complexity for 2000s midsize crossover. Data sourced from Wikipedia Buick Rendezvous article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Midsize SUV on GMT360 platform shared with Chevrolet TrailBlazer, GMC Envoy. RWD-based with optional AWD. Initially offered 4.2L Vortec inline-6 (2004-2005), later 5.3L V8 (2006-2007). Body-on-frame construction. Discontinued after 2007 model year. Standard service complexity for 2000s body-on-frame SUV. Data sourced from Wikipedia Buick Rainier article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Minivan on GM U-platform (long wheelbase) shared with Chevrolet Uplander, Pontiac Montana SV6, Saturn Relay. 3.5L V6 for 2005, upgraded to 3.9L V6 for 2006-2007. FWD standard, AWD optional. Discontinued after 2007 model year. Standard service complexity for 2000s minivan. Data sourced from Wikipedia Buick Terraza article, December 19, 2024 revision.

First generation full-size sedan replacing Century and Regal. GM W-platform. Base 3.8L V6 or optional 3.6L V6; high-performance Super model offered 5.3L V8 (2008-2009 only). FWD only. Standard service complexity for 2000s full-size sedan. Data sourced from Wikipedia Buick LaCrosse article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Full-size sedan replacing Park Avenue and LeSabre. GM G-platform (same as Cadillac DTS). Base 3.8L V6 (2006-2008) or 3.9L V6 (2009-2011); optional 4.6L Northstar V8 in Super trim. FWD only. Discontinued after 2011 model year. Standard service complexity for 2000s full-size sedan. Data sourced from Wikipedia Buick Lucerne article, December 19, 2024 revision.

First generation full-size crossover on GM Lambda platform shared with GMC Acadia, Chevrolet Traverse. 3.6L V6 initially 275 hp, upgraded to 288 hp with direct injection for 2009. 6-speed automatic transmission. FWD standard, AWD optional. Three-row seating. Standard service complexity for 2000s full-size crossover. Data sourced from Wikipedia Buick Enclave article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Compact sedan on GM Delta II platform shared with Chevrolet Cruze. Base 2.4L Ecotec inline-4 with 6-speed automatic; optional 2.0L turbo (Verano Turbo) offered 6-speed manual or automatic. Discontinued in North America after 2017 model year. Standard service complexity for modern compact sedan. Data sourced from Wikipedia Buick Verano article, December 19, 2024 revision.

engines: 2.0L turbocharged inline-4 eAssist mild hybrid (182 hp)
notes: Fifth generation midsize sedan based on Opel Insignia. Multiple powertrain options including eAssist mild hybrid system (2.4L + electric motor). Turbo GS model available with manual transmission and AWD. Standard service complexity for modern midsize sedan; eAssist mild hybrid does not require elevated difficulty modifier. Data sourced from Wikipedia Buick Regal article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Sixth generation based on Opel/Vauxhall Insignia B. Offered as Sportback (liftback sedan) and TourX (wagon with raised suspension). 2.0L turbo I4 standard; 3.6L V6 in GS performance model with AWD. Discontinued in North America after 2020 model year. Standard service complexity for modern midsize sedan/wagon. Data sourced from Wikipedia Buick Regal article, December 19, 2024 revision.

engines: 2.4L Ecotec inline-4 eAssist mild hybrid (182 hp)
notes: Second generation full-size sedan on GM Epsilon II platform. eAssist mild hybrid system available with 2.4L inline-4. 3.6L V6 standard engine, output increased from 280 hp to 304 hp during model run. AWD optional. Standard service complexity; eAssist mild hybrid does not require elevated modifier. Data sourced from Wikipedia Buick LaCrosse article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Third generation full-size sedan introduced for 2017 model year. Base inline-4 (2.4L then 2.5L) or optional 3.6L V6. Platform shared with Chevrolet Impala and Cadillac XTS (GM W-platform). AWD available with V6 only. Discontinued after 2019 model year in North America. Standard service complexity for modern full-size sedan. Data sourced from Wikipedia Buick LaCrosse article, December 19, 2024 revision.

First generation subcompact crossover on GM Gamma II platform shared with Chevrolet Trax. 1.4L turbocharged Ecotec inline-4 with 6-speed automatic. Output increased from 138 hp to 153 hp for 2016 model year. FWD standard, AWD optional. Sold alongside Encore GX starting 2020. Discontinued after 2022 model year. Standard service complexity for modern subcompact crossover. Data sourced from Wikipedia Buick Encore article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Compact convertible based on Opel Cascada. 1.6L turbocharged inline-4 with 6-speed automatic transmission. FWD only. Power-retractable hardtop convertible roof. Sold in North America 2016-2019, imported from Poland. Standard service complexity for modern convertible. Data sourced from Wikipedia Buick Cascada article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Second generation full-size crossover introduced for 2018 model year on C1XX platform. 3.6L V6 with 9-speed automatic replaces previous 6-speed. Three trim levels including new top Avenir trim. Intelligent AWD with active twin-clutch rear differential. Standard service complexity for modern full-size crossover. Data sourced from Wikipedia Buick Enclave article, December 19, 2024 revision.

First generation midsize crossover, first Chinese-built GM vehicle sold in America. Debuted at 2016 Detroit Auto Show. Base 2.5L inline-4 or available 2.0L turbocharged inline-4. AWD initially standard, FWD added for 2017. Five trim levels by 2017. Standard service complexity for modern midsize crossover. Data sourced from Wikipedia Buick Envision article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Subcompact crossover positioned between Encore and Envision. VSS-F platform. First GM vehicle in North America with 3-cylinder engines since 2000 Chevrolet Metro. 1.2L turbo I3 standard on FWD with CVT; 1.3L turbo I3 on AWD with 9-speed automatic. Standard service complexity for modern compact crossover. Data sourced from Wikipedia Buick Encore GX article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Second generation midsize crossover on E2XX platform shared with Cadillac XT4. Assembled in China, first Chinese-built GM vehicle sold in America (first generation 2016). Four trim levels: base, Preferred, Essence, Avenir. Standard suite of safety features including blind spot monitor, lane departure warning, forward collision alert. Standard service complexity for modern midsize crossover. Data sourced from Wikipedia Buick Envision article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Subcompact crossover SUV introduced for 2024 model year. GM E-Turbo engine (LIH) 1.2L turbo inline-3 (North American spec; China gets 1.5L I4). Three trim levels: Preferred, Sport Touring (ST), Avenir. FWD only. VSS-F platform. Standard service complexity for modern subcompact crossover. Data sourced from Wikipedia Buick Envista article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Third generation full-size crossover unveiled April 2024 for 2025 model year. Three trim levels: Preferred, Sport Touring, Avenir. First Buick with Super Cruise hands-free ADAS. 2025 model awarded IIHS Top Safety Pick+. Turbocharged 2.5L inline-4 replaces previous V6.
