Features Driver Attention Assist, Enhanced Automatic Park Assist, digital rearview camera mirror (Avenir). Standard service complexity for modern full-size crossover. Data sourced from Wikipedia Buick Enclave article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Buick's first production automobile (1903-1904). Horizontal opposed flat-twin 'valve-in-head' engine (OHV innovation). Tiller steering, 2-speed planetary transmission. Chain drive to rear axle. Open two-seat touring body. Brass radiator, oil/kerosene lamps, hand-crank starting, no brakes on front wheels. Wooden-spoke artillery wheels. Only ~37 Model B vehicles produced. Difficulty modifier 1.5 (highest) reflects turn-of-century construction, extreme rarity, pioneering technology, hand-crafted components, wooden construction, and virtually no parts availability. Data sourced from Wikipedia Buick Model B article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Brass-era Model F touring runabout (1906-1910). Horizontally-opposed flat-twin 'valve-in-head' engine. 2-speed planetary transmission, chain drive. Open runabout body. Brass trim, oil/acetylene lamps, hand-crank starting, mechanical brakes rear only. Wooden-spoke wheels. Early Buick success model. Difficulty modifier 1.45 reflects early brass-era construction, hand-fitted components, obsolete systems, wooden construction, and near-zero parts availability. Data sourced from Wikipedia Buick Model F article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Model 10 'White Streak' brass-era runabout/touring (1908-1910). First Buick four-cylinder model. Inline-4 'valve-in-head' engine. 2-speed planetary transmission. Open bodies. Brass radiator, acetylene/oil lamps, hand-crank starting. Famous for winning 1908 New York to Paris race (actually a Model 10 support vehicle). Difficulty modifier 1.45 reflects early brass-era construction, hand-fitted components, obsolete systems, and near-zero parts availability. Data sourced from Wikipedia Buick Model 10 article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Brass-era four-cylinder models (Models 10, 14, 16, 17, 19, etc.). Inline-4 engines. Open touring and roadster bodies predominant. RWD with chain or shaft drive. Brass radiators, acetylene/oil lamps, hand-crank starting, mechanical brakes on rear wheels only. Wooden-spoke wheels, wooden body framing. Difficulty modifier 1.4 reflects brass-era fragile construction, hand-fitted components, obsolete ignition/brake systems, wooden components, and near-zero parts availability. Data sourced from Wikipedia Buick Model history articles, December 19, 2024 revision.

Brass-era six-cylinder models (1914-1925). Inline-6 engines, smoother than contemporary four-cylinders. Multiple body styles including enclosed sedans in later years. RWD. Brass/nickel trim, wooden-spoke wheels initially, transitioning to disc wheels by early 1920s. Hand-crank starting, mechanical brakes. Difficulty modifier 1.35 reflects brass-era construction, transition to 'modern' era, hand-fitted components, and very limited parts availability. Data sourced from Wikipedia Buick Six history articles, December 19, 2024 revision.

D-Series brass-era touring cars (D-44, D-45, D-46, D-47 models, 1916-1917). Inline-6 engines. Open touring and roadster bodies. RWD. Brass radiator, acetylene lighting, hand-crank starting. Wooden-spoke wheels, leather upholstery. WWI-era production. Difficulty modifier 1.4 reflects WWI brass-era construction, extreme rarity, hand-fitted components, obsolete systems, and near-zero parts availability. Data sourced from Wikipedia Buick D-Series articles, December 19, 2024 revision.

Entry-level Buick Standard Six series (1925-1929). Inline-6 engine. Multiple body styles including open touring cars. RWD. Mechanical brakes, 6-volt electrical, magneto ignition. Difficulty modifier 1.3 reflects mid-1920s brass-era proximity, hand-fitted components, mechanical brakes only, and extreme parts scarcity. Data sourced from Wikipedia Buick Standard Six article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Mid-range Buick Master Six series (1925-1928). Larger inline-6 than Standard Six. Multiple body styles including touring and roadster. RWD. Mechanical brakes, brass-era construction techniques. Difficulty modifier 1.3 reflects mid-1920s brass-era proximity, hand-fitted construction, obsolete systems, and extreme parts scarcity. Data sourced from Wikipedia Buick Master Six article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Series 50 and Series 60 models (1926-1929). Inline-6 engines. Multiple body styles. RWD. Body-on-frame construction with wood framing. Mechanical brakes, 6-volt electrical. Difficulty modifier 1.3 reflects late-1920s brass-era proximity, wooden body framing, hand-assembled construction, and extreme parts scarcity. Data sourced from Wikipedia Buick history articles, December 19, 2024 revision.

Entry-level Buick Series 40 through Great Depression era (1930-1935). Inline-8 engine. Multiple body styles. RWD. Mechanical brakes, 6-volt electrical system. Difficulty modifier 1.25 reflects early 1930s brass-era proximity, Depression-era production variations, mechanical brake systems, and extreme parts scarcity. Data sourced from Wikipedia Buick Series 40 article, December 19, 2024 revision.

First and second generation Century (1936-1958, wartime gap 1943-1945). Performance model with Roadmaster engine in lighter Special body. Name signified 100 mph capability. Buick straight-8 engines. Multiple body styles. Difficulty modifier 1.2 reflects 1930s-1950s vintage complexity, WWII production gap, and transition-era mechanical systems. Data sourced from Wikipedia Buick Century article, December 19, 2024 revision.

First generation flagship Roadmaster (1936-1953, wartime production gap). Buick straight-8 engine. Luxury full-size sedan. Multiple upscale body styles. RWD body-on-frame. Difficulty modifier 1.2 reflects 1930s-1950s vintage complexity, WWII era production variations, and obsolete systems. Data sourced from Wikipedia Buick Roadmaster article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Top-of-line luxury series (1936-1942). Buick straight-8 engine. Ultra-luxury appointments, long wheelbase. RWD. Sedan and limousine body styles. Discontinued due to WWII, not revived postwar. Difficulty modifier 1.25 reflects 1930s-1940s vintage luxury complexity, ultra-rare limited production, and specialized restoration requirements. Data sourced from Wikipedia Buick Limited article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Series 50 Super mid-range model (1939-1941, later continued as just 'Super' postwar). Buick inline-8 engine. Multiple body styles. RWD. Positioned between Special and Roadmaster. Production halted 1942 for WWII. Difficulty modifier 1.2 reflects late-1930s/early-1940s vintage complexity and pre-war construction. Data sourced from Wikipedia Buick Super article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Mid-range Buick series spanning 1940-1958 (production halted 1943-1945 for WWII). Buick inline-8 engines until 1953, V8 from 1954. Multiple body styles. RWD. Positioned between Special and Roadmaster. Difficulty modifier 1.15 reflects 1940s-1950s vintage complexity, WWII-era production variations, and obsolete mechanical systems. Data sourced from Wikipedia Buick Super article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Postwar flagship full-size luxury sedan (1946-1958). Buick straight-8 engine through entire run. Introduced Dynaflow automatic transmission 1948. Multiple upscale body styles including convertible. RWD body-on-frame. Difficulty modifier 1.15 reflects postwar 1940s-1950s vintage complexity. Data sourced from Wikipedia Buick Roadmaster article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Fastback body style variant (1941-1942, 1946-1949, no 1943-1945 production due to WWII). Buick inline-8 engine. Sleek fastback design popular in postwar era. RWD. Available in Super and Roadmaster series. Collectible for distinctive styling. Difficulty modifier 1.2 reflects 1940s vintage construction, WWII-era gaps in production, and specialized body restoration. Data sourced from Wikipedia Buick Sedanette article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Early wood-bodied estate wagons (1940-1953, wartime production gap). Buick inline-8 engines. Real wood construction through early 1950s. RWD body-on-frame. Available in Super and Roadmaster series. Difficulty modifier 1.15 reflects 1940s-1950s vintage complexity and wood body restoration requirements. Data sourced from Wikipedia Buick Estate Wagon article, December 19, 2024 revision.

First generation Skylark as limited-production luxury convertible. Based on Roadmaster chassis with lowered suspension. Buick Nailhead V8. Wire wheels, leather interior. Only 1,690 units in 1953, 836 in 1954. Collectible 1950s American luxury car. Difficulty modifier 1.1 reflects 1950s vintage rarity and specialized restoration requirements. Data sourced from Wikipedia Buick Skylark article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Entry-level Buick through the 1950s. Initially inline-8 engines, transitioned to V8 for 1954. Multiple body styles. RWD body-on-frame construction. Difficulty modifier 1.1 reflects 1950s vintage complexity and parts availability. Data sourced from Wikipedia Buick Special article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Third generation midsize sedan with powerful Nailhead V8 in lighter Special body. Performance orientation (Century name = 100 mph capability). Multiple body styles. RWD. Difficulty modifier 1.1 reflects 1950s vintage complexity. Data sourced from Wikipedia Buick Century article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Third generation full-size luxury sedan. Initially inline-8, transitioned to Nailhead V8 for 1954. Top Buick model below limited. Multiple upscale body styles including convertible. RWD body-on-frame. Difficulty modifier 1.1 reflects 1950s vintage complexity and luxury feature restoration. Data sourced from Wikipedia Buick Roadmaster article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Full-size sedan positioned between LeSabre and Electra (1959-1963). Powerful 401 cu in Nailhead V8. Multiple body styles including convertible and wagon. RWD. Replaced Century nameplate temporarily. Difficulty modifier 1.05 reflects late-1950s/early-1960s vintage. Data sourced from Wikipedia Buick Invicta article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Third and fourth generation full-size sedan. Entry-level full-size Buick. Nailhead V8 engines through 1966. Multiple body styles. RWD body-on-frame construction. Difficulty modifier 1.05 reflects 1960s vintage complexity. Data sourced from Wikipedia Buick LeSabre article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Full-size luxury sedan on GM C-platform. Buick Nailhead V8 engine (vertical valves). Multiple body styles including convertible. Premium Electra 225 variant with longer wheelbase. RWD body-on-frame construction. Difficulty modifier 1.05 reflects 1960s vintage parts availability. Data sourced from Wikipedia Buick Electra article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Full-size performance sedan positioned between LeSabre and Electra. Nailhead V8 engines with high performance. Multiple body styles including convertible. RWD only. Discontinued after 1970 model year. Difficulty modifier 1.05 reflects 1960s vintage complexity. Data sourced from Wikipedia Buick Wildcat article, December 19, 2024 revision.

First generation personal luxury coupe with distinctive styling by Bill Mitchell. E-body platform. Nailhead V8 engines. 2-door hardtop only, no B-pillar. Competed with Ford Thunderbird. Iconic 1963-1965 design considered one of most beautiful American cars. Difficulty modifier 1.05 reflects 1960s vintage parts availability. Data sourced from Wikipedia Buick Riviera article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Third generation midsize sedan on GM A-platform. Gran Sport (GS) performance variants with big-block V8 engines. Multiple body styles including convertible and wagon. RWD only. Competed with Chevrolet Chevelle. Stage 1 performance package available. Difficulty modifier 1.05 reflects 1960s vintage complexity. Data sourced from Wikipedia Buick Skylark article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Midsize station wagon variant on A-platform. Part of Skylark/Special family. Multiple V8 engine options. RWD only. Sporty wagon design with performance options available. Discontinued after 1971 model year. Difficulty modifier 1.05 reflects 1960s-early 1970s vintage. Data sourced from Wikipedia Buick Special / Skylark article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Fifth generation midsize sedan on GM A-platform (downsized). Introduced as part of GM's 1973 downsizing. Multiple V6/V8 engine options. RWD only. Platform shared with Chevrolet Malibu, Pontiac LeMans, Oldsmobile Cutlass. Standard service complexity for 1970s midsize RWD sedan. Data sourced from Wikipedia Buick Century article, December 19, 2024 revision.

First generation Regal introduced as upscale Century trim, became standalone model 1973. GM A-platform. Multiple V6/V8 engines. 2-door coupe only. RWD. Replaced Skylark GS nameplate. Standard service complexity for 1970s midsize RWD coupe. Data sourced from Wikipedia Buick Regal article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Subcompact on GM H-platform shared with Chevrolet Monza, Pontiac Sunbird, Oldsmobile Starfire. Initially 2.3L inline-4 (Vega engine), optional 3.8L V6 added 1978. RWD only. Hatchback and notchback body styles. First Buick with 4-cylinder engine since 1930s. Standard service complexity for 1970s subcompact. Data sourced from Wikipedia Buick Skyhawk article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Compact sedan on GM X-platform shared with Chevrolet Nova, Pontiac Ventura, Oldsmobile Omega. Badge-engineered Nova variant. Base inline-6 or optional V8 engines. RWD only. Replaced by Skylark for 1975. Short production run 1973-1975. Standard service complexity for 1970s compact RWD sedan. Data sourced from Wikipedia Buick Apollo article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Fifth generation full-size sedan, dramatically downsized for 1977 on GM C-platform (RWD). Base 3.8L V6, optional 5.0L V8 or 5.7L Oldsmobile diesel V8. Remained RWD until 1985 FWD redesign. Coupe and sedan body styles. Standard service complexity for 1970s-1980s downsized full-size sedan; Oldsmobile diesel optional. Data sourced from Wikipedia Buick Electra article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Sixth generation full-size sedan, downsized for 1977 on GM B-platform (RWD). Base 3.8L V6, optional 5.0L V8 or 4.3L diesel V8. Remained RWD until 1985 FWD redesign. Coupe and sedan body styles. Platform shared with Chevrolet Impala/Caprice. Standard service complexity for 1970s-1980s downsized full-size sedan. Data sourced from Wikipedia Buick LeSabre article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Full-size luxury station wagon spanning multiple B-body platforms (1970-1990). Initially large pre-downsizing body, downsized 1977, remained RWD throughout production. Various V6/V8 engines through the decades. Wood-grain exterior trim (Di-Noc). Last full-size RWD Buick wagon. Discontinued 1990. Standard service complexity for full-size RWD wagon. Data sourced from Wikipedia Buick Estate Wagon article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Second-generation Seville on K-body platform, first FWD Seville. Distinctive 'bustleback' styling inspired by 1930s Cadillacs. First American car to offer diesel engine (5.7L). HT-4100 V8 notorious for reliability issues including intake manifold gasket failure, aluminum oil pump failure, and weak block castings. Diesel and problematic HT-4100 require specialized service knowledge. Data sourced from Wikipedia and web research, December 19, 2024.

Front-wheel drive C-body platform introduced 1985. First transverse-mounted V8 ever. HT-4100 (1985-1987) prone to intake manifold gasket failure, aluminum oil pump failure, and block casting issues. Replaced by improved 4.5L HT-4500 for 1988-1989. First car with federally-mandated high-mounted rear stop lamp (1986). HT-4100 and HT-4500 require specialized service knowledge. 1980s portion only (1985-1989). Data sourced from Wikipedia and web research, December 19, 2024.

Compact luxury sedan on GM J-body platform, badge-engineered Chevrolet Cavalier. Controversial entry-level Cadillac with McPherson strut front suspension and torsion-beam rear axle. First Cadillac with manual transmission since 1950. V6 became optional in 1985, standard in 1988. Approximately 100,000 units produced 1982-1988. Data sourced from Wikipedia and web research, December 19, 2024.

engines: 6.0L V8 (368 cu in, digital fuel injection, 1980-1981)
notes: Dramatically downsized for 1979 (1,000 lbs lighter, 20 inches shorter). Tenth generation (1979-1985) on E-body, eleventh generation (1986-1991, 1980s portion 1986-1989) on shortened E-body. First GM digital fuel injection (1980). HT-4100 (1982-1987) and diesel engines notorious for reliability issues. 4.5L HT-4500 introduced 1988. Diesel and HT-series engines require specialized service knowledge. Data sourced from Wikipedia and web research, December 19, 2024.

Italian-bodied luxury roadster with Pininfarina-designed bodies built in Italy and flown to Detroit in Boeing 747s (56 bodies per flight). Two-seat convertible with removable hardtop. HT-4100 and HT-4500 engines underpowered for luxury roadster. Transatlantic production process and Italian coachwork require specialized knowledge. 1980s portion only (1987-1989). 21,000 total units produced 1987-1993. Data sourced from Wikipedia and web research, December 19, 2024.

Traditional rear-wheel drive luxury sedan on D-body platform. Previously marketed as Fleetwood Brougham 1977-1986, renamed Brougham for 1987. Last traditional RWD Cadillac sedan until 1993 Fleetwood. 5.7L Chevrolet 350 V8 became optional 1990. 1980s portion only (1987-1989). Data sourced from Wikipedia and web research, December 19, 2024.

Fourth-generation Seville on FWD K-body platform. Introduced Northstar System in 1993 with quad-cam 32-valve aluminum V8. At 300 hp, became one of the most powerful front-wheel-drive cars in 1994. Motor Trend Car of the Year 1992. Northstar V8 requires service attention for head gasket and coolant system issues. 1990s portion only (1992-1999). Data sourced from Wikipedia Cadillac Seville article and web research, December 19, 2024.

Twelfth-generation luxury coupe on K-body platform. Touring Coupe (ETC) introduced 1992, featuring higher-output Northstar V8. Northstar System coupled 4T80-E transmission with Northstar engines starting 1993. Northstar V8 requires service attention for head gasket and coolant system issues. 1990s portion only (1992-1999). Data sourced from Wikipedia and web research, December 19, 2024.

Eighth-generation DeVille Concours on FWD K-body platform. Equipped with Northstar V8 producing 270-275 hp (1994-1995), upgraded to 300 hp (1996-1999). Paired with 4T80-E four-speed automatic. Northstar V8 requires service attention for head gasket and coolant system issues. 1990s portion only (1994-1999). Data sourced from Wikipedia and web research, December 19, 2024.

Compact executive sedan on GM V platform, rebadged Opel Omega B. Manufactured by Opel in Rüsselsheim, Germany. Engine built in England, transmission in France. Entry-level luxury sedan marketed to compete with European imports. Approximately 95,000 units built. Replaced by CTS. Data sourced from Wikipedia Cadillac Catera article, December 19, 2024 revision.

First-generation full-size luxury SUV on GMT435 platform. Rushed to market to compete with Lincoln Navigator. Essentially badge-engineered GMC Yukon Denali with minimal differentiation. Two-row seating for five passengers. Auto-Trac selectable 4x4 system. Priced at $46,225. 1990s portion only (1999-2000). Data sourced from Wikipedia Cadillac Escalade article, December 19, 2024 revision.

First-generation CTS on GM Sigma platform introduced Cadillac's 'Art and Science' design language. CTS-V performance variant offered with LS6/LS2 V8 engines and manual transmission. Data sourced from Wikipedia Cadillac CTS article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Second-generation CTS on GM Sigma II platform. 2000s portion only (2008-2009). Optional all-wheel drive introduced. Direct-injection V6 available. Data sourced from Wikipedia Cadillac CTS article, December 19, 2024 revision.

First-generation mid-size luxury crossover on GM Sigma platform (GMT265). Three-row, seven-passenger configuration. Longitudinally mounted front engine with rear differential. 2000s portion only (2004-2009). Data sourced from Wikipedia Cadillac SRX article, December 19, 2024 revision.

engines: 4.4L Northstar LC3 supercharged V8 (469 hp, STS-V)
notes: Mid-size luxury sedan on GM Sigma platform. First Cadillac sedan with all-wheel drive option (STS4 badge). STS-V features supercharged 4.4L Northstar V8 producing 469 hp. Optional Magnetic Ride Control suspension. Supercharged variant requires specialized service knowledge. Data sourced from Wikipedia Cadillac STS article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Full-size luxury sedan on GM G platform with transverse FWD layout. Replaced DeVille. Standard wheelbase (115.6 in) and long wheelbase DTS-L (123.6 in) variants available. Optional Magnetic Ride Control. Northstar V8 requires service attention for head gasket and coolant system issues. Data sourced from Wikipedia Cadillac DTS article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Luxury roadster on GM Y-body platform shared with Corvette C6. Rear-mounted transmission for near 50/50 weight distribution. Power retractable hardtop. XLR-V features supercharged 4.4L Northstar producing 443 hp. Magnetic Ride Control suspension. Built at Bowling Green Assembly Plant. Corvette-based platform and supercharged variant require specialized service knowledge. Data sourced from Wikipedia Cadillac XLR article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Full-size luxury SUV spanning second generation GMT800 (2002-2006) and third generation GMT900 (2007-2014, 2000s portion 2007-2009). Available in standard, ESV (extended), and EXT (sport utility truck) body styles. 2000s portion only. Escalade Hybrid introduced 2009 (different entry). Data sourced from Wikipedia Cadillac Escalade article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Compact luxury sedan and coupe on GM Alpha platform competing with BMW 3-Series. ATS-V features twin-turbocharged V6 with 464 hp, available with 6-speed manual transmission. Production ended 2019. Data sourced from Wikipedia Cadillac ATS article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Third-generation mid-size luxury sedan on GM Alpha platform. CTS-V features supercharged LT4 V8 producing 640 hp, available with 6-speed manual transmission. Vsport trim offered twin-turbo V6. Supercharged variant requires performance-oriented service knowledge. Data sourced from Wikipedia Cadillac CTS article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Full-size luxury sedan on Epsilon II LWB platform. Replaced DTS and STS models. Vsport trim featured twin-turbocharged V6 producing 410 hp. Production ended 2019. Data sourced from Wikipedia Cadillac XTS article, December 19, 2024 revision.

engines: 4.2L LTA twin-turbocharged V8 (500 hp, Platinum trim)
notes: Full-size luxury sedan on GM Omega platform. First Cadillac with Super Cruise semi-autonomous driving. 4.2L 'Blackwing' twin-turbo V8 exclusive to CT6, producing up to 550 hp in CT6-V. North American production ended February 2020 at Detroit/Hamtramck Assembly. Twin-turbo V8 requires specialized service knowledge. Data sourced from Wikipedia Cadillac CT6 article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Mid-size luxury crossover SUV on GM C1XX platform. Replaced SRX. Features Active Fuel Management cylinder deactivation and automatic stop-start. AWD system includes twin-clutch differential with active torque vectoring and can disconnect rear drive unit for efficiency. 2010s portion only (2017-2019). Data sourced from Wikipedia Cadillac XT5 article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Subcompact luxury crossover SUV on E2XX platform, slotting below XT5. Went on sale fall 2018 as 2019 model. 2010s portion only (first year). Data sourced from Wikipedia Cadillac XT4 article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Fourth-generation full-size luxury SUV on GMT K2XX platform. Available in standard and ESV (extended) body styles. Transmission upgraded from 6-speed to 8-speed (2015-2017), then to 10-speed (2018-2020). Production ran January 2014 to December 2019. Hennessey HPE550 supercharger upgrade available. Data sourced from Wikipedia Cadillac Escalade article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Compact luxury sedan on GM Alpha platform. CT4-V Blackwing is ultra-high performance variant with twin-turbo V6 producing 472 hp, 0-60 in 3.9 seconds. Available with manual transmission on Blackwing. Data sourced from Wikipedia Cadillac CT4 article, December 19, 2024 revision.

engines: 6.2L LT4 supercharged V8 (668 hp, CT5-V Blackwing)
notes: Mid-size luxury sedan on GM Alpha 2 platform with fastback styling. CT5-V Blackwing features supercharged 6.2L LT4 V8 producing 668 hp, making it one of the most powerful sedans available. Requires performance-oriented service knowledge for supercharged variants. Data sourced from Wikipedia Cadillac CT5 article, December 19, 2024 revision.

engines: 3.0L LM2 Duramax I6 Diesel (277 hp, 460 lb-ft, discontinued 2025)
notes: Fifth-generation full-size luxury SUV on GMT T1XX platform. Available in standard and ESV (extended) body styles. Optional 3.0L Duramax diesel discontinued in 2025 facelift. Escalade-V features supercharged LT4 V8 with 682 hp. All-electric Escalade IQ introduced as separate model for 2025. Diesel and supercharged variants require specialized service knowledge. Data sourced from Wikipedia Cadillac Escalade article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Subcompact luxury crossover SUV on E2XX platform. North American production ends in 2025 model year. Diesel variant available in Europe only (not included). Data sourced from Wikipedia Cadillac XT4 article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Mid-size luxury crossover SUV on GM VSS-S (C1-2) platform. First generation continued through 2024 in North America. Second generation with mild hybrid system introduced in China (2025+) but mild hybrid not available in North American market. Data sourced from Wikipedia Cadillac XT5 article, December 19, 2024 revision.
Three-row mid-size luxury crossover SUV on C1XX platform. North American production continues through 2025 model year. Data sourced from Wikipedia Cadillac XT6 article, December 19, 2024 revision.

engines: Single electric motor RWD (340 hp, 325 lb-ft)
Dual electric motors AWD (500 hp, 450 lb-ft)
notes: Cadillac's first mass-market all-electric vehicle on GM BEV3 Ultium platform. Features 102 kWh battery with 314-mile EPA range (RWD) or 307 miles (AWD). DC fast charging up to 190 kW. High-voltage electric vehicle system requires EV-certified technicians. Permanent magnet synchronous AC motors. Production started May 2022. Data sourced from Wikipedia Cadillac Lyriq article, December 19, 2024 revision.

engines: Dual electric motors AWD (655 hp, 488 kW)
notes: Ultra-luxury flagship electric sedan on GM BEV3 Ultium platform. Hand-built at GM Technical Center in Warren, Michigan with limited production of fewer than 500 units per year. Price approximately $340,000 as of 2025. Features 111 kWh Ultium battery. High-voltage electric system and hand-built bespoke construction require specialized EV-certified technicians and luxury vehicle expertise. Data sourced from Wikipedia Cadillac Celestiq article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Cadillac's first production automobiles (1902-1908). Single-cylinder engine under seat. Planetary transmission. Runabout (2-seat) and Tonneau (rear-entry 4-seat) body styles. Tiller steering initially, steering wheel from 1904. Won Dewar Trophy 1908 for interchangeable parts demonstration. Difficulty modifier 1.5 (highest) reflects turn-of-century construction, single-cylinder engine, pioneering technology, hand-crafted components, and virtually no parts availability. Data sourced from Wikipedia Cadillac Runabout article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Model B and Model C designations (1904-1905). Single-cylinder engines. Improved versions of original runabout design. Chain drive to rear axle. Brass radiators, oil/kerosene lamps, hand-crank starting. Difficulty modifier 1.5 reflects early brass-era construction, single-cylinder technology, extreme rarity, hand-fitted components, and virtually no parts availability. Data sourced from Wikipedia Cadillac Model B/C articles, December 19, 2024 revision.

Model K and M four-cylinder models (1906-1908). First Cadillac four-cylinder engines. Model K with larger 4.0L engine, Model M with 2.5L. Transitioning from single-cylinder to four-cylinder production. Brass-era construction with improved reliability. Difficulty modifier 1.45 reflects early brass-era four-cylinder complexity, pioneering multi-cylinder technology, hand-fitted construction, and near-zero parts availability. Data sourced from Wikipedia Cadillac Model K/M articles, December 19, 2024 revision.

Type 30 brass-era model (1909-1911). Inline-4 engine with innovation in interchangeable parts (won Dewar Trophy 1908). Multiple body styles available. Brass radiator, acetylene/oil lamps, hand-crank starting, mechanical brakes rear only. Difficulty modifier 1.4 reflects brass-era construction, hand-fitted components, pioneering interchangeable parts (but still vintage), and near-zero parts availability. Data sourced from Wikipedia Cadillac Type 30 article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Type 51 with first production V8 engine (1914-1916). Industry-first mass-produced V8. Electric starter and lights standard (major innovation). Multiple luxury body styles. Brass-era construction with modern features. Difficulty modifier 1.35 reflects WWI-era brass construction, pioneering V8 technology, hand-assembled components, and extreme parts scarcity. Data sourced from Wikipedia Cadillac Type 51 article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Type 53/55/57/59/61 series evolution (1916-1923). Continued V8 engine development through WWI and early 1920s. Multiple body styles with coachwork. Transitioned from brass-era to modern construction. Type numbers changed yearly. Difficulty modifier 1.35 reflects WWI/early-1920s vintage, brass-era proximity, transition technologies, and very limited parts availability. Data sourced from Wikipedia Cadillac history articles, December 19, 2024 revision.

Type 61 V8-powered luxury sedan (1916-1917). Established Cadillac's V8 reputation. Electric starter and lights standard. Multiple body styles available. WWI-era production. Difficulty modifier 1.35 reflects WWI brass-era construction, early V8 technology, hand-fitted components, and extreme parts scarcity. Data sourced from Wikipedia Cadillac Type 61 article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Type V-63 with Cadillac's first V8 engine (1923-1925). Introduced 90-degree V8 replacing inline engines. Multiple body styles. Mechanical brakes, 6-volt electrical. Difficulty modifier 1.3 reflects early 1920s brass-era proximity, first-generation V8 technology, hand-fitted components, and extreme parts scarcity. Data sourced from Wikipedia Cadillac Type V-63 article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Series 314 luxury sedan (1926-1927). Continued V8 engine development. Multiple coachwork styles. Mechanical brakes, brass/nickel trim. Difficulty modifier 1.3 reflects mid-1920s complexity, brass-era proximity, hand-assembled construction, and extreme parts scarcity. Data sourced from Wikipedia Cadillac Series 314 article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Series 341 with larger V8 (1928-1929). Introduced synchromesh transmission for 1929 (industry first). Safety glass standard. Multiple luxury body styles. Mechanical brakes transitioning to mechanical with vacuum assist. Difficulty modifier 1.25 reflects late-1920s vintage, transition technologies, and very limited parts availability. Data sourced from Wikipedia Cadillac Series 341 article, December 19, 2024 revision.

LaSalle companion brand (1927-1940). Styled by Harley Earl, positioned below Cadillac. Various V8 engines through production. Multiple body styles. Became Cadillac Series 52 briefly. Discontinued 1940. Difficulty modifier 1.25 reflects 1920s-1930s vintage, companion brand rarity, multiple engine variations, and parts scarcity. Data sourced from Wikipedia LaSalle automobile article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Series 355 V8 luxury sedan during Great Depression (1931-1935). Flathead V8 engine. Multiple body styles with custom coachwork available. X-braced frame. Vacuum-assisted brakes. Difficulty modifier 1.25 reflects early 1930s complexity, Depression-era variations, mechanical systems, and extreme parts scarcity. Data sourced from Wikipedia Cadillac Series 355 article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Series 370 V12 ultra-luxury model (1931-1937). Twelve-cylinder flathead engine for ultra-smooth operation. Multiple custom coachwork bodies. Positioned between V8 and V16 models. Difficulty modifier 1.3 reflects 1930s V12 complexity, custom coachwork, Depression-era production, obsolete systems, and extreme parts scarcity. Data sourced from Wikipedia Cadillac V-12 article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Legendary Series 452 V16 ultra-luxury flagship (1930-1937). First production V16 engine. Flathead sixteen-cylinder for ultimate smoothness. Only 4,076 units built. Custom coachwork by Fleetwood and others. Ultra-exclusive Depression-era luxury. Difficulty modifier 1.4 reflects V16 complexity, extreme rarity, custom coachwork restoration, 1930s vintage systems, and virtually no parts availability. Data sourced from Wikipedia Cadillac V-16 article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Series 60, 65, and 70 models (1936-1940). Flathead V8 engines. Various wheelbase lengths. Series 60 introduced as mid-range model. Series 65/70 for longer wheelbase variants. Pre-war luxury sedans. Difficulty modifier 1.2 reflects late-1930s vintage complexity, pre-war construction, and limited parts availability. Data sourced from Wikipedia Cadillac history articles, December 19, 2024 revision.

LaSalle Series 50 companion brand to Cadillac (1934-1940, LaSalle existed 1927-1940). Smaller flathead V8 initially, larger V8 from 1937. Positioned as more affordable luxury alternative to Cadillac. Discontinued 1940. Difficulty modifier 1.2 reflects 1930s vintage complexity, companion brand parts scarcity, and obsolete systems. Data sourced from Wikipedia LaSalle automobile article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Long-running luxury sedan series (1940-1964, WWII production gap 1943-1945). Initially flathead V8, switched to overhead-valve V8 for 1949. Introduced tail fins 1948. Multiple body styles including Coupe de Ville hardtop. X-frame chassis. Difficulty modifier 1.15 reflects 1940s-1960s vintage complexity, WWII-era variations, and transition technologies. Data sourced from Wikipedia Cadillac Series 62 article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Entry-level Cadillac series (1941-1951, wartime gap 1943-1945). Shorter wheelbase than Series 62. Flathead V8 until 1948, OHV V8 from 1949. Discontinued after 1951. Difficulty modifier 1.15 reflects 1940s vintage complexity, WWII production variations, and postwar transition era. Data sourced from Wikipedia Cadillac Series 61 article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Luxury Fleetwood Series 60 Special (1941-1947, no 1943-1945 production due to WWII). Long wheelbase luxury sedan. Flathead V8 engine. Formal styling with division window optional. Replaced by updated Sixty Special for 1948. Difficulty modifier 1.2 reflects 1940s luxury vehicle complexity, wartime production gap, and specialized trim restoration. Data sourced from Wikipedia Cadillac Sixty Special article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Flagship Series 75 limousine and 7-passenger sedan (1940-1949 portion, series continued to 1976). Longest wheelbase Cadillac. Flathead V8 until 1948, OHV from 1949. Formal limousine coachwork. Commercial chassis available for funeral/ambulance use. Difficulty modifier 1.2 reflects 1940s luxury limousine complexity, WWII production variations, and extended wheelbase service. Data sourced from Wikipedia Cadillac Series 75 article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Full-size luxury car Series 62 with Coupe de Ville as premium hardtop variant. First Coupe de Ville introduced late 1949 with new OHV V8. 331 cu in V8 (160-190 hp, 1950-1955), upgraded to 365 cu in V8 (285-310 hp, 1956-1959). Iconic tailfins. Coupe de Ville production: 2,150 (1949), 4,507 (1950), 10,241 (1951). Brass-era service complexity requires specialized knowledge. 1950s portion only. Data sourced from web research, December 19, 2024.

Ultra-luxury convertible and hardtop, top-of-line Cadillac. 1953 launched with 331 cu in V8 (210 hp). Multiple carburetor setups: dual 4-barrel (1955-1956), tri-power 3x2-barrel (1958-1959). Engine progression: 331 cu in (1953-1955), 365 cu in (1956-1958), 390 cu in (1959). Performance-oriented with premium equipment. Brass-era service complexity requires specialized knowledge. 1950s portion only (1953-1959). Data sourced from web research, December 19, 2024.

Premium luxury sedan on 130 in wheelbase. 1950: 331 cu in V8 (160 hp), 13,755 produced at $3,800. 1953: 12-volt electrical system, 331 cu in V8 upgraded to 210 hp, 20,000 produced at $4,303. Engine upgraded to 365 cu in (285-310 hp) for 1956-1959. Fleetwood luxury appointments with extended wheelbase. Brass-era service complexity requires specialized knowledge. 1950s portion only. Data sourced from web research, December 19, 2024.

Flagship limousine on extended 146.8 in wheelbase (1950+). All-new Series 75 introduced 1950. 331 cu in OHV V8 (160 hp 1950-1951, 190 hp 1952-1955). Upgraded to 365 cu in V8 (285-310 hp) for 1956-1959. Available as 9-passenger sedan or limousine with division window. Hydra-Matic automatic optional early, standard later. Brass-era service complexity requires specialized knowledge. 1950s portion only. Data sourced from web research, December 19, 2024.

Incomplete vehicle chassis produced 1931-1979 for coachbuilders (Eureka, Superior, Miller-Meteor). Heavier-duty frame with lower rear rails for cargo access. Bodywork from dashboard rearward completed by coachbuilders for funeral coaches (hearses), ambulances, and combination vehicles. Same engines as passenger cars: 331 cu in V8 (1950-1955), 365 cu in V8 (1956-1959). Commercial duty and coachbuilt construction require specialized service knowledge. 1950s portion only. Data sourced from Wikipedia and web research, December 19, 2024.

Entry-level full-size luxury car on C-body platform, replaced Series 62. Identical styling and mechanics to more expensive DeVille. 129.5 in wheelbase. 429 cu in V8 (340 hp) for 1965-1967, upgraded to 472 cu in V8 (375 hp) for 1968-1970. Turbo Hydra-Matic became standard 1965. 1960s portion only (1965-1970). Data sourced from web research, December 19, 2024.

Full-size luxury car on C-body platform. Engine progression: 390 cu in V8 (325 hp, 1959-1963), 429 cu in V8 (340 hp, 1964-1967), 472 cu in V8 (375 hp at 4400 rpm, 525 lb-ft torque at 3000 rpm, 1968-1970). Turbo Hydra-Matic transmission standard from 1965. Iconic tailfins in early 1960s. 1960s portion only (1959-1970). Data sourced from Wikipedia and web research, December 19, 2024.

Premium luxury sedan on stretched C-body platform with 133 in wheelbase (longer than other Cadillacs). Brougham option package introduced 1965, became separate model 1966. Standard features: real wood trim, power windows, power ventipanes, power front seat, automatic level control. Brougham added padded vinyl roof, walnut trim, rear writing tables (through 1967), foot rests, reading lamps. 429 cu in V8 (1965-1967), 472 cu in V8 (1968-1970). 1960s portion only (1965-1970). Data sourced from web research, December 19, 2024.

Personal luxury coupe radically redesigned 1967 as Cadillac's first front-wheel drive production car. Adapted Oldsmobile Toronado FWD unified powerplant package. 221 inches long, 4,700 lbs. 0-60 mph under 9 seconds, 120 mph top speed. 429 cu in V8 (340 hp) for 1967, upgraded to 472 cu in V8 (375 hp) for 1968-1970. Platform remained through 1978. 1960s portion only (1967-1970). Data sourced from Wikipedia and web research, December 19, 2024.

Ultra-luxury limousine on extended wheelbase (149.75-156 in). Available as 9-passenger sedan or limousine with division window. Chauffeur compartment upholstered in leather, rear in Bedford cord or wool cloth. Weight approximately 5,500 lbs. Engine progression: 390 cu in V8 (1960-1963), 429 cu in V8 (1964-1967), 472 cu in V8 (1968-1970). Priced $9,533-$9,748 in 1960. Series 75 designation dropped 1977. 1960s portion only (1960-1970). Data sourced from web research, December 19, 2024.

model: Coupe de Ville / Sedan de Ville (C-body)
notes: Full-size luxury car on C-body platform. 1971 featured 7.7L (472 cu in) V8 with 345 hp. Switched to massive 8.2L (500 cu in) V8 for 1975-1976 with dramatically reduced output due to emissions regulations (190-215 hp). Electronic fuel injection optional on 1976 model boosted output to 215 hp. One of the largest production engines ever installed in American automobile. Data sourced from web research, December 19, 2024.

engines: 8.2L V8 (500 cu in, 365 hp SAE gross, 235 hp SAE net, 1971)
notes: Personal luxury coupe on E-body platform with front-wheel drive. Massive 8.2L (500 cu in) V8 exclusive to Eldorado 1971-1976, one of largest production engines ever (400 hp gross in 1970, reduced to 365 hp in 1971, 190 hp by 1976 due to emissions). Optional Bendix EFI boosted 1976 output to 215 hp. Switched to 425 cu in V8 for 1977-1978. Last Eldorado convertible until 1984. 126.3 in wheelbase. Data sourced from Wikipedia and web research, December 19, 2024.

Full-size luxury sedan on downsized C-body platform. 1977 redesign shrank car by 9.8 inches and 750 lbs. 121.5 in wheelbase. 425 cu in (7.0L) V8 was de-bored version of previous 472/500 V8s. Major downsizing effort by GM for improved fuel economy while maintaining luxury. Renamed to just 'Brougham' for 1987. 1970s portion only (1977-1979). Data sourced from Wikipedia and web research, December 19, 2024.

engines: 5.7L Oldsmobile V8 (350 cu in, 180 hp, fuel injection)
5.7L LF9 diesel V8 (350 cu in, 120 hp, 1978-1979)
notes: Compact luxury sedan on K-body platform, Cadillac's first 'international-size' luxury car. Oldsmobile-sourced 350 cu in V8 with Bendix analog port fuel injection and Cadillac-designed intake manifold. Diesel option added 1978 (5.7L, 120 hp). Fuel economy: 15 city/21 highway (gas), 21 city/30 highway (diesel). 114.3 in wheelbase. Diesel option requires specialized service knowledge. Data sourced from Wikipedia and web research, December 19, 2024.

model: Coupe de Ville / Sedan de Ville (Downsized C-body)
notes: Downsized full-size luxury car on C-body platform. 1977 redesign reduced size by 9.8 inches and 750 lbs compared to 1976. 121.5 in wheelbase, 221.2 in length. 425 cu in (7.0L) V8 based on 472 architecture with smaller bore, 100 lbs lighter. Optional electronic multi-port fuel injection (L35) produced 195 hp vs 180 hp carburetor version (L33). 234,171 DeVilles produced in 1977. Major downsizing initiative. Data sourced from Wikipedia and web research, December 19, 2024.

Subcompact city car on GM Gamma II platform. 1.2L Ecotec inline-4 with 5-speed manual or CVT. FWD only. Entry-level Chevrolet, popular for urban commuting. Standard service complexity for modern subcompact. Data sourced from Wikipedia Chevrolet Spark article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Second generation subcompact hatchback on GM Gamma II platform. Upgraded 1.4L Ecotec inline-4 with improved power. 5-speed manual or CVT available. FWD only. Popular budget car, many still in service. Discontinued after 2022 model year in North America. Standard service complexity for modern subcompact. Data sourced from Wikipedia Chevrolet Spark article, December 19, 2024 revision.

First generation standalone Town Car on Ford Panther platform (1981-1989, continued to 1990). Separated from Continental nameplate. 5.0L V8 with electronic fuel injection. RWD only. Body-on-frame construction. AOD 4-speed overdrive automatic from 1984. Available in base, Signature, and Cartier trims. Standard service complexity for 1980s Panther-platform full-size sedan. Data sourced from Wikipedia Lincoln Town Car article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Eighth generation Continental on Ford Fox platform (1982-1987). Dramatically downsized, first FWD Continental. Initially 3.8L V6, optional 5.0L V8 from 1984 (marketed as 'HO' High Output). Digital instrumentation. Available with BMW-sourced diesel briefly (1984-1985, rare). Standard service complexity for 1980s FWD luxury sedan. Data sourced from Wikipedia Lincoln Continental article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Seventh generation Continental on Ford FN9 platform (1988-1994). FWD only. 3.8L V6 engine throughout production. Electronic air suspension standard. Introduced driver airbag 1988 (industry leader). Available in base, Signature, and Executive trim levels. Standard service complexity for late-1980s/early-1990s FWD luxury sedan. Data sourced from Wikipedia Lincoln Continental article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Personal luxury coupe on Ford Fox platform (1984-1992). 5.0L V8 with significant power increases through production. RWD only. LSC (Luxury Sport Coupe) performance variant with upgraded suspension. Electronic air suspension, BMW-sourced diesel option briefly (rare). Last traditional Mark series before Mark VIII. Standard service complexity for 1980s RWD luxury coupe. Data sourced from Wikipedia Lincoln Mark VII article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Second generation Town Car on Ford Panther platform (1990-1997). Introduced modular 4.6L V8 replacing 5.0L. RWD only. Body-on-frame construction. Popular for livery and executive transport. Available in Executive, Signature, and Cartier trim levels. Standard service complexity for Panther-platform full-size sedan. Data sourced from Wikipedia Lincoln Town Car article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Third generation Town Car on Ford Panther platform (1998-2011, covering 1998-2002 here). Continued 4.6L V8, improved output. RWD only. Body-on-frame construction. Very popular for limousine conversions and livery service. Signature, Cartier, and Executive L trim levels. Standard service complexity for Panther-platform full-size sedan. Data sourced from Wikipedia Lincoln Town Car article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Ninth generation Continental on Ford FN10 platform (1995-2002). 4.6L InTech DOHC V8 engine. FWD only. Independent rear suspension. Available in base and Collector's Edition. Discontinued after 2002 model year, later revived 2017. Standard service complexity for FWD luxury sedan. Data sourced from Wikipedia Lincoln Continental article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Personal luxury coupe on Ford FN10 platform (1993-1998). 4.6L InTech DOHC V8 with 280 hp (increased to 290 hp in 1996). RWD only. Independent rear suspension, air suspension optional. Advanced for its time with HID headlights (1996+), side airbags. Last of the Lincoln Mark series. Standard service complexity for RWD luxury coupe. Data sourced from Wikipedia Lincoln Mark VIII article, December 19, 2024 revision.

First generation Navigator on Ford U platform (1998-2002). Body-on-frame construction based on Ford Expedition. 5.4L Triton V8 engine (initially 230 hp, increased to 300 hp for 2001). RWD standard, 4WD optional. Three-row seating. Lincoln's first SUV, highly successful launch. Standard service complexity for body-on-frame full-size luxury SUV. Data sourced from Wikipedia Lincoln Navigator article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Sport luxury sedan on Ford DEW98 platform shared with Jaguar S-Type. RWD only. Base 3.0L V6 or optional 3.9L V8. Rare 5-speed manual available with V6 in early years. Independent rear suspension. Aimed at BMW 3/5 Series market. Discontinued after 2006 model year. Standard service complexity for RWD luxury sedan. Data sourced from Wikipedia Lincoln LS article, December 19, 2024 revision.

First generation midsize luxury SUV (2003-2005). Body-on-frame construction on Ford U152 platform shared with Ford Explorer. 4.6L DOHC V8 engine standard. RWD standard, AWD optional with ControlTrac. Three-row seating, 7-passenger capacity. Independent rear suspension. Discontinued after 2005, revived 2020 as second generation. Standard service complexity for body-on-frame V8 SUV. Data sourced from Wikipedia Lincoln Aviator article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Luxury pickup truck based on Ford F-150 (2002 model year only). 5.4L Triton V8 engine. RWD only (no 4WD option). Power-operated tonneau cover, stainless steel cargo bed. Limited production, only 3,356 units built. Discontinued after single model year due to poor sales. Standard service complexity for F-150-based luxury truck. Data sourced from Wikipedia Lincoln Blackwood article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Luxury pickup truck based on Ford F-150 (2006-2008 in North America). 5.4L Triton V8 engine. RWD standard, 4WD optional. Crew cab only. Updated with 6-speed automatic for 2007. Continued in Mexico through 2014. Discontinued in US/Canada after 2008 due to low sales. Standard service complexity for F-150-based luxury truck. Data sourced from Wikipedia Lincoln Mark LT article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Midsize luxury sedan initially named Zephyr (2006), renamed MKZ for 2007. Based on Ford CD3 platform (Fusion/Milan). 3.0L V6 for 2006, upgraded to 3.5L V6 from 2007. FWD standard, AWD optional. Replaced Lincoln LS. Standard service complexity for modern midsize luxury sedan. Data sourced from Wikipedia Lincoln MKZ article, December 19, 2024 revision.

First generation midsize luxury crossover on Ford CD3 platform (shared with Ford Edge). 3.5L V6 initially, upgraded to 3.7L V6 for 2011. FWD standard, AWD optional. Two-row seating. Replaced by second generation for 2016 (later renamed Nautilus). Standard service complexity for midsize luxury crossover. Data sourced from Wikipedia Lincoln MKX article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Full-size luxury flagship sedan on Ford D3 platform. Base 3.7L V6 or optional 3.5L EcoBoost twin-turbo V6. FWD standard, AWD optional. Replaced Lincoln Town Car as flagship sedan. Discontinued after 2016 model year, succeeded by Continental. Standard service complexity for modern full-size luxury sedan. Data sourced from Wikipedia Lincoln MKS article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Full-size luxury crossover wagon on Ford D4 platform (Flex-based). Base 3.7L V6 or optional 3.5L EcoBoost twin-turbo. FWD standard, AWD optional. Three-row seating. Popular for livery/limousine service. Discontinued after 2019 model year. Standard service complexity for full-size luxury crossover. Data sourced from Wikipedia Lincoln MKT article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Second generation Navigator on U222 platform (Ford Expedition-based). 5.4L Triton V8 engine. Body-on-frame construction. RWD standard, 4WD optional. Regular wheelbase only (no L variant this generation). Three-row seating. Updated styling and interior. Standard service complexity for body-on-frame full-size luxury SUV. Data sourced from Wikipedia Lincoln Navigator article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Third generation Navigator on U326 platform (Ford Expedition-based). Initially 5.4L V8, switched to 3.5L EcoBoost twin-turbo V6 for 2015. Body-on-frame construction. RWD standard, 4WD optional. Regular and extended wheelbase (Navigator L) variants. Three-row seating. 6-speed automatic throughout. Standard service complexity for body-on-frame full-size luxury SUV. Data sourced from Wikipedia Lincoln Navigator article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Second generation midsize luxury sedan on CD4 platform. Multiple powertrains: 2.0L turbo I4, 3.7L V6 (early years), 2.7L twin-turbo V6 (2017+), and 2.0L hybrid. FWD standard, AWD optional (except hybrid). Hybrid uses Atkinson-cycle engine with CVT. Standard service complexity for modern luxury sedan; hybrid variant well-integrated. Data sourced from Wikipedia Lincoln MKZ article, December 19, 2024 revision.

First generation MKX (2016-2018), renamed Nautilus for 2019 model year through 2023. Based on Ford Edge CD4 platform. Standard 3.7L V6 initially, 2.7L twin-turbo V6 standard from 2019. FWD standard, AWD optional. Two-row seating. Renamed to align with Lincoln's naming strategy. Standard service complexity for modern luxury crossover. Data sourced from Wikipedia Lincoln MKX / Nautilus articles, December 19, 2024 revision.

Compact luxury crossover on Ford C2 platform (shared with Ford Escape). Base 2.0L turbo inline-4, optional 2.3L turbo for performance. FWD standard, AWD optional. Replaced by Lincoln Corsair for 2020 model year. Standard service complexity for modern compact luxury crossover. Data sourced from Wikipedia Lincoln MKC article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Tenth generation Continental revival (2017-2020) on CD4 platform. Standard 2.7L twin-turbo V6, optional 3.0L twin-turbo V6 in Black Label trim. FWD standard, AWD optional. Flagship luxury sedan with coach doors available in limited 2019 80th Anniversary Edition (30 units). Discontinued after 2020 model year. Standard service complexity for modern full-size luxury sedan. Data sourced from Wikipedia Lincoln Continental article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Fourth generation Navigator (2018-2021 early years). Complete redesign on T1 platform shared with Ford Expedition. 3.5L EcoBoost twin-turbo V6 with 450 hp. Body-on-frame construction. Standard RWD, optional 4WD. Regular and extended wheelbase (Navigator L) variants. Three-row seating. Adaptive suspension, advanced driver aids. Standard service complexity for modern full-size luxury SUV. Data sourced from Wikipedia Lincoln Navigator article, December 19, 2024 revision.

engines: 3.0L twin-turbo V6 plug-in hybrid (494 hp combined, Grand Touring)
notes: Second generation Aviator introduction (2020-2021). RWD-based CD6 platform shared with Ford Explorer. Standard 3.0L twin-turbo V6; Grand Touring PHEV with 494 hp combined and 13.6 kWh battery. Three-row seating. RWD standard, AWD optional. Difficulty modifier 1.1 for plug-in hybrid HV system and 10-speed complexity. Data sourced from Wikipedia Lincoln Aviator article, December 19, 2024 revision.

engines: 2.3L turbocharged inline-4 (295 hp, 310 lb-ft, Grand Touring)
notes: Compact luxury crossover replacing Lincoln MKC. Based on Ford Escape platform (C2 platform). Standard 2.0L turbo inline-4, optional 2.3L turbo in Grand Touring trim. FWD standard, AWD optional. Three trim levels: Standard, Reserve, Grand Touring. Standard service complexity for modern luxury crossover. Data sourced from Wikipedia Lincoln Corsair article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Second generation midsize luxury crossover (2024 redesign). Based on Ford Edge platform (CD6 platform). Single 2.0L turbocharged inline-4 engine option. FWD standard, AWD optional. Multiple luxury trim levels. Replaces previous MKX nameplate completely. Standard service complexity for modern luxury crossover. Data sourced from Wikipedia Lincoln Nautilus article, December 19, 2024 revision.

engines: 3.0L twin-turbo V6 plug-in hybrid (494 hp combined, Grand Touring)
notes: Second generation midsize luxury SUV (2020-present). RWD-based platform (CD6) shared with Ford Explorer. Standard 3.0L twin-turbo V6 with 400 hp; Grand Touring PHEV variant with 494 hp combined output and 13.6 kWh battery. Three-row seating. RWD standard, AWD optional. Difficulty modifier 1.1 reflects plug-in hybrid variant requiring HV system expertise and 10-speed transmission complexity. Data sourced from Wikipedia Lincoln Aviator article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Fourth generation Navigator with 2022 mid-cycle refresh (L-refresh). Body-on-frame construction on T1 platform shared with Ford Expedition. 3.5L EcoBoost twin-turbo V6 with increased output (440 hp). Standard RWD, optional 4WD. Regular and extended wheelbase (Navigator L) variants. Three-row seating. Standard service complexity for modern full-size luxury SUV. Data sourced from Wikipedia Lincoln Navigator article, December 19, 2024 revision.

First-generation Focus used split-port SOHC engine (110 hp) on base models and Zetec DOHC (130 hp later 136 hp) on upper trims. SVT Focus offered 170 hp Zetec for performance enthusiasts. Timing belt on DOHC engines requires periodic replacement. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford Focus (first generation) article, October 2025 revision.

2005-2007 Focus received updated styling and dropped base SOHC engine. ST sedan replaced SVT with 151 hp 2.3L Duratec and 5-speed manual only. Final years of first-generation before 2008 redesign. Timing belt on DOHC Zetec requires replacement every 120k miles. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford Focus (first generation) article, October 2025 revision.

engines: 2.0L Duratec 20 I4 (140 hp sedan/143 hp coupe)
notes: North American second-generation Focus was a unique design different from European Mk2. Dropped hatchback and wagon variants, offering only coupe and sedan. Weight reduced by 30 lbs, highway fuel economy rated at 35 mpg. Production ended late 2010 with switchover to third-generation in early 2011. Timing chain engine eliminates belt maintenance. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford Focus (second generation, North America) article, October 2025 revision.

First-generation Escape jointly developed with Mazda (Tribute twin). CD2 platform derived from Mazda. 2.0L I4 standard on XLS, 3.0L V6 optional. Manual transmission only available with I4 and FWD. Intelligent 4WD system on AWD models. Timing belt on both engines requires periodic replacement. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford Escape article, October 2025 revision.

Mid-cycle refresh replaced 2.0L with 2.3L Duratec increasing output to 153 hp. Updated exterior styling and interior improvements. Manual transmission available with I4/FWD only. Intelligent 4WD system continues on AWD models. Timing belt maintenance required on both engines. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford Escape article, October 2025 revision.

engines: 2.3L Duratec 23 Atkinson cycle I4 hybrid (153 hp combined with electric motor)
notes: First hybrid SUV in North America. 2.3L Atkinson cycle engine combined with electric motor and 330V NiMH battery pack. eCVT transmission integrates electric motor and generator. Regenerative braking system. HV battery isolation procedures required for service. High-voltage orange cables visible under hood. Difficulty modifier reflects hybrid system complexity and HV safety requirements. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford Escape article, October 2025 revision.

Second-generation Escape launched for 2008 with carry-over engines initially. Retained first-gen powertrain for 2008 only before 2009 upgrades. Updated exterior styling and improved interior. Manual transmission only with I4/FWD configuration. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford Escape article, October 2025 revision.

Major powertrain update for 2009. I4 displacement increased from 2.3L to 2.5L (+18 hp to 171 hp). V6 output jumped from 200 hp to 240 hp. Manual transmission discontinued, 6-speed automatic became standard across all trims. Improved fuel economy and performance. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford Escape article, October 2025 revision.

engines: 2.5L Duratec 25 Atkinson cycle I4 hybrid (175 hp combined, 2009+)
notes: Second-generation Escape Hybrid continued with updated hybrid system. 2009 displacement increased to 2.5L with electric motor for 175 hp combined output. 330V NiMH battery pack with eCVT. Regenerative braking and electric-only mode at low speeds. HV isolation and orange cables require certified hybrid technician training. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford Escape article, October 2025 revision.

Ground-up redesign on new rear-drive platform, ending Ranger commonality. First Explorer with independent rear suspension and optional third-row seating (7-passenger capacity). Manual transmission final year 2002, 5-speed automatic standard 2003+. Timing chain on both engines. Control Trac 4WD system on AWD models. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford Explorer article, October 2025 revision.

engines: 4.6L Modular SOHC V8 (292 hp, 3-valve with VCT)
notes: Fourth-generation Explorer launched mid-2005 for 2006 model year. 4.6L V8 featured 3-valve heads with variable cam timing (300 lb-ft torque). V6 retained 5-speed auto, V8 received new 6-speed automatic. Electronically controlled 4WD optional. Independent rear suspension continued. Timing chain on both engines eliminates belt maintenance. Production ended December 2010. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford Explorer article, October 2025 revision.

Sport Trac combined Explorer SUV front with integrated pickup bed. Shared UN105 platform with second-generation Explorer. Only engine option was 4.0L SOHC V6 with 210 hp. Manual transmission standard through 2003, dropped for 2004-2005. 5-speed automatic optional then standard. Control Trac 4WD system available. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford Explorer Sport Trac article, October 2025 revision.

Second-generation Sport Trac skipped 2006 model year. First V8 option with 292 hp 4.6L from F-150. 4.0L V6 standard with 5-speed auto. V8 initially received 5-speed, upgraded to 6-speed (6R80) for 2009. Independent rear suspension. Manual transmission no longer offered. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford Explorer Sport Trac article, October 2025 revision.

engines: 5.4L Triton SOHC V8 (300 hp, 24-valve with VVT, 2005-2006)
notes: Second-generation Expedition launched May 2002 for 2003 model year. First full-size SUV with fully independent suspension. Base 4.6L V8 dropped for 2005, making 5.4L V8 standard. 2005+ 5.4L featured 24-valve heads and variable valve timing (300 hp, 365 lb-ft). 4R75E 4-speed automatic with Smart Shift technology. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford Expedition article, October 2025 revision.

engines: 5.4L Triton SOHC V8 (310 hp, 2009, FlexFuel E85 capable)
notes: Third-generation Expedition on new T1 ladder frame with improved torsional rigidity. 5.4L Triton V8 sole engine, upgraded to 310 hp and E85 FlexFuel for 2009. New 6-speed automatic (6R75 2007-2008, stronger 6R80 2009+ with tow/haul mode). Four-wheel independent suspension. AdvanceTrac stability control standard. Timing chain engine. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford Expedition article, October 2025 revision.

engines: 4.6L Modular DOHC V8 (320-390 hp, SVT Cobra/Cobra R)
notes: Fourth-generation SN95 New Edge styling (1999-2004). Base V6 produced 190-193 hp from 3.8L Essex. GT used 4.6L SOHC 2-valve V8 (260 hp). SVT Cobra featured 4.6L DOHC 4-valve (320 hp naturally aspirated, 390 hp supercharged 2003-2004). 2003-2004 Mach 1 offered 305 hp DOHC variant. Fox platform final evolution. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford Mustang (fourth generation) article, October 2025 revision.

engines: 4.6L Modular SOHC V8 (300 hp, GT, 3-valve with VCT)
5.4L Modular DOHC supercharged V8 (500-550 hp, Shelby GT500)
transmissions: 5-speed manual (T-5 V6, TR-3650 GT, T-56 Shelby)
notes: Fifth-generation S197 retro-inspired design launched 2005. Base 4.0L V6 produced 210 hp. GT featured all-aluminum 4.6L 3-valve SOHC V8 with variable cam timing (300 hp, 320 lb-ft). Shelby GT500 returned 2007 with 5.4L supercharged DOHC V8 (500 hp initial, 540-550 hp later). New D2C platform based on DEW98. Timing chain on all engines. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford Mustang (fifth generation) article, October 2025 revision.

Fourth-generation Taurus (2000-2007) on DN5 platform. Base 3.0L Vulcan OHV V6 standard on LX/SE/SES (155 hp). Optional 3.0L Duratec DOHC V6 on SES/SEL (200 hp, increased to 201 hp for 2004). Wagon discontinued after 2005. AX4S transmission phased out October 2002, replaced by AX4N. Timing chain on Duratec, timing belt on Vulcan. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford Taurus (fourth generation) article, October 2025 revision.

transmissions: CVT (Continuously Variable Transmission, FWD and AWD)
notes: Five Hundred full-size sedan on D3 platform (revised Volvo P2). Single engine option: 3.0L Duratec 30 V6 (203 hp, 207 lb-ft). CVT standard on FWD SE and all AWD models. Aisin 6-speed automatic on FWD SEL/Limited. 61.5-inch height over 5 inches taller than contemporary Taurus. Renamed Taurus for 2008. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford Five Hundred article, October 2025 revision.

First-generation Fusion on CD3 platform (Mazda6-derived, stretched 30mm width, 55mm length). Base 2.3L Duratec I4 (160 hp) with Mazda 5-speed manual or automatic. Optional 3.0L V6 (221 hp) with Aisin 6-speed automatic and available AWD. Sold October 2005 through 2009 model year. Timing chain on both engines. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford Fusion (Americas) article, October 2025 revision.

First-generation Edge on CD3 platform shared with Fusion, Mazda6, Mazda CX-9. Standard 3.5L Duratec 35 V6 (265 hp, 250 lb-ft). 6-speed automatic (6F50) standard across all trims. FWD standard, AWD optional. Debuted January 2006 at Detroit Auto Show, production started late 2006 for 2007 model year. Timing chain engine. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford Edge article, October 2025 revision.

Flex launched 2009 on D4 platform (re-engineered D3 for multiple wheelbases). Standard 3.5L Duratec V6 (262 hp, 248 lb-ft). 6-speed automatic co-developed with GM. FWD standard, AWD optional. Boxy retro-modern styling. EcoBoost 3.5L turbo not available until 2010. Timing chain engine. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford Flex article, October 2025 revision.

engines: 3.9L Essex OHV V6 (193 hp, standard US)
4.2L Essex OHV V6 (201 hp, Canada/export, optional US)
notes: Freestar replaced Windstar minivan for 2004-2007. Standard 3.9L Essex V6 (193 hp, 240 lb-ft) shared with Mustang. Optional/Canada standard 4.2L V6 (201 hp, 263 lb-ft) from E-150. 4-speed automatic with improved shifting and reliability. Production ended November 2006, sold through 2007 model year. Timing chain engines. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford Freestar article, October 2025 revision.

Freestyle crossover wagon on D3 platform (related to Five Hundred sedan). Single 3.0L Duratec 30 V6 (203 hp). CVT standard on all FWD and AWD models. Three-row seating for 6-7 passengers. Renamed Taurus X for 2008 with 3.5L V6 and 6-speed automatic. CVT shared with AWD Five Hundred. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford Freestyle article, October 2025 revision.

engines: 4.6L Modular SOHC V8 (250 hp, Police Interceptor 2004-2011)
notes: Crown Victoria on Panther platform (body-on-frame RWD shared with Grand Marquis, Town Car). 4.6L Modular V8 received power increase to 224 hp (239 hp dual exhaust) for 2003 with engine knock sensor. Police Interceptor rated 250 hp 2004-2011. FlexFuel E85 capable from 2008. Panther platform re-engineered 2003. Timing chain engine. Production ended September 2011. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford Crown Victoria article, October 2025 revision.

Third-generation Ranger (1998-2012, 2000s coverage). 2.3L Duratec I4 replaced 2.5L in late 2001 (143 hp). 3.0L Vulcan V6 base V6 (150 hp). 4.0L SOHC V6 top option (207 hp). Multiple facelifts 2001, 2004, 2006. Manual transmission standard, automatic optional. Timing belt on 3.0L and early 4.0L, timing chain on 2.3L and later 4.0L SOHC. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford Ranger (Americas) article, October 2025 revision.

body_styles: 4-door crew cab pickup (F-250, F-350, F-450, F-550)
notes: First-generation Super Duty launched 1999 on dedicated heavy-duty platform. 7.3L Power Stroke diesel (235 hp/500 lb-ft initial, 250-275 hp later) through mid-2003. Replaced by 6.0L Power Stroke (325 hp, 560-570 lb-ft) mid-2003 through 2007. Gasoline options: 5.4L V8, 6.8L V10. Manual and automatic transmissions. Diesel maintenance complexity and emissions systems warrant difficulty modifier. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford Super Duty article, October 2025 revision.

engines: 6.4L Power Stroke turbodiesel V8 (350 hp, 650 lb-ft)
body_styles: 4-door crew cab pickup (F-250, F-350, F-450, F-550)
notes: Second-generation Super Duty launched 2008 (delayed from 2007). All-new 6.4L Power Stroke twin-turbo diesel V8 (350 hp, 650 lb-ft) with DPF diesel particulate filter. Gasoline: 5.4L V8 (300 hp), 6.8L V10 (362 hp). 6-speed manual or 5-speed TorqShift automatic. DPF regeneration and diesel emissions complexity justify difficulty modifier. Production 2008-2010. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford Super Duty article, October 2025 revision.

engines: 3.9L Jaguar AJ-35 DOHC V8 (280 hp, 2003-2005, with VVT)
notes: Eleventh-generation Thunderbird revival on DEW platform (shared with Lincoln LS, Jaguar S-Type). 2002 used 3.9L Jaguar AJ-30 V8 (252 hp). 2003-2005 upgraded to 280 hp with intake-side VVT, higher compression (10.8:1), electronic throttle. 5-speed automatic with SelectShift manual mode. Two-seater convertible with removable hardtop. Production ended July 2005. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford Thunderbird (eleventh generation) article, October 2025 revision.

engines: 6.8L Triton SOHC V10 (310 hp, 425 lb-ft, gasoline)
6.0L Power Stroke turbodiesel V8 (325 hp, 560 lb-ft, 2003-2005)
notes: Excursion full-size SUV derived from F-250 Super Duty 3/4-ton platform (2000-2005). Gasoline: 5.4L V8 (255 hp), 6.8L V10 (310 hp, 425 lb-ft). Diesel: 7.3L Power Stroke (2000-2003), 6.0L Power Stroke (325 hp, 560 lb-ft, 2003-2005). Max towing 11,000 lbs with V10/diesel. Diesel complexity and emissions warrant difficulty modifier. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford Excursion article, October 2025 revision.

Fourth-generation E-Series (1992-2014, 2000s coverage). Triton engine lineup: 4.2L V6, 4.6L V8, 5.4L V8, 6.8L V10. 7.3L Power Stroke diesel through 2003. No manual transmission after 1989. Available as cargo van (E-150, E-250, E-350), passenger wagon, cutaway chassis. Commercial duty cycle and diesel option justify difficulty modifier. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford E-Series article, October 2025 revision.

engines: 1.6L EcoBoost Ti-VCT turbo I4 (180 hp, ST model)
notes: PowerShift dual-clutch transmission requires specialized service knowledge and has known reliability concerns. Manufactured at Cuautitl�n Assembly Plant in Mexico. EcoBoost turbocharged engines require synthetic oil and premium fuel recommended for ST variant. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford Fiesta (sixth generation) article, 2021 revision.

engines: 2.0L EcoBoost turbo I4 (252 hp, ST model)
2.3L EcoBoost turbo I4 (350 hp, RS model)
notes: RS model features all-wheel drive with torque vectoring. PowerShift dual-clutch transmission requires specialized service knowledge and has known reliability concerns. ST and RS performance variants require synthetic oil and high-performance brake service. First Ford vehicle designed under CEO Alan Mulally's 'One Ford' global platform strategy. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford Focus (third generation) article, revision date not specified.

engines: Electric motor (143 hp, 107 kW synchronous motor)
notes: Electric vehicle with 23 kWh lithium-ion battery (2012-2016) or 33.5 kWh battery (2017-2018) requires EV-certified technicians for high-voltage system service. EPA range 76 miles (initial) or 115 miles (2017+). Platform originally designed for piston engines with battery packaged in trunk area affecting cargo space. Manufactured at Michigan Assembly Plant. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford Focus Electric article, May 31, 2025 revision.

engines: 2.0L EcoBoost turbo I4 (240 hp, FWD only)
3.7L Cyclone Ti-VCT FFV V6 (Police Interceptor Utility, AWD only)
notes: Fifth generation transitions from body-on-frame to unibody construction on Ford D4 platform (modified D3). Twin-turbo EcoBoost V6 requires premium fuel and synthetic oil. Police Interceptor Utility variant features heavy-duty cooling and electrical systems. Assembled at Chicago Assembly Plant. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford Explorer article, revision date not specified.

Built on Ford C1 platform (Global C platform). EcoBoost turbocharged engines require synthetic oil and 87 octane minimum fuel. Third generation replaces Escape Hybrid with focus on turbocharged gasoline engines only. Dual-clutch transmission option requires specialized service procedures. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford Escape article, revision date not specified.

Revolutionary aluminum-intensive body construction reduces weight by approximately 750 lbs compared to predecessor. First aluminum-bodied vehicle in large-scale production. Power Stroke diesel V6 requires diesel-specific oil and fuel system service. EcoBoost engines require synthetic oil and premium fuel recommended. 10-speed automatic transmission requires specialized diagnostic equipment. Aluminum body repair requires specialized training and equipment. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford F-Series (thirteenth generation) article, September 23, 2025 revision.

engines: 5.2L Voodoo flat-plane V8 (526 hp, GT350 model)
notes: Built on Ford D2C platform (S550 code). GT350 features high-revving 5.2L flat-plane crank V8 requiring specialized service knowledge and synthetic oil. All engines require premium fuel recommended. Independent rear suspension replaces live axle. Performance variants require high-performance brake and cooling system service. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford Mustang (sixth generation) article, revision date not specified.

engines: 6.7L Power Stroke V8 diesel (440 hp, 925 lb-ft 2017; 450 hp, 935 lb-ft 2018-2019)
6.8L Triton V10 gasoline (288 hp, 424 lb-ft, F-450/F-550 chassis cab)
body_styles: SuperCab extended cab heavy-duty pickup truck
notes: Aluminum alloy body (6000-series military-grade) with 95% high-strength steel frame saves up to 350 lbs. Power Stroke diesel requires specialized diesel service including high-pressure fuel system and diesel exhaust fluid (DEF) system. Heavy-duty models (F-450/F-550/F-600) may feature air brakes requiring CDL certification. Built on Ford T3 platform. Chassis cab configurations require commercial vehicle service expertise. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford Super Duty article, revision date not specified.

First Transit generation offered in North America, replacing E-Series. Available in multiple wheelbases (129.9 in regular, 147.6 in long) and three roof heights. Designated as T-150/T-250/T-350/T-350HD based on payload capacity. Power Stroke diesel inline-5 requires diesel-specific service and DEF system. Commercial van configurations require specialized service knowledge. Rear-wheel drive layout differs from front-drive Transit Connect. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford Transit article, revision date not specified.

body_styles: SuperCab extended cab mid-size pickup truck
SuperCrew crew cab mid-size pickup truck
notes: Returns to North American market after 8-year absence. Developed from global Ranger T6 platform with modifications to frame and bumpers for North American standards. First Ranger offered with four full doors in United States and Canada. No manual transmission or V6 option offered unlike previous generations. Manufactured at Michigan Assembly Plant. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford Ranger (Americas) article, revision date not specified.

body_styles: 2-door mid-engine supercar coupe with butterfly doors
notes: Carbon fiber monocoque with aluminum front and rear subframes and carbon fiber body panels. Rear mid-engine configuration requires specialized service procedures. Limited production supercar with exotic materials and construction methods demands specialist technician expertise. Seven-speed dual-clutch transmission requires specialized diagnostic equipment. Butterfly doors and aerodynamic active elements require careful service protocols. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford GT article, revision 1313551951.

Built on Ford CD4 platform (Global C/D platform). EcoBoost turbocharged engines require synthetic oil and premium fuel recommended for twin-turbo 2.7L V6. Sport trim with 2.7L engine features performance-tuned suspension and steering. Note that diesel variants (2.0L Duratorq/EcoBlue) were offered in European markets only, not North America. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford Edge article, revision date not specified.

engines: 3.5L EcoBoost twin-turbo V6 (355 hp 2010-2012, 365 hp 2013-2019, AWD only)
notes: Built on Ford D4 platform (variant of D3). Distinctive boxy design with horizontal door grooves evoking classic woody wagon styling. EcoBoost twin-turbo V6 available only with all-wheel drive and requires synthetic oil and premium fuel recommended. Full-size crossover with three-row seating capacity. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford Flex article, September 30, 2025 revision.

engines: 3.5L EcoBoost twin-turbo V6 (365 hp, SHO model)
3.7L Cyclone Ti-VCT V6 (305 hp, Police Interceptor, AWD only)
notes: Built on Ford D3 platform. Taurus SHO performance variant features twin-turbo EcoBoost V6 with all-wheel drive standard, requiring synthetic oil and premium fuel. Police Interceptor Sedan variant features heavy-duty cooling, electrical systems, and AWD standard. Final generation before Taurus discontinuation in 2019. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford Taurus (sixth generation) article, September 20, 2025 revision.

Built on Ford CD4 platform (Global C/D platform). Fusion Sport with 2.7L EcoBoost twin-turbo V6 features all-wheel drive and requires premium fuel and synthetic oil. EcoBoost turbocharged engines require synthetic oil. Note: Hybrid and Energi plug-in hybrid variants are tracked separately. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford Fusion (Americas) article, revision date not specified.

engines: 2.0L Duratec Atkinson-cycle I4 hybrid (141 hp engine, 188 hp total system)
notes: Full hybrid system with 2.0L Atkinson-cycle engine paired with electric motor and lithium-ion battery. eCVT requires specialized hybrid service knowledge. High-voltage battery system requires certified hybrid technicians. Regenerative braking system requires specialized brake service procedures. Built on Ford CD4 platform. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford Fusion (Americas) article, revision date not specified.

engines: 2.0L Duratec Atkinson-cycle I4 plug-in hybrid (141 hp engine, 188 hp total system)
notes: Plug-in hybrid electric vehicle (PHEV) with 2.0L Atkinson-cycle engine and larger battery pack than Fusion Hybrid. Features 7.6 kWh lithium-ion battery with external charging capability and all-electric driving mode. High-voltage system requires certified EV/hybrid technicians. eCVT and regenerative braking require specialized service knowledge. Charging system and EVSE (Electric Vehicle Supply Equipment) require additional diagnostic capabilities. Built on Ford CD4 platform. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford Fusion (Americas) article, revision date not specified.

engines: 2.0L Atkinson-cycle I4 hybrid (141 hp engine, 188 hp total system with 88 kW electric motor)
notes: Full hybrid system with 2.0L Atkinson-cycle engine paired with 88 kW electric motor and 1.4 kWh lithium-ion battery. Top electric-only speed of 65 mph with overall top speed of 115 mph. High-voltage hybrid system requires certified hybrid technicians. eCVT and regenerative braking require specialized service knowledge. Assembled at Wayne, Michigan. Discontinued in U.S. market late 2017. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford C-Max article, revision date not specified.

engines: 2.0L Atkinson-cycle I4 plug-in hybrid (141 hp engine, 195 hp total system in charge-depleting mode)
notes: Plug-in hybrid electric vehicle (PHEV) with 2.0L Atkinson-cycle engine and 7.6 kWh lithium-ion battery providing 20-mile all-electric range. Features external charging capability and charge-depleting/charge-sustaining modes. High-voltage system requires certified EV/hybrid technicians. eCVT and regenerative braking require specialized service knowledge. Charging system diagnostics require additional equipment and training. Assembled at Wayne, Michigan. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford C-Max article, revision date not specified.

Built on Ford Global C-car platform (C2 platform). Compact commercial van with optional CNG/LPG conversion hardware available for 2.5L engine for fleet applications.
