Passenger wagon variant available with 5 or 7 passenger seating. Diesel engine plans for North America were abandoned in July 2019. Note: Diesel variants (1.5L Duratorq/EcoBlue) offered in other markets only, not North America. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford Transit Connect article, revision date not specified.

engines: 3.0L Power Stroke Turbo Diesel V6 (250 hp)
notes: Fourteenth generation F-150 introduced for 2021 model year. Hybrid system pairs electric motor with 3.5L EcoBoost V6. Regular Cab discontinued for consumer models after 2021. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford F-Series article, October 11, 2025 revision.

engines: Dual Permanent Magnet Electric Motors (452 hp standard battery)
Dual Permanent Magnet Electric Motors (580 hp extended battery)
notes: Battery electric version of F-150 with up to 320 mile range. High-voltage system (400V/800V switchable) demands EV-certified technicians. Only available in SuperCrew body style. Production began 2022 model year. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford F-150 Lightning article, October 11, 2025 revision.

High-performance off-road variant of F-150 with specialized suspension and 37-inch tires. Features advanced traction control systems. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford F-Series article, October 11, 2025 revision.

Compact pickup truck on C2 platform. Hybrid variant uses parallel hybrid system with 1.1kWh lithium-ion battery. AWD only available with EcoBoost engine until 2025 refresh. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford Maverick (2022) article, October 11, 2025 revision.

Mid-size SUV with removable top and doors. Features G.O.A.T. (Goes Over Any Type) terrain management system with multiple drive modes. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford Bronco article, October 11, 2025 revision.

Compact crossover SUV on Ford C2 platform. AWD system with selectable terrain modes. Badlands trim features rear differential locker. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford Bronco Sport article, October 11, 2025 revision.

engines: Extended Range Battery (286 hp rear motor, 346 hp all-wheel drive)
notes: Battery electric crossover SUV. Uses 68-98 kWh battery packs. GT variant features dual electric motors producing 480 hp. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford Mustang Mach-E article, October 11, 2025 revision.
Mid-size SUV on Ford CD6 platform. Hybrid variant uses 3.3L V6 with electric motor. ST performance variant uses 3.0L V6. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford Explorer article, October 11, 2025 revision.

Fourth generation compact crossover SUV on Ford C2 platform. Introduced as 2020 model year. Hybrid variant uses 2.5L Atkinson-cycle I4 with electric motor. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford Escape article, October 11, 2025 revision.
Mid-size crossover SUV on Ford CD5 platform. AWD system standard on higher trims. Discontinued after 2024 model year. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford Edge article, October 11, 2025 revision.
Full-size SUV on Ford T3 platform. Features advanced towing capabilities up to 9,300 lbs. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford Expedition article, October 11, 2025 revision.

engines: 5.2L V8 Flat Plane Crank (500 hp - Shelby GT500)
notes: Sports car with both S550 (2015-2023) and S650 (2024-present) generations in 2020s. GT500 variant features supercharged V8. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford Mustang article, October 11, 2025 revision.

engines: 3.0L Power Stroke Turbo Diesel I6 (210 hp)
notes: Mid-size pickup truck based on T6 platform. Diesel variant uses 3.0L I6 turbo diesel engine. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford Ranger (T6) article, October 11, 2025 revision.

engines: 3.7L Power Stroke Turbo Diesel I6 (190 hp)
notes: Commercial van series with multiple configurations. Third generation with 2020 facelift. Diesel variant uses 3.7L I6 turbo diesel. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford Transit article, October 11, 2025 revision.

First-generation Explorer launched as replacement for Bronco II. Based on Ranger platform with independent front suspension. Uses timing chain (4.0L V6). Early 4R55E transmissions (1995+) prone to failure. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford Explorer article, October 2025 revision.

Second generation introduced SOHC V6 with timing chains. Optional 5.0L V8 available. Firestone tire recall in 2000-2001 affected safety reputation. Control Trac 4WD system standard on 4x4 models. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford Explorer article, October 2025 revision.

SN95 generation represents major redesign on Fox platform. Introduced modular V8 (4.6L) in 1996. Cobra models feature DOHC V8 with timing chains. All engines use timing chains except 3.8L V6. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford Mustang (fourth generation) article, October 2025 revision.

Final generation full-size Bronco on F-Series truck platform. All engines use timing chains. E4OD transmission standard with electronic controls. Production ended 1996 after O.J. Simpson chase. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford Bronco article, October 2025 revision.

Tenth generation introduced modular Triton V8 engines replacing Windsor V8s. All Triton engines use timing chains. First generation with 4-door SuperCrew cab (1999). Built on new P2 platform. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford F-Series (tenth generation) article, October 2025 revision.

First generation full-size SUV based on F-150 platform. Replaced Bronco as Ford's full-size SUV. All Triton V8 engines use timing chains. Independent rear suspension available. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford Expedition article, October 2025 revision.

Second generation Taurus with rounded aerodynamic styling. SHO models feature Yamaha-developed DOHC V6 with timing belt. Standard engines use timing chains. AXOD/AX4S transmissions known for reliability issues. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford Taurus article, October 2025 revision.

Third generation with controversial oval styling. SHO model upgraded to Yamaha V8 (timing belt). Duratec V6 uses timing chains. Criticized for interior ergonomics. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford Taurus article, October 2025 revision.

First Ford minivan designed from ground up. Replaced Aerostar. All engines use timing chains. AX4S transmission known for premature failure. Head gasket issues common on 3.8L Essex V6. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford Windstar article, October 2025 revision.

North American version of Ford Mondeo on CDW27 platform. All engines use timing belts requiring replacement at 60k-100k miles. SVT model features sport-tuned suspension. CD4E transmission prone to failure. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford Contour article, October 2025 revision.

Second generation Crown Victoria on Panther platform. Body-on-frame construction. 4.6L Modular V8 uses timing chains. Popular for police, taxi, and fleet use. Known for durability and simple maintenance. NOTE: Overlaps with 2000s entry - decade coverage split. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford Crown Victoria article, October 2025 revision.

Third generation compact pickup with updated styling. Shares platform with Explorer. All engines use timing chains. Available with splash side graphics package. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford Ranger (Americas) article, October 2025 revision.

Major facelift for third generation with updated front end. Introduced 4.0L SOHC V6 with timing chains. Edge and FX4 off-road packages available. NOTE: Overlaps with 2000s - decade coverage split. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford Ranger (Americas) article, October 2025 revision.

Fifth generation redesign on Mazda 323 platform (BG). 1.9L CVH engine uses timing belt. GT model features Mazda BP engine with DOHC and timing belt. Replaced Escort EXP with more conventional styling. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford Escort (North America) article, October 2025 revision.

Sixth generation with redesigned bodywork. 2.0L Zetec I4 uses timing belt requiring replacement every 100k miles. ZX2 sport coupe variant available. NOTE: Overlaps with 2000s - decade coverage split. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford Escort (North America) article, October 2025 revision.

Compact van based on Ranger platform. First Ford minivan with rear-wheel drive layout. All engines use timing chains. AWD system available (first minivan with AWD). Replaced by Windstar in 1995 but continued through 1997. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford Aerostar article, October 2025 revision.

Fifth generation full-size van. Diesel engines (7.3L, 6.0L, 6.4L Power Stroke) require specialized service knowledge - difficulty modifier 1.2. 6.0L known for reliability issues. 6.8L V10 uses timing chains. Popular for commercial and fleet use. NOTE: Overlaps multiple decades. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford E-Series article, October 2025 revision.

First year of Super Duty line replacing F-250/F-350 heavy-duty models. 7.3L Power Stroke diesel highly regarded for reliability but requires diesel service knowledge - difficulty modifier 1.2. Available in F-250, F-350, F-450, F-550 configurations. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford Super Duty article, October 2025 revision.

Tenth generation on MN12 platform with aerodynamic styling. Super Coupe features supercharged 3.8L V6 (210 hp). All engines use timing chains. Shared platform with Mercury Cougar. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford Thunderbird article, October 2025 revision.
NOTE: Explorer Sport Trac not officially launched until 2001. Removing this entry as it doesn't apply to 1990s production vehicles. Placeholder for reference only.

First generation Ford Escort on CE14 platform. Diesel option (2.0L Mazda RF) available 1984-1987 requires diesel service knowledge (difficulty_modifier 1.1). Turbocharged CVH engine in GT models requires boost system maintenance. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford Escort (North America) article, January 2025 revision.

First generation Ford Escort on CE14 platform with updated 1.9L engine introduced mid-1985. Diesel option (2.0L Mazda RF) available through 1987 requires diesel service knowledge (difficulty_modifier 1.1). Central Fuel Injection system introduced 1987. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford Escort (North America) article, January 2025 revision.

First generation compact pickup on body-on-frame platform with Twin I-Beam front suspension. SuperCab extended cab introduced 1986. Diesel options include 2.2L Perkins (1983-1984) and 2.3L Mitsubishi turbo diesel (1985-1987), requiring diesel service knowledge (difficulty_modifier 1.1). Available in 6-foot and 7-foot bed lengths. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford Ranger (North America) article, January 2025 revision.

Ninth generation aerodynamic Thunderbird on Fox platform. Turbo Coupe model features 2.3L turbocharged engine with intercooler added in 1987 (190 hp). First Thunderbird with 5-speed manual transmission option. Significant refresh in 1987 with new aerodynamic sheet metal and composite headlamps. Special editions include Elan (1984) and 30th Anniversary (1985). Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford Thunderbird article, January 2025 revision.

First generation Taurus on DN5 platform with revolutionary aerodynamic 'jelly bean' design. Launched 1985 as 1986 model, replacing Ford LTD mid-size car. HSC I4 engine available with 5-speed manual or 3-speed automatic. 3.8L Essex V6 added in 1988 as optional upgrade. Wheelbase 106.0 inches. Trim levels: MT-5 (manual), L (base), GL, and LX. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford Taurus (first generation) article, January 2025 revision.

Compact sedan and coupe sharing components with Ford Escort but with 5.7-inch longer wheelbase. Optional AWD introduced 1987. Diesel option (2.0L Mazda RF) available 1984-1986 paired only with 5-speed manual, requires diesel service knowledge (difficulty_modifier 1.1). Mercury twin badged as Topaz. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford Tempo article, January 2025 revision.

First generation minivan on VN1 platform with 118.9-inch wheelbase. Marketed as 'first minivan powered exclusively by V6 engines' though 2.3L I4 available 1986-1987. 2.8L V6 only available first few months of 1986, 3.0L Vulcan became sole engine in 1988. Designed with focus on garageability and towing capacity. Trim levels: XL and XLT. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford Aerostar article, January 2025 revision.

Compact SUV derived from Ford Ranger platform with 94.0-inch wheelbase. 1984-1985 models exclusively four-wheel drive with carbureted 2.8L V6. Three-door wagon body style only. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford Bronco II article, January 2025 revision.

Compact SUV derived from Ford Ranger platform with 94.0-inch wheelbase. 1986+ models available with RWD or 4WD. Optional 2.3L Mitsubishi turbodiesel (1986-1987) had poor performance and low sales, requires diesel service knowledge (difficulty_modifier 1.1). Upgraded to fuel-injected 2.9L V6 in 1986. Three-door wagon body style only. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford Bronco II article, January 2025 revision.

Seventh generation full-size pickup. SuperCab returned in 1980, four-door crew cab introduced 1982. 3.8L V6 standard in 1982 (phased out 1983), 4.2L V8 phased out by 1982. 6.9L diesel V8 available for F-250/F-350 starting 1983, requires diesel service knowledge (difficulty_modifier 1.1). Final generation with 3-speed manual transmission. 5.0L V8 gained fuel injection in 1986. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford F-Series article, January 2025 revision.

Eighth generation full-size pickup. 4.9L inline-six gained fuel injection in 1987. 5.8L V8 fuel injected starting 1988. Diesel engine upgraded from 6.9L to 7.3L, requires diesel service knowledge (difficulty_modifier 1.1). E4OD 4-speed automatic introduced 1989 for heavy-duty applications. All gasoline engines feature fuel injection. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford F-Series article, January 2025 revision.

Third generation Fox body Mustang (1979-1993). Convertible returned in 1983 after decade-long hiatus. 2.3L turbocharged engine gained fuel injection in 1983. 4.2L V8 (255 cu in) available 1980-1981 only. 5.0L V8 evolved from carbureted to Central Fuel Injection to Sequential Electronic Fuel Injection with power ranging from 139 hp to 225 hp. 3.8L Essex V6 introduced 1983. Various performance packages including GT. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford Mustang (third generation) article, January 2025 revision.

Fifth generation full-size Bronco based on F-Series platform. Four-wheel drive standard with New Process 208 transfer case. Dana 44 front axle with Twin Traction Beam suspension. Ford 9-inch rear axle transitioning to 8.8 rear axle by 1986. Hardtop configuration with sliding window glass option prior to 1984. Trim levels: Bronco (base), Bronco XL, Bronco XLT. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford Bronco article, January 2025 revision.

Third generation Econoline full-size van with Twin-I-Beam front suspension and live rear axle with leaf springs. Available as cargo van, passenger van (Club Wagon), and cutaway chassis. Multiple engine options including large-displacement V8s for commercial applications. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford E-Series article, January 2025 revision.

Third generation Econoline full-size van with Twin-I-Beam front suspension and live rear axle with leaf springs. 6.9L International IDI diesel V8 introduced 1983 for E-350 models only, requires diesel service knowledge (difficulty_modifier 1.1). Available as cargo van, passenger van (Club Wagon), and cutaway chassis. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford E-Series article, January 2025 revision.

Third generation Econoline full-size van with Twin-I-Beam front suspension and live rear axle with leaf springs. Diesel engine enlarged from 6.9L to 7.3L International IDI V8 in 1988, available for E-350 models only, requires diesel service knowledge (difficulty_modifier 1.1). Available as cargo van, passenger van (Club Wagon), and cutaway chassis. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford E-Series article, January 2025 revision.

Full-size sedan and wagon on rear-wheel drive Panther platform. Became stand-alone model line in 1983 after being premium trim of Ford LTD. 5.0L V8 upgraded to Sequential-Fire multiport fuel injection in 1986 (150 hp). Trim levels include Standard, LX (introduced 1986), and S (fleet/police oriented). Station wagon available with optional woodgrain trim. Police Package available with heavy-duty specifications. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford LTD Crown Victoria article, January 2025 revision.

First production years of iconic Model T. Introduced October 1908. Planetary transmission operated by three foot pedals. Vanadium steel construction. Hand-crank starting. Brass radiator and fixtures. Requires specialized brass-era expertise and extremely rare parts. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford Model T article, January 2025 revision.

Ford Motor Company's first production vehicle. Horizontal opposed twin-cylinder engine mounted under seat. Chain drive. Tiller steering initially, steering wheel added later. Extremely rare brass-era vehicle requiring highly specialized restoration expertise. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford Model A (1903–04) article, January 2025 revision.

Low-priced runabout that preceded Model T. Four-cylinder engine front-mounted. Planetary transmission. Sold for $500, making it affordable for middle class. Brass-era vehicle requiring specialized vintage expertise. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford Model N article, January 2025 revision.

Ford's first six-cylinder model and most expensive early offering at $2,500. Large luxury car competing with upscale brands. Commercial failure that convinced Henry Ford to focus on affordable vehicles. Brass-era complexity requires highly specialized knowledge. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford Model K article, January 2025 revision.

Revolutionary mass-produced vehicle using assembly line manufacturing. Planetary transmission with three foot pedals. Magneto ignition. Brass radiator (early years). Requires specialized brass-era expertise, period-specific parts, and hand-crank starting knowledge. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford Model T article, January 2025 revision.

Iconic mass-produced vehicle. Planetary transmission with three foot pedals (clutch, reverse, brake). Hand throttle on steering column. Requires specialized brass-era/vintage expertise. Limited parts availability. Final production year 1927. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford Model T article, January 2025 revision.

Replaced Model T with modern features. Conventional sliding-gear transmission. Four-wheel mechanical brakes. Safety glass. Over 4 million produced 1927-1931. Requires vintage service expertise and period-correct parts. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford Model A article, January 2025 revision.

Introduced legendary Flathead V8 engine in 1932 (Model 18). Four-cylinder Model B also available. Revolutionary affordable V8 performance. Hot rod favorite. Requires brass-era/early vintage expertise and specialized parts. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford Model 18 article, January 2025 revision.

Updated styling with more streamlined appearance. Improved V8 engine with higher compression. Four-cylinder option continued. Mechanical brakes. Vintage service requires period-specific knowledge. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford Model 48 article, January 2025 revision.

More streamlined styling each year. Hydraulic brakes introduced 1939. Sealed-beam headlights in 1940. Two trim levels: Standard and Deluxe. Flathead engines require vintage expertise. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford De Luxe article, January 2025 revision.

Last pre-WWII Ford design. Wider bodies and new front-end styling. Production halted February 1942 for wartime production. Sealed-beam headlights introduced 1940. Flathead engines require period-specific knowledge. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford De Luxe article, January 2025 revision.

Postwar continuation of 1942 design with minor updates. Woodie Sportsman convertible featured wood body panels. First full production year was 1946. Flathead engines require vintage expertise and period-correct parts. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford De Luxe article, January 2025 revision.

First all-new postwar Ford design with modern styling. Independent front suspension. Slab-sided bodies with integrated fenders. Revolutionary design influenced entire industry. Flathead engines require period-specific service knowledge. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford Custom article, January 2025 revision.

First dedicated Ford truck series, replacing car-based pickups. F-1 through F-8 designations for different weight classes. All-new cab design. Flathead engines require vintage truck expertise. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford F-Series article, January 2025 revision.

First all-new postwar Ford design. Features independent front suspension and updated styling. Flathead engines require period-specific knowledge and tooling. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford Custom article, January 2025 revision.

All-new body design for 1952. Introduced Ford-O-Matic automatic transmission option. Flathead engines require vintage-specific expertise. Three trim levels: Mainline (base), Customline (mid), Crestline (top). Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford Crestline article, January 2025 revision.

engines: 223 cu in (3.7L) Mileage Maker I6 (120 hp)
notes: Revolutionary redesign introducing overhead-valve Y-block V8 engine family, replacing flathead. Fairlane became top trim level. Wraparound windshield and modern styling. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford Fairlane article, January 2025 revision.

engines: 223 cu in (3.7L) Mileage Maker I6 (144 hp)
notes: Major redesign for 1957 with longer, lower styling. Introduced larger FE engine series in 1958. Fairlane 500 became top trim. Retractable hardtop Skyliner available. Vintage complexity requires period expertise. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford Fairlane article, January 2025 revision.

First-generation two-seater personal luxury car. Optional supercharger available on 312 V8 (1957). Removable hardtop or soft convertible top. High collectibility requires careful service. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford Thunderbird article, January 2025 revision.

Redesigned as four-seater personal luxury car. Unibody construction. Optional 430 V8 in 1959. Increased size and luxury features. Collectible model requires vintage expertise. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford Thunderbird article, January 2025 revision.

F-100 introduced for 1953 as first light-duty F-Series. Overhead-valve Y-block V8 available from 1955. Updated cab styling and increased payload capacity. Vintage truck requires period-specific service knowledge. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford F-Series article, January 2025 revision.

All-new styling for 1957. Introduced Styleside integrated cargo bed alongside traditional Flareside. Larger FE engine series available. First year for factory-installed automatic transmission. Vintage truck complexity. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford F-Series article, January 2025 revision.

Full-size station wagon models. Country Squire featured wood-grain paneling. Country Sedan was unpaneled version. Three-row seating available. Vintage service requirements. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford Country Squire article, January 2025 revision.

Redesigned station wagon on Fairlane platform. Country Squire with wood-grain paneling, Country Sedan without. Three-row seating available. Larger FE V8s from 1958. Vintage complexity requires period expertise. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford Country Squire article, January 2025 revision.

engines: 223 cu in (3.7L) Mileage Maker I6 (144 hp)
notes: First car-based pickup, based on Fairlane platform. Combined car comfort with light-duty cargo capability. Introduced concept of compact utility vehicle. Vintage service requirements. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford Ranchero article, January 2025 revision.

Separate Edsel division vehicles marketed as Ford premium brand. Push-button Teletouch automatic transmission. Unique styling with vertical grille. Production ended 1960 due to poor sales. Complex vintage systems require specialized knowledge. Data sourced from Wikipedia Edsel article, January 2025 revision.

First generation pony car introduced April 1964. Multiple engine options from inline-6 to big-block V8s. K-code 289 HiPo produced 271 hp. Boss 302 and 429 engines available late in decade. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford Mustang (first generation) article, January 2025 revision.

Compact car platform. Mileage Maker inline-six engines standard. V8 option introduced mid-1963. Ranchero pickup variant covered separately. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford Falcon (North America) article, January 2025 revision.

Second generation compact car. Thriftpower six-cylinder engines. Multiple body style variants including station wagons. Ranchero pickup variant covered separately. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford Falcon (North America) article, January 2025 revision.
Third generation compact car continuing Falcon nameplate through end of 1960s. Shared platform with Fairlane. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford Falcon (North America) article, January 2025 revision.
Mid-size car platform. 427 V8 option available in 1964 for racing homologation. Multiple body style variants. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford Fairlane (Americas) article, January 2025 revision.

Third generation mid-size car. Larger body than previous generation. 427 V8 option continued for performance applications. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford Fairlane (Americas) article, January 2025 revision.

Fourth generation mid-size car. Fastback body style introduced. Shared platform with upscale Torino models. 428 Cobra Jet V8 available in 1969. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford Fairlane (Americas) article, January 2025 revision.

Full-size car platform. Multiple high-performance V8 options including 406 and 427 FE engines. Mileage Maker six-cylinder base engine. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford Galaxie article, January 2025 revision.

Fourth generation full-size car. Multiple big-block V8 options including 427, 428, and 429 engines. LTD became premium sub-series in 1965. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford Galaxie article, January 2025 revision.

engines: 6.4L FE V8 with three 2-barrel carbs (390 ci, 340 hp)
notes: Third generation personal luxury car. Sports Roadster package included fiberglass tonneau cover. Standard 390 V8 with optional triple-carburetor setup. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford Thunderbird article, January 2025 revision.

Fourth generation personal luxury car. Standard 390 V8 with optional 428 big-block. Sports Roadster package continued through 1964. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford Thunderbird article, January 2025 revision.

Fifth generation personal luxury car. Four-door hardtop body style introduced for first time. Standard 390 V8 with optional 428 big-block. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford Thunderbird article, January 2025 revision.

First generation compact van/truck platform. Based on Ford Falcon mechanicals with cab-over-engine design. 240 ci inline-6 introduced in 1965. 4-speed manual available 1963-1964 only. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford Econoline article, January 2025 revision.
Second generation compact van/truck platform. Continued cab-over-engine design. Multiple van and truck body configurations. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford Econoline article, January 2025 revision.

Fourth generation F-Series trucks. Unibody integrated pickup offered 1961-1963. Crew cab introduced 1965 on F-250/F-350. 240/300 ci inline-6 engines replaced Mileage Maker sixes in 1965. Ranger styling package introduced 1965. Available as F-100 (1/2 ton), F-250 (3/4 ton), F-350 (1 ton). Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford F-Series (fourth generation) article, January 2025 revision.

Fifth generation F-Series trucks. Multiple bed length options (6.5', 8', 9', 12'). Crew cab optional on F-250/F-350 with seating for six and four doors. 302 Windsor V8 introduced in 1969. Available as F-100 (1/2 ton), F-250 (3/4 ton), F-350 (1 ton). Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford F-Series (fifth generation) article, January 2025 revision.

First generation compact SUV. All examples sold with four-wheel drive. Open-body roadster discontinued after 1968. 289 V8 introduced March 1966, replaced by 302 V8 in 1969. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford Bronco article, January 2025 revision.

First generation mid-size car. Upscale variation of intermediate Ford Fairlane platform. 428 Cobra Jet V8 available for performance applications. Multiple body style variants. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford Torino article, January 2025 revision.

Fifth generation full-size station wagon. Based on Ford Galaxie platform. Top-level woodgrain-trimmed wagon. 10-passenger seating option available. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford Country Squire article, January 2025 revision.

Sixth generation full-size station wagon. Based on Ford LTD platform starting 1965. Top-level woodgrain-trimmed wagon. 10-passenger seating option available. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford Country Squire article, January 2025 revision.

Full-size sedan platform. Entry-level trim designed for basic transportation, fleet sales, police and taxi use. Base inline six-cylinder with multiple V8 options up to 427 high-performance engine. Ranch Wagon was companion station wagon series. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford Custom article, January 2025 revision.

First generation premium full-size car. Introduced 1965 as upscale Galaxie variant. Multiple V8 engine options including big-block 427 and 428 FE engines. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford LTD (Americas) article, January 2025 revision.
Full-size station wagon. Entry-level wagon companion to Custom sedan series. 221 ci V8 dropped in 1964. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford Ranch Wagon article, January 2025 revision.

Full-size station wagon returned to full-size Ford line in 1965. Dual-action Magic Doorgate introduced 1966. First Ranch Wagon with third-row seating introduced 1968. Part of Custom series in 1969. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford Ranch Wagon article, January 2025 revision.
Coupe utility vehicle based on Ford Falcon compact car platform. Multiple inline-6 and V8 engine options. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford Ranchero article, January 2025 revision.

Coupe utility vehicle transitioned to Ford Fairlane mid-size platform in 1966. Multiple inline-6 and V8 engine options including big-block 428. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford Ranchero article, January 2025 revision.

Final years of first-generation Mustang with multiple performance variants including Mach 1 and Boss 351. Grande trim offered luxury features. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford Mustang (first generation) article, September 1970 revision.
Coke bottle styling with increased dimensions. GT and Cobra performance packages available. Wheelbase 117.0 inches. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford Torino article, model years 1970-1971.

Full-size sedan with squared-off rooflines from 1971. Convertible discontinued after 1972. XL model ended 1970. Final year 1974 before nameplate discontinued. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford Galaxie article, latest revision.

Full-size luxury sedan. Convertible available 1971-1972. Hidden headlamps removed in 1971. Wheelbase 121.0 inches. Country Squire wagon variant available. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford LTD (Americas) article, specifications for 1970-1979.

Body-on-frame chassis with distinctive bird's beak grille projection. Sequential turn signals in full panel tail lights. Wheelbase 115 inches (2-door) and 117.2 inches (4-door landau). Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford Thunderbird (fifth generation) article, October 11, 2025 revision.

Body-on-frame chassis. 460 V8 became standard from 1974. Wheelbase 120.4 inches, length 225 inches. Curb weight approximately 5,000 lbs. Assembled in Wixom, Michigan and Pico Rivera, California. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford Thunderbird (sixth generation) article, August 9, 2025 revision.

Compact car marketed as simple and economical. 4-door sedan introduced 1971. 302 V8 added mid-1971. Wheelbase 103 inches (2-door) and 109.9 inches (4-door). Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford Maverick (Americas) article, June 8, 2025 revision.

Subcompact economy car with rear-engine, rear-wheel-drive layout. Wheelbase 94.0 inches. 2.3L I4 introduced 1974, 2.8L V6 introduced 1975. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford Pinto article, July 1980 revision.

Switched to body-on-frame construction in 1972. 5 mph bumper standards added 1973. Gran Torino Elite introduced 1974. SportsRoof discontinued after 1974. 460 V8 available in Police package only. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford Torino article, 2023 revision.
Coupe utility pickup based on Torino platform. Wheelbase 114.0 inches. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford Ranchero article, October 4, 2025 revision.

Coupe utility pickup based on Gran Torino platform. Wheelbase 118.0 inches, length 215.7 inches. 429 V8 available 1972-1973, 460 V8 available 1974-1976. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford Ranchero article, October 4, 2025 revision.
Final generation coupe utility pickup based on LTD II platform. Length 220.1 inches. Production ended 1979. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford Ranchero article, October 4, 2025 revision.

Compact pickup imported from Mazda B-series platform. Load capacity 1,400 lbs. 5-speed manual introduced 1976. Base engine increased to 2.0L in 1979. Optional Ford-built 2.3L engine same as Pinto and Mustang II. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford Courier article, September 4, 2025 revision.

Full-size pickup truck. SuperCab extended cab introduced 1974. Available trims: Custom, Ranger, Ranger XLT, Ranger Lariat (1978-1979). Part-time and full-time 4WD options. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford F-Series (sixth generation) article, September 5, 2025 revision.

Compact Mustang redesign. 302 V8 added in 1975 with C4 automatic. Rack and pinion steering, compression strut front suspension. Wheelbase 96.2 inches. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford Mustang (second generation) article, September 26, 2025 revision.

Personal luxury coupe. Initially marketed as Gran Torino Elite in 1974, renamed Elite for 1975-1976. Wheelbase 114 inches. Assembled in Chicago, Lorain, and Pico Rivera. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford Elite article, August 27, 2025 revision.

Compact sedan with unibody construction. Wheelbase 109.9 inches. Coil-spring front suspension, leaf-sprung live rear axle. Standard 11-inch front disc brakes and 10-inch rear drums, optional 4-wheel disc brakes. 4-speed manual introduced 1976. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford Granada (North America) article, July 17, 2025 revision.

First Ford van with body-on-frame construction. Available in 100/150/250/350 variants. Wheelbase options 124 inches and 138 inches. Club Wagon passenger van variant. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford Econoline article, 1975 model year introduction.

Full-size SUV based on F-Series platform. Part-time 4WD with New Process 205 gear-driven transfer case standard. Optional permanent 4WD with New Process 203 chain-driven transfer case. Wheelbase 104 inches, curb weight 4,663-4,718 lbs. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford Bronco article, latest revision.

Subcompact imported from Europe. Fitted with catalytic converter, air pump, energy-absorbing bumpers, side-marker lamps, and round sealed-beam headlamps for US market. Trim levels: Base, Decor, Sport, Ghia. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford Fiesta (first generation) article, September 19, 2025 revision.

Compact sedan on Ford Fox platform with steel unibody construction. Futura coupe introduced late 1978. 4-speed manual available in 1979 for all engines. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford Fairmont article, August 1977 revision.

First Lincoln model, designed by Henry Leland. Precision-built luxury car. Ford acquired Lincoln Motor Company in 1922. Custom coachbuilt bodies by Brunn, LeBaron, Judkins. Often used as presidential limousine. Brass-era through early vintage requires highly specialized expertise. Data sourced from Wikipedia Lincoln Model L article, January 2025 revision.

Revolutionary streamlined design by John Tjaarda. Unibody construction. More affordable Lincoln to compete with Packard. Flathead V12 engine. Continental was derived from Zephyr. Vintage service requires specialized knowledge. Data sourced from Wikipedia Lincoln Zephyr article, January 2025 revision.

Top-of-line Lincoln with massive V12 engine. Competed with Cadillac V16 and Packard Twelve. Custom coachbuilt bodies available. Largest displacement Lincoln engine until 1970s. Depression-era luxury car requires highly specialized vintage expertise. Data sourced from Wikipedia Lincoln Model K article, January 2025 revision.

Mid-range Lincoln V12 model. Smaller engine than KB. More affordable Depression-era luxury option. Vintage complexity requires period-specific service knowledge. Data sourced from Wikipedia Lincoln Model K article, January 2025 revision.

Original Continental created for Edsel Ford. Iconic long hood, short deck design. Flathead V12 engine. Exposed spare tire on trunk. Considered one of most beautiful cars ever designed. Production halted 1942 for WWII. Requires specialized vintage expertise. Data sourced from Wikipedia Lincoln Continental article, January 2025 revision.

Streamlined mid-priced Lincoln. Unibody construction. Flathead V12 engine. Production ended 1942 for WWII. Continental was originally upscale Zephyr variant. Vintage service requirements. Data sourced from Wikipedia Lincoln Zephyr article, January 2025 revision.

Postwar continuation of prewar Continental design with minor updates. Flathead V12 engine. Production ended 1948. Highly collectible. Requires specialized brass-era/vintage expertise and rare parts. Data sourced from Wikipedia Lincoln Continental article, January 2025 revision.

Postwar continuation of Zephyr design renamed Standard/Custom. Flathead V12 engine. Last Lincoln V12s. Production ended 1948. Vintage complexity requires period-specific knowledge. Data sourced from Wikipedia Lincoln automobile article, January 2025 revision.

Top-level Lincoln model in early 1950s. Overhead-valve Y-block V8. First use of ball-joint front suspension (1952). Vintage complexity requires period-specific service knowledge. Data sourced from Wikipedia Lincoln Cosmopolitan article, January 2025 revision.

Mid-level Lincoln model. Shared platform with Cosmopolitan. Four-speed automatic transmission introduced 1955. Vintage service requirements. Data sourced from Wikipedia Lincoln Capri article, January 2025 revision.

engines: 368 cu in (6.0L) Lincoln Y-block V8 (285-300 hp)
notes: Top-level Lincoln replacing Cosmopolitan/Capri. Larger 368 V8 engine. Failed attempt to compete with Cadillac. Unibody construction. Vintage complexity requires period expertise. Data sourced from Wikipedia Lincoln Premiere article, January 2025 revision.

engines: 368 cu in (6.0L) Lincoln Y-block V8 (285-300 hp)
notes: Ultra-luxury limited production vehicle marketed by separate Continental Division. Hand-built with extensive quality control. Cost $10,000 (twice Cadillac Eldorado price). Only 2,996 produced. Highly collectible, requires specialized restoration expertise. Data sourced from Wikipedia Continental Mark II article, January 2025 revision.

Largest Lincolns ever produced. Mark III (1958), Mark IV (1959), Mark V (1960) were model year designations. Massive 430 MEL (Mercury-Edsel-Lincoln) V8. Unibody construction. Commercial failure due to quality issues and styling. Vintage complexity. Data sourced from Wikipedia Lincoln Continental article, January 2025 revision.

Iconic suicide doors (rear-hinged) design. Presidential limousine variant (JFK assassination vehicle). Last four-door convertible in America until 1980s. Unibody construction. Highly collectible. Vintage complexity requires specialized service knowledge. Data sourced from Wikipedia Lincoln Continental article, January 2025 revision.

Revival of Mark series as personal luxury coupe. Based on Ford Thunderbird platform. Signature Rolls-Royce-style grille. Hidden headlights. Long hood, short deck proportions. Vintage service requirements. Data sourced from Wikipedia Lincoln Mark series article, January 2025 revision.

Final years of fifth-generation Continental. Massive 460 V8 engine. Full-size luxury car with 127-inch wheelbase. Vintage complexity requires period-specific service knowledge. Data sourced from Wikipedia Lincoln Continental article, January 2025 revision.

Personal luxury coupe based on Ford Thunderbird platform. Signature opera windows and vinyl roof. Emissions-era detuned 460 V8. Popular luxury coupe requiring vintage service expertise. Data sourced from Wikipedia Lincoln Mark series article, January 2025 revision.

Full-size luxury sedan and coupe. 460 V8 standard, smaller 400 V8 added 1977 for fuel economy. Last Continental coupe ended 1976. Town Car became separate model 1980. Vintage service requirements. Data sourced from Wikipedia Lincoln Continental article, January 2025 revision.

Downsized personal luxury coupe. Designer editions by Bill Blass, Cartier, Givenchy, Pucci. Last year for 460 V8. First Lincoln with overdrive automatic (1979). Vintage complexity requires period expertise. Data sourced from Wikipedia Lincoln Mark series article, January 2025 revision.

Compact luxury sedan based on Ford Granada/Mercury Monarch. Lincoln's response to Cadillac Seville. Not commercially successful. Standard vinyl roof and opera windows. Vintage service requirements. Data sourced from Wikipedia Lincoln Versailles article, January 2025 revision.

First Dodge Brothers automobile. Reputation for quality and durability. All-steel body construction (advanced for era). Flathead four-cylinder engine. Brass-era vehicle requires highly specialized vintage expertise and rare parts. Data sourced from Wikipedia Dodge Brothers article, January 2025 revision.

Dodge Brothers vehicles after founding brothers' deaths. Flathead four-cylinder engine. Reliable, sturdy construction. Sold to Chrysler 1928. Brass-era/early vintage requires highly specialized expertise. Data sourced from Wikipedia Dodge Brothers article, January 2025 revision.

Depression-era Dodge models. Flathead inline-six engines. Art Deco styling influences. Affordable transportation during economic hardship. Vintage complexity requires specialized knowledge. Data sourced from Wikipedia Dodge automobile article, January 2025 revision.

Postwar Dodge based on prewar design. Flathead inline-six engine. Fluid Drive semi-automatic transmission optional. Last year before major 1949 redesign. Vintage complexity requires period expertise. Data sourced from Wikipedia Dodge automobile article, January 2025 revision.

All-new postwar design. Wayfarer was entry-level, Coronet top-line. First all-new Dodge since 1940. Modern styling replacing prewar look. Vintage service requirements. Data sourced from Wikipedia Dodge Wayfarer article, January 2025 revision.

Full-size Dodge with distinctive Forward Look styling by Virgil Exner. D-500 performance package available. Legendary Hemi V8 engine. Tall tailfins in late 1950s. Vintage service requirements. Data sourced from Wikipedia Dodge Custom Royal article, January 2025 revision.

Iconic muscle car based on Coronet platform. 1968-1970 models featured Coke-bottle styling. 1969 Charger famously used in Dukes of Hazzard. Daytona aerodynamic variant for NASCAR. Hemi engine legendary. Vintage muscle car requires specialized knowledge. Data sourced from Wikipedia Dodge Charger article, January 2025 revision.

Compact car initially full-size (1960-1961), then compact (1963-1976). Available with Slant-6 or V8 engines. GTS performance variant. Popular drag racing platform. Vintage complexity. Data sourced from Wikipedia Dodge Dart article, January 2025 revision.

Iconic muscle car on E-body platform. Available with legendary 426 Hemi. Convertible only 1970-1971. Emissions regulations reduced power outputs after 1971. High-performance muscle car requires vintage expertise. Data sourced from Wikipedia Dodge Challenger article, January 2025 revision.

Subcompact hatchback based on Simca/Talbot Horizon. Chrysler's first front-wheel drive car. VW engine initially, then Chrysler 2.2L. GLH performance variant. Saved Chrysler during 1970s crisis. Data sourced from Wikipedia Dodge Omni article, January 2025 revision.

Compact car on F-body platform. Replaced Dart. Available as coupe, sedan, or wagon. Rust and reliability issues. Motor Trend Car of the Year 1976. Vintage service requirements. Data sourced from Wikipedia Dodge Aspen article, January 2025 revision.

Compact car on K platform. Saved Chrysler from bankruptcy. Available as sedan, coupe, or wagon. Front-wheel drive. Sister car to Plymouth Reliant. Data sourced from Wikipedia Dodge Aries article, January 2025 revision.

Revolutionary minivan that created the segment. Based on K-car platform. Shorter wheelbase than Grand Caravan. Replaced traditional station wagons. Car of the Year 1985. Data sourced from Wikipedia Dodge Caravan article, January 2025 revision.

Sports coupe on G platform. Available with turbocharged engines. Shelby variants with enhanced performance. IROC R/T racing models. Replaced Challenger name temporarily. Data sourced from Wikipedia Dodge Daytona article, January 2025 revision.

Compact hatchback sedan based on H platform. Replaced Challenger. Shelby Lancer variants available with turbo. European-influenced styling. Data sourced from Wikipedia Dodge Lancer article, January 2025 revision.

Compact car on P platform. Replaced Omni. Available as 2-door or 4-door hatchback. Shelby Shadow performance variant. Sister car to Plymouth Sundance. Data sourced from Wikipedia Dodge Shadow article, January 2025 revision.

Rebadged Mitsubishi Mighty Max compact pickup. Sold by Dodge through Mitsubishi partnership. Available with diesel engine. Replaced by Dakota. Diesel service requires specialized knowledge. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mitsubishi Triton article, January 2025 revision.

American supercar with massive V10 engine. No traction control or ABS initially. GTS coupe added 1996. Hand-built at New Mack Assembly. Exotic performance requires specialized service expertise. Data sourced from Wikipedia Dodge Viper article, January 2025 revision.

Full-size sedan on LH platform (cab-forward design). Shared with Chrysler Concorde/LHS and Eagle Vision. Aerodynamic styling. Popular rental fleet vehicle. Data sourced from Wikipedia Dodge Intrepid article, January 2025 revision.

Compact car replacing Shadow/Sundance. Fun, affordable transportation. Available as sedan or coupe. Dual airbags standard. Popular with young buyers. Data sourced from Wikipedia Dodge Neon article, January 2025 revision.

Mid-size sedan on JA platform (Cloud Cars). Replaced Spirit. Available as sedan or coupe. Competed with Honda Accord and Toyota Camry. Data sourced from Wikipedia Dodge Stratus article, January 2025 revision.

Sports coupe on JA platform. Shared with Chrysler Sebring coupe. Built by Mitsubishi in Illinois (Diamond-Star Motors). Replaced Daytona. Data sourced from Wikipedia Dodge Avenger article, January 2025 revision.

Second-generation mid-size pickup. First Dakota with V8 engine option. Club Cab configuration added. Available in 2WD or 4WD. Competed with Ford Ranger and Chevrolet S-10. Data sourced from Wikipedia Dodge Dakota article, January 2025 revision.

Full-size SUV based on Dakota platform. Three-row seating for 8. Body-on-frame construction. Competed with Ford Explorer and Chevrolet Blazer. Data sourced from Wikipedia Dodge Durango article, January 2025 revision.

Third-generation Caravan on AS platform. Grand Caravan long-wheelbase variant. Optional all-wheel drive (1991-1992). Driver-side sliding door added 1994. Data sourced from Wikipedia Dodge Caravan article, January 2025 revision.

Charger revival as four-door sedan on LX platform. Brought back Charger nameplate after 26-year hiatus. SRT8 variant with 6.1L Hemi. AWD available on some models. Based on Mercedes E-Class platform. Data sourced from Wikipedia Dodge Charger article, January 2025 revision.

Modern Challenger revival inspired by 1970 original. Retro styling on LX platform. SRT8 with 6.1L Hemi. Manual transmission available. Pony car competing with Mustang and Camaro. Data sourced from Wikipedia Dodge Challenger article, January 2025 revision.

Performance station wagon on LX platform. Shared platform with Charger and Chrysler 300. SRT8 variant with 425 hp. AWD available. Discontinued 2008 due to declining wagon market. Data sourced from Wikipedia Dodge Magnum article, January 2025 revision.

Compact crossover/hatchback replacing Neon. PM platform (shared with Jeep Compass/Patriot). SRT4 variant planned but cancelled. Diesel engine available (2.0L VW turbodiesel). CVT transmission. Diesel service requires specialized knowledge. Data sourced from Wikipedia Dodge Caliber article, January 2025 revision.

Mid-size SUV based on Jeep Liberty KJ platform. Body-on-frame construction. Available with 4WD. Discontinued 2012 as Dodge refocused on cars. Data sourced from Wikipedia Dodge Nitro article, January 2025 revision.

Mid-size sedan on JS platform (Mitsubishi GS platform). Replaced Intrepid/Stratus. Pentastar V6 introduced 2011. Production ended 2014. Data sourced from Wikipedia Dodge Avenger article, January 2025 revision.

Mid-size crossover on JS platform. Three-row seating available. Replaced Caravan as family hauler option. Value-oriented pricing. Data sourced from Wikipedia Dodge Journey article, January 2025 revision.

Seventh-generation Charger refresh on LD platform. Hellcat variant introduced 2015 with 707 hp supercharged 6.2L. Hellcat Redeye 797 hp (2019). AWD available on V6 and 5.7L models. High-performance variants require specialized service knowledge. Data sourced from Wikipedia Dodge Charger article, January 2025 revision.

Third-generation Challenger continuation. Hellcat (707 hp, 2015), Hellcat Widebody, Demon (840 hp, 2018), Redeye (797 hp, 2019). Manual transmission available on some trims. Supercharged models require specialized service. Data sourced from Wikipedia Dodge Challenger article, January 2025 revision.

Third-generation Durango on Mercedes ML platform. Three-row seating for 7. SRT 392 variant with 6.4L Hemi introduced 2018. Towing capacity up to 8,700 lbs. Data sourced from Wikipedia Dodge Durango article, January 2025 revision.

Compact sedan based on Alfa Romeo Giulietta platform (Compact US Wide). Dual-clutch automatic transmission on some models. Replaced Neon/Caliber. Production ended 2016 due to poor sales. Data sourced from Wikipedia Dodge Dart article, January 2025 revision.

Fifth and final generation Viper. 8.4L V10 engine producing 645-665 hp. Manual transmission only. ACR track-focused variant. Hand-built at Conner Avenue Assembly. Production ended 2017. Exotic supercar requires specialized service expertise. Data sourced from Wikipedia Dodge Viper article, January 2025 revision.

Fifth-generation Grand Caravan final run. Pentastar V6 replaced older 3.3L/3.8L engines. Stow 'n Go seating. Value-oriented minivan. Production ended 2020 as Chrysler Pacifica took over minivan duties. Data sourced from Wikipedia Dodge Caravan article, January 2025 revision.

engines: 1.3L Turbo I4 plug-in hybrid (288 hp combined)
notes: Compact crossover based on Alfa Romeo Tonale platform (STLA Medium). Available as plug-in hybrid R/T model with 288 hp combined output. Turbo I4 gasoline or PHEV powertrain. Hybrid systems require PHEV-trained technicians. Data sourced from Wikipedia Dodge Hornet article, January 2025 revision.

engines: 3.0L Hurricane twin-turbo I6 (420 hp Standard Output)
3.0L Hurricane twin-turbo I6 (550 hp High Output)
notes: All-new seventh-generation Charger on STLA Large platform. Twin-turbo Hurricane I6 replaces Hemi V8. Sixpack name honors historic performance. Standard Output (420 hp) or High Output (550 hp) twin-turbo configurations. Modern turbocharged complexity. Data sourced from Wikipedia Dodge Charger article, January 2025 revision.

All-electric Charger variant on STLA Large platform. 400V or 800V battery architecture. Scat Pack model produces 670 hp. Simulated exhaust sound (Fratzonic Chambered Exhaust). High-voltage EV system requires EV-certified technicians. Data sourced from Wikipedia Dodge Charger article, January 2025 revision.

Final years of third-generation Durango. Based on Mercedes ML platform. SRT 392 and Hellcat high-performance variants with 6.4L Hemi (475-710 hp). Last Hellcat Durango produced 2023. Three-row SUV capability. Data sourced from Wikipedia Dodge Durango article, January 2025 revision.

First Dodge Brothers commercial trucks. One-ton capacity. Screenside delivery variants. Flathead four-cylinder engine. All-steel construction. Brass-era vehicle requires highly specialized vintage expertise and extremely rare parts. Data sourced from Wikipedia Dodge Brothers article, January 2025 revision.

Early Dodge commercial vehicles. Flathead four-cylinder engine. Screen-side delivery trucks. Graham Brothers built some half-ton models. Brass-era complexity requires highly specialized vintage expertise. Data sourced from Wikipedia Dodge Brothers article, January 2025 revision.

Depression-era commercial trucks. Flathead inline-six engines. Simple, rugged construction. KC half-ton, LC three-quarter ton. Brass-era/early vintage complexity requires specialized knowledge. Data sourced from Wikipedia Dodge truck article, January 2025 revision.

Legendary civilian version of WC military trucks. One of first civilian 4WD trucks. PTO winch, low-range transfer case. Flathead inline-six engine. Extremely rugged construction. Vintage 4WD complexity requires specialized expertise. Data sourced from Wikipedia Dodge Power Wagon article, January 2025 revision.

Job-Rated light-duty pickup trucks. Pilot-house cab design. Flathead six-cylinder engines. Available in various weight classes. Vintage truck complexity. Data sourced from Wikipedia Dodge D series article, January 2025 revision.

Job-Rated truck series. Sweptside pickup variant with car-like styling (1957-1959). Town Panel and Town Wagon utility vehicles. Transition to overhead-valve V8. Vintage truck requires specialized knowledge. Data sourced from Wikipedia Dodge D series article, January 2025 revision.

Sweptline cab with modern integrated bed design. D-Series 2WD, W-Series 4WD. Available with legendary Slant-6 or V8 engines. Crew Cab option for commercial use. Vintage truck complexity. Data sourced from Wikipedia Dodge D series article, January 2025 revision.

Updated styling with more modern appearance. Special editions: Lil' Red Express (1978-1979), Warlock, Utiline. Club Cab option. Heavy-duty capabilities. Vintage truck requires period-specific service knowledge. Data sourced from Wikipedia Dodge D series article, January 2025 revision.

Full-size SUV based on D/W pickup platform. Removable fiberglass hardtop. Competed with Ford Bronco. Trail Duster was Plymouth version. Vintage complexity requires specialized knowledge. Data sourced from Wikipedia Dodge Ramcharger article, January 2025 revision.

Rebranded as 'Ram' starting 1981. Cummins diesel introduced 1989 (legendary). Club Cab extended cab 1991. D-Series 2WD, W-Series 4WD. Diesel requires specialized knowledge. Data sourced from Wikipedia Dodge Ram article, January 2025 revision.

Revolutionary big-rig styling by Trevor Creed. Motor Trend Truck of the Year 1994. V10 engine for heavy towing. Cummins diesel popular. Quad Cab four-door added 1998. Diesel requires specialized service knowledge. Data sourced from Wikipedia Dodge Ram article, January 2025 revision.

Full-size SUV based on Ram pickup platform. Removable hardtop. Competed with Ford Bronco and Chevrolet Blazer. Production ended US 1993, Mexico 2001. Vintage SUV complexity. Data sourced from Wikipedia Dodge Ramcharger article, January 2025 revision.

Major redesign with bold styling. Hemi V8 returned. Mega Cab introduced 2006 with extended cab space. SRT-10 variant with Viper V10 (2004-2006). 6.7L Cummins replaced 5.9L in 2007. Diesel engines require specialized service. Data sourced from Wikipedia Dodge Ram article, January 2025 revision.

High-performance pickup with Viper V10 engine. 500+ hp, 0-60 mph in 4.9 seconds. Manual transmission only. Limited production performance truck. Requires performance-tuned service expertise. Data sourced from Wikipedia Dodge Ram SRT-10 article, January 2025 revision.

First generation as separate RAM brand (split from Dodge 2009). Major redesign with coil spring rear suspension. EcoDiesel V6 added 2014. 8-speed automatic from 2013. Ram Box storage system. EcoDiesel requires diesel-trained technicians. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ram pickup article, January 2025 revision.

Heavy-duty Ram with Cummins 6.7L diesel. Manual transmission available. Mega Cab configuration with extended cab space. Towing capacity up to 35,100 lbs. 6.4L Hemi replaced 5.7L in 2014. Heavy-duty diesel requires specialized service expertise. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ram pickup article, January 2025 revision.

Rebadged Fiat Doblò. Compact commercial van competing with Ford Transit Connect. Available as cargo or passenger (Wagon) variant. Discontinued 2022. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ram ProMaster City article, January 2025 revision.

All-new fifth-generation Ram 1500 on DT platform. Available with mild hybrid eTorque system (48V). TRX variant with 702 hp supercharged Hemi (2021-2023). 12-inch touchscreen Uconnect 5. EcoDiesel requires diesel-trained technicians. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ram pickup article, January 2025 revision.

Heavy-duty Ram refresh with updated styling. Cummins 6.7L diesel produces up to 1,075 lb-ft torque. Available in 2500/3500/3500HD configurations. Aisin 8-speed automatic on diesel models. Towing capacity up to 37,100 lbs. Diesel and heavy-duty systems require specialized service. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ram pickup article, January 2025 revision.

High-performance off-road pickup competing with Ford Raptor. 702 hp supercharged 6.2L Hemi. Launch control, off-road suspension, 35-inch tires. 0-60 mph in 4.5 seconds. Production ended 2023. High-performance systems require specialized service knowledge. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ram TRX article, January 2025 revision.

Rebadged Fiat Ducato. Front-wheel drive commercial van. Available in multiple roof heights and wheelbases. Diesel option 2014-2016. ProMaster City was smaller variant. EcoDiesel requires diesel service knowledge. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ram ProMaster article, January 2025 revision.

Fourth generation JL platform (2018-present). Diesel option warrants 1.1 modifier. Part-time four-wheel drive with multiple systems available. Removable roof and doors require specific service procedures. Data sourced from Wikipedia Jeep Wrangler article, January 2025 revision.

engines: 2.0L turbocharged I4 + electric motors (375 hp combined, 470 lb-ft)
notes: Plug-in hybrid variant with 17 kWh battery (15 kWh usable) providing 21 miles electric range. PHEV complexity warrants 1.1 modifier. 400V battery system requires HV safety protocols. Data sourced from Wikipedia Jeep Wrangler article, January 2025 revision.

High-performance variant with 6.4L V8 engine achieving 0-60 mph in 4.5 seconds. Only available in 4-door Unlimited configuration. Data sourced from Wikipedia Jeep Wrangler article, January 2025 revision.

Midsize pickup truck based on Wrangler JL platform. Standard four-wheel drive with Command-Trac, Selec-Trac, or Rock-Trac systems. Removable roof and doors. Manual transmission discontinued for 2025. Data sourced from Wikipedia Jeep Gladiator (JT) article, January 2025 revision.

Diesel variant available 2021-2023 only, discontinued after 2023. Diesel complexity warrants 1.1 modifier. Diesel exhaust fluid (DEF) system requires specialized service knowledge. Data sourced from Wikipedia Jeep Gladiator (JT) article, January 2025 revision.

engines: 3.6L Pentastar V6 with eTorque mild hybrid (290 hp, 257 lb-ft)
notes: Fifth generation WL platform. eTorque mild hybrid system provides torque assist but not electric-only driving. Four-wheel drive options include Quadra-Trac I, Quadra-Trac II, and Quadra-Drive II with electronic limited slip. 2.0L Hurricane turbo I4 coming in 2026. Data sourced from Wikipedia Jeep Grand Cherokee article, January 2025 revision.

engines: 2.0L turbocharged I4 + electric motors (375 hp combined, 470 lb-ft)
notes: Plug-in hybrid variant with 17.3 kWh 400V lithium-ion battery providing 25 miles electric range. PHEV complexity warrants 1.1 modifier. High-voltage system requires HV-certified technicians. Data sourced from Wikipedia Jeep Grand Cherokee article, January 2025 revision.

engines: 3.6L Pentastar V6 with eTorque mild hybrid (290 hp, 257 lb-ft)
notes: Three-row extended-wheelbase variant of WL Grand Cherokee. eTorque mild hybrid system provides torque assist. Same platform and drivetrain options as standard Grand Cherokee. Data sourced from Wikipedia Jeep Grand Cherokee article, January 2025 revision.

Second generation facelift (MP/552). Became Jeep's entry-level model in North America for 2024 after Renegade withdrawal. AWD optional on Sport/Latitude, standard on Trailhawk/Limited/High Altitude. 4xe PHEV available in Europe only. Data sourced from Wikipedia Jeep Compass article, January 2025 revision.

Subcompact crossover facelift (2019-2023). Discontinued in US and Canada after 2023 model year. FWD available until 2023, then AWD became standard. Latitude became base trim in 2023. Data sourced from Wikipedia Jeep Renegade article, January 2025 revision.

engines: 5.7L Hemi V8 with eTorque mild hybrid (392 hp, 2022-2023 only)
notes: Full-size luxury SUV revival on WS platform. Optional Quadra-Trac full-time four-wheel drive. Extended 'L' wheelbase approximately 1 foot longer. Standard RWD with optional 4WD. Data sourced from Wikipedia Jeep Wagoneer (WS) article, January 2025 revision.

Premium variant of Wagoneer with standard four-wheel drive (Quadra-Trac). Extended 'L' wheelbase available. Higher-output Hurricane twin-turbo engines. NHTSA investigation into potential engine shutdown issues in late 2024. Data sourced from Wikipedia Jeep Wagoneer (WS) article, January 2025 revision.

JK generation third-generation Wrangler. 3.8L V6 standard through 2011. Optional rear-wheel drive available until 2010. 4-door Unlimited variant became increasingly popular. Data sourced from Wikipedia Jeep Wrangler (JK) article, January 2025 revision.

JK generation with upgraded 3.6L Pentastar V6 introduced in 2012. Four-wheel drive standard across all models. 4-door Unlimited represented approximately 75% of sales by 2017. Data sourced from Wikipedia Jeep Wrangler (JK) article, January 2025 revision.

JL generation fourth-generation Wrangler introduced for 2018 model year. New 2.0L turbocharged four-cylinder engine option. Multiple 4WD systems available: Command-Trac, Selec-Trac, Rock-Trac. EcoDiesel V6 not available until 2020. Data sourced from Wikipedia Jeep Wrangler (JL) article, January 2025 revision.

WK2 generation fourth-generation Grand Cherokee. Multiple 4WD systems available: Quadra-Trac I, Quadra-Trac II, Quadra-Drive II. Optional air suspension (Quadra-Lift) and Selec-Terrain drive mode system. SRT performance variant introduced with 6.4L Hemi V8. Data sourced from Wikipedia Jeep Grand Cherokee (WK2) article, January 2025 revision.

WK2 generation with 8-speed automatic standard from 2014. 3.0L EcoDiesel V6 diesel available 2014-2019. Diesel service requires DEF fluid system maintenance and diesel-rated oil. Multiple 4WD systems: Quadra-Trac I, Quadra-Trac II, Quadra-Drive II. Optional air suspension and Selec-Terrain system. SRT variant with 6.4L Hemi V8. Data sourced from Wikipedia Jeep Grand Cherokee (WK2) article, January 2025 revision.

KL generation fifth-generation Cherokee on FCA Compact Wide platform (shared with Chrysler 200). 9-speed ZF automatic transmission had early reliability issues requiring multiple software updates. Multiple 4WD systems: Active Drive I, Active Drive II, Active Drive Lock. 2.0L Hurricane turbo I4 introduced in 2019. Data sourced from Wikipedia Jeep Cherokee (KL) article, January 2025 revision.

MK generation first-generation Compass. Multiple 4WD systems available: Freedom Drive I full-time 4WD and Freedom Drive II with CVT low-range capability. Diesel engines available in European markets only. Platform shared with Jeep Patriot and Dodge Caliber. Data sourced from Wikipedia Jeep Compass article, January 2025 revision.

MP/552 generation second-generation Compass introduced in 2017. Front-wheel drive standard with optional four-wheel drive. Trailhawk trim features 4WD standard. Diesel engines available in international markets only. Data sourced from Wikipedia Jeep Compass article, January 2025 revision.

MK generation Patriot manufactured at Belvidere, Illinois assembly plant. Multiple 4WD systems: Freedom Drive I and Freedom Drive II. 2.2L Mercedes-Benz CRD diesel available in European market only. Platform shared with Jeep Compass and Dodge Caliber. Discontinued after 2017 model year. Data sourced from Wikipedia Jeep Patriot article, January 2025 revision.

BU generation first-generation Renegade, smallest vehicle in Jeep lineup. 2.4L Tigershark I4 standard in North American market. Front-wheel drive standard with optional Active Drive I and Active Drive Low 4WD systems. Diesel engines available in international markets only. Data sourced from Wikipedia Jeep Renegade article, January 2025 revision.

XK generation Commander final model year 2010. Multiple 4WD systems available: Quadra-Trac I, Quadra-Trac II, Quadra-Drive II. 3.0L OM642 V6 diesel available in export markets only. Discontinued after 2010 model year. Data sourced from Wikipedia Jeep Commander (XK) article, January 2025 revision.

TJ generation features part-time 4WD with live axles front and rear. Trim levels include SE, Sport, Sahara, and Rubicon (introduced 2003 with Dana 44 axles and locking differentials). 2004 introduced Unlimited long-wheelbase variant with 10-inch stretch. Data sourced from Wikipedia Jeep Wrangler (TJ) article, January 2025 revision.

JK generation introduced first-ever 4-door Wrangler Unlimited. Features part-time 4WD with electronic stability control standard. Trim levels include X/Sport, Sahara, and Rubicon. Optional rear-wheel drive (4x2) available on some models. Data sourced from Wikipedia Jeep Wrangler (JK) article, January 2025 revision.

WJ generation features UniFrame construction for improved rigidity. Quadra-Drive and Quadra-Trac II 4WD systems available. Trim levels include Laredo, Limited, Sport, Special Edition, and Overland. Trail Rated 4X4 certification introduced in 2004. Data sourced from Wikipedia Jeep Grand Cherokee (WJ) article, January 2025 revision.

WK generation introduced available 3.0L Mercedes-Benz CRD diesel (2007-2008 only) with 376 lb-ft torque, requiring diesel service expertise including emissions system maintenance. Quadra-Drive II 4WD system available. High-performance SRT-8 variant features 6.1L HEMI with performance suspension. Data sourced from Wikipedia Jeep Grand Cherokee (WK) article, January 2025 revision.

engines: 2.8L VM Motori R428 I4 Turbo Diesel CRD (160 hp, 2005-2006)
notes: KJ generation Liberty featured available 2.8L CRD turbo diesel (2005-2006 only in Sport and Limited trims) with 295 lb-ft torque, requiring diesel service expertise. 4WD options include Command-Trac (part-time) and Selec-Trac (full-time). Trim levels include Sport, Renegade, and Limited. Diesel option discontinued due to emissions standards. Data sourced from Wikipedia Jeep Liberty (KJ) article, January 2025 revision.

KK generation Liberty features updated styling with available 4WD system. Standard features include electronic stability control, traction control, and anti-lock brakes. 6-speed manual transmission dropped after 2008. Trim levels include Sport and Limited. Towing capacity rated at 5,000 lbs. Data sourced from Wikipedia Jeep Liberty (KK) article, January 2025 revision.

First-generation Compass (MK49) built on GS platform shared with Dodge Caliber. Targets first-time Jeep buyers and primarily on-road driving. Optional 4WD system available. CVT transmission option provides continuous ratio variation for improved fuel economy. Data sourced from Wikipedia Jeep Compass article, January 2025 revision.

First-generation Patriot (MK74) built on GS platform shared with Compass and Dodge Caliber. Debuted at 2006 New York Auto Show. 4WD available with Freedom Drive I system. More rugged styling than Compass aimed at traditional Jeep buyers. Data sourced from Wikipedia Jeep Patriot article, January 2025 revision.

XK Commander built on WK Grand Cherokee platform with three-row seating for 5 or 7 passengers. 4WD options include Quadra-Trac I (full-time), Quadra-Trac II (full-time with low range), and Quadra-Drive II (adds electronic limited-slip differentials). 5.7L HEMI output increased from 330 hp to 360 hp during production. Data sourced from Wikipedia Jeep Commander (XK) article, January 2025 revision.
YJ generation with distinctive rectangular headlights. Transfer case: New Process NP231. Data sourced from Wikipedia Jeep Wrangler (YJ) article, January 2025 revision.
TJ generation reintroduced round headlights. Available with rear-wheel drive or four-wheel drive configurations. Data sourced from Wikipedia Jeep Wrangler (TJ) article, January 2025 revision.

engines: 5.2L Chrysler Magnum V8 (318 CID, 225 hp, 300 lb-ft)
5.9L Chrysler Magnum V8 (360 CID, 245 hp, 345 lb-ft) - 1998 only
notes: ZJ generation offered multiple 4WD systems: Command-Trac (part-time, until 1996), Selec-Trac (full-time/part-time), and Quadra-Trac (permanent all-time). Trim levels included Base/SE, Laredo, Limited, Special Edition, TSi, Orvis Edition, and 5.9 Limited. Data sourced from Wikipedia Jeep Grand Cherokee (ZJ) article, January 2025 revision.

engines: 4.0L AMC Power-Tech I6 (242 CID, 195 hp @ 4600 rpm, 230 lb-ft @ 3000 rpm)
4.7L PowerTech V8 (287 CID, 235 hp @ 4800 rpm, 295 lb-ft @ 3200 rpm)
notes: WJ generation introduced in 1999 model year with improved refinement and new V8 engine option. Available in 2WD rear-wheel drive or 4WD configurations. Data sourced from Wikipedia Jeep Grand Cherokee (WJ) article, January 2025 revision.

engines: 4.0L I6 (242 CID, 190 hp @ 4,750 rpm) - 1991-1999 Chrysler MPI
notes: XJ generation compact SUV available throughout 1990s. 4WD models offered Command-Trac or Selec-Trac transfer cases. Fuel system transitioned from Renix MPI to Chrysler MPI in 1991. Data sourced from Wikipedia Jeep Cherokee (XJ) article, January 2025 revision.
Final years of CJ-5 production ending in 1983. Part-time two-speed transfer case. AMC engines standard. Data sourced from Wikipedia Jeep CJ article, December 2024 revision.

Part-time two-speed transfer case with optional Quadra-Trac all-wheel drive. Multiple trim packages including Renegade, Laredo, Golden Eagle (through 1980), Golden Hawk (1980), Limited (1982-1983), and Jamboree Commemorative Edition (1982). Diesel option available with Isuzu C240 engine. Data sourced from Wikipedia Jeep CJ article, December 2024 revision.
Longer wheelbase (103.5 in) variant with removable half cab and pickup-style box. Shared powertrain options with CJ-7. Data sourced from Wikipedia Jeep CJ article, December 2024 revision.

Final generation of SJ platform Cherokee before XJ replacement. Dana 44 axles front and rear. Disc brakes front, drum brakes rear. Semi-elliptical leaf springs. Trim levels included Laredo, Cherokee Chief, and Pioneer. Data sourced from Wikipedia Jeep Cherokee (SJ) article, September 14, 2025 revision.

Full-size SUV with body-on-frame construction. Platform shared with J-Series pickups. Final years before transition to Grand Wagoneer nameplate in 1984. Data sourced from Wikipedia Jeep Wagoneer article, October 10, 2025 revision.

Full-size pickup sharing chassis with Wagoneer. J10 for lighter payload, J20 for higher payload capacity. Selec-Trac full-time four-wheel drive introduced in 1983. Discontinued by Chrysler in 1988 after acquiring AMC in 1987. Data sourced from Wikipedia Jeep Gladiator (SJ) article, September 17, 2025 revision.

Luxury full-size SUV with body-on-frame construction. Continued production alongside compact XJ models due to high demand. Maintained almost unchanged body structure from original 1963 design. Data sourced from Wikipedia Jeep Wagoneer article, October 10, 2025 revision.

transmissions: 5-speed manual (Borg-Warner T-5, Aisin AX-5, Peugeot BA-10/5)
notes: Compact unibody SUV replacing SJ Cherokee. Command-Trac and Selec-Trac 4WD systems available. 4.0L I6 introduced in 1987 with Renix multi-port fuel injection. 2.1L Renault TurboDiesel available 1985-1987 in North America. Data sourced from Wikipedia Jeep Cherokee (XJ) article, 2025 revision.

Luxury trim variant of Cherokee XJ platform. Available in Wagoneer and Wagoneer Limited trim levels. Compact unibody construction. Intended to replace SJ models but both remained in production. Data sourced from Wikipedia Jeep Wagoneer article, October 10, 2025 revision.

Compact pickup based on Cherokee XJ platform with Uniframe fully boxed frame design. Quadralink front suspension with coil springs, rear leaf springs. Standard Dana 35 rear axle with optional Dana 44 in Metric Ton package. 4.0L I6 introduced in 1987. 6-foot bed introduced in 1987, 7-foot bed from 1986. First generation Wrangler replacing CJ-7. Distinguished by rectangular headlights and wider track. New Process NP207 transfer case (1987 only). Dana 30 front axle, Dana 35 rear axle (Dana 44 optional). Introduced March 1986 as 1987 model year. Data sourced from Wikipedia Jeep Wrangler (YJ) article, September 17, 2025 revision.

First Tesla production vehicle. Based on Lotus Elise chassis. 53 kWh battery pack. 400V architecture. 0-60 mph in 3.7 seconds. 244-mile range. Proved viability of electric sports cars. Limited production (~2,450 units). Hand-built in limited quantities. Early EV technology requires specialized vintage EV expertise. Data sourced from Wikipedia Tesla Roadster (first generation) article, January 2025 revision.

First mass-market Tesla sedan. 60-100 kWh battery pack options. 400V architecture. Ludicrous Mode on P100D (0-60 in 2.5 seconds). Over-the-air software updates. Autopilot introduced 2014. Up to 402-mile range. High-voltage EV system requires EV-certified technicians. Data sourced from Wikipedia Tesla Model S article, January 2025 revision.

First Tesla SUV with distinctive falcon-wing rear doors. 75-100 kWh battery pack. 400V architecture. Three-row seating for 6-7. Bioweapon Defense Mode air filtration. Ludicrous Mode available. Up to 351-mile range. Falcon-wing doors add mechanical complexity. High-voltage systems require specialized service. Data sourced from Wikipedia Tesla Model X article, January 2025 revision.

engines: EV Dual Motor AWD Long Range (346-450 hp)

Best-selling premium sedan in USA. Up to 358-mile range. High-voltage EV system requires EV-certified technicians. Data sourced from Wikipedia Tesla Model 3 article, January 2025 revision.

Compact crossover on Model 3 platform. Best-selling EV globally. Available in RWD, Long Range AWD, and Performance configurations. 75-82 kWh battery pack. 400V architecture. Over-the-air updates. Autopilot standard. High-voltage EV system requires EV-certified technicians. Data sourced from Wikipedia Tesla Model Y article, January 2025 revision.

Major refresh with new interior design (yoke steering wheel option). High-voltage systems require specialized service. Data sourced from Wikipedia Tesla Model S article, January 2025 revision.

Major refresh matching Model S updates. Falcon-wing rear doors. Plaid tri-motor produces 1,020 hp. 100 kWh battery pack. 400V architecture. Data sourced from Wikipedia Tesla Model X article, January 2025 revision.

engines: EV Dual Motor AWD Long Range (366 hp)

Best-selling EV sedan. High-voltage systems require EV-certified technicians. Data sourced from Wikipedia Tesla Model 3 article, January 2025 revision.

engines: EV Single Motor RWD (~600 hp, planned)

Bulletproof stainless steel body panels. 800V high-voltage system and unique construction require highly specialized service expertise. Class 8 electric semi-truck. Quad-motor powertrain. 500-mile range configuration. 300-mile range option. Megawatt charging capability. 0-60 mph in 20 seconds (loaded). Data sourced from Wikipedia Tesla Semi article, January 2025 revision.

High-voltage system requires certified technicians. eCVT transmission demands specialized diagnostic equipment. Discontinued in US market 2012. Data sourced from Wikipedia Lexus HS article, January 2025 revision.

Fifth-generation LS flagship sedan. Available as LS 500 (twin-turbo V6) or LS 500h (hybrid). AWD available. Advanced luxury features. Hybrid system requires specialized service. Data sourced from Wikipedia Lexus LS article, January 2025 revision.

Seventh-generation ES mid-size luxury sedan. Available as ES 350 (V6) or ES 300h (hybrid). AWD available on V6 models. Front-wheel drive based. Hybrid requires specialized service. Data sourced from Wikipedia Lexus ES article, January 2025 revision.

Third-generation IS sport sedan refresh. Available with turbo I4 or V6. RWD or AWD. F Sport variants. Compact sport sedan competing with BMW 3-Series. Data sourced from Wikipedia Lexus IS article, January 2025 revision.

Second-generation NX compact luxury crossover. Available as NX 250 (turbo), NX 350h (hybrid), or NX 450h+ (PHEV). PHEV offers 37 miles electric range. Hybrid and PHEV systems require specialized service. Data sourced from Wikipedia Lexus NX article, January 2025 revision.

Fourth-generation RX luxury crossover. Available as RX 350 (V6) or RX 450h (hybrid). Best-selling Lexus model. Three-row RX 350L variant. Hybrid requires specialized service. Data sourced from Wikipedia Lexus RX article, January 2025 revision.

High-performance RX variant. Turbo hybrid produces 366 hp. 0-60 mph in 5.9 seconds. Torque vectoring AWD. Most powerful RX ever. Performance hybrid complexity requires specialized service. Data sourced from Wikipedia Lexus RX article, January 2025 revision.

New three-row luxury crossover. Larger than RX. Available as TX 350 (turbo) or TX 500h (hybrid). Seating for up to 7. Hybrid system requires specialized service. Data sourced from Wikipedia Lexus TX article, January 2025 revision.

Second-generation GX body-on-frame luxury SUV. Based on Toyota Land Cruiser Prado. V8-only powertrain. Off-road capability. Three-row seating. Long production run. Data sourced from Wikipedia Lexus GX article, January 2025 revision.

All-new third-generation GX. Twin-turbo V6 replaces V8. Enhanced off-road capability. Body-on-frame construction. Three-row seating. Turbocharged complexity. Data sourced from Wikipedia Lexus GX article, January 2025 revision.

Fourth-generation LX flagship SUV. Based on Toyota Land Cruiser J300. Twin-turbo V6 replaces V8. Advanced off-road systems. Three-row seating for 7. Turbocharged complexity. Data sourced from Wikipedia Lexus LX article, January 2025 revision.

Grand touring luxury coupe. Available as LC 500 (V8) or LC 500h (hybrid). Convertible variant available. 0-60 mph in 4.4 seconds (V8). Stunning design. Hybrid requires specialized service. Data sourced from Wikipedia Lexus LC article, January 2025 revision.

First dedicated Lexus battery electric vehicle. 71.4 kWh battery pack. Up to 220-mile range. Dual-motor AWD. Based on e-TNGA platform. High-voltage EV system requires EV-certified technicians. Data sourced from Wikipedia Lexus RZ article, January 2025 revision.
Fourth-generation Civic. Available as sedan, hatchback, or wagon. Manual transmission available. Reliable compact car. Data sourced from Wikipedia Honda Civic article, January 2025 revision.
