Legendary roadster. 9,000 rpm redline (AP1). Manual transmission only. Rear-wheel drive. VTEC performance. Cult classic sports car. Data sourced from Wikipedia Honda S2000 article, January 2025 revision.

First Acura model and first production Honda with V6 engine. Sedan launched 1986 with 2.5L C25A (151 hp). Coupe introduced 1987 with 2.7L C27A (161 hp), later adopted by sedans. 1987 coupe was first Japanese car with driver's side airbag. Data sourced from Wikipedia Acura Legend article, January 2025 revision.

First-generation Integra launched alongside Legend in 1986 as Acura's founding models. 1.6L DOHC 16-valve engine: early 'Browntop' D16A1 (1986-1987) produced 113 hp, updated 'Blacktop' (1988-1989) produced 118 hp. Available as 3-door liftback or 4-door sedan. Data sourced from Wikipedia Acura Integra article, January 2025 revision.

First-generation TL replaced Acura Vigor. Introduced alphanumeric naming scheme. Available with 2.5L inline-5 (176 hp) or 3.2L V6 (200 hp). Data sourced from Wikipedia Acura TL article, January 2025 revision.

First-generation CL luxury coupe. I4 engines: 2.2L F22B1 (145 hp) or 2.3L F23A1 (150 hp, 1998-1999). V6: 3.0L J30A1 (200 hp). Manual transmission available on I4 models only. First Acura built in United States. Data sourced from Wikipedia Acura CL article, January 2025 revision.

First-generation RL flagship sedan launched December 1995. Longitudinally-mounted 3.5L V6 without VTEC producing 225 hp. Gradelogic transmission control. Double wishbone front and multilink rear suspension. Data sourced from Wikipedia Acura RL article, January 2025 revision.

Second-generation Legend with larger, streamlined design. Longitudinally-mounted 3.2L V6. Base: 200 hp. Type II (introduced 1993): 230 hp with 6-speed manual on coupes. Dual airbags standard from 1993. Replaced by RL nameplate in 1996. Data sourced from Wikipedia Acura Legend article, January 2025 revision.

First-generation NSX supercar with aluminum semi-monocoque construction, first in production car history. Initial 3.0L C30A (270 hp) enlarged to 3.2L C32B (290 hp) in 1997. Coupe 1990-1995, targa top from 1995. 6-speed manual introduced 1997. Mid-engine exotic layout and aluminum construction require specialized service knowledge, justifying increased difficulty modifier. Data sourced from Wikipedia Acura NSX article, January 2025 revision.

engines: 1.8L B18C5 VTEC I4 Type R (195 hp)
notes: Integra second generation (1990-1993) featured 1.8L base (130 hp) and 1.7L B17A1 VTEC GS-R (160 hp, 1992-1993). Third generation (1994-2001) offered 1.8L B18B1 base (140 hp), B18C1 VTEC GS-R (170 hp), and B18C5 VTEC Type R (195 hp, 1997-1998, 2000-2001). Type R features performance-tuned suspension, limited-slip differential. Data sourced from Wikipedia Acura Integra article, January 2025 revision.

Mid-size sedan with longitudinally-mounted 2.5L inline-5 engine producing 176 hp. Unusual inline-5 configuration for front-wheel drive layout. Replaced by TL nameplate in 1996. Data sourced from Wikipedia List of Acura vehicles article, January 2025 revision.

Fourth-generation TL introduced 2009 with larger size and aggressive styling. First TL to offer SH-AWD with 3.7L V6 (305 hp). Manual transmission available only on SH-AWD models. Data sourced from Wikipedia Acura TL article, January 2025 revision.

Third-generation TL with A-SPEC package introduced. Type-S variant features 3.5L V6 with 286 hp. Manual transmission available but limited production. Data sourced from Wikipedia Acura TL article, January 2025 revision.

Compact executive sedan based on European Honda Accord. K24A2 engine produced 200 hp (2004-2005) and 205 hp (2006-2008). i-VTEC technology provides efficient performance. Data sourced from Wikipedia Acura TSX article, January 2025 revision.

First-generation MDX three-row luxury SUV. VTM-4 all-wheel drive system. Power increased from 240 hp (2001-2002) to 260 hp (2003) to 265 hp (2004-2006). Seven-passenger seating with limited third-row space. Data sourced from Wikipedia Acura MDX article, January 2025 revision.

Second-generation MDX introduced advanced Super Handling All-Wheel Drive system. 3.7L V6 produces 300 hp at 6,000 rpm. Upgraded to 6-speed automatic in 2010. Data sourced from Wikipedia Acura MDX article, January 2025 revision.

First-generation RDX introduced July 2006. Features turbocharged 2.3L I4 producing 240 hp and 260 lb-ft torque. Available with FWD or Super Handling All-Wheel Drive. Data sourced from Wikipedia Acura RDX article, January 2025 revision.

Sport compact replacing Integra nameplate. Base model features K20A3 engine with 160 hp. K-series DOHC i-VTEC technology. Rebadged Honda Integra for North American market. Data sourced from Wikipedia Honda Integra article, January 2025 revision.

Performance variant with K20A2 engine producing 200 hp. Features 6-speed manual transmission or 5-speed automatic. Enhanced suspension and braking compared to base RSX. Data sourced from Wikipedia Honda Integra article, January 2025 revision.

Updated Type-S with revised K20Z1 engine producing 210 hp. Enhanced i-VTEC system provides improved performance. Discontinued August 2006 due to coupe market shrinkage. Data sourced from Wikipedia Honda Integra article, January 2025 revision.

Second-generation CL luxury coupe. Type-S features 260 hp J32A2 engine with performance upgrades. 6-speed manual transmission available only on 2003 Type-S with limited production. First Acura built in United States. Known automatic transmission reliability issues. Data sourced from Wikipedia Acura CL article, January 2025 revision.

First-generation NSX with 3.2L V6 (enlarged from 3.0L in 1997). Targa top configuration introduced 1995. All-aluminum semi-monocoque construction requires specialized repair knowledge. Exotic mid-engine layout complexity justifies increased difficulty modifier. Production ended 2005. Data sourced from Wikipedia Acura NSX article, January 2025 revision.

Second-generation RL flagship sedan with torque vectoring Super Handling All-Wheel Drive standard. 3.5L J35A8 (290 hp) used 2005-2008. Upgraded to 3.7L J37A2 (300 hp) in 2009, first SOHC V6 with VTEC on both intake and exhaust. Data sourced from Wikipedia Acura RL article, January 2025 revision.

Second-generation TL derived from Honda Accord platform. Type-S variant introduced with 260 hp. Upgraded to 5-speed automatic transmission in 2000. Popular mid-size luxury sedan. Data sourced from Wikipedia Acura TL article, January 2025 revision.

First-generation RL flagship sedan with longitudinally-mounted 3.5L V6 (no VTEC). Gradelogic transmission control. Double wishbone front and multilink rear suspension. Replaced by second-generation RL in 2005. Data sourced from Wikipedia Acura RL article, January 2025 revision.

First-generation TLX replaced both TSX and TL models. I4 engine FWD only with dual-clutch transmission. V6 available with FWD or Super Handling All-Wheel Drive with ZF 9-speed automatic. Data sourced from Wikipedia Acura TLX article, January 2025 revision.

Third-generation MDX with optional Sport Hybrid system featuring three electric motors (total 321 hp) and 1.3 kWh lithium-ion battery. Hybrid uses 7-speed dual-clutch with SH-AWD. Gasoline models transitioned from 6-speed to 9-speed ZF automatic in 2016. Hybrid complexity justifies increased difficulty modifier. Data sourced from Wikipedia Acura MDX article, January 2025 revision.

Third-generation RDX introduced May 2018 for 2019 model year. Features turbocharged engine with 10-speed automatic and available Super Handling All-Wheel Drive. A-Spec trim available. Data sourced from Wikipedia Acura RDX article, January 2025 revision.
Second-generation RDX switched from turbocharged I4 to naturally aspirated V6 with simplified AWD system (not SH-AWD). Data sourced from Wikipedia Acura RDX article, January 2025 revision.

Entry-level luxury sedan introduced 2013. Hybrid variant with 1.5L engine and CVT available. Only 4% of ILX sold had manual transmissions. Hybrid system justifies increased difficulty modifier. Data sourced from Wikipedia Acura ILX article, January 2025 revision.

2016 facelift standardized on 2.4L engine with 8-speed dual-clutch transmission. Discontinued manual and hybrid options. A-Spec trim introduced. Data sourced from Wikipedia Acura ILX article, January 2025 revision.

Flagship sedan with optional Sport Hybrid SH-AWD featuring three electric motors (47 hp front, two 36 hp rear) and 1.3 kWh battery, 377 hp total. FWD models upgraded to 10-speed automatic in 2018. Hybrid torque vectoring system complexity justifies increased difficulty modifier. Data sourced from Wikipedia Acura RLX article, January 2025 revision.

Second-generation NSX hybrid supercar with three electric motors and twin-turbo V6, total 573 hp. Space frame construction with aluminum and ultra-high-strength steel. High-voltage hybrid system and specialized performance components require expert-level service. Data sourced from Wikipedia Acura NSX article, January 2025 revision.

Second-generation NSX launched for 2016 model year. Hybrid supercar with three electric motors and twin-turbo V6, total 573 hp. Space frame construction with aluminum and ultra-high-strength steel. High-voltage hybrid system and specialized performance components require expert-level service. Data sourced from Wikipedia Acura NSX article, January 2025 revision.

Fourth-generation TL with larger dimensions and aggressive styling. First TL to offer SH-AWD with 3.7L V6 (305 hp). Manual transmission available only on SH-AWD models 2010-2014. Automatic upgraded to 6-speed in 2012. Replaced by TLX in 2015. Data sourced from Wikipedia Acura TL article, January 2025 revision.

Second-generation TSX with optional V6 engine starting 2010. Sport Wagon variant introduced 2011-2014. Manual transmission available with I4 engine. V6 exclusive to 5-speed automatic with paddle shifters. Replaced by TLX in 2015. Data sourced from Wikipedia Acura TSX article, January 2025 revision.

Second-generation RL final years with 3.7L SOHC V6 featuring VTEC on intake and exhaust (first Honda SOHC V6 with dual VTEC). Torque vectoring SH-AWD standard. Upgraded to 6-speed automatic in 2011. Replaced by RLX in 2014. Data sourced from Wikipedia Acura RL article, January 2025 revision.

Luxury sports coupe SUV with distinctive sloping roofline. SH-AWD standard. Low sales led to discontinuation after 2013. Nameplate revived as EV in 2024. Data sourced from Wikipedia Acura ZDX article, January 2025 revision.

engines: 3.0L J30AC turbocharged V6 Type S (355 hp)
notes: Second-generation TLX features turbocharged engines and available Super Handling All-Wheel Drive. Type S variant exclusive to SH-AWD with performance-tuned suspension, Brembo brakes, and active exhaust. Production ended July 2025. Data sourced from Wikipedia Acura TLX article, January 2025 revision.

Fourth-generation MDX offers three-row seating for seven passengers. Type S variant features turbocharged V6 with performance enhancements. No hybrid option in this generation. Data sourced from Wikipedia Acura MDX article, January 2025 revision.

Third-generation RDX features turbocharged engine with available Super Handling All-Wheel Drive. A-Spec and PMC Edition trims available. Data sourced from Wikipedia Acura RDX article, January 2025 revision.

Integra nameplate revival after 21-year hiatus. Based on Honda Civic platform. Available with manual transmission or CVT. A-Spec trim features sportier styling. Data sourced from Wikipedia Acura Integra article, January 2025 revision.

engines: Electric motor (358 hp RWD, 490 hp AWD, 500 hp Type S)
notes: All-electric ZDX built on GM Ultium BEV3 platform with 102 kWh battery. EPA range 278-313 miles. Supports up to 190 kW DC fast charging. High-voltage EV system requires certified technicians. Type S variant offers 500 hp. Production ending September 2025. Data sourced from Wikipedia Acura ZDX article, January 2025 revision.

New subcompact luxury crossover sharing platform with Honda HR-V and ZR-V. Entry-level Acura SUV positioned below RDX. Data sourced from Wikipedia List of Acura vehicles article, January 2025 revision.

Flagship sedan discontinued June 2020. Sport Hybrid SH-AWD features three electric motors (47 hp front, two 36 hp rear for torque vectoring) with 1.3 kWh lithium-ion battery, total system output 377 hp. Hybrid system complexity justifies increased difficulty modifier. Data sourced from Wikipedia Acura RLX article, January 2025 revision.

Entry-level luxury sedan discontinued February 2022, replaced by Integra. A-Spec trim with 18-inch wheels and sporty design. AcuraWatch safety features standard. Data sourced from Wikipedia Acura ILX article, January 2025 revision.

engines: 3.5L twin-turbocharged V6 hybrid (573 hp, 602 hp Type S)
notes: Hybrid supercar with three electric motors and twin-turbo V6, total output 573 hp (602 hp for Type S). Space frame construction using aluminum and ultra-high-strength steel. High-voltage hybrid system and specialized performance components require expert-level service. NSX Type S limited production (300 US units). Production ended 2022. Data sourced from Wikipedia Acura NSX article, January 2025 revision.

Early export Datsun Type 11/12 models used a 495 cc side-valve engine with three-speed manual and lightweight bodywork; pre-war parts scarcity, mechanical brakes, and hand-built components make preservation highly specialized, warranting a 1.3 difficulty. Data sourced from Wikipedia Datsun Type 11 article, October 7, 2025 revision.

The Datsun Type 13 expanded engine displacement to 722 cc and introduced multiple body styles; hand-formed panels, cable brakes, and 6-volt electrics demand specialist knowledge, keeping difficulty at 1.3. Data sourced from Wikipedia Datsun Type 11 article, October 7, 2025 revision.

The Datsun 15/16 roadsters offered export-friendly styling with fold-down windscreens and tonneau covers, powered by 722 cc engines and 3-speed manuals; convertible tops, manual brakes, and limited production increase restoration complexity to 1.3. Data sourced from Wikipedia Datsun Sports article, October 9, 2025 revision.

The Datsun Type 17 truck updated the earlier 13T with rounded fenders and the 722 cc engine paired to a 3-speed manual, offering light commercial capability; mechanical brakes and wood-framed beds require careful craftsmanship, maintaining a 1.3 difficulty. Data sourced from Wikipedia Datsun Truck article, October 9, 2025 revision.

Postwar Datsun 1121 passenger cars reintroduced exports with a 0.9L side-valve four, 3-speed manual, and simple ladder frame; sourcing components and adapting to 6-volt electrics and mechanical brakes increase restoration difficulty to 1.3. Data sourced from Wikipedia Datsun 1121 article, October 8, 2025 revision.

The Datsun 212/312 cabover trucks resumed light commercial exports with a 1.0L Type C engine, 4-speed manual, and payloads around 1,000 kg; mechanical brakes, left-hand drive conversion, and limited documentation require specialized restoration skills, earning a 1.3 rating. Data sourced from Wikipedia Datsun Truck article, October 9, 2025 revision.

The 5147 truck expanded payload and wheelbase over the 212 series while retaining the Type C engine and 4-speed transmission; cabover service, mechanical brakes, and wood-and-steel bed construction increase complexity for modern technicians, warranting a 1.3 difficulty. Data sourced from Wikipedia Datsun Truck article, October 9, 2025 revision.

The first U.S.-market Datsun passenger car, the PL210 arrived in 1958 with a 988 cc E-series engine (34 hp), column-shift 4-speed manual, and 12-volt electrics—requiring scarce parts and careful valve adjustments, so vintage microcar complexity sets difficulty at 1.2. Data sourced from Wikipedia Datsun 210 article, October 9, 2025 revision.

The Datsun 113/114 sedans improved on the 110 with a slightly larger C-series OHV four and full synchromesh transmission, imported in small volumes to North America; fragile trim and limited documentation require specialty restoration skills, keeping difficulty at 1.2. Data sourced from Wikipedia Datsun 1000 article, October 8, 2025 revision.

The 220 and improved 223 Datsun pickups established Nissan’s U.S. truck presence with E-series inline-fours, column-shift 4-speeds, and 1-ton payload ratings; vintage drum brakes and scarce drivetrain parts increase service difficulty to 1.2. Data sourced from Wikipedia Datsun truck article, October 9, 2025 revision.

The limited-run Datsun Sports DC-3 roadster reached select U.S. dealers in 1959 with a 1.0L C-series engine and 4-speed manual; hand-built bodywork, cable-operated brakes, and extremely limited parts push difficulty to 1.3. Data sourced from Wikipedia Datsun Sports article, October 9, 2025 revision.

Early U.S. Patrol shipments in 1959 featured the P40 inline-six, 4-speed manual, and part-time 4WD; heavy-duty leaf springs, drum brakes, and minimal documentation elevate service difficulty to 1.3. Data sourced from Wikipedia Nissan Patrol article, October 11, 2025 revision.

Datsun Fairlady roadsters (SP/SR) sold in the U.S. from 1961 to 1970 with OHV and SOHC inline-fours culminating in the 2.0L U20 with dual SU carbs and a 5-speed manual; SU carb tuning, manual soft tops, and limited parts availability raise the difficulty to 1.2. Data sourced from Wikipedia Datsun Fairlady article, October 9, 2025 revision.

The mid-1960s Bluebird 410/411 (Datsun 410/411) introduced more refined styling, J13 engines, and optional Borg-Warner automatic transmission along with MacPherson strut front suspension; scarcity of parts and carburetor tuning challenges justify a 1.1 difficulty. Data sourced from Wikipedia Nissan Bluebird article, October 10, 2025 revision.

Limited North American imports of the Cedric 130 (Custom 6/2000) featured 2.0L H20 or J20 engines, column-shift automatics, and luxury appointments; sourcing parts and service literature for this executive sedan raises difficulty to 1.2. Data sourced from Wikipedia Nissan Cedric article, October 12, 2025 revision.

The hand-built CSP311 Silvia used the Fairlady’s 1.6L R16 and 4-speed manual on a Bluebird chassis, with only a few dozen reaching North America through special order. Handmade body panels and scarce trim significantly increase restoration complexity, setting difficulty at 1.2. Data sourced from Wikipedia Nissan Silvia article, October 8, 2025 revision.

The Patrol 60 series sold in the U.S. (1962-1969) with a 4.0L P40 inline-six, 4-speed manual, and part-time 4WD; its heavy-duty leaf-spring chassis, drum brakes, and scarce U.S. parts network increase service difficulty to 1.2. Data sourced from Wikipedia Nissan Patrol article, October 11, 2025 revision.

While officially limited to Japan, a handful of C10 Skyline and GT-R models entered North America via racing and private import in 1969-1970, carrying the S20 DOHC triple-carb engine and four-wheel disc brakes. Exotic drivetrain components and gray-market compliance drive the difficulty to 1.3. Data sourced from Wikipedia Nissan Skyline article, October 12, 2025 revision.

engines: 2.4L L24 I6 (151 hp SAE gross, 151 hp net 1972)
notes: The S30 Z-line began in the U.S. with the 240Z (L24), evolving to the 260Z (L26) in 1974 and fuel-injected 280Z (L28E) for 1975-1978 with optional 5-speed manuals, 3-speed automatics, and dealer-installed air conditioning; later cars offered 2+2 seating. Carburetor synchronization (240Z/260Z), aging EFI, and emissions retrofits make service more involved than a typical classic coupe, warranting a 1.1 difficulty modifier. Data sourced from Wikipedia Nissan S30 article, October 11, 2025 revision.

The Datsun 510 (PL510) used the 1.6L L16 with independent rear suspension and available automatic transmission, becoming popular for SCCA racing; its vintage carburetion, emissions retrofits, and rust-prone body require skilled restoration work, justifying a 1.1 difficulty. Data sourced from Wikipedia Datsun 510 article, October 12, 2025 revision.

Successor Bluebird U models (610/710) sold as Datsun 610/710 in the U.S. with L18/L20B inline-fours, four-speed manuals, and available Borg-Warner automatics; MacPherson strut front suspension and conventional driveline keep service straightforward, so difficulty remains 1.0. Data sourced from Wikipedia Datsun 610 article, October 10, 2025 revision.

The Datsun B210 (Sunny) targeted fuel economy with A-series engines, manual transmissions, and light curb weight; emissions-era carburetion remains simple to service, so difficulty stays at 1.0. Data sourced from Wikipedia Datsun Sunny article, October 9, 2025 revision.

The S10 200SX (sold as Datsun 200SX) used the L20B with 5-speed manual availability, rear-wheel drive, and both fastback and notchback body styles; mechanical simplicity keeps difficulty at 1.0. Data sourced from Wikipedia Nissan Silvia article, October 8, 2025 revision.

The Datsun 620 compact pickup offered L16/L18/L20B engines, choice of manual or automatic transmissions, and long-bed or King Cab configurations, remaining mechanically simple with carbureted inline-fours. Data sourced from Wikipedia Datsun Truck article, October 9, 2025 revision.

Limited U.S. availability of the compact Vanette (C20) brought sliding doors, configurable seating, and carbureted four-cylinders; mechanical layout is simple, so difficulty remains 1.0. Data sourced from Wikipedia Nissan Vanette article, October 7, 2025 revision.

The S130 280ZX combined grand-touring features (power steering, available T-tops, digital dashboards) with the L28E inline-six and, from 1981, an optional turbocharged L28ET (180 hp) paired with close-ratio manual or 4-speed automatic transmissions. Aging turbo hardware, early electronic fuel injection, and removable roof seals increase service complexity over a basic coupe, supporting a 1.1 modifier. Data sourced from Wikipedia Nissan S130 article, October 11, 2025 revision.

The Z31 300ZX introduced Nissan’s VG-series V6 to North America, offering naturally aspirated and turbo variants (200 hp) plus digital dash instrumentation, T-top roofs, and 2+2 seating options; Shiro Special and 50th Anniversary editions added adjustable dampers and body kits. Turbocharging and aging electronics elevate service complexity to 1.1. Data sourced from Wikipedia Nissan 300ZX article, October 10, 2025 revision.

The first U.S.-market Sentra (B11) switched to front-wheel drive with E-series 1.5L and 1.6L engines, manual or automatic transmissions, and multiple body styles; its simple carbureted/early EFI driveline makes service straightforward. Data sourced from Wikipedia Nissan Sentra article, October 14, 2025 revision.

The B12 Sentra offered multiport fuel-injected GA16DE engines, roomier interiors, and SE turbos with 1.8L engines and sport suspension plus four-wheel discs; these performance variants add service steps beyond the base GA16i commuter, meriting a 1.1 difficulty. Data sourced from Wikipedia Nissan Sentra article, October 14, 2025 revision.

The U11 Maxima moved to front-wheel drive for 1985 with a 157 hp VG30E, voice warning system, digital dash on GXE, and optional Sonar Suspension and Bose audio, yet the drivetrain remains conventional for a mid-1980s sedan. Data sourced from Wikipedia Nissan Maxima article, October 14, 2025 revision.

The second-generation Stanza (T11) offered sedan and wagon variants with the CA20E and either 5-speed manual or 4-speed automatic transmissions; adjustable air suspension was optional on wagons, but overall service remains simple, keeping difficulty at 1.0. Data sourced from Wikipedia Nissan Stanza article, October 7, 2025 revision.

The Pulsar NX (N13) for North America featured removable SportBak wagon or standard coupe hatch modules, GA16-series engines, and optional CA18DE on SE models with four-wheel disc brakes. Modular body panels, pop-up headlights, and optional performance hardware add service complexity, earning a 1.1 difficulty modifier. Data sourced from Wikipedia Nissan Pulsar NX article, October 6, 2025 revision.

The original WD21 Pathfinder combined a two-door (later four-door) SUV body with a ladder frame, part-time 4WD, optional limited-slip rear differential, and VG30E V6 (153 hp) plus torsion-bar front suspension. Rust-prone frames, timing belt service, and 4WD drivetrain upkeep justify a 1.2 difficulty modifier. Data sourced from Wikipedia Nissan Pathfinder article, October 14, 2025 revision.

The D21 Hardbody pickup offered 2WD and 4WD configurations with Z24i/KA24E four-cylinders or VG30E V6, torsion-bar front suspension, and available limited-slip differential and off-road packages; long production runs mean corrosion and frame inspections are routine, pushing difficulty to 1.1. Data sourced from Wikipedia Nissan Navara article, October 11, 2025 revision.

North American S12 200SX models included CA20E and CA18ET engines with turbocharged options, while later SE models gained the VG30E V6 and IRS rear suspension. Turbo plumbing, pop-up headlights, and V6 packaging increase service complexity versus the base coupe, supporting a 1.1 modifier. Data sourced from Wikipedia Nissan 200SX (S12) article, October 8, 2025 revision.

Imported for the 1990 model year, the Nissan Axxess (Prairie) offered sliding rear doors, configurable seating, and the KA24E with manual or automatic transmissions; its minivan-like packaging but simple drivetrain keep difficulty at 1.0. Data sourced from Wikipedia Nissan Prairie article, October 6, 2025 revision.

The Z32 300ZX arrived in the U.S. for 1990 featuring a 222 hp naturally aspirated VG30DE or a 300 hp VG30DETT twin-turbo with dual intercoolers, four-wheel steering (HICAS), aluminum suspension components, and available removable T-tops; 2+2 models extended the wheelbase while the SMZ special edition offered dealer-installed Stillen performance upgrades. Twin-turbo plumbing, HICAS rear steering hydraulics, and timing belt service complexity warrant the 1.2 difficulty modifier. Data sourced from Wikipedia Nissan 300ZX article, October 10, 2025 revision.

Fourth-generation Sentra (B13) sold in the U.S. from 1991 with the GA16DE (110 hp) and optional 4-speed automatic, while the SE-R added a 140 hp SR20DE, viscous limited-slip differential, sport suspension, and four-wheel disc brakes—performance hardware justifying a 1.1 difficulty rating despite the compact platform. Data sourced from Wikipedia Nissan Sentra article, October 14, 2025 revision.

Fifth-generation Sentra (B14) arrived for 1995 on a lighter platform with a 115 hp GA16DE and available 4-speed automatic, while the SE-R retained the 140 hp SR20DE with viscous limited-slip diff and sport suspension. Safety revisions added dual airbags and optional ABS, so performance trim components continue to raise complexity to 1.1. Data sourced from Wikipedia Nissan Sentra article, October 14, 2025 revision.

First-generation Altima (U13) replaced the Stanza for 1993 with a 150 hp KA24DE, manual or automatic transmission, and raised-roof four-door sports car styling, adding optional ABS and leather on SE/GXE trims while retaining conventional service characteristics. Data sourced from Wikipedia Nissan Altima article, October 13, 2025 revision.

Fourth- and fifth-generation Maxima (A32 1995–1999, early A33 2000) continued the 4-Door Sports Car formula with the 190 hp VQ30DE, manual or automatic transmission, and multi-link beam rear suspension; 1997+ models added side airbags and minor styling updates but remain conventional to service for a midsize V6 sedan. Data sourced from Wikipedia Nissan Maxima article, October 14, 2025 revision.

North American 240SX models used the KA24E/KA24DE 2.4L engines with five-speed manual or four-speed automatic transmissions, multi-link rear suspension, and optional limited-slip differential or HICAS rear steering on SE trims plus an ASC-built convertible. Sport suspension tuning and performance add-ons increase alignment and driveline service complexity, supporting a 1.1 difficulty modifier. Data sourced from Wikipedia Nissan 240SX article, October 8, 2025 revision.

Second-generation Pathfinder (R50) adopted unibody construction with a 168 hp VG33E V6, part-time 4WD system with auto hubs, and optional rear air leveling; a 240 hp VQ35DE with All-Mode automatic AWD arrived for 2001 along with higher tow ratings. Mixed driveline systems and timing belt/chain service elevate complexity to 1.1. Data sourced from Wikipedia Nissan Pathfinder article, October 14, 2025 revision.

North American Frontier (D22) arrived for 1998 with the KA24DE and later VG33E V6, five-speed manual or four-speed automatic, optional 4WD, and the first compact Crew Cab pickup in the market; Desert Runner and PRO-4X packages added off-road shocks, skid plates, and limited-slip differentials. Added off-road hardware increases service complexity to 1.1. Data sourced from Wikipedia Nissan Frontier article, October 6, 2025 revision.

The first-generation Quest shared the Ford TN platform with the Mercury Villager, using the 151 hp VG30E V6, 4-speed automatic, and optional rear air suspension and dual sliding doors. Shared components and conventional systems keep difficulty at 1.0. Data sourced from Wikipedia Nissan Quest article, October 14, 2025 revision.

The first-generation Xterra launched for the 2000 model year with body-on-frame construction, washable interior, roof basket, and choice of KA24DE inline-four or VG33E V6 (plus VG33ER supercharged from 2002) with manual or automatic gearboxes and part-time 4WD. Supercharged cooling needs, off-road suspension, and accessory roof hardware increase complexity to 1.2. Data sourced from Wikipedia Nissan Xterra article, October 13, 2025 revision.

Federalized Skyline GT-R R32 imports legalized by Motorex in the late 1990s brought the RB26DETT (276 hp) with ATTESA E-TS AWD and Super-HICAS rear steering to a limited U.S. customer base under show-and-display exemptions; specialized twin-turbo AWD systems and grey-market compliance requirements justify a 1.3 difficulty modifier. Data sourced from Wikipedia Nissan Skyline GT-R article, October 12, 2025 revision.

Fifth-generation Z-car uses the FM platform with the VQ35DE V6 (287–300 hp) before the 2007-up VQ35HR update (306 hp), paired with either the FS6R31A 6-speed or RE5R05A 5-speed automatic. Track models added Brembo brakes, forged wheels, and viscous limited-slip differential, while all cars feature aluminum hood, doors, and hatch plus front-mid engine packaging—higher-performance hardware that calls for specialty brake bleeding and driveline service beyond a typical coupe. Data sourced from Wikipedia Nissan 350Z article, September 22, 2024 revision.

engines: 3.7L VQ37VHR V6 Nismo tune (350 hp, 276 lb⋅ft)
notes: The initial Z34 370Z launched for 2009 with the 332 hp VQ37VHR V6, a carbon-fiber composite driveshaft, standard viscous limited-slip differential on manual cars, and the first production use of SynchroRev Match rev-matching on a 6-speed manual; a 7-speed automatic with paddle shift and downshift rev matching was optional. The 2010 model year added the power soft-top Roadster and the Nismo performance variant tuned to 350 hp with chassis bracing and larger brakes, raising service complexity to 1.2. Data sourced from Wikipedia Nissan 370Z article, October 5, 2025 revision.

Fourth-generation Altima rode on Nissan’s FF-L platform with a 112.2 in wheelbase, offering the QR25DE four-cylinder (175 hp) or VQ35DE V6 (240 hp, 260 hp in 2005–2006 SE-R) paired to 5-speed manual, 4-speed automatic, or 5-speed automatic gearboxes. Higher trims added sport suspension, larger brakes, and stability control while retaining conventional service procedures appropriate for a midsize sedan. Data sourced from Wikipedia Nissan Altima article, October 13, 2025 revision.

engines: 2.5L QR25DE hybrid + electric motor (198 hp net)
notes: Fifth-generation Altima moved to Nissan’s D platform with an aluminum hood and decklid, standard keyless start, and availability of a 2.5L hybrid (shared Toyota hybrid system) rated at 198 hp combined alongside the QR25DE four-cylinder and 270 hp VQ35DE V6. A 6-speed manual remained on base sedans and 3.5 SE/SR with sport suspension, while the volume trims adopted the Xtronic CVT; the 2008 coupe introduced a shorter wheelbase and unique bodywork. Hybrid high-voltage systems and CVT service elevate complexity to 1.1. Data sourced from Wikipedia Nissan Altima article, October 13, 2025 revision.

The B15 Sentra (2000–2006) used Nissan’s MS platform and introduced the 1.8L QG18DE with 5-speed manual or 4-speed automatic, while the SE-R returned in 2002 with a QR25DE (165 hp) and the Spec V increased output to 175 hp with a close-ratio 6-speed manual, helical limited-slip differential, stiffer springs, and optional Brembo front brakes. Performance hardware and the larger QR25DE require more specialized brake and driveline service than base models, supporting a 1.1 difficulty modifier. Data sourced from Wikipedia Nissan Sentra article, October 14, 2025 revision.

engines: 2.5L QR25DE I4 (177 hp SE-R, 200 hp Spec V)
notes: The B16 Sentra adopted Nissan’s new C platform for 2007 with a larger cabin, standard keyless ignition, and the MR20DE (140 hp) paired to a 6-speed manual or Xtronic CVT. SE-R models used a 177 hp QR25DE and sport-tuned suspension, while the SE-R Spec V received a 200 hp tune, close-ratio 6-speed, helical limited-slip differential, and performance brakes, leading to higher maintenance complexity than the base sedan. Data sourced from Wikipedia Nissan Sentra article, October 14, 2025 revision.

Sixth-generation Maxima (A34) shared the FF-L architecture with Altima but positioned as a performance sedan—offering the 3.5L VQ35DE V6 (265 hp, later 255 hp), standard independent multi-link rear suspension, and available 6-speed manual on SE models plus optional SkyView roof and Xenon HID lighting. Service remains conventional aside from the sport-oriented suspension tuning. Data sourced from Wikipedia Nissan Maxima article, October 14, 2025 revision.

Seventh-generation Maxima (A35) debuted for 2009 with a stiffer "super 4-Door Sports Car" chassis, 290 hp VQ35DE, and a standard Xtronic CVT featuring a manual shift mode plus Drive Mode Selector for sport tuning. Standard Vehicle Dynamic Control, paddle shifters on premium trims, and dual-panel panoramic moonroof increase calibration and interior service effort, earning a 1.1 difficulty modifier. Data sourced from Wikipedia Nissan Maxima article, October 14, 2025 revision.

First-generation Murano (Z50) introduced Nissan’s high-capacity Xtronic CVT paired with the 245 hp VQ35DE V6, optional all-wheel drive, and a fully independent suspension, combining minivan practicality with sport-sedan tuning. The CVT’s high-torque application and electronic AWD coupling increase service demands relative to conventional automatics. Data sourced from Wikipedia Nissan Murano article, October 14, 2025 revision.

Second-generation Murano (Z51) launched for 2009 with a refined Xtronic CVT, 265 hp VQ35DE, available Intelligent AWD, and features like the dual-panel "SkyView" roof, Bose audio, and Around View Monitor (2011). Expanded electronics and the carryover high-torque CVT keep service complexity at 1.1. Data sourced from Wikipedia Nissan Murano article, October 14, 2025 revision.

First-generation Armada rode on the F-Alpha platform shared with the Titan, using a 5.6L VK56DE V8 (305 hp early, 317 hp from 2008) and RE5R05A 5-speed automatic with optional All-Mode 4WD, independent rear suspension, available auto-leveling rear air suspension, and towing capacity up to 9,100 lb. The combination of heavy-duty tow equipment and rear air leveling increases service complexity versus a standard SUV, supporting a 1.1 difficulty modifier. Data sourced from Wikipedia Nissan Armada article, October 14, 2025 revision.

The original Titan A60 full-size pickup launched for 2004 with the 5.6L VK56DE (305 hp, 317 hp from 2008) and RE5R05A 5-speed automatic, riding on the F-Alpha chassis with fully boxed frame, Dana 44 rear axle, and available off-road FOR package (Rancho shocks, skid plates, electronic locking rear differential). Utili-track adjustable bed channels and high tow ratings require additional setup and specialized driveline service versus a standard half-ton, supporting a 1.1 difficulty modifier. Data sourced from Wikipedia Nissan Titan article, October 14, 2025 revision.

Third-generation Frontier (D40) for North America debuted for 2005 on the F-Alpha chassis with the 261 hp 4.0L VQ40DE V6 (standard from 2015) or 2.5L QR25DE four-cylinder, in King Cab or Crew Cab configurations with 2WD or 4WD. PRO-4X models added Bilstein off-road dampers, skid plates, and an electronic locking rear differential, while the long lifespan means technicians encounter corrosion and frame-rust inspections on older trucks—factors elevating service complexity to 1.1. Data sourced from Wikipedia Nissan Frontier article, October 6, 2025 revision.

The third-generation Quest minivan (V42) built in Canton, Mississippi, used the 3.5L VQ35DE V6 (240 hp, later 253 hp) with a 5-speed automatic, available power sliding doors and tailgate, and optional full-length SkyView glass roof panels plus fold-flat third-row seating. Servicing the power door modules and panoramic glass drains requires more care than a conventional minivan, warranting a 1.1 difficulty. Data sourced from Wikipedia Nissan Quest article, October 14, 2025 revision.

North American Versa hatchbacks correspond to the C11 Tiida, using the 1.8L MR18DE (122 hp) with standard 6-speed manual, optional 4-speed automatic, or Xtronic CVT, 60/40 split folding rear seats, and available Intelligent Key/keyless start—remaining straightforward to service as a subcompact hatchback. Data sourced from Wikipedia Nissan Tiida article, October 5, 2025 revision.

The first-generation Rogue (S35) launched for the 2008 model year with the 170 hp QR25DE and Xtronic CVT, available Intelligent All-Wheel Drive, and an optional paddle-shift manual mode; 2011 brought an S35 refresh with sport mode for the CVT, navigation, and Around View Monitor, while 2013 added NissanConnect telematics. The CVT and AWD coupling require specialized service beyond a conventional compact crossover, justifying a 1.1 difficulty. Data sourced from Wikipedia Nissan Rogue article, October 14, 2025 revision.

North American GT-R sales began for 2009 with the hand-built VR38DETT twin-turbo V6 (480 hp, raised to 530 hp for 2011) feeding a rear-mounted GR6 dual-clutch transaxle and ATTESA E-TS all-wheel-drive system. Launch Control, Brembo monoblock brakes, and large composite rotors demand specialized diagnostics, fluid service, and torque procedures beyond standard sports cars, justifying a 1.2 difficulty. Data sourced from Wikipedia Nissan GT-R article, October 14, 2025 revision.

The third-generation Cube (Z12) arrived in the U.S. for 2009 with the MR18DE (122 hp) driving the front wheels via 6-speed manual or Xtronic CVT, featuring asymmetrical wrap-around rear glass, lounge-inspired interior with shag dashboard insert, and available Intelligent Key with 20-color ambient lighting. Mechanical content mirrors the Versa hatchback, keeping service straightforward. Data sourced from Wikipedia Nissan Cube article, October 6, 2025 revision.

The NV full-size van family (NV1500/2500/3500) arrived for 2012 on an F-Alpha-derived frame with 261 hp VQ40DE V6 or 317 hp VK56DE V8, five-speed automatic, and a tall roof option offering 76.9 inches of interior height plus configurations for cargo or 12-passenger seating. Commercial duty cycles, ladder frame service, and high-roof panel repairs increase complexity versus a typical consumer van, justifying a 1.1 difficulty modifier. Data sourced from Wikipedia Nissan NV (North America) article, October 5, 2025 revision.

Fifth-generation Altima for North America debuted for the 2013 model year with 2.5L QR25DE or 3.5L VQ35DE power, an Xtronic CVT, and extensive use of high-strength steel that shed about 120 lb versus the prior L32 while retaining the mid-size footprint. NASA-inspired "zero gravity" front seats introduced with this generation reduce fatigue on longer drives, and the 2016 facelift added the SR trim with sport tuning and updated fascias. Data sourced from Wikipedia Nissan Altima article, October 13, 2025 revision.

engines: 1.6L MR16DDT turbo I4 (188 hp, 177 lb⋅ft) – SR Turbo/NISMO
notes: North America’s seventh-generation Sentra (B17) launched for 2013 with the 1.8L MRA8DE four-cylinder (130 hp) and either a 6-speed manual on base trims or Xtronic CVT, while the 2014 update added NissanConnect with smartphone integration and the 2016 facelift brought LED headlights, a D-shaped steering wheel, and an SR sport trim. For 2017 the SR Turbo and NISMO models introduced the 1.6L MR16DDT turbo (188 hp) with performance chassis tuning, adding turbocharger service and calibration needs that raise the difficulty to 1.1. Data sourced from Wikipedia Nissan Sentra article, October 14, 2025 revision.

Second-generation Versa sedan for North America (N17) arrived for the 2012 model year with the 1.6L HR16DE four-cylinder (109 hp) paired to a 5-speed manual standard, optional 4-speed automatic on S, or an Xtronic CVT on higher trims; it continued through 2019 with updates such as the 2015 fascia redesign and the 2018 addition of a standard 7-inch infotainment display, rearview monitor, and Bluetooth hands-free messaging. Data sourced from Wikipedia Nissan Almera/Nissan Versa (N17) article, October 14, 2025 revision.

transmissions: Xtronic CVT with D-Step shift logic
notes: Eighth-generation Maxima (A36) arrived for 2016 with the 300 hp 3.5L VQ35DE and an updated Xtronic CVT using D-Step logic, plus a stiffer body with structural adhesives and Integrated Dynamics-control Module systems such as Active Ride and Active Trace Control. The 2019 refresh sharpened the exterior, and the 2020 update made Nissan Safety Shield 360 standard—so radar/camera calibration elevates difficulty to 1.1. Data sourced from Wikipedia Nissan Maxima article, October 14, 2025 revision.

engines: EM61 80 kW electric motor (107 hp, 207 lb⋅ft)
notes: First-generation Leaf (ZE0) launched in the U.S. for 2011 with an 80 kW (107 hp) EM61 motor driving the front axle through a single-speed reduction gear and a 24 kWh lithium-ion battery (EPA range 73 mi), later offering a 6.6 kW onboard charger for 2013 and a 30 kWh pack in 2016 that raised EPA range to 107 miles. High-voltage battery service procedures, thermal management, and CHAdeMO fast-charge diagnostics justify the 1.4 difficulty rating. Data sourced from Wikipedia Nissan Leaf article, October 14, 2025 revision.

engines: 1.6L MR16DDT turbo I4 NISMO (197 hp manual / 193 hp CVT)
1.6L MR16DDT turbo I4 NISMO RS (215 hp manual / 211 hp CVT)
transmissions: Xtronic CVT with S-mode and manual shift logic
notes: North American Juke (F15) arrived for 2011 with a direct-injected, turbocharged 1.6L MR16DDT (188 hp) tied to either a 6-speed manual on FWD trims or an Xtronic CVT with S-mode; AWD models used Nissan’s torque-vectoring I-AWD system with rear drive module, and NISMO/NISMO RS trims increased output up to 215 hp with enhanced brakes and Recaro seating. The combination of turbocharging, torque-vectoring AWD hardware, and performance NISMO calibrations elevates service complexity to a 1.2 difficulty. Data sourced from Wikipedia Nissan Juke article, October 9, 2025 revision.

Third-generation Murano (Z52) went on sale in North America for 2015 with the carryover 3.5L VQ35DE (260 hp) and Xtronic CVT, NASA-inspired zero-gravity seating, and an available panoramic roof, while offering optional all-wheel drive. The 2019 refresh introduced Safety Shield 360 with automatic emergency braking, rear automatic braking, blind-spot warning, and rear cross-traffic alert, increasing post-repair calibration needs enough to warrant a 1.1 difficulty rating. Data sourced from Wikipedia Nissan Murano article, October 14, 2025 revision.

engines: 3.5L VQ35DD direct-injected V6 (284 hp, 259 lb⋅ft) – 2017 refresh
2.5L QR25DER supercharged hybrid I4 + 15 kW motor (net 250 hp) – 2014-2015
notes: Fourth-generation Pathfinder (R52) returned to unibody construction for 2013 on Nissan’s D platform with a 260 hp VQ35DE V6 and Xtronic CVT, offered in front- or all-wheel drive and optional 2.5L QR25DER supercharged hybrid system (net 250 hp) for 2014–2015. The 2017 refresh added direct injection to the V6 (284 hp) plus motion-activated liftgate, stronger towing, and expanded driver assists, so technicians must handle hybrid service procedures and CVT cooling requirements—supporting the 1.1 difficulty. Data sourced from Wikipedia Nissan Pathfinder article, October 14, 2025 revision.

engines: 2.0L MR20DD I4 hybrid with 30 kW motor (176 hp net) – 2017-2019
notes: Second-generation Rogue (T32) launched in North America for 2014 with the 170 hp QR25DE, seating for five or an optional third row, and an updated Xtronic CVT with Sport and Eco modes; 2017 brought a hybrid using the 2.0L MR20DD with a 30 kW motor (176 hp net) plus a freshened exterior. Rogue adopted Nissan Safety Shield technologies—including forward emergency braking with pedestrian detection and lane departure prevention—along with ProPILOT Assist availability for 2018, driving up ADAS calibration requirements and justifying a 1.1 difficulty. Data sourced from Wikipedia Nissan Rogue article, October 14, 2025 revision.

engines: 5.0L Cummins ISV diesel V8 (310 hp, 555 lb⋅ft) – Titan XD
notes: Second-generation Titan entered the 2016 model year with a fully boxed frame, standard 390 hp VK56VD V8 and 7-speed automatic, while the Titan XD added a 5.0L Cummins turbodiesel (310 hp/555 lb⋅ft) with an Aisin 6-speed gearbox, longer 151.6 in wheelbase, and heavy-duty cooling/towing hardware. PRO-4X trims layered Bilstein shocks, electronic locking rear differential, and skid plates. The mix of gasoline and diesel powertrains, HD tow ratings, and chassis-specific service procedures justify a 1.2 difficulty. North American NV200 cargo van production started in 2013 with a 2.0L MR20DE (131 hp) driving the front wheels through an Xtronic CVT, 122.7 in wheelbase, and 122.7 cu ft cargo volume accessible by dual sliding doors and 40/60 split rear doors. Nissan also built an NV200 Taxi variant for New York City featuring a panoramic roof panel, antimicrobial vinyl, and wheelchair ramp provisions—service considerations include fleet telematics wiring and taxi-specific HVAC filters. Data sourced from Wikipedia Nissan NV200 article, October 10, 2025 revision.

The Kicks subcompact crossover entered the U.S. and Canada for the 2018 model year with a 1.6L HR16DE four-cylinder (125 hp) and Xtronic CVT driving the front wheels. SV and SR trims added standard 7-inch infotainment with Apple CarPlay/Android Auto, Intelligent Cruise Control, and the optional Bose Personal Plus headrest speakers, while all models include Automatic Emergency Braking—yet overall service demands remain conventional, keeping difficulty at 1.0. Data sourced from Wikipedia Nissan Kicks article, October 14, 2025 revision.

The U.S.-market Rogue Sport (rebadged Qashqai J11) arrived for 2017 with a 2.0L MR20DD (141 hp) and Xtronic CVT, offering front- or all-wheel drive, 61.1 cu ft of cargo space with seats folded, and Safety Shield technologies such as Forward Emergency Braking, blind-spot warning, and rear cross-traffic alert. The 2019 refresh added standard Safety Shield 360 and ProPILOT Assist availability, requiring ADAS calibrations that push service difficulty to 1.1. Data sourced from Wikipedia Nissan Rogue Sport article, October 10, 2025 revision.

engines: 3.8L VR38DETT twin-turbo V6 (565 hp GT-R Premium)
3.8L VR38DETT twin-turbo V6 (600 hp Nismo/Track Edition)

For 2020 Nissan added new turbochargers that improve response, a Track Edition with carbon-fiber roof, and the 50th Anniversary package. The high-output twin-turbo AWD driveline and motorsport-grade hardware justify a 1.2 difficulty. Data sourced from Wikipedia Nissan GT-R article, October 14, 2025 revision.

engines: 2.5L PR25DD I4 (188 hp FWD, 182 hp AWD)

ProPILOT Assist bundles lane centering with radar adaptive cruise and automated braking, and NHTSA opened a 13 December 2023 probe into potential bearing failures for the KR20DDET used on the Altima—factors that elevate diagnostic complexity above a standard midsize sedan and justify the 1.1 difficulty modifier. B18 Sentra for North America launched for 2020 with a standard 2.0L MR20DD four-cylinder (149 hp, 146 lb⋅ft) paired exclusively to the Xtronic CVT, multi-link rear suspension, and standard Nissan Safety Shield 360 driver-assist suite with automated emergency braking, blind-spot warning, and rear cross-traffic alert. transmissions: Xtronic CVT (updated 17% wider ratio spread, 32% less friction for 2022+)

NHTSA opened a 13 December 2023 investigation into main-bearing failures on KR-series VC-T engines, contributing to the elevated 1.1 difficulty modifier as technicians must navigate the VC-T hardware and safety-critical ADAS electronics. Fifth-generation Pathfinder R53 (2022-on) returns to a boxier SUV profile with standard Safety Shield 360 and NissanConnect services, pairing the direct-injected 3.5L VQ35DD V6 (284 hp/259 lb⋅ft) with a JR913E 9-speed automatic—replacing the previous CVT—and available Intelligent 4x4 system with seven terrain modes and 6,000 lb towing capacity. The combination of electronic drive-mode management and high-capacity towing hardware increases service complexity versus prior unibody crossovers, supporting a 1.1 difficulty modifier. Data sourced from Wikipedia Nissan Pathfinder article, October 14, 2025 revision.

North American Frontier D41 (2022-on) continues the F-Alpha frame with a redesigned body, standard 3.8L VQ38DD V6 (310 hp/281 lb⋅ft) and 9-speed automatic, offering S, SV, Pro-X and Pro-4X trims. Safety Shield 360 is standard on SV/Pro-X/Pro-4X (optional on S), while Pro-4X adds Bilstein off-road shocks, larger front skid plate, a Dana 44 rear axle with electronic locking differential, and underbody skid plates. These integrated off-road systems and electronic assists exceed the baseline midsize pickup complexity, supporting a 1.1 difficulty modifier. Data sourced from Wikipedia Nissan Frontier article, October 6, 2025 revision.

The third-generation Versa sedan (N18) for the U.S. and Canada uses the 1.6L HR16DE four-cylinder with either a 5-speed manual on the base S through the 2024 model year or an Xtronic CVT. Eighth-generation Maxima A36 continued for 2020–2023 with the 3.5L VQ35DE V6 rated at 300 hp and an Xtronic CVT, Nissan Safety Shield 360 driver-assist features made standard in the 2020 update, and optional 40th Anniversary appearance-and-interior package before production ended after the 2023 model year. The third-generation Murano Z52 received a 2020 update adding Nissan Safety Shield 360 with rear automatic braking, standard LED headlights, and a revised V-Motion front fascia while continuing the 3.5L VQ35DE V6 (260 hp) and Xtronic CVT with available Intuitive AWD. The ADAS suite and CVT service considerations elevate complexity modestly for diagnostics. Data sourced from Wikipedia Nissan Murano article, October 14, 2025 revision.

The fourth-generation Murano debuts for the 2025 model year on the CMF-D platform with a 2.0L KR20DDET variable-compression turbo four-cylinder (300 hp/295 lb⋅ft), 9-speed automatic, and standard Intelligent All-Wheel Drive for 2026 along with ProPILOT Assist, dual 12.3-inch displays, and optional two-tone paint. The higher-output VC-T powertrain and integrated ProPILOT systems increase service complexity. Data sourced from Wikipedia Nissan Murano article, October 14, 2025 revision.

For 2020–2024 the refreshed second-generation Titan and Titan XD adopted a 400 hp 5.6L VK56VD Endurance V8 paired with a 9-speed automatic. Titan XD rides on a longer 151.6-inch wheelbase, shares hardware with the NV heavy van, and in PRO-4X trim adds Bilstein off-road shocks, electronic rear locker, skid plates, and unique front styling. Production of both Titan and Titan XD ends after the 2024 model year. Data sourced from Wikipedia Nissan Titan article, October 14, 2025 revision.

The subcompact Kicks (P15) for North America uses the 1.6L HR16DE engine with an Xtronic CVT driving the front wheels, and its 2021 refresh brought standard Apple CarPlay/Android Auto with 8-inch touchscreen while SV/SR trims include Intelligent Cruise Control and Nissan Safety Shield 360 driver assistance with optional Bose Personal Plus audio. Data sourced from Wikipedia Nissan Kicks article, October 14, 2025 revision.
