engines: 2.2L (134 cu in) L134 Go-Devil I4 (60 hp gross, 54 hp net)
notes: Iconic WWII quarter-ton military Jeep (1,200 lb payload). 80-inch wheelbase, 3-4 person capacity. 15-gallon fuel tank, 300-mile range, 65 mph max speed. Live axles with leaf springs front and rear. 6-volt electrical system, manual choke carburetor, points-based ignition. Military-grade construction requiring vintage vehicle and military equipment expertise. Highly collectible wartime vehicle with specialized maintenance requirements. Difficulty modifier reflects WWII-era technology, parts scarcity, and historical preservation standards. Data sourced from Wikipedia Willys MB article, January 2025 revision.

First full-production civilian Jeep. Total production of 214,760 units. Civilianized version of military MB with seven-slot grille (vs. nine-slot MB). 80-inch wheelbase. Available in multiple colors (Pasture Green, Harvest Tan). Agricultural and industrial options available. Leaf spring suspension, Dana axles. 6-volt electrical system, manual choke carburetor, points-based ignition. 1940s-era vintage vehicle requiring specialized restoration and maintenance expertise. Difficulty modifier reflects post-war technology and collectible status. Data sourced from Wikipedia Jeep CJ article, January 2025 revision.

Introduced 1949 as successor to CJ-2A. Total production of 131,843 units (1949-1953). One-piece windshield with bottom vent, beefed-up 10-leaf suspension. 80-inch wheelbase. Farm Jeep and Jeep Tractor versions available. Leaf spring suspension, Dana axles. 6-volt electrical system, manual choke carburetor, points-based ignition. Late 1940s vintage vehicle requiring specialized knowledge. Difficulty modifier reflects vintage technology and collectible status. Data sourced from Wikipedia Jeep CJ article, January 2025 revision.

engines: 2.2L (134 cu in) L-134 Go-Devil flathead I4
notes: Introduced July 1946 as first mass-market all-steel station wagon. Designed by Brooks Stevens. Independent front suspension with transverse seven-leaf 'Planadyne' spring system. Panel van introduced 1947 (one seat, doors instead of tailgate, no rear side windows). Initially RWD only, 4WD option added 1949. 6-volt electrical system, manual choke carburetor, points-based ignition. 1940s vintage vehicle with unique suspension system requiring specialized expertise. Data sourced from Wikipedia Willys Jeep Station Wagon article, January 2025 revision.

engines: 2.2L (134 cu in) Go-Devil L4-134 side-valve I4 (63 hp)
notes: Introduced 1947 based on Station Wagon and CJ-2A. 118-inch wheelbase. 4T model (1-ton 4WD) and 2T model (¾-ton 2WD, by 1949). Final drive ratios: 5.38:1 standard, 4.88:1 and 6.17:1 optional. Various body configurations: pickup, stake truck, cab/chassis, bare chassis. Leaf spring suspension, 6-volt electrical system, manual choke carburetor, points-based ignition. Late 1940s vintage commercial vehicle requiring specialized knowledge. Data sourced from Wikipedia Willys Jeep Truck article, January 2025 revision.

Replaced CJ-3A in 1953 with higher grille and hood to accommodate new Willys Hurricane engine. Total production of ~196,000 (155,494 U.S. assembled). Could be converted to M606 military variant. 4-speed manual transmission added as option in 1963. 1950s-era leaf spring suspension, Dana axles, manual locking hubs. Manual choke carburetors, 6-volt electrical system, points-based ignition require specialized vintage vehicle expertise. Data sourced from Wikipedia Jeep CJ article, January 2025 revision.

Introduced 1954, influenced by Kaiser and Korean War M38A1 Jeep. Initial engine was Willys Hurricane 4-cylinder. Leaf spring suspension, Dana axles, manual locking hubs. Manual choke carburetors, 6-volt electrical system, points-based ignition. 1950s-era vintage vehicle requiring specialized restoration and maintenance knowledge. Buick V6 and AMC engines not introduced until 1960s. Data sourced from Wikipedia Jeep CJ article, January 2025 revision.

Introduced 1955 as stretched CJ-5 with 20 inches added to wheelbase (101 inches). Primarily exported to Sweden and South America. Total production of 50,172 units across entire run (1955-1981). Leaf spring suspension, Dana axles, manual locking hubs. Manual choke carburetors, 6-volt electrical system, points-based ignition. 1950s-era vintage vehicle requiring specialized knowledge. Data sourced from Wikipedia Jeep CJ article, January 2025 revision.

engines: 3.7L (226 cu in) Super Hurricane flathead I6
notes: One of Willys' most successful post-WWII models. 1950 introduced F-134 Hurricane engine and V-shaped grille. 1952 added F-161 Hurricane. 1954 introduced 6-226 Super Hurricane flathead I6. 1955 renamed 'Utility Wagon' after Willys withdrew from passenger car market. 1958 introduced luxury 'Maverick' model (2WD, two-tone paint, AM radio). Vintage leaf spring suspension, drum brakes. 6-volt electrical systems, manual choke, points ignition require vintage vehicle expertise. Data sourced from Wikipedia Willys Jeep Station Wagon article, January 2025 revision.

engines: 2.2L (134 cu in) Hurricane F4-134 I4 (63-72 hp)
notes: Model 473 (1950-1952) and Model 475 (1953-1959+). Go-Devil I4 standard in 1950, Hurricane F4-134 I4 became standard (power increased from 63 to 72 hp in 1951). Super Hurricane 6-226 I6 introduced 1954. Borg-Warner T-90 3-speed manual transmission. Final drive ratios: 5.38:1 standard, 4.88:1 and 6.17:1 optional. 1950 restyled with V-shaped grille (5 horizontal bars), changed to 3 bars in 1953. Vintage leaf spring suspension, drum brakes, 6-volt electrical system, manual choke, points ignition require vintage vehicle expertise. Data sourced from Wikipedia Willys Jeep Truck article, January 2025 revision.

engines: 3.7L (225 cu in) Buick Dauntless V6 (155 hp)
notes: Optional Perkins 192 diesel I4 available 1961-1965. Buick 225 Dauntless V6 introduced in 1965, became dominant by 1968 (75% of sales). Power steering was $81 option. Vintage leaf spring suspension, Dana axles, manual locking hubs. Manual choke carburetors, points-based ignition, and 1960s-era electrical systems require specialized vintage vehicle knowledge. Diesel variants require diesel service expertise. Data sourced from Wikipedia Jeep CJ article, January 2025 revision.

engines: 3.7L (225 cu in) Buick Dauntless V6 (155 hp)
notes: Long-wheelbase variant with 101-inch wheelbase. Shared engine options with CJ-5 including optional Perkins diesel. Buick Dauntless V6 introduced 1965. Primarily exported to Sweden and South America. Vintage leaf spring suspension, Dana axles, manual locking hubs. Manual choke carburetors, points-based ignition, 1960s-era electrical systems require vintage vehicle expertise. Diesel variants require specialized diesel service knowledge. Data sourced from Wikipedia Jeep CJ article, January 2025 revision.

engines: 3.8L (230 cu in) Tornado SOHC I6 (140 hp)
notes: Introduced 1963 with industry-first overhead cam Tornado I6 engine (140 hp), replaced by AMC 232 I6 in 1965. 327 AMC V8 added in 1965 (250 hp). Independent front suspension standard on RWD, optional on 4WD with torsion bar springs. 11-inch drum brakes all around. Manual locking front hubs on 4WD. 1965 added safety package (seat belts, padded dashboard). 1966 introduced luxury 'Super Wagoneer' model. Vintage points ignition and 1960s electrical systems. Data sourced from Wikipedia Jeep Wagoneer (SJ) article, January 2025 revision.

engines: 3.8L (230 cu in) Tornado SOHC I6 (140 hp)
5.4L (327 cu in) AMC V8 (250 hp, 340 lb-ft)
notes: Introduced 1963 as first American light truck/SUV with production overhead cam engine (Tornado SOHC I6). Industry-first optional automatic transmission for 4WD pickup. Optional dual rear wheels, wrecker, camper configurations. Townside (smooth) and Thriftside (flareside) bed options. Up to 8,600 lb GVW, nearly 2-ton payload capacity. Optional independent front suspension (deleted by 1965). Optional power brakes and power steering. Vintage points ignition and 1960s electrical systems. Data sourced from Wikipedia Jeep Gladiator (SJ) article, January 2025 revision.

engines: 2.2L (134 cu in) F134 Hurricane I4 (75 hp, 114 lb-ft)
3.7L (225 cu in) Dauntless V6 (160 hp, 235 lb-ft)
notes: Designed to compete in recreational vehicle market against International Scout and Ford Bronco. Multiple body styles: station wagon (metal hardtop), convertible (soft top), pickup truck, roadster (optional half/full soft tops). 4WD standard. Flagship 'Jeepster' and 'Commando Convertible' trims. Vintage leaf spring suspension, Dana axles. Manual choke carburetors, points-based ignition, 1960s electrical systems require vintage vehicle expertise. Data sourced from Wikipedia Jeepster Commando article, January 2025 revision.

Classic open-top off-road vehicle with leaf spring suspension, Dana axles, and transfer case. 1972 saw wheelbase stretch and introduction of AMC engines. 1976 body tub and frame modifications. Manual choke carburetors and points-based ignition require vintage vehicle maintenance knowledge. Optional Quadra-Trac full-time 4WD system. Data sourced from Wikipedia Jeep CJ article, January 2025 revision.

Long-wheelbase variant of CJ-5 with 101-103.5 inch wheelbase (vs. 81-84 inch CJ-5). Total production of 50,172 units (1955-1981), primarily exported to Sweden and South America. Similar mechanical specifications to CJ-5 with same AMC engine options, leaf spring suspension, and Dana axles. Manual choke carburetors and points-based ignition. Data sourced from Wikipedia Jeep CJ article, January 2025 revision.

engines: 2.5L (151 cu in) GM Iron Duke I4
body_styles: 2-door open-top utility vehicle with optional hardtop
notes: Introduced in 1976 with 93.3-inch wheelbase, longer than CJ-5 allowing for optional automatic transmission and hardtop. Optional Quadra-Trac all-wheel drive system. Available with molded hardtop and steel doors. Renegade and Laredo trim packages offered. Diesel option via Isuzu 2.4L I4. Manual choke carburetors and points-based ignition on most models. Dana axles and leaf spring suspension. Data sourced from Wikipedia Jeep CJ article, January 2025 revision.

First marketed use of 'Sport Utility Vehicle' term appeared in 1974 Cherokee sales brochure. Initially 2-door only, 4-door added in 1977. Optional Quadra-Trac full-time 4WD system. Dana 44 axles front and rear, Dana 20 transfer case. Optional disc brakes, leaf spring suspension. 401 V8 discontinued end of 1978. Data sourced from Wikipedia Jeep Cherokee (SJ) article, January 2025 revision.

engines: 5.7L (350 cu in) Buick Dauntless V8 (230 hp)
notes: 1970 introduced 327 AMC V8 (250 hp), replaced by 360 AMC V8 in 1971. Buick 350 Dauntless V8 used 1968-1971. Quadra-Trac full-time 4WD introduced 1973. Front disc brakes standard from 1974. Strengthened boxed frame rails in 1976. 'Limited' luxury trim introduced 1978 with Quadra-Trac, power disc brakes, leather upholstery. Dana axles and leaf spring suspension. Data sourced from Wikipedia Jeep Wagoneer (SJ) article, January 2025 revision.

engines: 4.2L (258 cu in) AMC I6 (112 hp, 210 lb-ft)
6.6L (401 cu in) AMC V8 (330 hp, 430 lb-ft)
notes: J-10 and J-20 designations introduced in 1974 (indicating payload capacity). Full-time Quadra-Trac 4WD system available (replaced by Selec-Trac in 1983). Larger brakes standard from 1974, reduced turning radius. Dana axles and leaf spring suspension. 401 V8 available 1974-1978. Various bed configurations offered. Data sourced from Wikipedia Jeep Gladiator (SJ) article, January 2025 revision.

Compact rotary-engined car based on Capella (616/618) platform. Available in coupe and sedan body styles. High difficulty modifier reflects specialized rotary engine maintenance including apex seal replacement, oil consumption monitoring, and compression testing requirements. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mazda Capella article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Compact rotary sports car based on Grand Familia platform. Available in multiple body styles. Successful in racing. High difficulty modifier reflects specialized rotary engine maintenance including apex seal replacement, oil consumption monitoring, and compression testing requirements. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mazda RX-3 article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Midsize rotary-engined car based on Luce platform. First Mazda to use 13B rotary engine. Available in multiple body styles. High difficulty modifier reflects specialized rotary engine maintenance including apex seal replacement, oil consumption monitoring, and compression testing requirements. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mazda RX-4 article, December 19, 2024 revision.

First-generation RX-7 sports car with 12A twin-rotor Wankel rotary engine. Launched 1978 as 1979 model year. Lightweight and affordable sports car. High difficulty modifier reflects specialized rotary engine maintenance including apex seal replacement, oil consumption monitoring, and compression testing requirements. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mazda RX-7 article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Subcompact car marketed as 808 in North America (Grand Familia in Japan). Available in multiple body styles with piston engines. Replaced by GLC/323. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mazda Familia article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Great Little Car (GLC) subcompact. Familia platform with multiple body styles. Transitioned from RWD to FWD during this generation. Fuel-efficient economy car during energy crisis. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mazda Familia article, December 19, 2024 revision.

First-generation B-Series compact pickup (PROCEED in Japan). Available in various displacements throughout decade. Simple and reliable truck design. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mazda B series article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Second-generation Cosmo (AP designation) luxury/sports coupe. Available with rotary or piston engines. High difficulty modifier reflects specialized rotary engine maintenance on rotary models. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mazda Cosmo article, December 19, 2024 revision.

First-generation 626 (Capella) in North America from late 1970s. Available in multiple body styles. Rear-wheel drive with various piston engine options. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mazda Capella article, December 19, 2024 revision.

First-generation RX-7 sports car with 12A twin-rotor Wankel rotary engine. Lightweight and affordable sports car. High difficulty modifier reflects specialized rotary engine maintenance including apex seal replacement, oil consumption monitoring, and compression testing requirements. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mazda RX-7 article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Second-generation RX-7 with improved 13B rotary engine. Turbocharged variants available. Convertible body style added 1988. High difficulty modifier reflects specialized rotary engine maintenance and turbo complexity on turbocharged models. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mazda RX-7 article, December 19, 2024 revision.

First-generation 626 (Capella) in North America. Available in sedan, coupe, and hatchback body styles. Some models offered with rear-wheel drive. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mazda Capella article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Second-generation 626 with front-wheel drive. Available in sedan, coupe, and hatchback body styles. Turbocharged engine optional on some models. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mazda Capella article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Third-generation 626 with updated styling. Available in sedan, coupe, and hatchback body styles. Turbocharged engine optional on GT models. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mazda Capella article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Third-generation 323 (Familia) subcompact. Sold as Mazda GLC in some North American markets until 1985, then as 323. Available in sedan and hatchback body styles. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mazda Familia article, December 19, 2024 revision.

First-generation MX-6 sports coupe sharing platform with 626. Available with naturally aspirated or turbocharged four-cylinder engines. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mazda MX-6 article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Second-generation B-Series compact pickup truck based on Ford Ranger platform. Available in regular cab configuration. Multiple engine options including Mitsubishi 2.6L. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mazda B series article, December 19, 2024 revision.

First-generation MPV minivan with truck-based rear-wheel-drive platform. Optional four-wheel drive. Seating for up to seven passengers. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mazda MPV article, December 19, 2024 revision.

First-generation MX-5 Miata launched late 1989 as 1990 model. Revolutionary affordable sports car that revived the roadster market. Lightweight rear-wheel-drive with near 50/50 weight distribution. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mazda MX-5 article, December 19, 2024 revision.

First-generation MX-5 Miata launched 1989 as 1990 model. Revolutionary affordable sports car that revived the roadster market. 1.6L engine 1990-1993, 1.8L from 1994+. Lightweight rear-wheel-drive with near 50/50 weight distribution. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mazda MX-5 article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Second-generation MX-5 Miata with updated styling and improved rigidity. More powerful 1.8L engine. 6-speed manual transmission available from 2001. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mazda MX-5 article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Third-generation RX-7 with sequential twin-turbo 13B rotary engine. Iconic sports car with pop-up headlights and sleek design. Sold in North America 1993-1995, continued in other markets until 2002. Very high difficulty modifier reflects twin-turbo rotary complexity, apex seal maintenance, sequential turbo system, oil injection system, and specialized compression testing requirements. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mazda RX-7 article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Second-generation Protegé compact sedan. Renamed from 323 in North American market. Available in sedan and hatchback body styles. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mazda Familia article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Third-generation Protegé compact sedan. Replaced by Mazda3 for 2004 model year. Multiple engine options depending on trim level. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mazda Familia article, December 19, 2024 revision.
Fourth-generation 626 midsize sedan. Available in sedan and hatchback body styles. Optional V6 engine on higher trims. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mazda Capella article, December 19, 2024 revision.
Fifth-generation 626 midsize sedan. Sedan body style only in this generation. Replaced by Mazda6 for 2003 model year. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mazda Capella article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Second-generation MX-6 sports coupe sharing platform with Ford Probe. Available with four-cylinder or V6 engines. Discontinued after 1997 model year. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mazda MX-6 article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Luxury sedan with unique Miller-cycle supercharged V6 engine on S trim. Positioned above 626 as flagship sedan. Difficulty modifier reflects Miller-cycle engine complexity and supercharger maintenance. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mazda Millenia article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Third-generation B-Series compact pickup truck based on Ford Ranger platform. Available in regular cab and extended cab configurations. Multiple engine options. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mazda B series article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Second-generation MPV minivan with car-based FWD platform. Replaced truck-based RWD first generation. Seating for up to seven passengers. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mazda MPV article, December 19, 2024 revision.

First-generation Mazda3 replaces Protegé. Built on Ford C1 platform shared with Volvo S40 and Ford Focus. MazdaSpeed3 performance variant with turbocharged engine available 2007-2009. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mazda3 article, December 19, 2024 revision.

First-generation Mazda6 midsize sedan. Available in sedan, hatchback, and wagon body styles. MazdaSpeed6 performance variant with turbocharged AWD available 2006-2007. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mazda6 article, December 19, 2024 revision.
Second-generation Mazda6 introduced late in decade. Sedan body style only. Larger V6 engine available. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mazda6 article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Third-generation Protegé compact sedan. Replaced by Mazda3 for 2004 model year. Protegé5 hatchback variant available 2002-2003. MazdaSpeed Protegé turbocharged variant (170 hp) available 2003 only. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mazda Familia article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Second-generation MPV minivan with car-based FWD platform. Seating for up to seven passengers. Discontinued in North America after 2006 model year. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mazda MPV article, December 19, 2024 revision.
Fifth-generation 626 midsize sedan. Final years before replacement by Mazda6. Sedan body style only in this generation. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mazda Capella article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Luxury sedan with unique Miller-cycle supercharged V6 engine on S trim. Discontinued after 2002 model year. Difficulty modifier reflects Miller-cycle engine complexity and supercharger maintenance. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mazda Millenia article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Second-generation MX-5 Miata with updated styling and improved rigidity. 6-speed manual transmission available from 2001. Lightweight rear-wheel-drive sports car. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mazda MX-5 article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Third-generation MX-5 Miata introduced for 2006 model year. Larger and more powerful than previous generations. Power retractable hardtop (PRHT) available from 2007. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mazda MX-5 article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Sports car with 1.3L Renesis twin-rotor Wankel rotary engine. Features unique freestyle doors (rear-hinged rear doors). Manual transmission models produce 238 hp (232 hp from 2009), automatic models 212 hp. High difficulty modifier reflects specialized rotary engine maintenance including apex seal replacement, oil consumption monitoring, and compression testing requirements. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mazda RX-8 article, December 19, 2024 revision.

First-generation Tribute compact SUV based on Ford Escape/Mercury Mariner CD2 platform. Jointly developed with Ford. Available with four-cylinder or V6 engines. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mazda Tribute article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Second-generation Tribute compact SUV based on Ford Escape/Mercury Mariner CD2 platform. Hybrid variant available with 2.5L Atkinson-cycle engine and electric motor (153 hp combined). Difficulty modifier reflects hybrid system complexity. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mazda Tribute article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Midsize crossover with sporty styling and turbocharged engine. Built on Ford CD3 platform. Naturally aspirated 2.5L engine added for 2010 model year. Difficulty modifier reflects turbo maintenance complexity. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mazda CX-7 article, December 19, 2024 revision.

First-generation CX-9 three-row crossover with V6 engine. Shares Ford CD3 platform with Ford Edge and Lincoln MKX. Largest Mazda crossover SUV. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mazda CX-9 article, December 19, 2024 revision.

First-generation Mazda5 compact minivan with sliding rear doors. Six-passenger seating in three rows. Smaller alternative to traditional minivans. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mazda5 article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Fourth-generation B-Series compact pickup truck based on Ford Ranger platform. Available in regular cab and extended cab configurations. Discontinued after 2009 model year in North America. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mazda B series article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Second-generation Mazda3 with updated styling and improved dynamics. MazdaSpeed3 performance variant available with 2.3L turbo engine (263 hp) until 2013. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mazda3 article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Third-generation Mazda3 introduces SkyActiv technology with improved fuel efficiency and performance. Kodo 'Soul of Motion' design language. No turbocharged variant offered in this generation. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mazda3 article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Second-generation Mazda6 midsize sedan. V6 engine optional on higher trims. Final generation before SkyActiv technology introduction. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mazda6 article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Third-generation Mazda6 features SkyActiv technology and Kodo design. Turbo engine added for 2018 model year. Manual transmission availability limited to early years. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mazda6 article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Third-generation Mazda2 subcompact offered in North America from 2011-2014. Discontinued after 2014 model year. Replaced briefly by Scion iA/Toyota Yaris iA sedan based on Mazda2 platform. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mazda2 article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Second-generation Tribute compact SUV based on Ford Escape/Mercury Mariner CD2 platform. Hybrid variant available with 2.5L Atkinson-cycle engine and electric motor (153 hp combined). Final years before discontinuation. Difficulty modifier reflects hybrid system complexity. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mazda Tribute article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Midsize crossover with sporty styling. Turbocharged engine standard on early models, naturally aspirated 2.5L added for 2010+. Discontinued after 2012 model year in North America. Difficulty modifier reflects turbo maintenance complexity. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mazda CX-7 article, December 19, 2024 revision.

First-generation CX-9 three-row crossover with V6 engine. Shares Ford CD3 platform with Ford Edge and Lincoln MKX. Received facelift for 2010 model year. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mazda CX-9 article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Second-generation CX-9 features SkyActiv technology and downsized turbocharged four-cylinder replacing V6. Lighter weight and improved fuel efficiency. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mazda CX-9 article, December 19, 2024 revision.

First-generation CX-5 is first Mazda vehicle to feature full SkyActiv technology suite including engines, transmissions, body, and chassis. Replaced Tribute as compact crossover offering. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mazda CX-5 article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Second-generation CX-5 with refined SkyActiv technology and premium interior. Turbocharged engine optional starting 2019 model year. Most popular Mazda model in North America. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mazda CX-5 article, December 19, 2024 revision.
Subcompact crossover SUV based on Mazda2 platform. Sold in North America from 2016-2021. Replaced by CX-30 in 2020. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mazda CX-3 article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Subcompact crossover SUV introduced for 2020 model year (late 2019). Built on SkyActiv-Vehicle Architecture. Positioned between CX-3 and CX-5. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mazda CX-30 article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Second-generation Mazda5 compact minivan with sliding rear doors. Six-passenger seating in three rows. Discontinued in North America after 2015 model year. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mazda5 article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Sports car with 1.3L Renesis twin-rotor Wankel rotary engine. Features unique freestyle doors (rear-hinged rear doors). Final years in North America before discontinuation. High difficulty modifier reflects specialized rotary engine maintenance including apex seal replacement, oil consumption monitoring, and compression testing requirements. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mazda RX-8 article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Third-generation MX-5 Miata with available power retractable hardtop (PRHT). Received facelift for 2009 model year. Larger and heavier than previous generations. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mazda MX-5 article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Fourth-generation MX-5 Miata with SkyActiv technology. Lighter weight and improved dynamics compared to NC. RF (Retractable Fastback) variant with power hardtop added for 2017. Power increased to 181 hp for 2019+ models. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mazda MX-5 article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Fourth-generation Mazda3 features SkyActiv-Vehicle Architecture with human-centric design philosophy. Turbo variants available on hatchback body style only. AWD available with 2.5L naturally aspirated engine. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mazda3 article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Final years of Mazda6 in North American market. Third-generation model discontinued after 2021 model year. Turbo engine optional on Grand Touring Reserve and Signature trims. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mazda6 article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Subcompact crossover SUV built on SkyActiv-Vehicle Architecture. Positioned between CX-3 and CX-5 in lineup. Turbo engine available starting 2021 model year on higher trims. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mazda CX-30 article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Second-generation CX-5 received refresh for 2022 model year with updated exterior styling and interior technology. Turbo engine optional on higher trims. Most popular Mazda model in North America. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mazda CX-5 article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Second-generation CX-9 is largest Mazda crossover sold in North America. Uses turbocharged four-cylinder engine instead of V6 from previous generation. Three-row seating for up to seven passengers. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mazda CX-9 article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Fourth-generation MX-5 Miata received power increase to 181 hp for 2019+ models. Available in soft-top roadster or RF (Retractable Fastback) with power hardtop. Maintains traditional front-engine, rear-wheel-drive sports car layout. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mazda MX-5 article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Battery electric vehicle with 35.5 kWh battery pack providing approximately 100 miles of range. Limited availability in California only. Features freestyle rear-hinged doors. Discontinued in North America after 2023. Difficulty modifier reflects EV-specific service requirements. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mazda MX-30 article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Compact crossover SUV built at Mazda Toyota Manufacturing USA plant in Alabama. More rugged styling than CX-5 with higher ground clearance and off-road capability. Does not replace CX-5, sold alongside it. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mazda CX-50 article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Two-row midsize crossover based on Large Product Group platform with longitudinal engine layout. Features Mazda's return to inline-six engines and RWD-based architecture. PHEV variant uses 2.5L four-cylinder with electric motor and 17.8 kWh battery. Difficulty modifier reflects PHEV high-voltage system service requirements. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mazda CX-70 article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Three-row midsize crossover based on Large Product Group platform with longitudinal engine layout. Replaces CX-9 as flagship crossover. Features Mazda's return to inline-six engines and RWD-based architecture. PHEV variant uses 2.5L four-cylinder with electric motor and 17.8 kWh battery. Difficulty modifier reflects PHEV high-voltage system service requirements. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mazda CX-90 article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Leone (DL/GL in North America) compact car. First Subaru models widely sold in North American market. Available in multiple body styles. Front-wheel drive standard, part-time four-wheel drive optional on some models. Established Subaru's presence in U.S. market. Data sourced from Wikipedia Subaru Leone article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Bi-drive Recreational All-terrain Transporter (BRAT) compact pickup launched 1978. Features open bed with rear-facing jump seats to circumvent chicken tax on light trucks. Available with FWD or part-time 4WD. Unique and practical vehicle that became cult classic. Data sourced from Wikipedia Subaru BRAT article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Leone marketed as DL/GL in North America. Available in multiple body styles. Front-wheel drive or part-time/full-time four-wheel drive. Turbocharged variants available in 1980s. Established Subaru's AWD reputation. Data sourced from Wikipedia Subaru Leone article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Bi-drive Recreational All-terrain Transporter (BRAT) compact pickup with open bed. Famous for rear-facing jump seats in bed to circumvent chicken tax. Available with FWD or part-time 4WD. Cult classic with strong following. Data sourced from Wikipedia Subaru BRAT article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Subcompact hatchback with three-cylinder engine. One of first production vehicles with CVT transmission (ECVT - Electro Continuously Variable Transmission). Available with FWD or part-time 4WD. Fuel-efficient economy car. Data sourced from Wikipedia Subaru Justy article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Sports coupe with wedge-shaped design and aircraft-inspired interior. Available with four-cylinder or flat-six engines. Digital instrumentation. Asymmetric steering wheel. Pop-up headlights. Unique and futuristic for its era. Difficulty modifier reflects flat-six engine complexity on XT6 models. Data sourced from Wikipedia Subaru XT article, December 19, 2024 revision.

First-generation Legacy launched late 1989 as 1990 model. Replaced Leone as midsize offering. Available with FWD or AWD. Modern design and improved refinement. Data sourced from Wikipedia Subaru Legacy article, December 19, 2024 revision.

First-generation Legacy midsize sedan and wagon. Available with front-wheel or all-wheel drive. Turbocharged variants available. Established Subaru's reputation for reliable AWD systems. Data sourced from Wikipedia Subaru Legacy article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Second-generation Legacy with improved styling and performance. Available with FWD or AWD. Legacy GT turbocharged variant available. 2.5L engine introduced late in generation. Data sourced from Wikipedia Subaru Legacy article, December 19, 2024 revision.

First-generation Outback introduced as Legacy trim level in 1995, became standalone model. Wagon body style with increased ground clearance and cladding. All-wheel drive standard. Helped establish crossover wagon segment. Data sourced from Wikipedia Subaru Outback article, December 19, 2024 revision.

engines: 2.0L EJ20 turbo boxer H4 (240 hp WRX)
notes: First-generation Impreza compact car. Available in multiple body styles including coupe, sedan, wagon, and hatchback. Available with FWD or AWD. WRX turbocharged performance variant introduced in some markets (not U.S. until 2002). Data sourced from Wikipedia Subaru Impreza article, December 19, 2024 revision.

First-generation Forester compact SUV based on Impreza platform. All-wheel drive standard. Higher seating position and increased cargo space compared to Impreza wagon. Helped establish compact crossover segment. Data sourced from Wikipedia Subaru Forester article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Sports coupe with unique window-within-a-window design by Giugiaro. Flat-six engine. Available with FWD or AWD. Automatic transmission only. Limited production and sales. Difficulty modifier reflects specialized six-cylinder engine maintenance. Data sourced from Wikipedia Subaru Alcyone SVX article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Fourth-generation Legacy midsize sedan and wagon. Symmetrical all-wheel drive standard. Legacy GT turbocharged variant and 3.0R six-cylinder available. Manual transmission available on select models. Data sourced from Wikipedia Subaru Legacy article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Second-generation Outback wagon based on Legacy platform. Symmetrical all-wheel drive standard. Optional flat-six engine. Increased ground clearance and rugged styling. Data sourced from Wikipedia Subaru Outback article, December 19, 2024 revision.

engines: 2.5L EJ25 turbo boxer H4 (243/250 hp XT)
notes: Third-generation Outback based on fourth-generation Legacy. Symmetrical all-wheel drive standard. Turbocharged XT and six-cylinder 3.0R variants available. Data sourced from Wikipedia Subaru Outback article, December 19, 2024 revision.

engines: 2.0L EJ20 turbo boxer H4 (227 hp WRX)
2.5L EJ25 turbo boxer H4 (300 hp STI)
notes: Second-generation Impreza compact car. Symmetrical all-wheel drive standard. WRX turbocharged variant available from 2002. WRX STI high-performance variant introduced to U.S. market in 2004. Multiple body styles including sedan, wagon, and hatchback. Data sourced from Wikipedia Subaru Impreza article, December 19, 2024 revision.

engines: 2.5L EJ25 turbo boxer H4 (265/305 hp WRX/STI)
notes: Third-generation Impreza with revised styling. Symmetrical all-wheel drive standard. WRX and WRX STI performance variants continue. Sedan and hatchback body styles. Wagon discontinued in U.S. market. Data sourced from Wikipedia Subaru Impreza article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Turbocharged performance variant of Impreza. First generation officially sold in U.S. market. Symmetrical all-wheel drive with driver-controlled center differential. Rally-inspired performance. Difficulty modifier reflects turbocharged engine maintenance and performance-oriented components. Data sourced from Wikipedia Subaru Impreza WRX article, December 19, 2024 revision.

High-performance STI variant introduced to U.S. market in 2004. Larger 2.5L turbocharged engine. Six-speed manual transmission. Enhanced suspension, brakes, and aerodynamics. Driver-controlled center differential with multiple modes. High difficulty modifier reflects performance-oriented maintenance, turbo complexity, and specialized components. Data sourced from Wikipedia Subaru Impreza WRX article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Third-generation Impreza-based WRX with hatchback body style added. Turbocharged 2.5L boxer engine. Symmetrical all-wheel drive. Difficulty modifier reflects turbocharged engine maintenance. Data sourced from Wikipedia Subaru Impreza WRX article, December 19, 2024 revision.

High-performance STI variant based on third-generation Impreza. Hatchback body style added. Enhanced power output. Six-speed manual transmission. High difficulty modifier reflects performance maintenance requirements. Data sourced from Wikipedia Subaru Impreza WRX article, December 19, 2024 revision.

engines: 2.5L EJ25 turbo boxer H4 (210/230 hp XT)
notes: Second-generation Forester compact SUV. Symmetrical all-wheel drive standard. Turbocharged XT variant available with manual or automatic transmission. Increased size compared to first generation. Data sourced from Wikipedia Subaru Forester article, December 19, 2024 revision.

engines: 2.5L EJ25 turbo boxer H4 (224 hp XT)
notes: Third-generation Forester with updated styling. Symmetrical all-wheel drive standard. Turbocharged XT variant available. Improved safety features. Data sourced from Wikipedia Subaru Forester article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Three-row midsize SUV built in Lafayette, Indiana. Named B9 Tribeca for first generation (renamed Tribeca from 2008). Flat-six engine standard. Symmetrical all-wheel drive. Controversial original front-end styling revised for 2008. Data sourced from Wikipedia Subaru Tribeca article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Compact pickup/utility vehicle based on Legacy platform. Features open bed with innovative switchback feature (fold-down midgate). Symmetrical all-wheel drive standard. Turbocharged variant available. Built in Lafayette, Indiana. Data sourced from Wikipedia Subaru Baja article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Fifth-generation Legacy midsize sedan. Symmetrical all-wheel drive standard. Optional flat-six engine on 3.6R trim. CVT transmission introduced during this generation. Data sourced from Wikipedia Subaru Legacy article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Sixth-generation Legacy on new Subaru Global Platform. Symmetrical all-wheel drive standard. CVT transmission standard across lineup. 3.6R trim with flat-six engine available until 2019. Data sourced from Wikipedia Subaru Legacy article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Fourth-generation Outback wagon/crossover. Symmetrical all-wheel drive standard. Optional flat-six engine on 3.6R trim. Increased ground clearance compared to Legacy sedan. Data sourced from Wikipedia Subaru Outback article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Fifth-generation Outback on Subaru Global Platform. Symmetrical all-wheel drive standard. CVT transmission standard. 3.6R trim with flat-six engine available until 2019. Data sourced from Wikipedia Subaru Outback article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Fourth-generation Impreza compact car. Symmetrical all-wheel drive standard. Available in sedan and hatchback body styles. WRX and WRX STI became separate model lines starting 2015. Data sourced from Wikipedia Subaru Impreza article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Fifth-generation Impreza on Subaru Global Platform. Symmetrical all-wheel drive standard. Available in sedan and hatchback body styles. Improved safety and handling with new platform. Data sourced from Wikipedia Subaru Impreza article, December 19, 2024 revision.

engines: 2.5L EJ25 turbo boxer H4 (305 hp STI)
notes: Fourth-generation WRX became standalone model separate from Impreza. WRX uses 2.0L direct-injection turbo, WRX STI retains 2.5L EJ25 turbo. Symmetrical all-wheel drive with driver-controlled center differential. Manual transmission standard, CVT optional on WRX (not STI). Difficulty modifier reflects turbocharged engine maintenance and performance components. Data sourced from Wikipedia Subaru Impreza WRX article, December 19, 2024 revision.

First-generation Crosstrek (XV in some markets) subcompact crossover based on Impreza. Increased ground clearance and rugged styling. Symmetrical all-wheel drive standard. Manual transmission available. Data sourced from Wikipedia Subaru XV article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Second-generation Crosstrek on Subaru Global Platform. Based on fifth-generation Impreza. Symmetrical all-wheel drive standard. Manual transmission available on base models. Data sourced from Wikipedia Subaru XV article, December 19, 2024 revision.

engines: 2.0L FB20 boxer H4 + electric motor (148 hp combined)
notes: First plug-in hybrid Subaru sold in North America. 8.8 kWh battery pack with approximately 17 miles electric-only range. Symmetrical all-wheel drive standard. Difficulty modifier reflects PHEV high-voltage system complexity. Data sourced from Wikipedia Subaru XV article, December 19, 2024 revision.

engines: 2.0L FA20 turbo boxer H4 (250 hp XT)
notes: Fourth-generation Forester compact SUV. Symmetrical all-wheel drive standard. Turbocharged XT variant available. Manual transmission available on base models. Data sourced from Wikipedia Subaru Forester article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Fifth-generation Forester on Subaru Global Platform. Symmetrical all-wheel drive standard. No turbocharged engine option in this generation. X-Mode off-road system available. Data sourced from Wikipedia Subaru Forester article, December 19, 2024 revision.

First-generation BRZ sports coupe co-developed with Toyota (86/FR-S twin). Rear-wheel drive layout unique among modern Subarus. Naturally aspirated 2.0L boxer engine. Low center of gravity and balanced handling. Power increased to 205 hp for 2017+ models. Data sourced from Wikipedia Subaru BRZ article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Three-row midsize SUV built in Lafayette, Indiana. Largest Subaru SUV available in North America. Seating for up to eight passengers. Turbocharged 2.4L boxer engine standard. Symmetrical all-wheel drive standard. Data sourced from Wikipedia Subaru Ascent article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Seventh-generation Legacy midsize sedan features Subaru Global Platform. Symmetrical all-wheel drive standard. Turbo engine optional on XT trim. CVT continuously variable transmission standard across lineup. Data sourced from Wikipedia Subaru Legacy article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Sixth-generation Outback features Subaru Global Platform with increased ground clearance. Symmetrical all-wheel drive standard. Turbo engine optional on XT trim. Popular crossover-wagon with rugged capability. Data sourced from Wikipedia Subaru Outback article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Fifth-generation Forester compact SUV on Subaru Global Platform. Symmetrical all-wheel drive standard. No turbocharged engine option in this generation. X-Mode off-road system available. Data sourced from Wikipedia Subaru Forester article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Fifth-generation WRX performance sedan with enlarged 2.4L turbocharged boxer engine. Symmetrical all-wheel drive with driver-controlled center differential. Manual transmission standard, CVT optional. No STI variant for this generation. Difficulty modifier reflects turbocharged engine maintenance and performance-oriented components. Data sourced from Wikipedia Subaru Impreza WRX article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Sixth-generation Impreza compact car on Subaru Global Platform. Symmetrical all-wheel drive standard. Available in sedan and hatchback body styles. Manual transmission available on base models. Data sourced from Wikipedia Subaru Impreza article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Third-generation Crosstrek (XV in some markets) subcompact crossover. Based on Impreza platform with increased ground clearance. Symmetrical all-wheel drive standard. Manual transmission available on base models. Data sourced from Wikipedia Subaru XV article, December 19, 2024 revision.

engines: EV: Dual electric motors (215 hp combined)
notes: Battery electric SUV co-developed with Toyota (bZ4X twin). Built on e-TNGA platform with 72.8 kWh battery pack. Dual-motor all-wheel drive system. Approximately 228 miles EPA range. Difficulty modifier reflects EV high-voltage system service requirements and specialized diagnostic equipment. Data sourced from Wikipedia Subaru Solterra article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Second-generation BRZ sports coupe co-developed with Toyota (GR86 twin). Rear-wheel drive layout unique among modern Subarus. Naturally aspirated 2.4L boxer engine with increased displacement. Low center of gravity and balanced handling. Data sourced from Wikipedia Subaru BRZ article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Three-row midsize SUV built in Lafayette, Indiana. Largest Subaru SUV available in North America. Seating for up to eight passengers. Turbocharged 2.4L boxer engine standard. Symmetrical all-wheel drive standard. Data sourced from Wikipedia Subaru Ascent article, December 19, 2024 revision.

engines: 2.0L FB20 boxer H4 + electric motor (148 hp combined)
notes: Plug-in hybrid variant of Crosstrek with 8.8 kWh battery pack. Electric-only range of approximately 17 miles. Combines boxer engine with electric motor for improved efficiency. Symmetrical all-wheel drive standard. Difficulty modifier reflects PHEV high-voltage system complexity. Data sourced from Wikipedia Subaru XV article, December 19, 2024 revision.
First Mitsubishi-branded sedan sold in North America. Compact FWD sedan. Timing belt maintenance required. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mitsubishi Tredia article, January 17, 2025 revision.
Compact sport coupe. Turbocharged variant available. Timing belt maintenance critical, especially on turbo models. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mitsubishi Cordia article, January 17, 2025 revision.

Rear-wheel drive turbocharged sport coupe. Intercooled turbo versions produced 188 hp. Timing belt maintenance critical. Turbocharger servicing requires attention to oil quality and cooling system. Also sold as Chrysler Conquest and Dodge Conquest. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mitsubishi Starion article, January 17, 2025 revision.
Fourth generation midsize sedan introduced to North American market. Timing belt maintenance required. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mitsubishi Galant article, January 17, 2025 revision.
Fifth generation introduced late 1988 for 1989 model year. Timing belt maintenance required. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mitsubishi Galant article, January 17, 2025 revision.

Compact pickup truck (L200/Triton internationally). Diesel variant available 1983-1985. Timing belt maintenance required on all engines. Diesel service requires specialized knowledge and glow plug maintenance. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mitsubishi Triton article, January 17, 2025 revision.

First generation compact/midsize SUV (Pajero internationally). Turbodiesel available 1983-1986. Part-time 4WD with lockable hubs. Timing belt maintenance required on all engines. Diesel variants require specialized service. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mitsubishi Pajero article, January 17, 2025 revision.
Third generation subcompact. Turbocharged variant available on certain trims. Timing belt maintenance required. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mitsubishi Mirage article, January 17, 2025 revision.
Rebadged Hyundai Excel. Entry-level subcompact hatchback. Timing belt maintenance required. Data sourced from Wikipedia Hyundai Excel article, January 17, 2025 revision.
Cab-over van design. Available with 4WD. Timing belt maintenance required. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mitsubishi Delica article, January 17, 2025 revision.

First generation Diamond-Star Motors sport coupe built in Normal, Illinois. Platform-shared with Eagle Talon and Plymouth Laser. GSX trim featured turbocharged 4G63 engine with AWD. Timing belt maintenance critical on all engines. AWD models require additional complexity for drivetrain service. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mitsubishi Eclipse article, January 17, 2025 revision.

Second generation with new rounded styling. Built in Normal, Illinois. Spyder convertible introduced 1996. GSX retained turbocharged 4G63 engine with AWD. Timing belt maintenance required on all engines. Last Eclipse generation with AWD option. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mitsubishi Eclipse article, January 17, 2025 revision.

High-performance grand tourer (GTO in Japan). VR-4 trim featured twin-turbocharged 6G72 engine, AWD, active aerodynamics, four-wheel steering, and electronically controlled suspension. Complex timing belt service with interference engine. VR-4 requires specialized diagnostic equipment for advanced systems. Premium fuel required for turbo variants. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mitsubishi GTO article, January 17, 2025 revision.

Revised styling and increased power for VR-4. 6-speed manual transmission available on 1999 VR-4. Complex timing belt service required. Active aerodynamics and four-wheel steering on VR-4. Discontinued after 1999 in North America. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mitsubishi GTO article, January 17, 2025 revision.
Sixth generation midsize sedan. Timing belt maintenance required. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mitsubishi Galant article, January 17, 2025 revision.
Seventh generation midsize sedan. Timing belt maintenance required on both engines. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mitsubishi Galant article, January 17, 2025 revision.
First generation full-size luxury sedan. Timing belt maintenance required. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mitsubishi Diamante article, January 17, 2025 revision.
Second generation with increased displacement. Timing belt maintenance required. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mitsubishi Diamante article, January 17, 2025 revision.

Second generation full-size SUV (Pajero internationally). Super Select 4WD system. Timing belt maintenance required. Known for Consumer Reports rollover concerns in 1996. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mitsubishi Pajero article, January 17, 2025 revision.
Midsize SUV based on Triton/L200 pickup platform. Timing belt maintenance required on all engines. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mitsubishi Challenger article, January 17, 2025 revision.

Compact pickup truck (L200/Triton internationally). Timing belt maintenance required on both engines. Discontinued in North America after 1996 model year. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mitsubishi Triton article, January 17, 2025 revision.
Fifth generation subcompact. Coupe variant available through 1996. Timing belt maintenance required. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mitsubishi Mirage article, January 17, 2025 revision.

Compact MPV/wagon (RVR in Japan). AWD available on certain trims. Timing belt maintenance required. Short North American run. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mitsubishi RVR article, January 17, 2025 revision.
First generation compact crossover SUV based on Lancer platform. Timing belt maintenance required every 60k miles. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mitsubishi Outlander article, January 17, 2025 revision.

Second generation with optional third-row seating. Available with V6 engine and 6-speed automatic. Timing chain on both engines. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mitsubishi Outlander article, January 17, 2025 revision.
Ninth generation compact sedan, redesigned on global platform. Timing chain engine. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mitsubishi Lancer article, January 17, 2025 revision.

Eighth generation compact sedan. Sportback wagon variant available. Timing belt maintenance required. Ralliart performance trim added 2004. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mitsubishi Lancer article, January 17, 2025 revision.

High-performance AWD sport sedan with turbocharged 4G63 engine. Active Center Differential and Active Yaw Control. MR (Mitsubishi Racing) variant with 6-speed and upgraded components. Requires premium fuel and frequent oil changes. Timing belt critical maintenance item. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mitsubishi Lancer Evolution article, January 17, 2025 revision.

Final evolution of 4G63 turbocharged engine. MIVEC variable valve timing. Active Center Differential and Super Active Yaw Control. MR variant with upgraded turbocharger and intercooler producing 300 hp. Requires premium fuel and frequent maintenance. Timing belt critical. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mitsubishi Lancer Evolution article, January 17, 2025 revision.

Ninth generation midsize sedan. Timing chain on V6, timing belt on 4-cylinder until 2009 refresh. Discontinued after 2012 model year. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mitsubishi Galant article, January 17, 2025 revision.
Eighth generation midsize sedan. Timing belt maintenance required on both engines. Manual transmission rare. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mitsubishi Galant article, January 17, 2025 revision.

Third generation sport coupe built at Normal, Illinois plant. No longer AWD/turbo variants. Timing belt maintenance required on both engines. Spyder convertible available. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mitsubishi Eclipse article, January 17, 2025 revision.

Fourth and final generation. Larger, heavier design. V6 with 5-speed automatic. Timing chain on both engines. Discontinued after 2012. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mitsubishi Eclipse article, January 17, 2025 revision.

Third generation full-size SUV (Pajero internationally). Super Select 4WD II system with Active Traction Control. Timing belt maintenance required. Discontinued in North America after 2006. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mitsubishi Pajero article, January 17, 2025 revision.

Second generation midsize SUV. Timing belt maintenance required. Discontinued in North America after 2006 model year. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mitsubishi Challenger article, January 17, 2025 revision.

Midsize crossover SUV positioned above Outlander. Timing belt maintenance required. Discontinued after 2011 model year. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mitsubishi Endeavor article, January 17, 2025 revision.

Rebadged Dodge Dakota built at Warren, Michigan plant. Shared powertrains and platform with Dakota. Timing chain engines. Short production run, discontinued after 2009. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mitsubishi Raider article, January 17, 2025 revision.
Third generation full-size luxury sedan. Timing belt maintenance required. Discontinued after 2004 model year. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mitsubishi Diamante article, January 17, 2025 revision.
Third generation Outlander with available third-row seating. S-AWC (Super All-Wheel Control) system available. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mitsubishi Outlander article, January 17, 2025 revision.

engines: 2.0L I4 + dual electric motors (197 hp combined)
2.4L I4 + dual electric motors (221 hp combined, 2019+)
notes: World's first plug-in hybrid SUV. 12 kWh lithium-ion battery (13.8 kWh from 2019). Twin-motor AWD with front and rear electric motors. High-voltage system servicing requires EV-certified technicians. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mitsubishi Outlander PHEV article, January 17, 2025 revision.

Compact crossover positioned below Outlander. Known as ASX in some markets, RVR in others. Manual transmission available early in production. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mitsubishi RVR article, January 17, 2025 revision.

Compact crossover reviving Eclipse nameplate. Turbocharged 1.5L engine with CVT. S-AWC system available on AWD models. Turbocharger maintenance requires attention to oil change intervals. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mitsubishi Eclipse Cross article, January 17, 2025 revision.

Tenth generation compact sedan. Sportback hatchback variant available 2010-2015. AWD available on certain trims. Discontinued after 2017 model year in North America. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mitsubishi Lancer article, January 17, 2025 revision.

High-performance AWD sport sedan with turbocharged 4B11T engine. S-AWC (Super All-Wheel Control) with Active Yaw Control. Twin-Clutch SST transmission on GSR models requires specialized service. Timing chain maintenance critical. Final Edition (2015) produced 303 hp. Requires premium fuel and frequent maintenance. Subcompact hatchback with three-cylinder engine. Sixth generation 2014-2016, seventh generation 2017+. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mitsubishi Mirage article, January 17, 2025 revision.

Early electric vehicle with 16 kWh lithium-ion battery (330-cell LEV50 modules). Range approximately 62 miles. Rear-wheel drive with rear-mounted electric motor. CHAdeMO DC fast charging. Fourth generation Outlander built on Nissan-Renault-Mitsubishi Alliance CMF-C/D platform. Standard 2.5L naturally aspirated engine paired with CVT. S-AWC (Super All-Wheel Control) available on AWD models. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mitsubishi Outlander article, January 17, 2025 revision.

Compact crossover known as RVR in some markets. Third generation continued from 2011 with minor updates. Discontinued after 2024 model year. CVT transmission standard across all trims. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mitsubishi RVR article, January 17, 2025 revision.

notes: EV variant (2018-present). 39.2/64 kWh battery options. Requires EV-certified technicians. Data sourced from Wikipedia, January 2025 revision.

RWD standard range (149 hp), RWD long range (225 hp), AWD long range (321 hp). 800V architecture, 10-80% charge in 18 minutes. Up to 614 km (382 mi) range. Requires EV-certified technicians for 800V high-voltage system. Data sourced from Wikipedia Hyundai Ioniq 6 article, January 2025 revision.

First generation compact SUV. Body-on-frame construction with part-time 4WD. Timing belt engine requires regular replacement. Unique convertible soft-top variant available. Data sourced from Wikipedia Kia Sportage article, January 2025 revision.

engines: Performance dual-motor AWD (429 hp Boost Mode) 77.4/84 kWh battery
notes: E-GMP-based EV with 400V/800V multi-charging architecture (10–80% in 18 minutes at 350 kW) and V2L 3.6 kW power export. North American GV60 adds Face Connect biometric entry, Crystal Sphere shift-by-wire and advanced ADAS sensors needing calibration after collision repair. High-voltage battery isolation checks and insulated PPE are mandatory. Data sourced from Wikipedia Genesis GV60 article, August 6, 2025 revision.

engines: Dual electric motors AWD (365 hp) 87.2/94.5 kWh battery (Electrified G80)
notes: Third-generation G80 rides on the M3 platform with standard 8-speed automatic and available HTRAC AWD. North American lineup features 2.5T and 3.5T gasoline engines plus the limited Electrified G80 dual-motor AWD with 400/800V rapid charging hardware and 87.2/94.5 kWh packs (California and select state availability through 2025). 2024 refresh adds a 27-inch OLED dash that requires OEM programming after replacement. Data sourced from Wikipedia Genesis G80 article, September 22, 2025 revision.

engines: 3.5L Smartstream G3.5 T-GDi V6 w/ 48V e-supercharger (409 hp)
notes: Flagship sedan with standard HTRAC AWD, rear-wheel steering and multi-chamber air suspension that require calibration after chassis work. Long-wheelbase models add a 48V e-supercharger mild-hybrid version of the 3.5T V6 (409 hp) alongside executive rear-seat electronics, demanding careful battery isolation and diagnostics. Data sourced from Wikipedia Genesis G90 article, September 13, 2025 revision.

Second generation W123 (1975-1985). Predecessor to E-Class. Multiple diesel variants including 240D, 300D, 300TD turbodiesel. Wagon (T-model) and coupe variants available. Known for exceptional durability. Brass-era diesel technology requires specialized service. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mercedes-Benz W123 article, January 2025 revision.

First generation W116 (1972-1980). First officially designated S-Class. 450SEL 6.9 features largest production gasoline engine at the time. Hydropneumatic self-leveling suspension on 6.9 variant. Pioneered safety and luxury standards. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mercedes-Benz W116 article, January 2025 revision.

Third generation R107 (1971-1989). 350SL and 450SL primary North American models. Removable hardtop. V8 engines only for US market. Known for build quality and longevity. Vintage technology requires specialized knowledge. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mercedes-Benz R107 article, January 2025 revision.

W114/W115 generation (1968-1976). Nicknamed stroke/8. 220D, 240D diesel variants popular. 280 and 280C coupe available. Predecessor to W123. Vintage diesel technology requires specialized service expertise. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mercedes-Benz W114 article, January 2025 revision.

First generation C107 (1971-1981). Fixed-roof coupe variant of R107 SL. 350SLC, 450SLC, and 500SLC available. Longer wheelbase than SL roadster. Vintage V8 technology. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mercedes-Benz R107 article, January 2025 revision.

First generation W201 (1982-1993). First compact Mercedes. 190E 2.3 features Cosworth-developed engine. Diesel 190D available. Pioneer of Mercedes compact sedan segment. Diesel requires specialized service. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mercedes-Benz W201 article, January 2025 revision.

Second generation W124 (1984-1997). Replaced W123. Multiple diesel variants available including 300D turbodiesel. E-Class designation adopted in 1993. Diesel requires specialized service. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mercedes-Benz W124 article, January 2025 revision.

Third generation W126 (1979-1991). Longest S-Class production run. SEC coupe variant available. 560SEL features 5.6L V8. Introduced aerodynamic design and improved fuel efficiency. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mercedes-Benz W126 article, January 2025 revision.

Third generation R107 (1971-1989). Longest SL production run at 18 years. 560SL features 5.6L V8. Removable hardtop. Known for build quality and durability. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mercedes-Benz R107 article, January 2025 revision.

Third generation C126 (1981-1991). Coupe variant of W126 S-Class. 500SEC and 560SEC popular models. Pillarless hardtop design. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mercedes-Benz W126 article, January 2025 revision.

First generation W202 (1993-2000). First C-Class model. C36 AMG features 3.6L V6. Diesel C220 available. Wagon variant introduced in 1996. Diesel requires specialized service. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mercedes-Benz C-Class article, January 2025 revision.

Second generation W124 (1984-1997). E-Class name adopted in 1993. 500E/E500 features hand-built 5.0L V8. Multiple diesel variants available. E320 4MATIC offers AWD. Diesel requires specialized service. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mercedes-Benz E-Class article, January 2025 revision.

Third generation W210 (1995-2002). Four headlight design. E55 AMG features 5.4L V8 producing 349 hp. E320 4MATIC offers AWD. Wagon variant available. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mercedes-Benz E-Class article, January 2025 revision.
