Fourth generation 718 Cayman (982.2 facelift) mid-engine coupe. Turbocharged 4-cylinder engines, naturally aspirated 6-cylinder in GTS/GT4 variants. GT4 features race-derived suspension and 4.0L engine from 911 GT3. Data sourced from Wikipedia Porsche Cayman article, January 2025 revision.

engines: 3.0L turbo V6 + electric motor E-Hybrid (455-469 hp)
notes: Third generation E3 Cayenne with turbocharged engines across lineup. E-Hybrid PHEV features 14.1 kWh battery, 3.0L V6 with electric motor, requires high-voltage system expertise. Turbo GT variant (631 hp) most powerful. AWD with Porsche Traction Management. Data sourced from Wikipedia Porsche Cayenne article, January 2025 revision.

engines: 3.0L turbo V6 + electric motor E-Hybrid (455-469 hp)
notes: Third generation E3 Cayenne Coupe variant with sloping roofline. Same powertrain options as standard Cayenne including E-Hybrid PHEV. Turbo GT variant (631 hp) available. AWD with Porsche Traction Management. Data sourced from Wikipedia Porsche Cayenne article, January 2025 revision.

First generation 95B Macan facelift (2019+) with updated styling and powertrains. Built on VW Group MLB platform. PDK dual-clutch transmission, AWD standard. Discontinued 4-cylinder in some markets. Data sourced from Wikipedia Porsche Macan article, January 2025 revision.

All-new second generation Macan as dedicated EV on PPE platform (co-developed with Audi). 100 kWh battery, 800V architecture like Taycan. Dual-motor AWD Turbo variant produces 630 hp. Requires EV-certified technicians for high-voltage system service. Data sourced from Wikipedia Porsche Macan article, January 2025 revision.

engines: 2.9L twin-turbo V6 + electric motor E-Hybrid (455-560 hp)
notes: Second generation G2 Panamera (2017+) with various powertrain options. E-Hybrid PHEV features 17.9 kWh battery (14.1 kWh pre-2021) with electric motor, requires high-voltage expertise. Turbo S E-Hybrid most powerful (689 hp). Sport Turismo wagon variant available. Data sourced from Wikipedia Porsche Panamera article, January 2025 revision.

First all-electric Porsche with 800V high-voltage architecture. 79.2-105 kWh Performance Battery Plus. 2-speed transmission on rear axle. Multiple variants: base RWD, 4S, GTS, Turbo, Turbo S (750 hp). Requires EV-certified technicians for service. Data sourced from Wikipedia Porsche Taycan article, January 2025 revision.

Cross Turismo variant of Taycan with increased ground clearance and wagon body style. 800V architecture, 93.4 kWh battery. Available in 4, 4S, Turbo, Turbo S variants. Off-road design mode available. Requires EV-certified technicians. Data sourced from Wikipedia Porsche Taycan article, January 2025 revision.

Sport Turismo wagon variant added in 2024 facelift, lower than Cross Turismo. 800V architecture with improved 105 kWh Performance Battery Plus. Available across all trim levels including base RWD. Requires EV-certified technicians. Data sourced from Wikipedia Porsche Taycan article, January 2025 revision.

Early BMW six-cylinder saloons with tubular backbone chassis. Mechanical drum brakes require meticulous adjustment and woven lining relining. Engines use poured babbitt bearings—line-bore service needed during rebuilds. Data sourced from Wikipedia BMW 303 article, October 3, 2025 revision.

Streamlined saloon with hydraulic brakes and box-section frame. Cable-operated gearbox linkage needs periodic lubrication; independent front suspension kingpins must be greased every 500 miles. Fabric roof cabriolets require canvas reproofing. Data sourced from Wikipedia BMW 326 article, October 8, 2025 revision.

Coachbuilt grand tourer sharing 326 chassis; timber framing needs preservation with modern epoxies. Dual Solex carburetors require synching; convertible tops use leather straps needing conditioning. Data sourced from Wikipedia BMW 327 article, October 8, 2025 revision.

Lightweight alloy-bodied sports roadster with hemispherical combustion chambers and triple Solex carbs. Requires wire-wheel truing, finned drum cooling, and pre-war electrical maintenance. Limited spare parts necessitate reproduction castings. Data sourced from Wikipedia BMW 328 article, October 6, 2025 revision.

Hand-built luxury sedans with perimeter frame and torsion-bar rear suspension. Brake system uses hydraulic assist with drum brakes—verify wheel cylinder availability. V8 models rely on cork gaskets and require leaded-fuel substitutes; engine removal demands nose clip removal. Data sourced from Wikipedia BMW 501 article, October 6, 2025 revision.

Front-hinged door microcar with sliding side windows and motorcycle-derived engine. Final drive uses duplex chain enclosed in oil bath requiring periodic tensioning. Cable-operated brakes need careful adjustment; check rubber suspension elements for dry rot. Data sourced from Wikipedia BMW Isetta article, October 6, 2025 revision.

Extended-wheelbase Isetta derivative with rear swing-axle; inspect portal gearbox oil and constant velocity bellows. Bathtub-style chassis prone to rust in heater duct; ensure body-off restoration for structural repairs. Data sourced from Wikipedia BMW 600 article, October 6, 2025 revision.

Aluminum-bodied roadster with magnesium components and drum brakes. Requires coach-built panel fabrication and careful torque on aluminum frame rails. V8 uses dual Zenith carbs and mechanical fuel pump—synchronize linkage and fit ethanol-safe hoses. Data sourced from Wikipedia BMW 507 article, October 9, 2025 revision.

Rear-engine monocoque microcar using motorcycle-derived flat-twin with chain-driven camshaft; valve clearance adjustment every 6,000 miles. Cooling shrouds crack with age—replace to prevent overheating. Early synchromesh gearbox still requires double-clutching into first gear. Data sourced from Wikipedia BMW 700 article, October 11, 2025 revision.

Neue Klasse introduced unit-body construction and front disc brakes; North American 2000 models used Solex two-barrel carbs requiring balance and throttle linkage sync. Generator charging upgrades recommended for air-conditioned cars. Mechanical valve lash adjustment every 6k miles critical on M10 engines. Data sourced from Wikipedia BMW Neue Klasse article, October 5, 2025 revision.

Lightweight sport sedan with MacPherson struts and semi-trailing rear arms. Kugelfischer mechanical injection on tii requires precise pump timing; Turbo models need boost-control check valves and forged pistons. Convert drum rear brakes to finned aluminum drums for improved cooling. Data sourced from Wikipedia BMW 2002 article, October 10, 2025 revision.

Executive sedan with dual Zenith carburetors (2800) or Bosch D-Jetronic injection (3.0Si). Aluminum front calipers require stainless line upgrades; replace timing chain guides and adjust valves every 7.5k miles. Heater box foam deteriorates—restoration improves defrost performance. Data sourced from Wikipedia BMW New Six article, October 12, 2025 revision.

Hand-built Karmann body prone to rust—inspect shock towers and rocker panels. D-Jetronic injection on CSi requires manifold pressure sensor calibration; CSL aluminum panels need specialized rivet/bonding repairs. Frameless doors require careful window alignment. Data sourced from Wikipedia BMW E9 article, October 9, 2025 revision.

First-generation 5 Series introduced fuel-injected M30 inline-six with Bosch L-Jetronic; careful vacuum leak diagnosis prevents lean conditions. Early thermal reactors on California cars create high underhood temps—inspect manifolds. Manual gearboxes require Redline MTL and clutch pivot lubrication. Data sourced from Wikipedia BMW 5 Series (E12) article, October 6, 2025 revision.

US-market E21 retained CIS fuel injection and thermal reactor emissions components; maintain timing chain tensioner and adjust valves every 15k miles. Rear semi-trailing arms benefit from eccentric bushings during alignments. Baur cabriolet conversions require inspection of rollover hoop mounting points. Data sourced from Wikipedia BMW 3 Series (E21) article, October 7, 2025 revision.

Hand-built mid-engine homologation car with tubular spaceframe and fiberglass body. Dry-sump lubrication requires pre-oiling before start-up; Kugelfischer mechanical injection demands throttle-body sync. Limited spare support necessitates custom fabrication and strict torque specs on composite panels. Data sourced from Wikipedia BMW M1 article, October 10, 2025 revision.

Iconic E30 uses timing belt-driven M20 engines (60k-mile interval) and K-Jetronic/Motronic injection. M3’s S14 requires shimmed valves and twin throttle synch. 325ix AWD adds transfer case viscous coupling—replace fluids to prevent bind. Data sourced from Wikipedia BMW 3 Series (E30) article, October 3, 2025 revision.

E28 features Bosch Motronic, ABS, and optional limited-slip differential. Timing belt service critical on M20, while M5’s hand-built M88/S38 needs 5k-mile valve adjustments and sodium-filled exhaust valves. Brake hydroboost accumulators require pressure testing. Data sourced from Wikipedia BMW 5 Series (E28) article, October 7, 2025 revision.

engines: 3.5L M30 inline-6 (208 hp) L6 (US luxury package)
notes: Sharknose GT uses forward-hinged hood over M30 engines; timing chain with oil spray bar—clean banjo bolts to avoid cam starvation. TRX metric tires on early cars require conversion. Self-leveling rear suspension (SLS) on M6/L6 needs nitrogen sphere replacement and ride-height reset. Data sourced from Wikipedia BMW 6 Series (E24) article, October 8, 2025 revision.

engines: 3.4L M102/M106 turbo inline-6 (252 hp) 745i (limited NA gray-market)
notes: First 7 Series with onboard computer and optional hydraulic self-leveling. K-Jetronic fuel injection requires CO adjustment; timing chain tensioner updates recommended. Turbocharged grey-market 745i uses air-to-air intercooling—ensure wastegate diaphragm integrity. Data sourced from Wikipedia BMW 7 Series (E23) article, October 9, 2025 revision.

E32 introduced double-glazed glass, ASC+T stability control, and V12 powertrains. Dual-battery system requires synchronized replacement, and self-leveling rear with LAD spheres needs nitrogen recharge. Early CAN-bus-style diagnostics require BMW DIS testers. Data sourced from Wikipedia BMW 7 Series (E32) article, October 8, 2025 revision.

E36 introduced multilink rear Z-axle and VANOS cam timing. Cooling systems are fragile—replace radiators, expansion tanks, and water pumps around 90k miles. M3 S52 requires valve adjustments and rear subframe reinforcement; Convertible tops need tension cable inspection. Data sourced from Wikipedia BMW 3 Series (E36) article, October 8, 2025 revision.

E34 uses recirculating-ball steering and EML throttle controls on V8s; check for timing chain guide wear. M5 hand-built engines require valve adjustments and twin fuel pumps. Self-leveling rear suspension on wagons demands fluid bleed and ride-height calibration. Data sourced from Wikipedia BMW 5 Series (E34) article, October 7, 2025 revision.

Last BMW flagship with traditional design; features double wishbone front suspension and extensive multiplex wiring. V12 cars use hydraulic brake booster and rear self-leveling—bleed LDS fluid carefully. Pixel failures in MID/cluster common; repairs require soldering or module exchange. Data sourced from Wikipedia BMW 7 Series (E38) article, October 8, 2025 revision.

Grand tourer with pillarless doors, active rear axle kinematics, and pop-up headlights. Twin battery electrical system requires synchronized charging; V12 timing chain guides and EML throttle modules demand specialized service. Check rear hydraulic rear-steer accumulators for leaks. Data sourced from Wikipedia BMW 8 Series (E31) article, October 13, 2025 revision.

Roadster built in Spartanburg with semi-trailing rear axle requiring regular bushing inspection. Canvas tops rely on tension straps and drain tubes—clear to prevent trunk module damage. M variants need subframe reinforcement and differential mount checks. Data sourced from Wikipedia BMW Z3 article, October 9, 2025 revision.

North American launch year imported from Spartanburg; combines Range Rover-derived chassis with BMW electronics. Monitor front CV axle boots and air suspension compressor (if equipped) on early builds. Data sourced from Wikipedia BMW X5 article, September 29, 2025 revision.

Entry-level rear-drive coupe/convertible with hydraulic steering and optional M Sport brakes. Twin-turbo N54/N55 models require high-pressure fuel pump and injector campaigns; convertible top frame demands BMW alignment fixtures during repair. Data sourced from Wikipedia BMW 1 Series (E81) article, October 9, 2025 revision.

E46 remains a core service vehicle with VANOS variable cam timing, SMG hydraulics on M3, and optional xi AWD requiring front diff fluid service. Rear subframe reinforcement is critical to prevent cracking; ensure rain tray drains clear to avoid DME water intrusion. Data sourced from Wikipedia BMW 3 Series (E46) article, October 15, 2025 revision.

E90 family introduced electric steering on xi models and EfficientDynamics systems. N54 twin-turbo engines need walnut blasting and HPFP replacement, while SCR-equipped 335d requires DEF/DPF maintenance. M3's carbon driveshaft and S65 rod bearings demand inspection schedules. Data sourced from Wikipedia BMW 3 Series (E90) article, October 3, 2025 revision.

E60 brought active steering, adaptive headlights, and early iDrive with MOST bus networking. SMG III clutches require clutch teach-in, while S85 V10 needs rod bearing and throttle actuator service. Aluminum front suspension arms demand torque-to-yield fasteners. Data sourced from Wikipedia BMW 5 Series (E60) article, October 14, 2025 revision.

engines: 3.0L M57 turbo diesel inline-6 (184 hp) 530d (limited NA diesel testing)
notes: E39 introduced rack-and-pinion steering and extensive aluminum front suspension—torque fasteners to spec to avoid shimmy. 540i/M5 models use DSC and Servotronic steering that need calibration; S62 V8 requires VANOS seal monitoring and rod bearing service. Self-leveling rear air suspension on wagons needs ride-height calibration. Data sourced from Wikipedia BMW 5 Series (E39) article, October 8, 2025 revision.

Luxury grand tourer with active roll stabilization, adaptive dampers, and aluminum body panels requiring OEM repair procedures. S85 V10-powered M6 uses SMG clutch adaptation and specific 10W-60 oil. Convertible top hydraulic lines run through trunk hinge area—check for leaks during service. Data sourced from Wikipedia BMW 6 Series (E63) article, October 14, 2025 revision.

First iDrive generation with fiber-optic MOST bus; requires specialized diagnostics for infotainment faults. Active anti-roll bars and comfort access door closers need ISTA calibration after replacement. N62 valve stem seal and coolant pipe issues common—BMW repair sleeves recommended. Data sourced from Wikipedia BMW 7 Series (E65) article, October 12, 2025 revision.

engines: 3.2L S54 inline-6 (330 hp) Z4 M Coupe/Roadster
notes: Roadster with power soft top utilizing hydraulic pump in trunk—susceptible to water intrusion. Coupe adds fixed roof stiffness; M variants use S54 with valve adjustment intervals and CSL-derived braking hardware. Alignment requires specialty front camber tools. Data sourced from Wikipedia BMW Z4 (E85) article, October 13, 2025 revision.

Folding hardtop integrates triple-hydraulic pump system; requires initialization and leak checks after service. Turbo engines need HPFP monitoring and charge pipe inspections. Adaptive M suspension with electronic damping requires ride-height calibration post repair. Data sourced from Wikipedia BMW Z4 (E89) article, October 8, 2025 revision.

First-generation SAV with xDrive transfer case requiring ATF flush intervals; front differential output seals prone to leaks. Panoramic roof drains clog easily—clean to prevent headliner water damage. Data sourced from Wikipedia BMW X3 article, September 29, 2025 revision.

Early SAV with air suspension on 7-seat models, requiring ride-height calibration and leak checks. V8 models prone to valve cover and timing chain guide wear; ensure cooling system overhaul at 100k miles. Transfer case fluid (BMW DTF1) needs periodic service to avoid xDrive binding. Data sourced from Wikipedia BMW X5 article, September 29, 2025 revision.

Second-generation X5 introduced optional third-row seats, active steering, and Dynamic Handling Package; calibrations needed after suspension work. Early models used 6-speed auto with xDrive clutch adaptation. Keep panoramic roof drains clear and monitor electronic parking brake for recalibration. Data sourced from Wikipedia BMW X5 article, September 29, 2025 revision.

Launch Sports Activity Coupe with standard xDrive, active roll stabilization, and optional self-leveling rear air suspension. Twin-turbo N63 requires turbo coolant line inspections; ensure active roll bar neutralization using ISTA before disconnecting links. Data sourced from Wikipedia BMW X6 article, October 10, 2025 revision.

Compact rear-drive coupe/convertible with optional xDrive and performance-oriented M Sport cooling, limited-slip differential, and adaptive dampers that require BMW ISTA calibrations after suspension or alignment work. Turbocharged engines use direct injection and require premium fuel with carbon-cleaning intervals. Data sourced from Wikipedia BMW 2 Series (F22) article, October 9, 2025 revision.

Advanced driver assistance (Active Cruise, Lane Departure) demand ISTA calibration following sensor replacement. Data sourced from Wikipedia BMW 3 Series (F30) article, October 5, 2025 revision.

F32/F33/F36 lineup leverages wider front track and adaptive suspension tuning; M4 models add carbon-ceramic brakes and active M differential requiring torque sensor resets after service. Options such as full LED headlamps and HUD demand coding/aiming post-replacement. Data sourced from Wikipedia BMW 4 Series (F32) article, October 5, 2025 revision.

Sixth-generation F10 brought optional xDrive, adaptive dampers, and integral active steering. Twin-turbo V8 models require valve stem seal and timing chain inspection; aluminum front subframes demand proper torque sequence. Active driver aids (night vision, lane keep) need BMW ISTA calibration after service. Data sourced from Wikipedia BMW 5 Series (F10) article, October 5, 2025 revision.

Gran Turismo flagship uses carbon fiber roof options, adaptive anti-roll, and active rear steering on xDrive models, all requiring calibration. N63 service includes valve stem seal, injectors, and turbo cooling campaigns. Heads-up display and night vision components need coding after replacement. Data sourced from Wikipedia BMW 6 Series (F12) article, September 25, 2025 revision.

engines: 2.0L B48 turbo I4 + e-motor (322 hp combined) 740e xDrive iPerformance

Gesture Control, Bowers & Wilkins audio, and HUD need coding post replacement. Data sourced from Wikipedia BMW 7 Series (G11) article, October 11, 2025 revision.

Second-generation X1 moved to UKL front-drive architecture but North American models remained AWD. Offers optional adjustable damping and head-up display needing coding. Tight packaging around transverse engine requires special service tools for timing chain and water pump access. Data sourced from Wikipedia BMW X1 article, September 9, 2025 revision.

engines: 2.0L B48 turbo I4 (302 hp) M35i xDrive

Coupe-profile SAV adds torque vectoring and optional adaptive suspension. M40i uses performance cooling and larger M Sport brakes requiring careful bleed and ISTA ABS initialization. Surround View cameras and Parking Assistant need calibration after body repair. Data sourced from Wikipedia BMW X4 article, October 14, 2025 revision.

engines: 3.0L B58 turbo I6 (382 hp) M240i xDrive

Carbon core SUV with 71–111.5 kWh packs on 400V architecture supporting up to 200 kW DC fast charging; technicians must follow BMW HV lockout/tagout and thermal management procedures. Active roll control, adaptive M dampers, and performance brake-by-wire system demand ISTA setup post-repair. Data sourced from Wikipedia BMW XM article, September 2, 2025 revision.

ÖV 4 'Jakob' (1927-1929). Volvo's first production car, nicknamed after factory worker Jakob who test-drove prototypes. Side-valve inline-4 engine, rear-wheel drive. Open tourer body style. Only 275 units produced. Brass-era vehicle requiring specialized vintage restoration expertise and extremely rare parts. Data sourced from Wikipedia Volvo ÖV 4 article, January 2025 revision.

PV4 (1927-1929). Closed sedan variant of ÖV 4, also known as 'Göteborgsvagnen'. Side-valve inline-4 engine, rear-wheel drive. Weatherproof closed body for Swedish climate. Only 500 units produced. Brass-era vehicle requiring specialized vintage restoration expertise. Data sourced from Wikipedia Volvo PV4 article, January 2025 revision.

PV36 Carioca (1935-1938). Volvo's first car with streamlined Art Deco styling. Inline-6 engine, rear-wheel drive. Independent front suspension. Named after Brazilian Carioca dance. Rare vintage model requiring specialized restoration expertise and period-correct parts. Data sourced from Wikipedia Volvo PV36 article, January 2025 revision.

PV51-58 Series (1936-1945). Pre-war and wartime production cars with various body styles. Inline-6 engines, rear-wheel drive. PV51 sedan, PV52 sedan, PV53 convertible, PV54 taxi, PV55 coupe, PV56 sedan, PV57 sedan, PV58 taxi. Production limited during WWII. Vintage restoration requires specialized knowledge. Data sourced from Wikipedia Volvo PV50 series article, January 2025 revision.

PV444 (1947-1958, 1940s coverage). Volvo's first mass-produced car after WWII. Unibody construction, independent front suspension. Fastback 2-door sedan design. Rear-wheel drive with inline-4 engine. Brass-era manufacturing techniques and vintage parts availability require specialized restoration expertise. Data sourced from Wikipedia Volvo PV444/544 article, January 2025 revision.

PV60 (1946-1950). Post-war continuation of pre-war PV models with updated styling. Large sedan with inline-6 engine. Rear-wheel drive. Separate body-on-frame construction. Vintage restoration requires specialized knowledge of 1940s automotive technology. Data sourced from Wikipedia Volvo PV60 article, January 2025 revision.

Amazon/120 Series (1956-1970, 1950s coverage). Named Amazon in Sweden, exported as 122S beginning in 1958. Rear-wheel drive with inline-4 engines. Three-box design influenced by American cars of the era. Introduced many safety innovations including three-point seatbelt. Data sourced from Wikipedia Volvo Amazon article, January 2025 revision.

PV544 (1958-1965, 1950s coverage). Evolution of PV444 with updated styling and more powerful engines. Fastback 2-door sedan design. Rear-wheel drive with inline-4 engines. Rally success in 1960s. Replaced by Amazon/120 Series. Data sourced from Wikipedia Volvo PV444/544 article, January 2025 revision.

P1900 sports roadster (1956-1957). Volvo's first sports car with fiberglass body. Limited production of only 68 units. Rear-wheel drive with inline-4 engine. Discontinued due to quality issues and poor sales. Extremely rare, requires vintage restoration expertise. Data sourced from Wikipedia Volvo P1900 article, January 2025 revision.

Duett (1953-1969, 1950s coverage). Commercial vehicle based on PV444/544 platform. Available as panel van or passenger wagon. Rear-wheel drive with inline-4 engines. Dual-purpose design for commercial and family use. Data sourced from Wikipedia Volvo Duett article, January 2025 revision.

P1800 sports coupe (1961-1973). Iconic sports car famously driven by Roger Moore in The Saint. P1800 (1961-1963 Jensen-built), 1800S (1963-1969 Sweden-built), 1800E (1970-1972), 1800ES (1972-1973 shooting brake). Inline-4 B18 or B20 engines. Rear-wheel drive. Vintage parts availability requires specialized service knowledge. Data sourced from Wikipedia Volvo P1800 article, January 2025 revision.

140 Series (1966-1974). Angular design replacing Amazon/120 Series. 142 (2-door), 144 (4-door), 145 (wagon). Rear-wheel drive with inline-4 engines. Introduced modern safety features including collapsible steering column and disc brakes. Data sourced from Wikipedia Volvo 140 Series article, January 2025 revision.

164 luxury sedan (1968-1975). Upmarket 6-cylinder variant of 140 Series. Volvo's first inline-6 engine (B30). Longer hood to accommodate inline-6. Rear-wheel drive. Positioned as flagship luxury sedan. Data sourced from Wikipedia Volvo 164 article, January 2025 revision.

Amazon/120 Series (1956-1970, 1960s coverage). Named Amazon in Sweden, exported as 122S. 121 (1-door), 122S (2/4-door), 123GT (2-door wagon), 221/222 (4-door/wagon). Rear-wheel drive with inline-4 engines. Classic three-box design. Highly regarded for durability. Data sourced from Wikipedia Volvo Amazon article, January 2025 revision.

240 Series (1974-1993, 1970s coverage). Iconic boxy Volvo design replacing 140 Series. 242 (2-door), 244 (4-door), 245 (wagon). Rear-wheel drive with inline-4 or diesel inline-6. Renowned for safety with energy-absorbing crumple zones. Data sourced from Wikipedia Volvo 200 Series article, January 2025 revision.

260 Series (1974-1982, 1970s coverage). Upmarket variant of 240 with PRV V6 engine. 262C Bertone coupe, 264 sedan, 265 wagon. PRV (Peugeot-Renault-Volvo) V6 co-developed engine. Rear-wheel drive. Data sourced from Wikipedia Volvo 200 Series article, January 2025 revision.

66 compact (1975-1981). Based on DAF 66 after Volvo acquired DAF passenger car division. Front-wheel drive with Renault engines and DAF Variomatic CVT or manual transmission. Not sold in North America. Data sourced from Wikipedia Volvo 66 article, January 2025 revision.

300 Series (1976-1991, 1970s coverage). Developed from DAF 77, rear-wheel drive compact. 340 hatchback, 360 sedan/wagon. Renault engines initially, later Volvo inline-4. Some models featured Variomatic CVT. Not officially sold in North America. Data sourced from Wikipedia Volvo 300 Series article, January 2025 revision.

140 Series (1966-1974, 1970s coverage). Angular design replacing Amazon/120 Series. 142 (2-door), 144 (4-door), 145 (wagon). Rear-wheel drive with inline-4 B18 or B20 engines. Introduced modern safety features including collapsible steering column. Data sourced from Wikipedia Volvo 140 Series article, January 2025 revision.

700 Series (1982-1992) including 740 and 760 variants. Replaced 240 at upper end of range. Rear-wheel drive with inline-4 gasoline/turbo, PRV V6, or diesel engines. 760 featured PRV V6 and more luxury appointments. Available as sedan and wagon. Data sourced from Wikipedia Volvo 700 Series article, January 2025 revision.

480 sports coupe (1986-1995). Volvo's first front-wheel drive car and first hatchback. Based on Mitsubishi platform with Renault engines. 3-door shooting brake/hatchback design. Not officially sold in North America. Data sourced from Wikipedia Volvo 480 article, January 2025 revision.

780 luxury coupe (1985-1990). Two-door coupe based on 760 platform, designed and built by Bertone in Italy. PRV V6 or turbocharged inline-4 engines. Rear-wheel drive. Limited production luxury coupe. Data sourced from Wikipedia Volvo 780 article, January 2025 revision.

940 sedan/wagon (1990-1998). Evolution of 740, part of 900 Series. Rear-wheel drive with inline-4 gasoline, turbo, or diesel engines. Known for reliability and safety. Available as sedan and wagon. Data sourced from Wikipedia Volvo 940 article, January 2025 revision.

960 sedan/wagon (1990-1998). Flagship model replacing 760, part of 900 Series. Inline-6 engines, rear-wheel drive. More luxurious than 940. Later renamed S90/V90 in 1996. Data sourced from Wikipedia Volvo 960 article, January 2025 revision.

240 Series (1974-1993, 1980s coverage). Iconic boxy Volvo design with rear-wheel drive. Inline-4 gasoline, turbo, or diesel engines. Renowned for safety and durability. Available as 2-door, 4-door sedan, and wagon. Production continued through 1993. Data sourced from Wikipedia Volvo 200 Series article, January 2025 revision.

First generation 850 (1991-1997). First front-wheel drive Volvo with transverse inline-5 engines. Available as sedan and wagon. High-performance T5 and T5-R variants with turbocharging. Competed in BTCC with estate/wagon body style. Data sourced from Wikipedia Volvo 850 article, January 2025 revision.

S70 sedan on P80 platform (1997-2000). Essentially a facelifted and renamed 850 sedan. Inline-5 engines with naturally aspirated or turbocharged T5 variants. AWD available on some models. Data sourced from Wikipedia Volvo S70 article, January 2025 revision.

First generation V70 wagon on P80 platform (1997-2000). Wagon variant replacing 850 estate. Inline-5 engines with turbo T5 and high-performance R variants. XC70 Cross Country off-road variant introduced. AWD available. Data sourced from Wikipedia Volvo V70 article, January 2025 revision.

First generation XC70 Cross Country (1997-2002, initially V70 XC). Raised-suspension AWD variant of V70 wagon with increased ground clearance and body cladding. Inline-5 turbo engines. Data sourced from Wikipedia Volvo XC70 article, January 2025 revision.

First generation S40 on GV platform (1995-2004). Compact sedan co-developed with Mitsubishi (Mitsubishi Carisma). Inline-4 engines with naturally aspirated or turbocharged configurations. Replaced 440 sedan. Data sourced from Wikipedia Volvo S40 article, January 2025 revision.

First generation V40 wagon on GV platform (1995-2004). Compact wagon co-developed with Mitsubishi. Inline-4 engines, naturally aspirated or turbocharged. Wagon variant of S40 sedan. Replaced 440/460 models. Data sourced from Wikipedia Volvo V40 article, January 2025 revision.

First generation C70 on P80 platform (1998-2005). Sports coupe and convertible based on 850/S70/V70 platform. Turbocharged inline-5 engines. Coupe produced 1997-2002, convertible 1998-2005. Convertible features power-retractable soft top. Data sourced from Wikipedia Volvo C70 article, January 2025 revision.

First generation S80 on P2 platform (1999-2006). Flagship sedan replacing 960. Inline-5 and inline-6 engines with transverse mounting. T6 twin-turbocharged inline-6 available. First Volvo with side-impact curtain airbags for all rows. Data sourced from Wikipedia Volvo S80 article, January 2025 revision.

First generation S90 sedan (1996-1998). Executive sedan replacing 960, essentially a facelifted and renamed 960. Inline-6 engines, rear-wheel drive. Short production run before replacement by first-gen S80. Data sourced from Wikipedia Volvo S90 article, January 2025 revision.

First generation V90 wagon (1996-1998). Executive wagon variant, essentially facelifted and renamed 960 estate. Inline-6 engines, rear-wheel drive. Short production run before discontinuation. Data sourced from Wikipedia Volvo V90 article, January 2025 revision.

Second generation S40 on C1/P1 platform (2004-2012). Compact sedan sharing platform with Ford Focus and Mazda3. Inline-5 engines, naturally aspirated 2.4L or turbocharged 2.5L T5. AWD available on T5 models. Data sourced from Wikipedia Volvo S40 article, January 2025 revision.

First generation V50 wagon on C1/P1 platform (2004-2012). Compact wagon variant of S40 sedan. Inline-5 engines with 2.4L naturally aspirated or 2.5L T5 turbo. AWD available on T5 variants. Data sourced from Wikipedia Volvo V50 article, January 2025 revision.

First generation S60 on P2 platform (2001-2009). Compact executive sedan replacing S70. Inline-5 engines with various turbo configurations. High-performance R variant (300 hp) available. AWD standard on T5 and R models. Data sourced from Wikipedia Volvo S60 article, January 2025 revision.

Second generation V70 on P2 platform (2001-2007). Mid-size wagon with inline-5 engines. High-performance R variant with 300 hp. XC70 Cross Country variant with raised suspension available. Data sourced from Wikipedia Volvo V70 article, January 2025 revision.

Third generation V70 on P3 platform (2007-2016). Mid-size wagon with transverse engine layout. Inline-5 and inline-6 turbo engines. XC70 Cross Country variant continued. Data sourced from Wikipedia Volvo V70 article, January 2025 revision.

Second/third generation XC70 Cross Country (2007-2016). Raised-suspension variant of V70 wagon with increased ground clearance and body cladding. AWD standard. Inline-5, inline-6 turbo, or naturally aspirated inline-6 engines. Data sourced from Wikipedia Volvo XC70 article, January 2025 revision.

Second generation S80 on P3 platform (2007-2016). Flagship sedan with transverse engine layout. Available with 3.2L inline-6, 3.0L turbocharged inline-6, or Yamaha-developed 4.4L V8. Executive variant with extended wheelbase available. Data sourced from Wikipedia Volvo S80 article, January 2025 revision.

First generation XC90 on P2 platform (2003-2014). Volvo's first SUV, 7-passenger luxury vehicle. 2.5L turbo I5, 2.9L twin-turbo I6, 3.2L I6, or 4.4L V8 engines. V8 developed with Yamaha. AWD standard on most models. Data sourced from Wikipedia Volvo XC90 article, January 2025 revision.

First generation XC60 on P3 platform (2008-2017). Compact luxury crossover derived from V70/XC70 platform. Inline-5 turbo, inline-6 turbo, and later 2.0L Drive-E inline-4 turbo engines. R-Design sport variant available. Data sourced from Wikipedia Volvo XC60 article, January 2025 revision.

First generation C30 (2008-2013). Compact 3-door hatchback on C1 platform. Inline-5 engines, naturally aspirated 2.4L or turbocharged 2.5L T5. Design inspired by Volvo PV544 and P1800ES with distinctive glass tailgate. Data sourced from Wikipedia Volvo C30 article, January 2025 revision.

Second generation XC90 on SPA platform (2016-present). First vehicle on Volvo's Scalable Product Architecture. Drive-E powertrains with T8 plug-in hybrid featuring 9.2 kWh battery (later 11.6 kWh), approximately 14-18 miles EPA electric range. T6 uses twin-charging (turbo + supercharger). 7-passenger seating. Data sourced from Wikipedia Volvo XC90 article, January 2025 revision.

Second generation S90 sedan on SPA platform (2017-present). Successor to first generation S80. Drive-E engines with T8 PHEV option (11.6 kWh battery). T6 twin-charged powertrain. Available in standard and long-wheelbase variants. Data sourced from Wikipedia Volvo S90 article, January 2025 revision.

Second generation V90 wagon on SPA platform (2017-present). Estate variant of S90 sedan. T8 PHEV available with 11.6 kWh battery. Cross Country variant with increased ground clearance offered. Data sourced from Wikipedia Volvo V90 article, January 2025 revision.

Second generation XC60 on SPA platform (2018-present). Compact luxury SUV with Drive-E powertrains. T8 plug-in hybrid with 11.6 kWh battery. T6 twin-charged engine. Awarded European Car of the Year 2018. Data sourced from Wikipedia Volvo XC60 article, January 2025 revision.

Third generation V60 on SPA platform (2019-present). Compact wagon with Drive-E powertrains. T8 PHEV available, Cross Country variant with raised suspension. Polestar Engineered performance version offered. Data sourced from Wikipedia Volvo V60 article, January 2025 revision.

Third generation S60 on SPA platform (2019-present). First Volvo manufactured in United States (Charleston, SC plant). Drive-E engines with T8 PHEV option. Polestar Engineered variant available. Data sourced from Wikipedia Volvo S60 article, January 2025 revision.

First generation XC40 on CMA platform (2019-present gasoline, 2021+ electric). Volvo's first compact SUV, shares platform with Geely models. T4 and T5 Drive-E gasoline engines. 2021+ saw introduction of fully electric Recharge variant. Data sourced from Wikipedia Volvo XC40 article, January 2025 revision.

Second generation V40 (2013-2019). Compact hatchback on C1 platform shared with Ford Focus. Not sold in North America. Drive-E powertrains. Cross Country variant with raised ride height available. Data sourced from Wikipedia Volvo V40 article, January 2025 revision.

Second generation S80 (2007-2016). Flagship sedan on P3 platform. Transverse engine layout. T6 inline-6 turbo, naturally aspirated 3.2L I6, and later Drive-E 2.0L turbo. Executive variant with extended wheelbase available in some markets. Data sourced from Wikipedia Volvo S80 article, January 2025 revision.

First generation XC90 late production (2003-2014). P2 platform 7-passenger SUV. 3.2L inline-6, 2.5L turbocharged inline-5, or 2.9L twin-turbo inline-6. Remained in production through 2014 until SPA-platform successor launched. Data sourced from Wikipedia Volvo XC90 article, January 2025 revision.

First generation C30 (2008-2013). Compact 3-door hatchback on C1 platform. Inline-5 engines with naturally aspirated or turbocharged configurations. Design inspired by Volvo PV544 and P1800ES. Data sourced from Wikipedia Volvo C30 article, January 2025 revision.

First generation XC40 Recharge (2021-2025). CMA platform-based BEV with 78 kWh battery pack (75 kWh usable), 400V architecture. Front motor 150 kW, rear motor 150 kW. EPA range approximately 223 miles. Requires EV-certified technicians for high-voltage battery system and powertrain service. Data sourced from Wikipedia Volvo XC40 article, January 2025 revision.

First generation C40 Recharge (2022-present). CMA platform-based BEV with coupe-like roofline. 78 kWh battery pack, 400V architecture, dual motors (150 kW front, 150 kW rear). EPA range approximately 226 miles. Requires EV-certified technicians for high-voltage system service. Data sourced from Wikipedia Volvo C40 article, January 2025 revision.

First generation EX30 (2024-present). CMA platform-based BEV, Volvo's smallest electric SUV. Available with 51 kWh (Single Motor) or 69 kWh (Twin Motor Performance) battery pack. 400V architecture. EPA range up to 275 miles (Single Motor Extended Range). Requires EV-certified technicians. Data sourced from Wikipedia Volvo EX30 article, January 2025 revision.

First generation EX90 (2024-present). SPA2 platform flagship BEV, successor to XC90. 111 kWh battery pack, 400V architecture. Dual motors with approximately 496 hp combined. EPA range approximately 300 miles. Advanced ADAS with LiDAR. Requires EV-certified technicians for high-voltage system and complex electronics. Data sourced from Wikipedia Volvo EX90 article, January 2025 revision.

Second generation S90 2021 refresh (2021-present). SPA platform sedan with Drive-E powertrains. T8 plug-in hybrid combines 2.0L twin-charged engine with electric motor, 11.6 kWh battery. EPA electric range approximately 22 miles. T6 uses both turbo and supercharger. Mild hybrid (B5/B6) available in some markets. Data sourced from Wikipedia Volvo S90 article, January 2025 revision.

Second generation V90 wagon (2017-present). SPA platform estate with Drive-E powertrains. T8 plug-in hybrid with 11.6 kWh battery, approximately 22 miles EPA electric range. Twin-charged T6 available. Cross Country variant with raised suspension also offered. Data sourced from Wikipedia Volvo V90 article, January 2025 revision.

Second generation XC60 2022 update (2018-present). SPA platform compact luxury SUV with Drive-E engines. T8 plug-in hybrid with 11.6 kWh battery (later 14.7 kWh), approximately 19-35 miles EPA electric range depending on model year. T6 twin-charged engine. Mild hybrid variants (B5/B6) available. Data sourced from Wikipedia Volvo XC60 article, January 2025 revision.

Series 1.5 (1968) and Series 2 (1968-1971) sports car. US-spec models with open headlights, raised bumpers, de-tuned engines for emissions. Twin-cam inline-6 engine requires specialized maintenance. Data sourced from Wikipedia Jaguar E-Type article, January 2025 revision.

Luxury sedan (1966-1968). Shared body with Mark X/420G. Featured independent rear suspension and twin-cam inline-6. Final years of Mark X platform before XJ6. Data sourced from Wikipedia Jaguar Mark X article, January 2025 revision.

Series I full-size sedan (1968-1973). Revolutionary design launched September 1968. Combined sports car performance with luxury sedan comfort. Available in standard and long-wheelbase. Twin-cam inline-6 engine. Data sourced from Wikipedia Jaguar XJ article, January 2025 revision.

Series I full-size sedan (1968-1973). Revolutionary design combined sports car performance with luxury sedan comfort. Available in standard and long-wheelbase. Twin-cam inline-6 engines. Data sourced from Wikipedia Jaguar XJ article, January 2025 revision.

Series II full-size sedan (1973-1979). Updated with raised bumpers for US federal regulations. Available in standard and long-wheelbase. Data sourced from Wikipedia Jaguar XJ article, January 2025 revision.

V12 full-size sedan (1972-1979). Series I (1972-1973) and Series II (1973-1979). Available in standard and long-wheelbase. Complex V12 engine requires specialized maintenance. Data sourced from Wikipedia Jaguar XJ article, January 2025 revision.

Grand tourer first generation (1975-1996). V12-only initially. Replaced E-Type. Convertible introduced 1988. Complex V12 engine requires specialized maintenance. Data sourced from Wikipedia Jaguar XJS article, January 2025 revision.

Series 3 sports car (1971-1974). Final E-Type generation with V12 engine. Enlarged grille and wider track. Complex V12 engine requires specialized maintenance. Data sourced from Wikipedia Jaguar E-Type article, January 2025 revision.

XJ Coupe Series II pillarless coupe (1975-1978). Available with inline-6 or V12 engines. Rare model with limited production. Complex V12 option requires specialized maintenance. Data sourced from Wikipedia Jaguar XJ article, January 2025 revision.

Series III full-size sedan (1979-1987). Final series of original XJ6 design. Available in standard and long-wheelbase Vanden Plas. Replaced by XJ40 in 1986. Data sourced from Wikipedia Jaguar XJ article, January 2025 revision.

Series III V12 full-size sedan (1979-1992). XJ12 and XJ-S V12 variants. Available in standard and long-wheelbase. Complex V12 engine requires specialized maintenance. Data sourced from Wikipedia Jaguar XJ article, January 2025 revision.
Grand tourer (1975-1996). V12 and inline-6 variants. Convertible introduced 1988. Manual transmission available 1981-1991. Data sourced from Wikipedia Jaguar XJS article, January 2025 revision.

First generation XJ40 full-size sedan (1986-1994). Completely redesigned from Series III. Available in standard and long-wheelbase Vanden Plas. Data sourced from Wikipedia Jaguar XJ article, January 2025 revision.

XJS convertible variant (1983-1988). Targa-top coupe and full convertible body styles. Complex V12 engine requires specialized maintenance. Data sourced from Wikipedia Jaguar XJS article, January 2025 revision.

Second generation X300 full-size sedan (1994-1997). XJ6 inline-6, XJ12 V12 variants. Available in standard and long-wheelbase. Replaced by X308 in 1997. Data sourced from Wikipedia Jaguar XJ article, January 2025 revision.
First generation X100 grand tourer (1996-2006). Replaced XJS. XKR performance variant introduced 1998 with supercharged V8. Data sourced from Wikipedia Jaguar XK article, January 2025 revision.
Grand tourer final years (1975-1996). Available with inline-6 or V12 engines. 6.0L V12 introduced 1993. Replaced by XK8 in 1996. Data sourced from Wikipedia Jaguar XJS article, January 2025 revision.

Third generation X308 full-size sedan (1997-2003). Introduced AJ-V8 engine family. XJR performance variant with supercharged V8. Available in standard and long-wheelbase. Data sourced from Wikipedia Jaguar XJ article, January 2025 revision.

Third generation X350 full-size luxury sedan (2003-2009). First all-aluminum monocoque Jaguar. Available in standard and long-wheelbase. XJR performance variant with supercharged 4.2L V8. Data sourced from Wikipedia Jaguar XJ article, January 2025 revision.
Second generation X150 grand tourer (2006-2014). Aluminum construction. XKR performance variant with supercharged 4.2L V8. Data sourced from Wikipedia Jaguar XK article, January 2025 revision.

engines: 4.2L supercharged V8 (390 hp, 400 hp - S-Type R)
notes: First generation X200 midsize sedan (1999-2007). Shared DEW platform with Lincoln LS. S-Type R performance variant introduced 2002 with supercharged V8. Data sourced from Wikipedia Jaguar S-Type article, January 2025 revision.

First generation X400 compact sedan (2001-2009). Based on Ford CD132 platform shared with Mondeo. Available in sedan and wagon body styles. Manual transmission available 2002-2005. Data sourced from Wikipedia Jaguar X-Type article, January 2025 revision.

First generation X250 midsize luxury sedan (2008-2015). Aluminum-intensive construction. Replaced S-Type. Supercharged variant requires premium fuel. Data sourced from Wikipedia Jaguar XF article, January 2025 revision.

Fourth generation X351 full-size luxury sedan (2009-2019). All-aluminum monocoque construction. Available in standard and long-wheelbase. Data sourced from Wikipedia Jaguar XJ article, January 2025 revision.

First generation X250 midsize luxury sedan (2008-2015). Aluminum-intensive construction. Supercharged variants require premium fuel. Data sourced from Wikipedia Jaguar XF article, January 2025 revision.
Second generation X260 (2015-2024). Aluminum-intensive architecture. Sportbrake wagon introduced 2017. Data sourced from Wikipedia Jaguar XF article, January 2025 revision.

Fourth generation X351 full-size luxury sedan (2009-2019). All-aluminum monocoque construction. Available in standard and long-wheelbase. Supercharged engines require premium fuel and precise maintenance. Data sourced from Wikipedia Jaguar XJ article, January 2025 revision.

engines: 5.0L supercharged V8 (510 hp XKR, 550 hp XKR-S)
notes: Second generation X150 grand tourer (2006-2014). Aluminum construction. XKR and XKR-S performance variants feature supercharged V8. Discontinued after 2014, replaced by F-Type. Data sourced from Wikipedia Jaguar XK article, January 2025 revision.

First generation sports car X152 (2013-2024). Aluminum-intensive construction. Manual transmission available 2013-2015, reintroduced 2016. SVR performance variant introduced 2016. Data sourced from Wikipedia Jaguar F-Type article, January 2025 revision.

First generation compact luxury sedan X760 (2015-2024). Aluminum-intensive architecture. XE S and XE S V6 performance variants available. Data sourced from Wikipedia Jaguar XE article, January 2025 revision.

First generation F-Pace X761 (2016-present). Jaguar's first crossover SUV. Aluminum-intensive construction. SVR performance variant introduced 2018 with supercharged V8. Data sourced from Wikipedia Jaguar F-Pace article, January 2025 revision.

First generation compact crossover X540 (2017-present). Built on transverse-engine platform. Standard 9-speed automatic transmission. Data sourced from Wikipedia Jaguar E-Pace article, January 2025 revision.

engines: Dual electric motors (394 hp combined, 512 lb-ft)
notes: All-electric crossover with 90 kWh lithium-ion battery pack. 400V high-voltage system requires EV-certified technicians. Aluminum-intensive construction. Estimated 234-256 miles EPA range. Data sourced from Wikipedia Jaguar I-Pace article, January 2025 revision.

Original Series I Land Rover launch (1948-1958). Aluminum body panels over steel framework, permanent four-wheel drive with lockable center differential. 80-inch wheelbase only at launch. Designed as agricultural utility vehicle for post-war Britain. Not officially exported to North America. Basic mechanical systems with minimal complexity. Vintage parts scarcity requires specialist knowledge. Data sourced from Wikipedia Land Rover Series article, January 2025 revision.

First-generation Series I Land Rover (1948-1958). Leaf spring body-on-frame construction, permanent four-wheel drive. Available in 80-inch and 86-inch wheelbases (88-inch from 1956). Utilitarian agricultural/military vehicle. Minimal electronics, basic mechanical systems. Virtually unavailable in North America during production. Vintage parts scarcity and specialist knowledge required. Data sourced from Wikipedia Land Rover Series article, January 2025 revision.

Series II Land Rover (1958-1961). Refined version of Series I with improved headlamp positioning and larger engine. Leaf spring body-on-frame, permanent four-wheel drive. 88-inch and 109-inch wheelbases. Basic mechanical design with minimal electronics. Limited North American availability (grey market). Diesel timing gear service critical. Data sourced from Wikipedia Land Rover Series article, January 2025 revision.

Series IIa Land Rover (1961-1971). Leaf spring body-on-frame construction with permanent four-wheel drive. Available in 88-inch and 109-inch wheelbases. Minimal electronics, basic mechanical systems. Limited US availability (grey market). Diesel timing gear maintenance required. Vintage parts availability concerns. Data sourced from Wikipedia Land Rover Series article, January 2025 revision.

109 Forward Control (1962-1976). Forward control cab-over design based on Series IIa/III. One-tonne payload capacity. Body-on-frame construction with permanent four-wheel drive. Rare in North America, primarily export/military markets. Specialist vehicle with limited parts availability. Data sourced from Wikipedia Land Rover Forward Control article, January 2025 revision.

Lightweight/Air Portable Land Rover (1968-1984). Half-tonne military vehicle designed for helicopter transport. Aluminum body construction, reduced weight versus standard Series models. Permanent four-wheel drive. Primarily British military use, virtually unavailable in North American civilian market. Specialist military components. Data sourced from Wikipedia Land Rover Series article, January 2025 revision.

Third-generation Series Land Rover (1971-1985). Leaf spring body-on-frame construction with permanent four-wheel drive. Features updated interior and dashboard versus Series IIa. Limited US availability (grey market). Basic mechanical systems, timing gear maintenance critical. Diesel timing belt service. Data sourced from Wikipedia Land Rover Series article, January 2025 revision.

First-generation Range Rover launch decade (1970-1996). Body-on-frame construction with coil spring suspension, permanent four-wheel drive. Originally three-door only (five-door added 1981). Carbureted V8 engine with timing chain. Limited US availability until 1987. Vintage mechanical complexity and parts scarcity. Data sourced from Wikipedia Range Rover article, January 2025 revision.

101 Forward Control military vehicle (1972-1978). One-tonne capacity forward control design. Body-on-frame construction with permanent four-wheel drive. Primary military use (British Army). Rare in civilian hands, virtually unavailable in North America. Specialist military-grade components and heavy-duty drivetrain. Data sourced from Wikipedia Land Rover 101 Forward Control article, January 2025 revision.

Coil-sprung Land Rover 90 and 110 models (introduced 1983). Replaced Series III with improved ride quality. Body-on-frame construction with permanent four-wheel drive. Limited US availability (grey market). Basic mechanical systems with minimal electronics. Diesel timing belt maintenance critical. Data sourced from Wikipedia Land Rover Defender article, January 2025 revision.

First-generation Range Rover (1970-1996) during 1980s. Body-on-frame construction with coil spring suspension. Permanent four-wheel drive with lockable center differential. Fuel injection introduced 1985. Diesel available internationally. Vintage carbureted and early fuel injection systems require specialized knowledge. Data sourced from Wikipedia Range Rover article, January 2025 revision.

First-generation Discovery launched 1989. Body-on-frame construction based on Range Rover chassis. Features permanent four-wheel drive, coil spring suspension. Diesel available internationally. Timing chain V8 engine. Transfer case and differential maintenance critical. Limited early US availability. Data sourced from Wikipedia Land Rover Discovery article, January 2025 revision.

Defender branding introduced 1990 for 90/110/130 models. Body-on-frame construction with permanent four-wheel drive. Td5 engine introduced 1998. Limited US availability (primarily grey market imports). Basic mechanical design with minimal electronics. Diesel timing belt service. Data sourced from Wikipedia Land Rover Defender article, January 2025 revision.

First-generation Range Rover final years (1970-1996). Body-on-frame construction with coil spring suspension. Features permanent four-wheel drive, optional air suspension (from 1992). Diesel available internationally. Vintage electronics and mechanical complexity. Timing chain V8 engines. Data sourced from Wikipedia Range Rover article, January 2025 revision.

engines: 2.5L I6 turbo diesel (136 hp BMW M51)
notes: Second-generation Range Rover (P38A). Body-on-frame construction with electronic air suspension standard. First Range Rover with electronic traction control (ETC). Features GEMS/Bosch engine management. BMW diesel engine. Complex air suspension and electronics notorious for reliability issues requiring specialized diagnostics. Data sourced from Wikipedia Range Rover article, January 2025 revision.

First-generation Freelander, marketed as LR1 in North America (2002-2005 only). Monocoque construction. Features Hill Descent Control, viscous coupling center differential. Timing belt I4 engine requires regular service. CVT transmission known for reliability issues. Data sourced from Wikipedia Land Rover Freelander article, January 2025 revision.

Discovery Series II (1999-2004) and late Series I models (1994-1998). Body-on-frame construction. Features Active Cornering Enhancement (ACE), Hill Descent Control. Diesel available internationally. Timing chain V8 engines. Transfer case and differential service critical for longevity. Data sourced from Wikipedia Land Rover Discovery article, January 2025 revision.

Defender with Td5 and TDCi diesel engines. Body-on-frame construction with permanent four-wheel drive. Limited US availability (grey imports). Features basic off-road capability without electronic aids. Diesel timing belt service required. Parts availability concerns for vintage components. Data sourced from Wikipedia Land Rover Defender article, January 2025 revision.

Third-generation Range Rover (L322). Integrated body-frame monocoque construction, first Range Rover with independent suspension. Features air suspension, Terrain Response (from 2005), Hill Descent Control. BMW engines (2003-2005), Ford engines (2006+). Complex electronics require Land Rover diagnostics. Timing chain engines. Data sourced from Wikipedia Range Rover article, January 2025 revision.

Third-generation Discovery, marketed as LR3 in North America. T5 platform with integrated body-on-frame construction. Features Terrain Response, air suspension, Hill Descent Control. Diesel available internationally only. Timing chain engines. Air suspension complexity requires specialized diagnostics. Data sourced from Wikipedia Land Rover Discovery article, January 2025 revision.

First-generation Range Rover Sport (L320). Based on Discovery 3 platform with sportier tuning. Features Terrain Response, air suspension standard, Dynamic Response. Diesel engines available internationally. Timing chain powertrains. Electronic complexity requires Land Rover diagnostic tools. Data sourced from Wikipedia Range Rover Sport article, January 2025 revision.

Second-generation Freelander, marketed as LR2 in North America (2008-2015). Ford EUCD platform. Features Terrain Response, optional Hill Descent Control. Diesel engines available internationally. Timing chain I6 gasoline engine. Haldex AWD system requires fluid service. Data sourced from Wikipedia Land Rover Freelander article, January 2025 revision.

Fourth-generation Discovery, marketed as LR4 in North America (2010-2016). T5 platform with integrated body-on-frame construction. Features Terrain Response, air suspension standard, and Hill Descent Control. Diesel available in international markets only. Timing chain engine. Data sourced from Wikipedia Land Rover Discovery article, January 2025 revision.

First-generation Range Rover Evoque (L538). LR-MS platform (D8 architecture). Available with FWD or AWD. Features Terrain Response and MagneRide adaptive damping. Diesel engines available internationally. Timing chain gasoline engines. Data sourced from Wikipedia Range Rover Evoque article, January 2025 revision.

Fourth-generation Range Rover (L405). All-aluminum monocoque construction. Features air suspension, Terrain Response 2, and Dynamic Response active anti-roll. Diesel variants available internationally. Timing chain engines require specialized service access in tight engine bay. Data sourced from Wikipedia Range Rover article, January 2025 revision.

Second-generation Range Rover Sport (L494). Aluminum-intensive D7u platform. PHEV variant introduced 2018 with 13.1 kWh battery, 31-mile electric range. Air suspension, Terrain Response 2, Dynamic Response standard. PHEV requires high-voltage system expertise. Data sourced from Wikipedia Range Rover Sport article, January 2025 revision.

First-generation Discovery Sport (L550). LR-MS platform (D8). Replaces Freelander in Land Rover lineup. Features Terrain Response, optional seven-seat configuration. Diesel engines available internationally. Timing chain engines. Data sourced from Wikipedia Land Rover Discovery Sport article, January 2025 revision.

Fifth-generation Discovery (L462). Premium Lightweight Architecture (PLA) with aluminum monocoque. Features air suspension, Terrain Response 2, optional seven seats. Diesel available internationally. Intelligent Driveline Dynamics (IDD) requires Land Rover diagnostics. Data sourced from Wikipedia Land Rover Discovery article, January 2025 revision.

First-generation Range Rover Velar (L560). D7u platform variant shared with Jaguar F-Pace. Positioned between Evoque and Range Rover Sport. Features Terrain Response 2, optional air suspension. Diesel engines available internationally. Timing chain powertrains. Data sourced from Wikipedia Range Rover Velar article, January 2025 revision.

Fifth-generation Defender 90 short-wheelbase model (L663 platform). Available with mild hybrid I6 powertrains, diesel options, and terrain management systems. Air suspension standard on V8, optional on others. Requires Land Rover diagnostic tools for Terrain Response 2, air suspension, and 48V MHEV system service. Data sourced from Wikipedia Land Rover Defender article, January 2025 revision.

Fifth-generation Defender 110 standard-wheelbase model (L663 platform). Shares powertrain options with Defender 90. Features aluminum monocoque construction, configurable Terrain Response 2, and optional Adaptive Off-Road Cruise Control. 48V MHEV system requires specialized diagnostic equipment. Data sourced from Wikipedia Land Rover Defender article, January 2025 revision.

Fifth-generation Defender 130 extended-wheelbase model introduced 2022. Eight-seat configuration standard. Shares L663 platform technology with 90/110 variants. 48V mild hybrid system, air suspension, and Terrain Response 2 require Land Rover diagnostic tools. Data sourced from Wikipedia Land Rover Defender article, January 2025 revision.

Fifth-generation Range Rover (L460). MLA-Flex platform supports PHEV with 31.8 kWh battery, delivering 48 miles electric range. 48V mild hybrid system standard across range. Features air suspension, Dynamic Response Pro, and Terrain Response 2. PHEV high-voltage system (400V) requires certified EV technicians. Data sourced from Wikipedia Range Rover article, January 2025 revision.

Third-generation Range Rover Sport (L461). MLA-Flex platform with PHEV variant featuring 31.8 kWh battery and 48-mile electric range. All models include 48V mild hybrid technology. Configurable Terrain Response 2, Dynamic Response Pro active anti-roll, and air suspension standard. PHEV service requires high-voltage system expertise. Data sourced from Wikipedia Range Rover Sport article, January 2025 revision.

Range Rover Velar with 2021 facelift updates, featuring 48V mild hybrid systems across all powertrains. Based on D7u platform variant shared with Jaguar F-Pace. Configurable Terrain Response 2 and optional air suspension. MHEV system requires diagnostic access to 48V electrical architecture. Data sourced from Wikipedia Range Rover Velar article, January 2025 revision.

Discovery Sport (L550) with 2020 facelift. Based on D8 platform (LR-MS). All powertrains feature 48V mild hybrid technology. Configurable Terrain Response and available seven-seat configuration. MHEV system adds service complexity requiring Land Rover diagnostic tools. Data sourced from Wikipedia Land Rover Discovery Sport article, January 2025 revision.

Second-generation Range Rover Evoque (L551). PHEV variant features 15 kWh battery with 41-mile electric range. All non-PHEV models include 48V mild hybrid system. Premium Transverse Architecture (PTA) platform shared with Discovery Sport. PHEV high-voltage service requires certified technicians. Data sourced from Wikipedia Range Rover Evoque article, January 2025 revision.

Fourth generation Spider 916 (1995-2006). Limited US availability 1991-1994 as grey market imports. Pininfarina design. Front-wheel drive platform. Final Alfa Romeo sold in US until 2014 return. Data sourced from Wikipedia Alfa Romeo Spider article, January 2025 revision.

Executive sedan (1987-1998). Sold in US 1991-1995. Shared Type Four platform with Saab 9000, Fiat Croma, Lancia Thema. Pininfarina design. Busso V6 engine. Final year 1995 marked Alfa Romeo's US market exit until 2014. Data sourced from Wikipedia Alfa Romeo 164 article, January 2025 revision.

GTV coupe (1995-2005). Very limited US market availability in 1995 only. Pininfarina design. Front-wheel drive platform. Turbo variant available. Data sourced from Wikipedia Alfa Romeo GTV article, January 2025 revision.

Mid-engine sports car (2013-2020). Carbon fiber monocoque chassis, no power steering. Marked Alfa Romeo's return to US market after 18-year absence. Spider convertible introduced 2015. Specialized carbon fiber construction requires expert repair. Data sourced from Wikipedia Alfa Romeo 4C article, January 2025 revision.

Type 952 compact luxury sedan (2016-present) on Giorgio platform. Quadrifoglio performance variant features Ferrari-derived 2.9L twin-turbo V6 producing 505 hp. Carbon fiber driveshaft, active aero. Aluminum construction. Data sourced from Wikipedia Alfa Romeo Giulia article, January 2025 revision.

First generation compact luxury crossover (2017-present) on Giorgio platform. Quadrifoglio performance variant features Ferrari-derived 2.9L twin-turbo V6 producing 505 hp. AWD standard on all models. Aluminum construction. Data sourced from Wikipedia Alfa Romeo Stelvio article, January 2025 revision.

Type 952 compact luxury sedan (2016-present) on Giorgio platform. Quadrifoglio performance variant features Ferrari-derived 2.9L twin-turbo V6 producing 505 hp. Carbon fiber driveshaft, active aero. Aluminum construction. Data sourced from Wikipedia Alfa Romeo Giulia article, January 2025 revision.

First generation compact luxury crossover (2017-present) on Giorgio platform. Quadrifoglio performance variant features Ferrari-derived 2.9L twin-turbo V6 producing 505 hp. AWD standard on all models. Aluminum construction. Data sourced from Wikipedia Alfa Romeo Stelvio article, January 2025 revision.

engines: 1.3L turbo I4 + electric motor (272 hp PHEV)
notes: Subcompact luxury crossover (2022-present). Plug-in hybrid standard in US market with 1.3L turbo + electric motor, 15.5 kWh battery. AWD standard on PHEV. Requires PHEV service expertise. Data sourced from Wikipedia Alfa Romeo Tonale article, January 2025 revision.

All-electric adventure pickup truck built in Normal, Illinois. 135-180 kWh battery packs (varies by year/trim). 400V/800V architecture. Quad-motor and dual-motor configurations. Requires EV-certified technicians for high-voltage systems. Data sourced from Wikipedia Rivian R1T article, January 2025 revision.

All-electric three-row SUV built in Normal, Illinois. 135-180 kWh battery packs (varies by year/trim). 400V/800V architecture. Quad-motor and dual-motor configurations. Requires EV-certified technicians for high-voltage systems. Data sourced from Wikipedia Rivian R1S article, January 2025 revision.

engines: Dual-motor electric (480 hp Pure, 620 hp Touring, 819 hp Grand Touring, 1,234 hp Sapphire)
notes: All-electric luxury sedan built in Casa Grande, Arizona. 88-118 kWh battery packs. 900V architecture enables ultra-fast charging. Sapphire tri-motor performance variant produces 1,234 hp. Requires EV-certified technicians for high-voltage systems. Data sourced from Wikipedia Lucid Air article, January 2025 revision.

All-electric three-row luxury SUV (2024+). Built in Casa Grande, Arizona. Shares 900V architecture with Air sedan. Ultra-fast charging capability. Requires EV-certified technicians for high-voltage systems. Data sourced from Wikipedia Lucid Gravity article, January 2025 revision.

engines: 2.0L supercharged/turbocharged I4 + electric motor (619 hp combined)
notes: Limited production plug-in hybrid performance coupe (2019-2021). Based on Volvo S60/V60. 34 kWh battery, 60 miles electric range. Twin-charged engine (supercharger + turbocharger) plus electric motors. Only 1,500 units produced. Requires PHEV expertise. Data sourced from Wikipedia Polestar 1 article, January 2025 revision.

All-electric liftback (2019+). Built on CMA platform shared with Volvo XC40 Recharge. 69-78 kWh battery packs. 400V architecture. Single-motor FWD or dual-motor AWD. Requires EV-certified technicians. Data sourced from Wikipedia Polestar 2 article, January 2025 revision.

engines: Dual electric motors (489 hp, 517 hp with Performance Pack)
notes: All-electric performance SUV (2023+). Built on SPA2 platform. 111 kWh battery pack. 400V architecture. Dual-motor AWD standard. Performance Pack available. Requires EV-certified technicians for high-voltage systems. Data sourced from Wikipedia Polestar 3 article, January 2025 revision.

All-electric crossover coupe (2023+). Built on SEA platform. 94-102 kWh battery packs. 400V architecture. Single-motor RWD or dual-motor AWD. Requires EV-certified technicians for high-voltage systems. Data sourced from Wikipedia Polestar 4 article, January 2025 revision.

Third generation retro-styled subcompact (2007-2020 global). US sales 2011-2019. Available as hardtop hatchback and convertible. Marked Fiat's return to US market after 27-year absence. Data sourced from Wikipedia Fiat 500 article, January 2025 revision.

Subcompact MPV (2012-2020). Larger variant of 500 with sliding rear doors and increased interior space. US sales 2014-2019. Built in Serbia. Data sourced from Wikipedia Fiat 500L article, January 2025 revision.

Subcompact crossover (2014-2024). Shares platform with Jeep Renegade. 1.4L MultiAir turbo or 2.4L Tigershark engines. AWD available. US sales 2016-2024. Data sourced from Wikipedia Fiat 500X article, January 2025 revision.

Rear-wheel drive roadster (2016-2020). Shares platform and structure with Mazda MX-5 Miata. Fiat 1.4L MultiAir turbo engine. Abarth performance variant available. Built by Mazda in Japan. US sales 2017-2020. Data sourced from Wikipedia Fiat 124 Spider article, January 2025 revision.

Subcompact crossover (2014-2024). Shares platform with Jeep Renegade. Final years in US market before discontinuation. AWD available. Data sourced from Wikipedia Fiat 500X article, January 2025 revision.

Rear-wheel drive roadster final year (2016-2020). Shares platform with Mazda MX-5 Miata. Fiat 1.4L MultiAir turbo engine. Abarth performance variant available. Discontinued after 2020. Data sourced from Wikipedia Fiat 124 Spider article, January 2025 revision.

All-electric subcompact (2020+ global, 2024+ US). Fourth generation 500 returns to US as EV-only. 42 kWh battery pack, ~149 miles EPA range. Built in Italy. Marks Fiat's return to US market after brief absence. Data sourced from Wikipedia Fiat 500 article, January 2025 revision.

Eagle Premier based on AMC/Renault design. PRV (Peugeot-Renault-Volvo) V6 engine shared with Renault 25. Front-wheel drive with longitudinal engine layout. Timing belt maintenance required on PRV V6. Data sourced from Wikipedia Eagle Premier article, January 2025 revision.

Eagle Medallion rebadged Renault 21. Front-wheel drive compact sedan/wagon. Short production run (1988-1989 only). Renault-sourced components require specialist knowledge. Timing belt engine. Data sourced from Wikipedia Eagle Medallion article, January 2025 revision.

Eagle Summit rebadged Mitsubishi Mirage. Built at Diamond-Star Motors plant in Normal, Illinois. Shared platform with Plymouth Colt. Front-wheel drive subcompact. Timing belt maintenance required. Data sourced from Wikipedia Eagle Summit article, January 2025 revision.

Eagle Premier continued production through 1992. AMC/Renault design with PRV V6 engine. Replaced by LH platform cars. Front-wheel drive with longitudinal engine layout. Timing belt service required. Data sourced from Wikipedia Eagle Premier article, January 2025 revision.

Eagle Summit rebadged Mitsubishi Mirage/Lancer. Built at Diamond-Star Motors (Normal, IL) and imported from Japan. AWD available 1990-1994. Timing belt engines require regular maintenance. Data sourced from Wikipedia Eagle Summit article, January 2025 revision.

Eagle Talon DSM (Diamond-Star Motors) platform shared with Mitsubishi Eclipse and Plymouth Laser. Built in Normal, Illinois. AWD TSi/TSi AWD models feature turbo 4G63 engine, viscous limited-slip center differential. Timing belt critical service item (interference engine). Transfer case and turbo maintenance adds complexity. Data sourced from Wikipedia Eagle Talon article, January 2025 revision.

Eagle Summit Wagon rebadged Mitsubishi RVR/Expo. Tall-wagon body style with available AWD. Imported from Japan. Timing belt maintenance required. AWD system adds modest service complexity. Data sourced from Wikipedia Eagle Summit article, January 2025 revision.

Eagle Vision LH platform shared with Dodge Intrepid and Chrysler Concorde. Front-wheel drive full-size sedan with cab-forward design. Timing chain V6 engines. TSi performance variant available with 3.5L V6. Data sourced from Wikipedia Eagle Vision article, January 2025 revision.

Geo Metro rebadged Suzuki Swift/Cultus. Built in Canada (CAMI Automotive) and imported from Japan. Fuel-efficient subcompact with 1.0L three-cylinder engine. Timing belt maintenance required. Data sourced from Wikipedia Geo Metro article, January 2025 revision.

Geo Prizm rebadged Toyota Corolla (E90). Built at NUMMI plant in Fremont, California (GM-Toyota joint venture). Shares platform, engines, and transmissions with Corolla. Timing belt engine. Data sourced from Wikipedia Geo Prizm article, January 2025 revision.

Geo Tracker rebadged Suzuki Sidekick/Vitara. Built at CAMI Automotive in Ontario, Canada. Compact SUV with body-on-frame construction, part-time 4WD available. Timing belt maintenance required. Data sourced from Wikipedia Geo Tracker article, January 2025 revision.

Geo Spectrum rebadged Isuzu I-Mark. Only sold in 1989 model year under Geo brand. Front-wheel drive subcompact. Timing belt engine. Replaced by Geo Storm for 1990. Data sourced from Wikipedia Geo Spectrum article, January 2025 revision.

Geo Metro continued through 1997 (rebadged Suzuki Swift). Built at CAMI Automotive Canada. LSi variant introduced 1995 with updated styling. Fuel-efficient three-cylinder subcompact. Timing belt maintenance required. Became Chevrolet Metro 1998. Data sourced from Wikipedia Geo Metro article, January 2025 revision.

Geo Prizm rebadged Toyota Corolla through 1997. Built at NUMMI California. Second generation (1993-1997) based on E100 Corolla platform. Timing belt engines. Became Chevrolet Prizm 1998. Data sourced from Wikipedia Geo Prizm article, January 2025 revision.

Geo Tracker continued through 1997 (rebadged Suzuki Sidekick). Built at CAMI Automotive Canada. Second generation (1996-1997) added 4-door model. Body-on-frame compact SUV with part-time 4WD. Became Chevrolet Tracker 1998. Data sourced from Wikipedia Geo Tracker article, January 2025 revision.

Geo Storm rebadged Isuzu Impulse (second generation). Sporty coupe with pop-up headlights. GSi variant featured DOHC engine and sport suspension. Front-wheel drive. Timing belt maintenance required. Discontinued 1993 with no direct replacement. Data sourced from Wikipedia Geo Storm article, January 2025 revision.

First-generation Saturn S-Series. Polymer body panels over space frame. Built at Spring Hill, Tennessee plant. No-haggle pricing model. Timing chain engines. SL sedan, SC coupe, SW wagon variants. Data sourced from Wikipedia Saturn S-Series article, January 2025 revision.

Saturn EV1 first modern production electric vehicle from major manufacturer. Lease-only program (not sold). Lead-acid battery (1996-1997) or NiMH battery (1999). Aluminum space frame, composite body panels. All units recalled and crushed except museum pieces. High-voltage system requires EV expertise. Data sourced from Wikipedia General Motors EV1 article, January 2025 revision.

Final years of first-generation Saturn S-Series. Polymer body panels, space frame construction. Built at Spring Hill, Tennessee. Timing chain engines. Replaced by Ion 2003. Data sourced from Wikipedia Saturn S-Series article, January 2025 revision.

Saturn L-Series mid-size sedan/wagon. Based on Opel Vectra platform (GM2900). Built at Wilmington, Delaware. Timing chain engines. L100/L200/L300 trim levels. Data sourced from Wikipedia Saturn L-Series article, January 2025 revision.

Saturn Vue compact crossover SUV. First generation (2002-2007) built at Spring Hill. Second generation (2008-2010) rebadged Opel Antara. Green Line hybrid (2007-2009) with BAS mild hybrid system. AWD available. Timing chain engines. Data sourced from Wikipedia Saturn Vue article, January 2025 revision.

Saturn Ion compact sedan, S-Series replacement. Delta platform shared with Chevy Cobalt. Quad Coupe featured rear-hinged rear doors. Red Line performance variant with supercharged Ecotec. Built at Spring Hill, Tennessee. Timing chain engines. Data sourced from Wikipedia Saturn Ion article, January 2025 revision.

Saturn Relay minivan. Rebadged Chevrolet Uplander/Pontiac Montana SV6 on GMT200 platform. Built at Doraville, Georgia. Timing chain V6 engines. Short production run, discontinued 2007. Data sourced from Wikipedia Saturn Relay article, January 2025 revision.

Saturn Sky roadster. Kappa platform shared with Pontiac Solstice, Opel GT. Rear-wheel drive sports car. Red Line turbo variant with 260 hp. Built at Wilmington, Delaware. Timing chain engines. Data sourced from Wikipedia Saturn Sky article, January 2025 revision.

Saturn Aura mid-size sedan. Epsilon platform shared with Chevy Malibu, Pontiac G6. Green Line hybrid variant with BAS mild hybrid system. Built at Kansas City, Kansas. Timing chain engines. Data sourced from Wikipedia Saturn Aura article, January 2025 revision.

Saturn Outlook full-size crossover SUV. Lambda platform shared with GMC Acadia, Buick Enclave, Chevy Traverse. Eight-passenger seating. Built at Lansing, Michigan. Timing chain V6. AWD available. Data sourced from Wikipedia Saturn Outlook article, January 2025 revision.

Final year of Saturn Vue (rebadged Opel Antara). Green Line hybrid with two-mode system. AWD available. Brand discontinued October 2010. Timing chain engines. Data sourced from Wikipedia Saturn Vue article, January 2025 revision.

Saturn Astra rebadged Opel Astra H. Imported from Belgium. Compact hatchback with European design. Short North American run (2008-2009). Timing chain engine. Data sourced from Wikipedia Saturn Astra article, January 2025 revision.

Civilian version of military HMMWV (1992-2006). Built by AM General. 16-inch ground clearance, portal axles. Diesel and gasoline V8 options. Central tire inflation system. Requires heavy-duty service expertise. Data sourced from Wikipedia Hummer H1 article, January 2025 revision.

Civilian HMMWV final years (1992-2006). 6.6L Duramax introduced 2002. Portal axles, central tire inflation. Discontinued 2006 due to emissions regulations. Requires heavy-duty diesel expertise. Data sourced from Wikipedia Hummer H1 article, January 2025 revision.

GMT820 platform shared with Chevy/GMC trucks (2002-2009). Built by GM. H2 SUT pickup variant introduced 2004. 6.2L V8 introduced 2008. Heavy fuel consumption led to discontinuation. Data sourced from Wikipedia Hummer H2 article, January 2025 revision.

GMT355 platform shared with Chevy Colorado/GMC Canyon (2005-2010). Smallest Hummer. H3 Alpha with 5.3L V8 introduced 2008. Manual transmission available 2006-2008. Data sourced from Wikipedia Hummer H3 article, January 2025 revision.

H3-based pickup truck (2009-2010). GMT355 platform. Short production run before brand discontinuation. Standard and Alpha variants. Data sourced from Wikipedia Hummer H3 article, January 2025 revision.

Rebadged Toyota ist/Urban Cruiser (2003-2006). Toyota youth brand launch vehicle. Shared platform with Echo/Yaris. Discontinued after 2006. Data sourced from Wikipedia Scion xA article, January 2025 revision.
First generation rebadged Toyota bB (2003-2007). Iconic box design. Youth market focus. Replaced by second generation in 2008. Data sourced from Wikipedia Scion xB article, January 2025 revision.
First generation sports coupe (2004-2010). Based on Toyota Avensis platform. Panoramic sunroof standard. Best-selling Scion model. Data sourced from Wikipedia Scion tC article, January 2025 revision.
Second generation rebadged Toyota bB (2007-2015). Larger than first generation. Discontinued after 2015 due to declining sales. Data sourced from Wikipedia Scion xB article, January 2025 revision.
Second generation sports coupe (2010-2016). Reintroduced as Toyota 86 after Scion discontinued. Panoramic sunroof standard. Data sourced from Wikipedia Scion tC article, January 2025 revision.
Rebadged Toyota ist second generation (2007-2014). Replaced xA. Discontinued 2014. Data sourced from Wikipedia Scion xD article, January 2025 revision.
Rebadged Toyota iQ (2011-2015). Ultra-compact city car. Poor sales led to early discontinuation. Data sourced from Wikipedia Scion iQ article, January 2025 revision.

Joint development with Subaru (2012-2016). Subaru BRZ twin. Boxer engine, rear-wheel drive. Became Toyota 86 after Scion discontinued. Popular enthusiast car. Data sourced from Wikipedia Scion FR-S article, January 2025 revision.
Second generation midsize SUV (1991-2002). Known for rollover controversy. 3.2L V6 introduced 1992. Rebadged as Acura SLX. Data sourced from Wikipedia Isuzu Trooper article, January 2025 revision.
First generation compact SUV (1990-2004). Rebadged as Honda Passport. Shared platform with Trooper. Data sourced from Wikipedia Isuzu Rodeo article, January 2025 revision.
Second generation compact SUV (1998-2001). Convertible soft top available. Based on Rodeo platform. Data sourced from Wikipedia Isuzu Amigo article, January 2025 revision.

Unique sport crossover (1997-2001 in Japan, 1999-2001 in US). Distinctive styling, limited production. TOD (Torque On Demand) AWD system. Data sourced from Wikipedia Isuzu VehiCross article, January 2025 revision.
