Second generation compact SUV (1998-2004). Rebadged as Honda Passport. Discontinued as Isuzu exited US passenger vehicle market. Data sourced from Wikipedia Isuzu Rodeo article, January 2025 revision.
Sport crossover final years (1997-2001 in Japan, 1999-2001 in US). Limited production, cult following. TOD AWD system. Data sourced from Wikipedia Isuzu VehiCross article, January 2025 revision.
Final years of midsize SUV (1991-2002). Discontinued as Isuzu focused on commercial vehicles. Data sourced from Wikipedia Isuzu Trooper article, January 2025 revision.
Sport crossover (2001-2004). Based on Rodeo platform. Unique styling. Discontinued as Isuzu exited US passenger market. Data sourced from Wikipedia Isuzu Axiom article, January 2025 revision.
Rebadged Chevy TrailBlazer/GMC Envoy on GMT360 platform (2002-2008). Built by GM. Final Isuzu passenger vehicle in US. Data sourced from Wikipedia Isuzu Ascender article, January 2025 revision.
Compact SUV (1985-1995 in US). Known for rollover controversy. Lightweight off-roader. Discontinued in US after 1995. Data sourced from Wikipedia Suzuki Samurai article, January 2025 revision.
First and second generation compact SUV (1988-1998). Rebadged as Geo/Chevy Tracker. 4-door introduced 1991. Data sourced from Wikipedia Suzuki Sidekick article, January 2025 revision.
Unique 2-seat coupe SUV (1995-1997). Based on Sidekick. T-top removable panels. Commercial failure. Data sourced from Wikipedia Suzuki X-90 article, January 2025 revision.
Second generation compact SUV (1998-2005). Renamed from Sidekick. Rebadged as Chevy Tracker. Data sourced from Wikipedia Suzuki Vitara article, January 2025 revision.
Second generation subcompact (1995-2001 in US). Rebadged as Geo/Chevy Metro. Economy car. Data sourced from Wikipedia Suzuki Swift article, January 2025 revision.
Compact sedan/wagon (1995-2002). Based on Suzuki Cultus Crescent. Budget-friendly. Data sourced from Wikipedia Suzuki Esteem article, January 2025 revision.
Second generation compact SUV (1998-2005). V6 engine introduced 2001. Rebadged as Chevy Tracker. Data sourced from Wikipedia Suzuki Vitara article, January 2025 revision.
Compact sedan/wagon final years (1995-2002). Replaced by Aerio. Data sourced from Wikipedia Suzuki Esteem article, January 2025 revision.
Compact sedan/wagon (2001-2007). Replaced Esteem. AWD available. Discontinued 2007. Data sourced from Wikipedia Suzuki Aerio article, January 2025 revision.
Rebadged Daewoo Lacetti (2004-2008). Built by GM Daewoo in Korea. Budget sedan. Data sourced from Wikipedia Suzuki Forenza article, January 2025 revision.
Rebadged Daewoo Lacetti hatchback (2004-2008). Built by GM Daewoo in Korea. Forenza hatchback variant. Data sourced from Wikipedia Suzuki Reno article, January 2025 revision.
Second generation compact SUV (2005-2015). Larger than previous Vitara. 3.2L V6 introduced 2009. Data sourced from Wikipedia Suzuki Grand Vitara article, January 2025 revision.
Rebadged Chevy Equinox/Pontiac Torrent on GM Theta platform (2006-2009). Built in Canada. Three-row seating. Data sourced from Wikipedia Suzuki XL7 article, January 2025 revision.
Rebadged Daewoo Magnus (2004-2006). Built by GM Daewoo in Korea. Inline-6 engine. Poor sales. Data sourced from Wikipedia Suzuki Verona article, January 2025 revision.
Second generation compact SUV final US years (2005-2013 in US). 2.4L I4 introduced 2009. Suzuki exited US market 2012. Data sourced from Wikipedia Suzuki Grand Vitara article, January 2025 revision.
Compact sedan/hatchback (2007-2013 in US). Joint development with Fiat. AWD available. Final model before US exit. Data sourced from Wikipedia Suzuki SX4 article, January 2025 revision.

Midsize sedan (2009-2013). Suzuki's premium sedan effort. Sport and GTS trims. AWD available. Discontinued with US market exit. Data sourced from Wikipedia Suzuki Kizashi article, January 2025 revision.
Rebadged Nissan Frontier on D40 platform (2008-2012). Built by Nissan in Tennessee. Final Suzuki vehicle in US. Data sourced from Wikipedia Suzuki Equator article, January 2025 revision.

Saab 96 compact sedan. Two-stroke three-cylinder engine (1960-1967), then Ford V4 (1967-1980). Front-wheel drive with freewheel mechanism. Aircraft-inspired design, rally heritage. Limited US imports. Vintage mechanical complexity. Data sourced from Wikipedia Saab 96 article, January 2025 revision.

Saab Sonett II (1966-1967) and Sonett V4 (1967-1970). Lightweight fiberglass body sports car. Two-stroke initially, Ford V4 from 1967. Front-wheel drive. Limited production, rare in North America. Data sourced from Wikipedia Saab Sonett article, January 2025 revision.

Saab 99 compact executive car. First turbocharged production Saab (1978). Front-wheel drive with longitudinal engine. Triumph-derived engine initially, later Saab B engine. Timing chain. Strong North American presence. Data sourced from Wikipedia Saab 99 article, January 2025 revision.

Saab Sonett III sports coupe (1970-1974). Fiberglass body, designed by Sergio Coggiola. Ford V4 engine. Front-wheel drive. Majority exported to North America. Timing chain. Data sourced from Wikipedia Saab Sonett article, January 2025 revision.

First-generation Saab 900 launch year (1979-1993). Based on Saab 99 platform. Turbo variants available. Front-wheel drive with longitudinal engine. Iconic Swedish design. Timing chain engines. Data sourced from Wikipedia Saab 900 article, January 2025 revision.

Classic Saab 900 (1980-1993). Convertible introduced 1986. Turbo SPG performance variant. Front-wheel drive with longitudinal engine. Quirky Swedish engineering, ignition key between seats. Timing chain engines. Data sourced from Wikipedia Saab 900 article, January 2025 revision.

First-generation Saab 9000 (1985-1998). Type Four platform shared with Fiat Croma, Lancia Thema, Alfa Romeo 164. Turbo engines standard. Front-wheel drive executive car. Timing chain engines. Data sourced from Wikipedia Saab 9000 article, January 2025 revision.

Final years of classic Saab 900 (1979-1993). Turbo engines, convertible variants. Front-wheel drive with longitudinal engine. Replaced by GM900 platform 1994. Timing chain engines. Data sourced from Wikipedia Saab 900 article, January 2025 revision.

Saab 9000 continued through 1998. Aero performance variant introduced. Type Four platform. Front-wheel drive executive car. Timing chain turbo engines. Strong North American sales. Data sourced from Wikipedia Saab 9000 article, January 2025 revision.

Second-generation Saab 900 (1994-1998). GM2900 platform shared with Opel Vectra. Controversial departure from classic 900. V6 option introduced. Front-wheel drive. Timing chain engines. Replaced by 9-3 in 1999. Data sourced from Wikipedia Saab 900 article, January 2025 revision.

First-generation Saab 9-3 launch years (1998-2002). Renamed 900 successor on GM2900 platform. Turbo engines standard. Front-wheel drive. Timing chain engines. Viggen high-performance variant available. Data sourced from Wikipedia Saab 9-3 article, January 2025 revision.

First-generation Saab 9-5 launch (1997-2010). GM2900 platform, 9000 replacement. Turbo engines standard, V6 turbo available. Front-wheel drive executive car. Timing chain engines. Aero performance variant. Data sourced from Wikipedia Saab 9-5 article, January 2025 revision.

Final years first-generation 9-3. GM2900 platform. Viggen high-performance model with 230 hp. Front-wheel drive. Timing chain turbo engines. Replaced by second-generation 2003. Data sourced from Wikipedia Saab 9-3 article, January 2025 revision.

Saab 9-5 continued through 2009. GM2900 platform. Aero performance variant. V6 turbo optional. Front-wheel drive executive sedan/wagon. Timing chain engines. Data sourced from Wikipedia Saab 9-5 article, January 2025 revision.

Second-generation Saab 9-3 (2003-2014). GM Epsilon platform shared with Opel Vectra. V6 turbo Aero with AWD available. SportCombi wagon variant. Timing chain engines. Data sourced from Wikipedia Saab 9-3 article, January 2025 revision.

Saab 9-2X rebadged Subaru Impreza wagon. Built by Fuji Heavy Industries in Japan. All-wheel drive standard. Boxer engines with timing belt. Called 'Saabaru' by enthusiasts. Short production run. Data sourced from Wikipedia Saab 9-2X article, January 2025 revision.

Saab 9-7X mid-size SUV rebadged GMT360 platform (Chevy TrailBlazer, GMC Envoy). Built in Ohio. Rear-wheel drive or all-wheel drive. Timing chain engines. V8 Aero performance variant. Data sourced from Wikipedia Saab 9-7X article, January 2025 revision.

Final years Saab 9-3 (2003-2014). GM Epsilon platform. Production continued briefly after bankruptcy under NEVS ownership. V6 turbo Aero with AWD. Brand bankruptcy 2011, final production 2014. Data sourced from Wikipedia Saab 9-3 article, January 2025 revision.

Second-generation Saab 9-5 (2010-2012). GM Epsilon II platform. XWD all-wheel drive available. Modern design, but short production due to Saab bankruptcy 2011. Limited production numbers. Timing chain turbo engines. Data sourced from Wikipedia Saab 9-5 article, January 2025 revision.

Saab 9-4X crossover SUV (2011 only). Theta Premium platform shared with Cadillac SRX. All-wheel drive standard. V6 turbo engine. Built in Mexico. Only ~800 units produced before Saab bankruptcy. Timing chain engine. Data sourced from Wikipedia Saab 9-4X article, January 2025 revision.

Full-size sedan on Ford Panther platform (1992-2011). Shared with Ford Crown Victoria. Fleet favorite. Modular V8 engine. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mercury Grand Marquis article, January 2025 revision.
Third generation midsize sedan (1996-2005). Ford Taurus twin. DN5 platform. Wagon discontinued 1999. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mercury Sable article, January 2025 revision.
Eighth generation sports coupe (1999-2002). Based on Ford Mondeo/Contour platform. Replaced by Marauder concept. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mercury Cougar article, January 2025 revision.
First generation midsize SUV (1997-2010). Ford Explorer twin. UN105/UN150 platform. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mercury Mountaineer article, January 2025 revision.
Rebadged Mazda 323/Familia convertible (1991-1994). Built by Mazda in Australia. Turbo XR2 variant available. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mercury Capri article, January 2025 revision.
Rebadged Nissan Quest (1993-2002). Joint venture with Nissan. Built in Ohio. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mercury Villager article, January 2025 revision.
Compact sedan (1995-2000). Ford Contour twin. CDW27 platform (Mondeo). Data sourced from Wikipedia Mercury Mystique article, January 2025 revision.
Fourth generation compact (1997-1999). Ford Escort twin. Replaced by Focus-based models. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mercury Tracer article, January 2025 revision.
Full-size sedan on Panther platform (1992-2011). Final Mercury model. Popular with fleets and seniors. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mercury Grand Marquis article, January 2025 revision.
Third generation midsize sedan (1996-2005). Ford Taurus twin. Discontinued 2005, revived 2008. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mercury Sable article, January 2025 revision.
Fifth generation (2008-2009). Ford Taurus twin. Discontinued again after 2 years. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mercury Sable article, January 2025 revision.
Eighth generation sports coupe (1999-2002). Final Mercury sports car. Based on Mondeo platform. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mercury Cougar article, January 2025 revision.
Second generation midsize SUV (2002-2010). Ford Explorer twin. V8 available 2002-2005. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mercury Mountaineer article, January 2025 revision.
First generation compact crossover (2005-2011). Ford Escape/Mazda Tribute twin. Hybrid available 2006+. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mercury Mariner article, January 2025 revision.
First generation midsize sedan (2006-2011). Ford Fusion/Lincoln MKZ twin. CD3 platform. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mercury Milan article, January 2025 revision.
Full-size sedan (2005-2007). Ford Five Hundred twin. D3 platform. Replaced by Sable. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mercury Montego article, January 2025 revision.
Full-size sedan final years (1992-2011). Last Mercury produced. Panther platform discontinued with brand. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mercury Grand Marquis article, January 2025 revision.
Second generation midsize sedan (2010-2011). Ford Fusion twin. Hybrid available. Brand discontinued 2011. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mercury Milan article, January 2025 revision.
Second generation compact crossover (2008-2011). Ford Escape twin. Hybrid available. Final Mercury SUV. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mercury Mariner article, January 2025 revision.
Third generation midsize SUV final years (2006-2010). Ford Explorer twin. V8 discontinued 2009. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mercury Mountaineer article, January 2025 revision.
Sixth generation midsize car (1988-1997). GM W-body platform. Convertible available 1990-1995. Data sourced from Wikipedia Oldsmobile Cutlass Supreme article, January 2025 revision.
Rebadged Chevrolet Malibu (1997-1999). GM N-body platform. Replaced Cutlass Supreme. Data sourced from Wikipedia Oldsmobile Cutlass article, January 2025 revision.
Ninth generation full-size sedan (1992-1999). GM H-body platform. Royale and LSS trims. Data sourced from Wikipedia Oldsmobile 88 article, January 2025 revision.
Eleventh generation flagship (1991-1996). GM C-body platform. Discontinued 1996. Data sourced from Wikipedia Oldsmobile 98 article, January 2025 revision.
First generation flagship (1995-2003). GM G-body platform. Cadillac Northstar V8 derivative. Data sourced from Wikipedia Oldsmobile Aurora article, January 2025 revision.
Midsize sedan (1998-2002). GM W-body platform. Replaced Cutlass Supreme. Data sourced from Wikipedia Oldsmobile Intrigue article, January 2025 revision.
Compact car (1999-2004). GM N-body platform. Replaced Achieva. Final Oldsmobile produced. Data sourced from Wikipedia Oldsmobile Alero article, January 2025 revision.
Second generation minivan (1990-2004). GM U-body platform. Shared with Pontiac Trans Sport/Chevy Venture. Data sourced from Wikipedia Oldsmobile Silhouette article, January 2025 revision.
First generation luxury SUV (1991-2004). Rebadged Chevy Blazer/GMC Jimmy. SmartTrak AWD system. Data sourced from Wikipedia Oldsmobile Bravada article, January 2025 revision.
Compact car (1992-1998). GM N-body platform. Replaced Calais. Quad 4 engine available. Data sourced from Wikipedia Oldsmobile Achieva article, January 2025 revision.
Fourth generation personal luxury coupe (1986-1992). GM E-body platform. Final generation. Data sourced from Wikipedia Oldsmobile Toronado article, January 2025 revision.
Full-size wagon (1971-1992). GM B-body platform. Final Oldsmobile RWD vehicle. Data sourced from Wikipedia Oldsmobile Custom Cruiser article, January 2025 revision.
Second generation flagship (2001-2003). GM G-body platform. V6 and V8 options. Final Oldsmobile flagship. Data sourced from Wikipedia Oldsmobile Aurora article, January 2025 revision.
Midsize sedan (1998-2002). GM W-body platform. Discontinued 2002. Data sourced from Wikipedia Oldsmobile Intrigue article, January 2025 revision.
Compact car (1999-2004). GM N-body platform. Final Oldsmobile model produced (April 29, 2004). Data sourced from Wikipedia Oldsmobile Alero article, January 2025 revision.
Third generation minivan (1997-2004). GM U-body platform. Shared with Pontiac Montana/Chevy Venture. Data sourced from Wikipedia Oldsmobile Silhouette article, January 2025 revision.
Second generation luxury SUV (1996-2001). Rebadged Chevy Blazer/GMC Jimmy. SmartTrak AWD. Data sourced from Wikipedia Oldsmobile Bravada article, January 2025 revision.
Third generation luxury SUV (2002-2004). Rebadged Chevy TrailBlazer/GMC Envoy on GMT360 platform. Final Oldsmobile SUV. Data sourced from Wikipedia Oldsmobile Bravada article, January 2025 revision.
Compact sedan (1989-1995). Chrysler AA platform. Shared with Dodge Spirit. Replaced by Breeze. Data sourced from Wikipedia Plymouth Acclaim article, January 2025 revision.
Sports coupe (1990-1994). Rebadged Eagle Talon/Mitsubishi Eclipse. Diamond-Star Motors. Turbo AWD available. Data sourced from Wikipedia Plymouth Laser article, January 2025 revision.
Compact car (1987-1994). Chrysler P platform. Dodge Shadow twin. Turbo variant available. Data sourced from Wikipedia Plymouth Sundance article, January 2025 revision.
Second generation minivan (1991-1995). Chrysler AS platform. Short and long wheelbase. AWD available. Data sourced from Wikipedia Plymouth Voyager article, January 2025 revision.
Third generation minivan (1996-2000). Chrysler NS platform. Shared with Dodge Caravan. Data sourced from Wikipedia Plymouth Voyager article, January 2025 revision.
Extended wheelbase Voyager (1996-2000). Chrysler NS platform. Long-wheelbase variant. Data sourced from Wikipedia Plymouth Voyager article, January 2025 revision.
First generation compact (1995-1999). Chrysler PL platform. Dodge/Plymouth shared. Expresso coupe available. Data sourced from Wikipedia Plymouth Neon article, January 2025 revision.
Retro hot rod roadster (1997-2002). Aluminum space frame. Limited production. 253 hp from 1999+. No manual transmission. Data sourced from Wikipedia Plymouth Prowler article, January 2025 revision.
Compact sedan (1996-2000). Chrysler JA platform. Shared with Dodge Stratus/Chrysler Cirrus. Data sourced from Wikipedia Plymouth Breeze article, January 2025 revision.
Third generation minivan final year (1996-2000). Chrysler NS platform. Replaced by Chrysler Voyager. Data sourced from Wikipedia Plymouth Voyager article, January 2025 revision.
Extended wheelbase Voyager final year (1996-2000). Chrysler NS platform. Discontinued with Plymouth brand phaseout. Data sourced from Wikipedia Plymouth Voyager article, January 2025 revision.
Second generation compact (2000-2001 as Plymouth). Chrysler PL platform. Continued as Dodge Neon after 2001. Data sourced from Wikipedia Plymouth Neon article, January 2025 revision.

Retro hot rod roadster (1997-2002). Final Plymouth model. Continued as Chrysler Prowler 2002. Aluminum space frame, limited production. Data sourced from Wikipedia Plymouth Prowler article, January 2025 revision.
Compact sedan final year (1996-2000). Chrysler JA platform. Discontinued with Plymouth phaseout. Data sourced from Wikipedia Plymouth Breeze article, January 2025 revision.

Pontiac Catalina full-size car (1960-1981). Third through sixth generations during 1960s. Wide range of V8 engines. B-body platform. Timing chain engines. Popular family car with performance options. Data sourced from Wikipedia Pontiac Catalina article, January 2025 revision.

Pontiac Tempest compact car (1961-1970). Unique transaxle design initially. A-body platform. Basis for GTO muscle car. Timing chain engines. Data sourced from Wikipedia Pontiac Tempest article, January 2025 revision.

First-generation Pontiac Grand Prix (1962-1968). Personal luxury coupe based on Catalina. Wide-track design. Timing chain V8 engines. Bucket seats and performance orientation. Data sourced from Wikipedia Pontiac Grand Prix article, January 2025 revision.

First-generation Pontiac GTO (1964-1974). Widely considered first true muscle car. Based on Tempest/LeMans. Ram Air performance packages. A-body platform. Timing chain V8 engines. Data sourced from Wikipedia Pontiac GTO article, January 2025 revision.

First-generation Pontiac Firebird (1967-2002). F-body platform shared with Chevy Camaro. Multiple engine options including Ram Air. Trans Am variant introduced 1969. Timing chain engines. Data sourced from Wikipedia Pontiac Firebird article, January 2025 revision.

Second-generation Pontiac Firebird (1970-1981). F-body platform. Trans Am performance variant with Firebird decal. Timing chain engines. Iconic 1970s muscle/pony car. Data sourced from Wikipedia Pontiac Firebird article, January 2025 revision.

Second-generation Pontiac GTO (1968-1972) and third-gen (1973-1974). A-body muscle car. Ram Air performance packages. Timing chain V8 engines. Production ended 1974. Data sourced from Wikipedia Pontiac GTO article, January 2025 revision.

Pontiac Catalina full-size car continued through 1970s. B-body platform. Downsized 1977. Timing chain engines. Final years 1980-1981. Data sourced from Wikipedia Pontiac Catalina article, January 2025 revision.

Third through fifth generation Grand Prix (1969-1987). Personal luxury coupe. A-body (1973-1977), G-body (1978-1987). Timing chain V8 engines. Popular mid-size coupe. Data sourced from Wikipedia Pontiac Grand Prix article, January 2025 revision.

Pontiac Ventura compact car (1971-1977). X-body platform shared with Chevy Nova. Sprint performance package available. Timing chain engines. Replaced by Phoenix 1978. Data sourced from Wikipedia Pontiac Ventura article, January 2025 revision.

Pontiac Astre subcompact (1975-1977). Rebadged Chevrolet Vega. H-body platform. Timing chain I4 engine. Economy car during fuel crisis. Data sourced from Wikipedia Pontiac Astre article, January 2025 revision.

First-generation Pontiac Sunbird (1975-1980). H-body platform based on Vega. Formula performance package available with V8. Timing chain engines. Data sourced from Wikipedia Pontiac Sunbird article, January 2025 revision.

First-generation Pontiac Grand Am (1973-1975, 1978-1980). A-body mid-size performance car. Radial-tuned suspension. Timing chain V8 engines. Discontinued 1980, revived 1985. Data sourced from Wikipedia Pontiac Grand Am article, January 2025 revision.

Third-generation Pontiac Firebird (1982-1992). F-body platform redesign. Trans Am and GTA performance variants. Timing chain engines. Knight Rider KITT car fame. Data sourced from Wikipedia Pontiac Firebird article, January 2025 revision.

Pontiac 2000/Sunbird J-body (1982-1994). Front-wheel drive compact car. Turbo GT performance package. Timing belt engines. Renamed J2000 then back to Sunbird. Data sourced from Wikipedia Pontiac 2000 article, January 2025 revision.

Pontiac 6000 mid-size car (1982-1991). A-body front-wheel drive. STE performance sedan variant. Timing chain engines. Popular family sedan. Data sourced from Wikipedia Pontiac 6000 article, January 2025 revision.

Pontiac Fiero mid-engine sports car (1984-1988). Plastic body panels over space frame. Mid-mounted engine, rear-wheel drive. GT suspension package. Timing chain engines. Fire recall issues early production. Data sourced from Wikipedia Pontiac Fiero article, January 2025 revision.

Second-generation Pontiac Grand Am (1985-1991). N-body front-wheel drive compact. Quad 4 DOHC engine available. Timing belt/chain depending on engine. Popular sporty compact. Data sourced from Wikipedia Pontiac Grand Am article, January 2025 revision.

Sixth-generation Pontiac Bonneville (1987-1991). H-body front-wheel drive full-size sedan. SSE performance sedan variant. Timing chain V6. Modern aerodynamic design. Data sourced from Wikipedia Pontiac Bonneville article, January 2025 revision.

Sixth-generation Pontiac Grand Prix (1988-1996). W-body front-wheel drive mid-size. Turbo performance package available. Timing chain engines. NASCAR association. Data sourced from Wikipedia Pontiac Grand Prix article, January 2025 revision.

Fourth-generation Pontiac Firebird (1993-2002). F-body redesign. Trans Am with LT1/LS1 V8, WS6 Ram Air package. Timing chain engines. Convertible added 1994. Data sourced from Wikipedia Pontiac Firebird article, January 2025 revision.

Third-generation Pontiac Grand Am (1992-1998) and fourth-gen (1999-2005). N-body front-wheel drive. Quad 4 DOHC I4 or V6. Timing belt/chain by engine. Best-selling Pontiac. Data sourced from Wikipedia Pontiac Grand Am article, January 2025 revision.

Sixth through seventh generation Grand Prix (1988-2003). W-body front-wheel drive. GTP supercharged variant with Series II 3800. Timing chain engines. NASCAR image. Data sourced from Wikipedia Pontiac Grand Prix article, January 2025 revision.

Seventh-generation Pontiac Bonneville (1992-1999) and eighth-gen (2000-2005). H/G-body front-wheel drive full-size. SSEi supercharged 3800 Series II. Timing chain V6. Data sourced from Wikipedia Pontiac Bonneville article, January 2025 revision.

Pontiac Sunfire compact car (1995-2005). J-body front-wheel drive, Sunbird replacement. GT performance package. Timing chain engines. Convertible available. Data sourced from Wikipedia Pontiac Sunfire article, January 2025 revision.

Pontiac Trans Sport (1990-1998) renamed Montana (1997-2009). U-body/GMT200 minivan. Front-wheel drive. Timing chain V6. Extended wheelbase available. Data sourced from Wikipedia Pontiac Trans Sport article, January 2025 revision.

Pontiac Aztek crossover SUV (2001-2005). GMT200 platform. Polarizing design, commercial failure. AWD available. Timing chain V6. Breaking Bad fame. Data sourced from Wikipedia Pontiac Aztek article, January 2025 revision.

engines: 5.7L V8 LS1 (325 hp Trans Am WS6)
notes: Final years fourth-generation Firebird (1993-2002). F-body platform. Trans Am with LS1 V8. WS6 Ram Air performance package. Production ended 2002. Timing chain engines. Data sourced from Wikipedia Pontiac Firebird article, January 2025 revision.

Fourth-generation Pontiac Grand Am final years (1999-2005). N-body front-wheel drive. GT and SE trim levels. Timing chain engines. Discontinued 2005. Data sourced from Wikipedia Pontiac Grand Am article, January 2025 revision.

Eighth-generation Pontiac Grand Prix (2004-2008). W-body front-wheel drive. GTP supercharged 3800 Series III, GXP with LS4 V8. Timing chain engines. Final Grand Prix generation. Data sourced from Wikipedia Pontiac Grand Prix article, January 2025 revision.

Final generation Pontiac Bonneville (2000-2005). G-body front-wheel drive full-size sedan. GXP with Cadillac Northstar V8. Timing chain engines. Discontinued 2005. Data sourced from Wikipedia Pontiac Bonneville article, January 2025 revision.

Pontiac Vibe compact wagon (2003-2010). NUMMI joint venture with Toyota, based on Corolla Matrix. E120/E140 platform. AWD available. Timing chain engines. Data sourced from Wikipedia Pontiac Vibe article, January 2025 revision.

Modern Pontiac GTO revival (2004-2006). Rebadged Holden Monaro from Australia. Zeta platform. LS1/LS2 V8 engines. Limited production run. Timing chain engines. Data sourced from Wikipedia Pontiac GTO article, January 2025 revision.

Pontiac G6 mid-size car (2005-2010). Epsilon platform, Grand Am replacement. GXP performance variant. Convertible hardtop retractable. Timing chain engines. Data sourced from Wikipedia Pontiac G6 article, January 2025 revision.

Pontiac Solstice roadster (2006-2009). Kappa platform shared with Saturn Sky. Rear-wheel drive sports car. GXP turbo variant. Timing chain engines. Data sourced from Wikipedia Pontiac Solstice article, January 2025 revision.

Pontiac Torrent crossover SUV (2006-2009). Theta platform shared with Chevy Equinox. AWD available. Timing chain V6 engines. Discontinued with Pontiac brand. Data sourced from Wikipedia Pontiac Torrent article, January 2025 revision.

Pontiac G5 compact coupe (2007-2009). Delta platform, rebadged Chevy Cobalt. GT performance package. Timing chain I4 engines. Canada also had sedan variant. Data sourced from Wikipedia Pontiac G5 article, January 2025 revision.

Pontiac G8 performance sedan (2008-2009). Rebadged Holden Commodore VE from Australia. Zeta platform. LS3 V8 in GXP. Timing chain engines. Discontinued with brand. Data sourced from Wikipedia Pontiac G8 article, January 2025 revision.

Fifth generation on GM Zeta platform (2010-2015). Reintroduced after 7-year hiatus. LS3 V8 in SS, supercharged LSA in ZL1. Z/28 track variant introduced 2014. Data sourced from Wikipedia Chevrolet Camaro article, January 2025 revision.
Third generation (2003-2006). Increased to 8.3L V10. Coupe introduced 2006. First Viper badged as SRT. Data sourced from Wikipedia Dodge Viper article, January 2025 revision.
Fourth generation (2008-2010). Increased to 8.4L V10, 600 hp. Final year before hiatus. ACR track variant available. Data sourced from Wikipedia Dodge Viper article, January 2025 revision.

First generation compact pickup. Available in standard and extended wheelbases. Club Cab introduced 1991. Convertible variant offered 1989-1991. V8 option made it unique in compact truck segment. Data sourced from Wikipedia Dodge Dakota article, January 2025 revision.

Second generation extended years. Quad Cab offered 2000+ with four full doors. 4.7L PowerTech V8 replaced 5.9L by 2003. Dakota R/T performance variant available with 5.9L V8. Data sourced from Wikipedia Dodge Dakota article, January 2025 revision.

Third generation final Dakota. Grew to midsize platform sharing components with Ram 1500. Available only in Extended and Crew Cab configurations. Discontinued 2011 as Chrysler exited midsize truck market. Data sourced from Wikipedia Dodge Dakota article, January 2025 revision.

Second generation heavy-duty trucks. 5.9L Cummins diesel became legendary for reliability and power (160-245 hp over production). 24-valve Cummins introduced 1998. 8.0L V10 offered exceptional gas alternative. NV5600 6-speed manual introduced 1999. Requires diesel service expertise for Cummins maintenance. Data sourced from Wikipedia Dodge Ram article, January 2025 revision.

Third generation heavy-duty trucks. Mega Cab introduced 2006 with extended cabin. 6.7L Cummins introduced mid-2007 with higher output and emissions controls. 68RFE 6-speed automatic replaced 48RE in 2007. Ram became separate brand for 2010 model year. Requires diesel service expertise and DPF/EGR system knowledge for 2007.5+ models. Data sourced from Wikipedia Dodge Ram article, January 2025 revision.

B-series full-size van produced 1971-2003. Available as Ram Van (cargo) or Ram Wagon (passenger). B150/B250/B350 weight classes. Conversion vans were popular in 1980s-1990s. Replaced by Mercedes Sprinter-based models. Requires attention to older carburetor systems (pre-1988) vs. fuel injection. Diesel option rare but available 1989-1993. Data sourced from Wikipedia Dodge B-Series article, January 2025 revision.

Second generation full-size SUV. Built on Tundra platform sharing 5.7L V8 and chassis components. Larger than first generation with three-row seating for 7-8 passengers. TRD Sport and Limited trim levels available. 6-speed automatic became standard 2010. Timing belt replaced by timing chain on both engines. Data sourced from Wikipedia Toyota Sequoia article, January 2025 revision.

Third generation Sprinter. Available in multiple wheelbases (144", 170", 170" EXT) and roof heights. 1500/2500/3500/4500 weight ratings. Diesel models require DEF and DPF maintenance. 4-cylinder diesel introduced 2023. eSprinter electric variant available 2023+. Requires Mercedes STAR diagnostic system for proper service. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mercedes-Benz Sprinter article, January 2025 revision.

Midsize commercial van (rebadged Vito for North America). Positioned between Transit Connect and Sprinter. Cargo and passenger configurations with 5-8 seat options. Discontinued in North America after 2023 model year. Replaced by eSprinter for commercial applications. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mercedes-Benz Vito article, January 2025 revision.

Subcompact crossover sold in North America 2018-2022. Built in India (2018-2021) and Brazil (early 2018). Based on Ford B-platform (Fiesta). Smallest SUV in Ford lineup. Discontinued in North America 2022 replaced by Maverick. 1.0L EcoBoost requires careful timing belt maintenance. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford EcoSport article, January 2025 revision.

engines: 6.7L Power Stroke V8 turbodiesel (475 hp, 1,050 lb-ft)
notes: Fourth generation Super Duty (2017-2022 refresh). Heavy-duty pickup with GVWR ≥8,500 lbs. 6.7L Power Stroke diesel produces 1,050 lb-ft torque - highest in class. Diesel requires DEF fluid, particulate filter regeneration. 10R140 TorqShift transmission. Aluminum body on fully-boxed steel frame. 4WD uses electronic shift-on-fly with torque-on-demand transfer case. Commercial-grade braking system. Mobile mechanic note: Diesel oil capacity 13 quarts, requires specialized DEF system service, air filter service critical in dusty conditions. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford Super Duty article, January 2025 revision.

engines: 6.7L Power Stroke V8 turbodiesel (500 hp, 1,200 lb-ft)
notes: Fourth generation 2023 major refresh. Heavy-duty pickup GVWR ≥8,500 lbs. Updated 6.7L Power Stroke now produces 1,200 lb-ft - class-leading torque. New 6.8L V8 replaces 6.2L. Upgraded 10R140 transmission with revised calibration. 12-inch digital instrument cluster standard. Tremor off-road package available with modified suspension, locking differentials. Mobile mechanic note: 2023+ models have updated emissions equipment, revised DEF injection system. Oil change intervals 10,000 miles (diesel)/7,500 miles (gas). Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford Super Duty article, January 2025 revision.

engines: 6.7L Power Stroke V8 turbodiesel (475 hp, 1,050 lb-ft)
notes: Fourth generation Super Duty F-350 Single Rear Wheel (2017-2022). GVWR ≥9,900 lbs, heavier-duty frame and rear axle than F-250. Dana M275 rear axle (vs Dana M300 DRW). Same powertrain options as F-250 but higher payload capacity (7,850 lbs max). Larger brake rotors (15.9-inch front on 4WD). Mobile mechanic note: Rear differential service requires 75W-90 synthetic, capacity 4.25 quarts. Transfer case uses Mercon LV ATF. Particulate filter regeneration cycles more frequent under heavy load. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford Super Duty article, January 2025 revision.

model: F-350 Super Duty SRW (Fourth generation, 2023 refresh)
engines: 6.7L Power Stroke V8 turbodiesel (500 hp, 1,200 lb-ft)
notes: Fourth generation 2023 refresh F-350 SRW. Same powertrain updates as F-250 (500 hp/1,200 lb-ft diesel). Revised suspension tuning for improved ride quality under load. Updated Pro Trailer Backup Assist. Tremor package adds rear electronic locking differential, modified dampers, 35-inch tires. Mobile mechanic note: Tremor models require specific tire rotation pattern due to wheel offset differences. Check rear differential fluid level after towing heavy loads. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford Super Duty article, January 2025 revision.

engines: 6.7L Power Stroke V8 turbodiesel (475 hp, 1,050 lb-ft)
notes: Fourth generation F-350 Dual Rear Wheel (2017-2022). Commercial-grade dually with GVWR up to 14,000 lbs. Dana M300 rear axle with dual wheels for maximum payload (7,850 lbs) and towing (37,000 lbs diesel/4WD). Wider track requires special service considerations. 17-inch dual rear wheels with load range G tires (14-ply). Mobile mechanic note: DRW requires inner/outer wheel torque specs (165 lb-ft), check for proper wheel seating. Rear brake pad replacement requires wheel removal sequence (outer then inner). Differential service 6.9 quarts 75W-140 synthetic. Higher difficulty due to dual wheel service complexity. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford Super Duty article, January 2025 revision.

model: F-350 Super Duty DRW (Fourth generation, 2023 refresh)
engines: 6.7L Power Stroke V8 turbodiesel (500 hp, 1,200 lb-ft)
notes: Fourth generation 2023 refresh F-350 DRW. Updated 6.7L diesel rated at 40,000 lbs towing (conventional), 50,000 lbs with gooseneck/fifth wheel. Upgraded rear suspension with progressive-rate springs. Available with factory-installed 5th wheel hitch prep. Mobile mechanic note: 5th wheel models have frame-mounted rails requiring specific service procedures. Dual rear wheel alignment critical for tire wear - requires commercial alignment rack. Check inner wheel bearing preload during brake service. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford Super Duty article, January 2025 revision.

engines: 6.7L Power Stroke V8 turbodiesel (475 hp, 1,050 lb-ft)
notes: Fourth generation F-450 chassis cab (2017-2022). Medium-duty commercial truck, GVWR 14,000-16,500 lbs. Designed for upfitter body installation (dump, flatbed, service body). 6.7L diesel uses TorqShift 6-speed (6R140) due to extreme torque demands. Dana M300 rear axle with 4.88-6.20 axle ratios. Hydraulic power take-off (PTO) capable. Mobile mechanic note: Chassis cab requires commercial-grade service procedures. Transmission service uses Mercon ULV (not standard ATF). Air brake prep available. Upfitter electrical interface requires specific diagnostic tools. Higher difficulty due to commercial specifications. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford Super Duty article, January 2025 revision.

engines: 6.7L Power Stroke V8 turbodiesel (500 hp, 1,200 lb-ft)
notes: Fourth generation 2023 refresh F-450. Updated 6.7L diesel with 1,200 lb-ft torque. GCWR up to 50,000 lbs with gooseneck/5th wheel. Available with Limited Slip or electronic locking rear differential. Integrated trailer brake controller standard. Mobile mechanic note: 2023+ models require updated scan tool software for DPF regeneration procedures. Dual alternator systems common on commercial builds. PTO clutch service requires Ford-specific diagnostic adapter. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford Super Duty article, January 2025 revision.

engines: 6.7L Power Stroke V8 turbodiesel (475 hp, 1,050 lb-ft)
notes: Fourth generation F-550 chassis cab (2017-2022). Heaviest Super Duty, GVWR 17,500-19,500 lbs. Medium-duty commercial class. Diesel-only (6.7L Power Stroke). Dana M350 planetary rear axle with up to 7.27 ratio. 19.5-inch wheels with commercial load range tires. Hydraulic brakes with larger calipers (not air brakes, but commercial-rated). Mobile mechanic note: F-550 requires commercial-grade brake fluid (DOT 3 Heavy Duty). Rear axle service 11.5 quarts 75W-140 synthetic. Transmission oil cooler critical - check for leaks during service. Upfitter wiring can interfere with diagnostic procedures. Very high difficulty due to commercial specifications and specialized components. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford Super Duty article, January 2025 revision.

engines: 6.7L Power Stroke V8 turbodiesel (500 hp, 1,200 lb-ft)
notes: Fourth generation 2023 refresh F-550. Updated 6.7L diesel producing 1,200 lb-ft. GCWR up to 52,500 lbs with gooseneck. Available with factory-installed compressed air system for air tools. Dual 397-amp alternator option for mobile service bodies. Mobile mechanic note: Air system (if equipped) requires drain moisture traps during service. Check PTO engagement clutch if equipped. Transmission service interval 50,000 miles under severe duty (towing). Diesel particulate filter regeneration more frequent due to commercial use - educate customers on active regen procedure. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford Super Duty article, January 2025 revision.

Fourth generation E-Series cutaway chassis (2015-present). Commercial stripped chassis for upfitter bodies (box trucks, ambulances, shuttle buses, RVs). Based on Super Duty frame. 6.8L Triton V10 (modular engine, not overhead cam). Twin I-beam front suspension, leaf spring rear. 158-inch or 178-inch wheelbase options. GVWR 9,500-14,500 lbs depending on configuration. Mobile mechanic note: Upfitter electrical systems vary widely - always check wiring diagrams before work. 6.8L V10 uses standard spark plugs (not 2-piece like 5.4L). Transmission cooler failure common on high-GVWR applications - check for fluid in radiator. Commercial-duty brake system with larger calipers. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford E-Series article, January 2025 revision.

Fourth generation E-450 cutaway chassis (2015-present). Heavier commercial chassis than E-350, GVWR 14,500-16,500 lbs. Dana M300 rear axle with higher gear ratios (4.88, 5.38). Used for Class C motorhomes, large shuttle buses, commercial box trucks. 178-inch wheelbase standard. Dual rear wheels. Hydraulic brakes (not air) with commercial-duty calipers and rotors. Mobile mechanic note: E-450 commonly has aftermarket air suspension on RV applications - check for leaks at air springs and compressor. V10 requires 7 quarts oil (conventional 5W-20 or synthetic). Transmission service critical - many upfitter bodies add significant weight. Check for overheating issues on transmission and rear differential. Higher difficulty due to commercial specifications and varied upfitter equipment. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford E-Series article, January 2025 revision.

Fifth generation E80. Notable for AE86 RWD sport coupe (4A-GE engine, 1984-1987) - cult classic drift car. FWD models with transverse engines introduced. 1C diesel available. 4A-GE DOHC 16V performance engine in SR5 Sport GT-S. Timing belt service required. Data sourced from Wikipedia Toyota Corolla (E80) article, January 2025 revision.

Sixth generation E90. All-new FWD platform. Optional All-Trac 4WD system on sedan and wagon. 4A-FE became standard engine. GT-S model with 4A-GE DOHC engine. Lean-burn 4A-FHE in some markets. Timing belt service required. Data sourced from Wikipedia Toyota Corolla (E90) article, January 2025 revision.

Seventh generation E100. Rounded aerodynamic design. North America received 1.6L 4A-FE (105 hp) and 1.8L 7A-FE engines. Available All-Trac 4WD system. AE101 Levin/Trueno performance models with 4A-GE (up to 160 hp 20-valve). Timing belt service required. Data sourced from Wikipedia Toyota Corolla (E100) article, January 2025 revision.

Eighth generation E110. North America received 1.8L 1ZZ-FE VVT-i engine (125 hp). New ZZ engine family introduced with variable valve timing. Euro NCAP 3-star crash rating. Timing chain on 1ZZ-FE (no belt service). Some markets retained timing belts on 4A-FE and 7A-FE engines. Data sourced from Wikipedia Toyota Corolla (E110) article, January 2025 revision.

Ninth generation E120/E130. North America E120 with 1.8L 1ZZ-FE VVT-i (130 hp, 2003-2008). 2008 facelift introduced 2ZR-FE engine and 5-speed automatic. E130 JDM variant. Common D-4 direct injection on some engines. Timing chain on ZZ and ZR engines (no belt service). Euro diesel options with 1CD-FTV and 2AD-FTV. Data sourced from Wikipedia Toyota Corolla (E120) and (E130) articles, January 2025 revision.

Tenth generation E140/E150. North America E140 with 1.8L 2ZR-FE (132 hp) or 2.4L 2AZ-FE (158 hp, Matrix). 2011 facelift updated styling. E150 primarily Asia-Pacific markets. Optional CVT transmission. Valvematic variable valve lift on some engines. Timing chain on all engines (no belt service). Common D-4 or D-4S dual injection. Data sourced from Wikipedia Toyota Corolla (E140) and (E150) articles, January 2025 revision.

Ninth generation F-150 (1992-1996), nicknamed 'OBS' (Old Body Style). Last generation with 300 I-6. Last generation with carbureted engines (1992 only). Introduction of 7.3L Power Stroke diesel in 1994 (first modern turbodiesel in F-Series). Hydraulic clutch fan. Twin I-beam front suspension. Extremely common in service today. Difficulty 1.2 due to Power Stroke diesel complexity and age-related component wear. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford F-Series (ninth generation) article, January 2025 revision.

Twelfth generation F-150 (2009-2014). Major powertrain revolution in 2011 with introduction of 3.5L EcoBoost twin-turbo V6 (365 hp) and 5.0L Coyote V8. First F-150 with turbocharged engine. All-new 6R80 6-speed automatic. SVT Raptor with 6.2L V8 (411 hp, 2011+). Timing chains on all engines. EcoBoost requires premium fuel and has turbo/intercooler complexity. Difficulty 1.1 for EcoBoost turbos and direct injection carbon buildup. Data sourced from Wikipedia Ford F-Series (twelfth generation) article, January 2025 revision.

GMT900 platform Silverado 1500 (2007-2013). All-new body-on-frame architecture. Active Fuel Management (cylinder deactivation) on 5.3L and 6.0L engines. Hybrid model available (2007-2013) with 6.0L Vortec + electric motors (332 hp combined). Six-speed automatics standard from 2009. Electronic throttle control. Timing chain on all engines. DoD/AFM lifter failure common on 5.3L. Data sourced from Wikipedia Chevrolet Silverado GMT900 article, January 2025 revision.

engines: 6.6L Duramax LMM diesel V8 (365 hp, 660 lb-ft, 2007-2010)
6.6L Duramax LML diesel V8 (397 hp, 765 lb-ft, 2011-2014)
notes: GMT900 platform Silverado HD (2007-2014). Heavy-duty truck with Duramax diesel option. LMM Duramax (2007-2010) with DPF exhaust aftertreatment. LML Duramax (2011+) with DEF (urea) injection for emissions. Allison 1000 six-speed automatic with diesel. CP4.2 high-pressure fuel pump on LML. Independent front torsion bar suspension. Difficulty 1.2 due to Duramax diesel complexity, DPF/DEF systems, and CP4.2 fuel pump failures. Data sourced from Wikipedia Chevrolet Silverado GMT900 article, January 2025 revision.

K2XX platform Silverado 1500 (2014-2018). All-new EcoTec3 engine family with direct injection and cylinder deactivation. Eight-speed automatic (8L90) introduced 2015. Aluminum hood and tailgate for weight reduction. Magnetic Ride Control suspension optional. Variable valve timing on all engines. Direct injection carbon buildup on intake valves. Timing chains on all engines. AFM/DFM lifter issues continue. Data sourced from Wikipedia Chevrolet Silverado K2XX article, January 2025 revision.

engines: 6.6L Duramax L5P diesel V8 (445 hp, 910 lb-ft, 2017-2019)
notes: K2XX platform Silverado HD (2015-2019). All-new L5P Duramax diesel introduced 2017 (445 hp, 910 lb-ft) - first Duramax without EGR cooler. Allison 1000 six-speed automatic with diesel. Improved DEF system. Diesel exhaust brake. Towing capacity up to 23,100 lbs. 6.0L Vortec gas option continues. Difficulty 1.2 due to Duramax diesel complexity and DEF/DPF emissions systems. Data sourced from Wikipedia Chevrolet Silverado K2XX article, January 2025 revision.
